headline: Bank to Buy Credit Card Business for $6.45 Billion
abstract: Washington Mutual, which grew rapidly from a Seattle savings institution to a home loan giant, said yesterday that it would buy Providian Financial for $6.45 billion in cash and stock, its first major foray into the credit card business.

headline: G.E. Chief Urges U.S. to Adopt Clearer Energy Policy
abstract: WASHINGTON, May 9 - The chief executive of the General Electric Company, Jeffrey R. Immelt, pushed the company squarely into the global warming debate on Monday, asking the government for a clear energy policy and saying later in an interview that he expected Washington to eventually impose controls on carbon emissions.

headline: Business Briefs | Jury Awards $128 Million in Wireless Patent Case
abstract: Cingular Wireless, the mobile phone carrier, and the Boston Communications Group were ordered by a jury to pay $128 million in damages for infringing a patent owned by Freedom Wireless. The verdict, reached in the United States District Court in Boston, named Cingular, its AT&T Wireless unit, Boston Communications, Western Wireless and CMT Partners. The closely held Freedom Wireless sued Boston Communications and cellular carriers in 2000, claiming Boston Communications' prepaid wireless services infringed two patents. The dispute is over prepaid services that let consumers pay for calls upfront, rather than sign up for a monthly plan, and then use the calling minutes without having to enter a pass code. A Cingular spokesman, Mark Siegel, said the company intended to appeal.

headline: Briefly: Guidant issues new warning
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: British Land in Acquisition
abstract: British Land Co, property developer, agrees to buy Pillar Property for 811 million pounds ($1.5 billion) to acquire shopping centers; photo (S)

headline: In Selection of New Pope, Third World Loses Out
abstract: Roman Catholics in Latin America express some disappointment that one of their own was not chosen as next pope, but episcopal conferences of each country in region, which are dominated by theological conservatives appointed by Pope John Paul II, are notably ehtusiastic with choice of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger; photos and priests in Vatican City and nuns in Enugu, Nigeria, celebrating election of new pope (M)

headline: David Lague: Is peace 'within reach' while China is arming?
Chevron Says S.E.C. Approves Its Contested Offer for Unocal
abstract: SEC clears Chevron's $16.4 billion offer for Unocal, lifting last regulatory hurdle for proposed acquisition; China National Offshore Oil Corp has made $18.5 billion bid for Unocal; Unocal shareholders will vote on Aug 10 (M)

headline: UN commission condemns Sudan abuses
Morgan Stanley's Choices: New Direction or Better Execution?
abstract: Question that Morgan Stanley's must decide is whether its main problem was chief executive Philip J Purcell, who is retiring after continuing 'personal attacks,' or his strategy to create financial supermarket that served customers ranging from retirees living on fixed incomes to multinational corporations; board's answer will determine what kind of chief executive it chooses as replacement for Purcell and what parts, if any, of sprawling firm it will spin off (M)

headline: Negroponte's cold war role is disclosed
2 wounded in Madrid car bombing
What Is Google, Anyway?
abstract: IS Google a media company? Jon Friedman, the media columnist for MarketWatch (marketwatch.com), bristles at the notion.    The question came up last week when the company's stock market value surpassed that of Time Warner. One answer is: Sure, Google is a media company, except when it isn't. The other answer is: It doesn't really matter anyway.

headline: A warm EU receptionfor U.S. trade official
Miscellany
abstract: Radio advertising revenue rose 2 percent in the first quarter, compared with the first quarter of 2004, the Radio Advertising Bureau, New York, reported. National ad revenue grew 3 percent, the bureau said. Local revenue rose 2 percent. For March, national and local revenue grew 3 percent, from March 2004.

headline: Iraqis Found in Torture House Tell of Brutality of Insurgents
abstract: Marines on an operation to eliminate insurgents that began Friday broke through the outside wall of a building in this small rural village to find a torture center equipped with electric wires, a noose, handcuffs, a 574-page jihad manual -- and four beaten and shackled Iraqis.    The American military has found torture houses after invading towns heavily populated by insurgents -- like Falluja, where the anti-insurgent assault last fall uncovered almost 20 such sites. But rarely have they come across victims who have lived to tell the tale.

headline: In a new turn for Kohl, he's favored once more
Italy's aerospace aid gets closer look
Stocks: Upbeat growth outlook cheers Wall Street
Economy Hits Energy Prices, and the Brakes
abstract: Commerce Department estimates nation's gross domestic product grew at 3.1 percent annual rate in first quarter, substantially slower than 3.8 percent growth in final three months of 2004 and slowest pace since first quarter of 2003; price index for personal consumption expenditures minus food and energy rose to annual pace of 2.2 percent, biggest climb since fourth quarter of 2001; consumer spending declined to 3.5 percent rate, from 4.2 percent in fourth quarter of 2004; graphs (M)

headline: NOT FOR SALE
abstract: Contrary to some speculation on Wall Street, Cablevision is not for sale, according to Rand Araskog, former chief executive of ITT. Mr. Araskog is one of four men recently appointed, as part of an internal struggle, to the Cablevision board by its chairman, Charles F. Dolan. Cablevision bought Madison Square Garden from ITT when it was led by Mr. Araskog.    Interviewed last Sunday night at the ''21'' Club in New York, at a party for its retiring restaurant manager, Bruce Snyder, Mr. Araskog said that as far as he knew, Cablevision was ''absolutely not'' for sale. ''I think it would be the last thing on Chuck's mind -- if I know that man, he wouldn't do that,'' he said.

headline: Currencies: Weak outlooks push yen and euro lower
Yesterday, an Oscar; Today, Covering Tehran
abstract: Sean Penn, the Hollywood actor who has taken out ads in newspapers in support of his political beliefs, has moved over to the other side of the media business. He is in Iran working as a journalist for The San Francisco Chronicle ahead of Iran's presidential election this Friday.     Mr. Penn, who arrived in Tehran on Thursday and is expected to stay until today or tomorrow, is preparing an article on the election and Iran's controversial nuclear programs. On his first day in Tehran, he met with Mehdi Hashemi, the son of the powerful politician Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president who is running for the job again. He attended Friday Prayer in Tehran where the hard-line head of the watchdog Guardian Council urged worshipers to vote in the election next Friday.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Rises
abstract: BNP Paribas says first-quarter profit rose 56 percent; net income increased to 1.72 billion euros ($2.2 billion) from 1.10 billion euros; revenue rose 13 percent (S)

headline: Cardinals set April 18 to begin papal vote
In Face of Opposition, Bush Renews Support for Bolton
abstract: The White House on Friday renewed its defense of John R. Bolton, President Bush's choice for ambassador to the United Nations, urging the Senate to confirm him quickly even as leading Democrats vowed to stall the vote until the State Department turned over certain classified documents.    ''We believe there is a majority of the Senate that agrees with the president that John Bolton is exactly the person we need at the United Nations during this critical time of reform,'' President Bush's spokesman, Scott McClellan, said, adding that he hoped that ''Democrats wouldn't try to play politics with this nomination.''

headline: So You Want to Be a Venture Capitalist
abstract: BY all rights Stewart Alsop should have been a terrific venture capitalist. So why did Mr. Alsop, long considered a cyber-prophet among technology leaders, wash out in a profession in which he seemed predestined to succeed?     In recent months, as venture capital firms have announced the formation of new investment funds, a hot topic among the Silicon Valley cognoscenti has been the exodus of ''tourist V.C.'s,'' as people from nonfinancial backgrounds are known here. Some have left the field because they did not pick enough winners; others have gone on to pursue different projects. Whatever the reason, there are hundreds fewer venture capitalists around today than just two years ago.

headline: Bush to Seek More Aid for War on Malaria in Sub-Saharan Africa
abstract: Pres Bush is expected to call for substantial increase in spending to fight malaria in 15 nations in sub-Saharan Africa, region hardest hit; malaria is one of deadliest diseases in developing world, and one of most preventable; it causes at least million deaths a year worldwide; Bush's new program would at least double $230 million US spends on fighting malaria now (M)

headline: Theater: A bold vision of an epic Irish tale
Russia Reduces Its Growth Forecast
abstract: The economy ministry of Russia cut its forecast for 2005 economic growth to 5.8 percent, as an investment slowdown crimped oil output. The forecast had been 6.5 percent, said Alla Borisenkova, a spokeswoman for the ministry. Growth in Russia's $533 billion economy is cooling for a second year, after confidence was eroded in 2003 and 2004 by investigations into the Yukos oil company, investors and economists have said.

headline: National Assembly vote watched closely in Taipei
EU pressures Italy over bank deals
My Big Fat C.E.O. Paycheck
abstract: Survey suggests that chief executives at large American corporations received 12 percent pay increase in 2004, to average $9.84 million, but link between rising pay and performance remains muddy at best; pay packages can remain robust even if at first blush they look reduced; discontent is rising among investors, who now appear less focused on how executives are paid and more concerned about exactly what they do to earn it; companies continue to rethink different pieces of pay package, hoping to link packages to actual corporate performance; photos; graphs (M)

headline: A Payday for Patents 'R' Us
abstract: Interview with Donald E Stout on Research in Motion accord to pay his NTP $450 million to settle long-running and sometimes bitter dispute over wireless e-mail patents granted to late NTP co-founder Thomas J Campana Jr; settlement has emboldened NTP, whose only business is extracting licensing fees from companies, in its pursuit of additional licenses; other companies, including Nokia, have already signed licensing accords; critics of such patent holding companies hold they rely on excessively broad patents, particularly for software, that should never have been granted; costs of patent disputes have become fact of life for technology companies; patnet suit graph; photos (M)

headline: Oreskes named top IHT editor
Uzbek government troops reclaim eastern town
At Least 20 Are Killed in Wave of Violence in Iraq
abstract: A group of Sunni Arab kidnappers threatened to kill several Shiite hostages on Saturday unless all Shiites agreed to evacuate a town south of Baghdad in a stark illustration of rising sectarian tensions here.    In the capital and other parts of the country, a wave of suicide bombings and shootings left 20 people dead. The violence on Saturday included a bomb that tore through a crowded restaurant a lunchtime in Baquba, northeast of Baghdad, killing at least 13 Iraqis.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,724 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    DUPLANTIER, Arnold II, 26, Sgt., Army National Guard; Sacramento; First Battalion, 184th Infantry.    TACKETT, Joseph M., 22, Sgt., Army; Whitehouse, Ky.; Third Infantry Division.

headline: Berlusconi Resigns as Italian Premier, but May Not Actually Leave
abstract: Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi of Italy resigns, bending to demands of his center-right allies for new government and change in policy after dismal election results this month; says he would form new government with same parties to carry out 'updated program'; says voters sent 'signal of discomfort' he would not ignore; in theory, Pres Carlo Azeglio Ciampi could call early elections or ask someone else from majority to form government, but he is expected to give Berlusconi new mandate to govern (M)

headline: Briefly: Australia to consider asylum for diplomat
China's 'nanny' overhauls state enterprises
U.S. appeals court hears plea to quash fund rule
Court clears Pinault, but his firm is guilty
Marines kill 100 rebels near Syrian border
Barclays considers bidding for Absa
Reformists rejected as candidates in Iran
Tracks Needs Cash to Keep the Music Going
abstract: Chief executive John Rollins says music magazine Tracks is going on hiatus while additional money is sought; says he lacks money to put out next issue (S)

headline: I.B.M. Job Cuts Will Hit Europe Especially Hard
abstract: IBM's cuts of 10,000 to 13,000 jobs will fall heaviest on Germany, France, Britain and Italy, where costs are high and growth prospects have recently been dimmed; IBM's European division, which is based in Paris and also covers Africa and Middle East, employs 100,000 people; chief financial officer Mark Loughridge says IBM wants to 'rebalance' its investment from low-growth to high-growth areas; public reaction to IBM's cuts is muted in Germany, partly because offices and stock markets are closed in France, Germany and other countries in observance of Ascension Day; IBM's move is likely to deepen fears that Europe is losing its competitiveness as place for business; IBM is shutting several of its smaller sites in Germany and consolidating at service centers in Hungary and Czech Republic, among other countries; photos (M)

headline: Learn to Play Like Clapton While Your Guitar Gently Lights Up
abstract: Optek Music Systems' $599 Fretlight FG-400 electric guitar has 132 computer-controlled LED's embedded in its fret board that display 3,000 chord variants, 500 arpeggios, notes and custom chords; photo (M)

headline: 2 GI's die in Iraq when helicopter is shot down
A 2nd Taiwan leaderis heading to China
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: De Klerk Protests 'Tshwane'
abstract: A long-running furor over plans to change the name of the capital, Pretoria, to Tshwane boiled over after F.W. de Klerk, the last president under apartheid, called on the government to abandon the renaming. Mr. de Klerk, who won the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize with Nelson Mandela for his role in ending apartheid, said that the name Pretoria had ''a central and honorable place in our history,'' reflecting South Africans' triumph against British colonialism. Pretoria was named for Andries Pretorius, a prominent Afrikaner figure. But he is best known for the 1838 Battle of Blood River, so named because a river ran red with Zulu blood. The city council voted in March to rename the city Tshwane, after a chief who ruled in the area in the 1800's.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    TODAY  None    TUESDAY  None    WEDNESDAY  Balance of Trade -- March    THURSDAY  Retail Sales -- April  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY  Inventory Sales Ratio -- March

headline: Israelis Against Gaza Pullout Clash With Police
abstract: Several thousand protesters took part at some 40 separate sites, and more than 200 were arrested, according to police reports.

headline: Trade Pacts to the South Losing Appeal
abstract: Senate Finance Committee approves plan for Central American Free Trade Agreement, but it still faces bruising battle in Congress and, if approved, may be watered down by concessions to American sugar growers worried about cheap imports; Cafta is only shadow of 34-nation hemispherewide trade pact that Pres Bush once portrayed as vital link for prosperity, but there is now widespread skepticism about its chances of ever materializing in face of disputes and deepening suspicion about it in Latin America; opposition of large countries like Brazil and Argentina led administration to focus on handful of smaller countries in Central America and Andes, but even there, tumult in Bolivia and Ecuador prevents them from entering trade deal anytime soon, and Peru and Colombia are now hesitating because of concerns that their farmers will be swamped by cheap, subsidized American imports; that leaves Chile as only country to have signed up; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Brazil reports surplus of $3.35 billion in March, up from $2.58 billion year earlier and $2.79 billion in February; exports rose to $9.25 billion in March, while imports continued to go higher, totaling $5.9 billion; trade surplus stands at $8.32 billion so far this year, up from $6.13 billion in 2004 period (S)

headline: Air Force Seeks Bush's Approval for Space Weapons Programs
abstract: Air Force, saying it must secure space to protect nation from attack, is seeking Pres Bush's approval of national-security directive that could move United States closer to fielding offensive and defensive space weapons; proposed change would be substantial shift in American policy; it would almost certainly be opposed by many American allies and potential enemies, who have said it may create arms race in sapce; senior administration official says new presidential directive would replace 1996 Clinton administration policy that emphasizes more peaceful use of space, including spy satellites' support for military operations, arms control and nonproliferation pacts; drawings illustrate some space weapons (M)

headline: Some settlers in Gaza still plan to stay put
In Switch, Insurer Lets Stores Fill 90-Day Prescriptions
abstract: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Minnesota says it is encouraging its members to buy their 90-day prescriptions for chronic problems at retail stores, bucking national trend among health care plans of forcing workers to order drugs from mail-order pharmacies to cut costs; some consumers have complained that mail odering is not safe or convenient as shopping at local pharmacy, while local drugstores have been struggling to cope with loss of business; participating employers will get same discounted prices for three-month prescriptions that are filled in stores as they would by mail; Blue Cross says in-store co-payments on some long=term prescriptions may be slightly higher than through mail; Al Heaton, director of pharmacy for Minnesota Blue Cross, says return to in-store prescriptions 'is the beginning of a trend'; drugstores may be required to lower their own prices to participate in Minnesota Blue Cross program and compete with mail-order discounts; Target has made Blue Cross program available in its pharmacies since February; about one-third of 900 pharmacies in Minnesota are participating, and spokesman for Walgreen says it expects to add 90-day Blue Cross program next month at its Minnesota stores (M)

headline: In Slovenia, prosperity and ambition
Edwards Suspends Clinical Trial on Heart Valve Replacement
abstract: Edwards Lifesciences said that it had suspended a clinical trial of a new method of replacing failing aortic heart valves without open heart surgery.

headline: Chirac holds firm on EUsubsidies
World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: U.S. Sentences Drug Kingpin To 40 Years
abstract: The first major cocaine lord sent to the United States in a round of extraditions that began in 2000 was sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan to 40 years in prison. The trafficker, Alberto Orlandez Gamboa, 49, who pleaded guilty to narcotics charges in 2003, was the head of a drug organization based in Barranquilla that earned hundreds of millions of dollars in illicit profits in the 1990's, prosecutors said. He exported cocaine to the United States on airplanes and speedboats and secreted in the walls of containers on cargo ships, according to evidence in the case, and often sent his earnings back in bulk shipments. In 1998 Customs agents found $11 million of his cash hidden inside truck transmissions in a shipping container in Port Elizabeth, N.J., that was destined for South America.   Julia Preston (NYT)

headline: Rice's Trip to Moscow Disrupted by Bomb Scare
France Will Get Fusion Reactor to Seek a Future Energy Source
abstract: An international consortium announced Tuesday that France would be the site of the world's first large-scale, sustainable nuclear fusion reactor, an estimated $10 billion project that many scientists see as crucial to solving the world's future energy needs.    ''It is a great success for France, for Europe and for all the partners in ITER,'' President Jacques Chirac said in a statement released after the six-member consortium of the United States, Russia, China, Japan, South Korea and the European Union chose the country as the site for the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor.

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction tomorrow of four-week bills and a three-year note. On Wednesday and Thursday, there will be an auction of 5-year and 10-year notes, respectively.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.86 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 3.18 percent and on the four-week issue was 2.63 percent.

headline: Macquarie moves onpublisher
World Business Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Petrobras to Advise on Oil
abstract: Iraq will seek the advice of Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, to help raise its oil production, which has fallen 47 percent in five years. Iraq's oil ministry plans to form a technical committee with Petrobras to advise its state-run production companies on increasing output, now less than two million barrels a day, said Jabbar al-Leaby, above, director of the South Oil Company, Iraq's largest oil producer. Global companies, including Royal Dutch/Shell Group and BP, have agreed to help Iraq increase output from damaged fields.

headline: Berlusconi backs president
Pressure rises on Arroyo to talk about audio recordings
Many theories on Myanmar bombs
When Betting on Russia, Kremlin Is the Wild Card
abstract: This week's guilty verdict for Russia's oil billionaire Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky capped a long-running tale that rocked the country's financial elite, upset foreign investors and prompted criticism from the White House.     Now investors are turning to the future, and wondering whether the case could be repeated.

headline: Israel Agrees to Free 9 Jordanian Prisoners
World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Troops Kill 21 Kurdish Rebels
abstract: Anatolia governor's office reports that 21 Kurdish rebels and three soldiers were killed in regional clash between Turkish troops and Kurds (S)

headline: Goodbye, Russia ... ... Hello again
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brasil Telecom Deal Is Blocked
abstract: Citigroup won a preliminary injunction blocking a deal that would allow Telecom Italia to gain greater control over the Brazilian telephone company Brasil Telecom Participações; Citigroup is already the controlling shareholder. The ruling, by a federal court in New York, stops Citigroup's former investment manager in Brazil, Daniel Dantas, from selling his Brasil Telecom shares to Telecom Italia. In April, the Italian group agreed to pay 341 million euros ($416 million) for the stake and to buy its mobile unit, Brasil Telecom GSM. Citigroup, which shares control of Brasil Telecom with a group of Brazilian state-run pension funds, contended that the deal would hurt the value of its investment.   Todd Benson (NYT)

headline: A Used Printer? No, It's a Refurb
abstract: Factory-reconditioned electronic goods are gaining ground on Internet, where they can be found on sections of manufacturers' Web pages and particularly on eBay; many consumers remain wary of 'refurbs,' despite manufacturers' assurances that they have been carefully repaired and rigorously tested or may even be 'open box' items, returned by people who unsealed package but never used product; some tips on buying refurbs; photo (M)

headline: Arroyo admits to 'lapse' during election
GAP'S DEBT RATING IS RAISED TO LOWEST INVESTMENT GRADE
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raised its long-term debt rating on Gap Inc., the clothing chain, to investment grade, citing the company's improved performance. The rating, which affects about $513 million in debt, was lifted one level, to Baa3, the lowest investment grade, Moody's said. Its rating outlook is positive. Moody's last raised Gap's rating in May. Gap, based in San Francisco, owns the Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy retail stores.

headline: Iraq's New President Strongly Backs U.S. Troop Presence
abstract: Jalal Talabani, new president of Iraq, says he strongly supports American military presence and believes Iraqis can devise constitution by target dates of mid-August despite delays in forming government, interview, CNN (S)

headline: Havas Fails in Move to Attract Chief From a Competitor
abstract: The head of the advertising agency TBWA Worldwide said that he had turned down the job of chief executive at a rival agency, Havas.

headline: Tech Brief: Sun plans to 'buy revenue'
Japanese emperor visits a WWII battleground
Beijing Moves to Rein In Anti-Japan Protests
Dutch Are Expected to Vote No on European Charter Today
abstract: Dutch are expected to reject European constitution in their referendum on June 1; are unhappy with direction European Union has been taking in recent years, above all since it adopted single currency and expanded eastward, taking in 10 new members; opinion polls show that Dutch feel pushed around by big countries and that union's heavy bureaucracy lacks transparency and democracy and is growing too fast; photo (M)

headline: A Tighter Rebooking Deadline
abstract: A TIGHTER REBOOKING DEADLINE -- Northwest Airlines has shortened the deadline for rebooking unused nonrefundable tickets to 90 days after a missed flight, from 365 days. ''The ticket can still be used for a year, it's just that the actual change has to be made within 90 days,'' said Kurt Ebenhoch, a Northwest spokesman. The new policy, which he said was adopted for better inventory control, applies to all tickets issued on or after April 15. Terry Trippler, the chief executive of Farefacts.com, a travel adviser based in Minneapolis, said, ''It's a big change.'' As of yesterday, he said, no other airline had followed Northwest's lead. Typically, major airlines allow passengers who cancel an original flight on a nonrefundable ticket to rebook the ticket anytime within a year for a $100 change fee. Over the last five years, business travelers have been rebelling against high walk-up fares by switching to the nonrefundable tickets favored by tourists. Because business travelers change their plans so often, many corporate travel managers use procedures, like American Express's TicketTrax service, to keep track of unused tickets and flag them for rebooking.    EUROPE'S LURE -- Despite a weak dollar, trans-Atlantic air traffic grew in March for the 21st consecutive month, according to Donald N. Martin & Company, a travel marketing specialist based in New York. For all of 2004, travel to Europe (including the Russian Federation) originating in the United States rose to 12.1 million trips, an increase of 12.4 percent over 2003, the company said, citing data from the United States Commerce Department. In 2005, industry analysts say, the volume of travel by Americans to Europe is expected to match or surpass the record of 12.8 million trips in 2000. Economy-class trans-Atlantic fares are expected to remain at last summer's levels, even though domestic carriers have been adding trans-Atlantic capacity, said Hugo Burge, the president of Cheapflights.com, an online fare broker. Premium cabin seats, however, are being discounted, Mr. Burge said. Airlines are sharply cutting fares in business class on trans-Atlantic routes, too, he said.    HANGING UP -- The revenue that hotels derive from guest room telephones fell last year to an average of $2 a day per occupied room, compared with $4.10 in 2000, according to the Hospitality Research Group of PKF Consulting, which is based in San Francisco. The reasons are fairly obvious, said Robert Mandelbaum, the director of research information services: increased use of cellphones and calling cards as well as a reaction against surcharges on telephone calls. While hotel managers struggle to adapt to and even profit from new portable communications technologies, room phones and fax machines could go the way of the in-room fly swatter, Mr. Mandelbaum said.    CHEAPER BY THE MILE -- As competition over fares remained fierce, the revenue airlines squeezed out of travelers for each mile flown fell 6.7 percent on domestic routes in the first quarter for eight major airlines, the Air Transport Association said. Most international routes fared better. Yields rose 2.7 percent on Atlantic routes and 3.7 percent on Pacific routes, while falling 4.4 percent on Latin American routes for the eight airlines surveyed: Alaska; American, America West, Continental, Delta, Northwest, United and US Airways.   JOE SHARKEY

headline: Name Brands Embrace Some Less-Well-Off Kinfolk
abstract: Article on growing number of companies that are introducing downmarket versions of upmarket brands that are less expensive focuses on Procter & Gamble's Charmin Basic, cheaper version of well-known toilet paper, and its lower-priced Bounty paper towels; photos (M)

headline: China's small steel mills feel heat
Bush pressing his case on Iraq asdoubts rise
World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Arroyo Apology For Vote 'Lapse'
abstract: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo went on national television, acknowledged that she had phoned an election commissioner during voting for president last year and apologized for a ''lapse in judgment.'' But she denied trying to influence the vote count and insisted she would not resign, as some of her opponents have been demanding in a three-week-long political crisis over a secretly recorded telephone conversation between a woman who sounds like Mrs. Arroyo and a man said to be an election commissioner. In the recording, the woman asks if her lead could fall below a million votes and expresses concern about areas in the south. The man tells her, ''We will do our best.'' The final tally gave her more than a million votes over her chief rival. In her address, Mrs. Arroyo said she had spoken to the election commissioner not because she wanted to influence the outcome of the election but because she was anxious to protect her votes. Members of her government said they hoped the apology would put the issue behind her.   Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

headline: Airbus Giant Will Stretch Many Airports' Ingenuity
abstract: Representatives of airports in Europe, Asia and US gather in Frankfurt, energized after smooth flight of Airbus's A380 jet, to discuss how they are getting ready for plane, which is scheduled to go into service in middle of next year with Singapore Airlines; some representatives say A380 is going to be more of burden, and risk, for airports than Airbus likes to suggest; most airports are reinforcing taxiways and retrofitting gates; will cost airports average of $100 million to upgrade their facilities; Heathrow Airport near London is spending $857 million; Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is spending $130 million on two mundane projects at Kennedy International to accommodate A380; photo (M)

headline: 5 marines die as vehicle hits bomb in Iraq
Briefly: Republican gets nod at Public Broadcasting
Bomber Posing as Iraqi Police Recruit Kills at Least 60
abstract: A suicide bomber struck a crowd applying for police jobs in the northern city of Erbil in the deadliest attack in over two months.

headline: I.B.M. Agrees to Modify Its Software for Sun Line
abstract: Sun Microsystems got a much-needed boost on Monday when I.B.M., a rival and sometime partner, said it would convert its software products to work with Sun's Solaris operating system on a new line of Sun computers.     Sun is counting heavily on the success of the new line, code-named Galaxy and designed by Andreas Bechtolsheim, a Sun co-founder. It is built around the new Opteron dual-core microprocessor from Advanced Micro Devices, designed for high-end corporate applications.

headline: Bombing strikes Afghan mosque, kills at least 20
Afghans Freed From GuantÃ¡namo Demand Repatriation for All
Justices Say Investors Must Show Loss in Fraud Suits
Fears Mount That Germany Faces Recession
abstract: Six influential German economic institutes have cut their growth forecast for this year in half, prompting new rash of fears that Germany economy is on brink of recession; economists say downward revision, to 0.7 percent from 1.5 percent, illustrates that economic forecasting in Germany has become mostly exercise in finding ever-more-precise ways to measure stagnation; Thomas Mayer, chief European economist at Deutsche Bank, says if oil prices keep going up, Germany will not even hold on to 0.7 percent number; institutes predict growth will be only 1.5 percent in 2006, less than in 2004, which was 1.6 percent; current unemployment rate of 12 percent is record in post-World War II period, and poses mounting political threat to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who faces difficult state election in May in North Rhine-Westphalia; Bert Rurup, head of Schroder's council of economic advisers, says Germany needs to grow from 1.5 percent to 2 percent a year to generate significant new jobs (M)

headline: Iran's president-elect is new even to Iranians
Troubled Euro Disney Abruptly Replaces Its Chief Executive
abstract: Euro Disney, the operator of two money-losing theme parks east of Paris, abruptly replaced its chief executive.

headline: Google sees ad opening in custom home pages
EU ordered to stop dumping its sugar on global markets
EU proposes to cut lawmakers' perks
Rumsfeld seeks unity in fight against piracy
Russia and China are cooperating more, but warily
'Reformer' in front as Iran opens campaign
Morgan to Pay Fine for Rule Violations in 1990's
abstract: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $2.7 million for violating rules in connection with initial public offerings sold at the height of the stock market bubble in the late 1990's, regulators announced yesterday.    While the amount is small relative to other settlements on Wall Street, in which Morgan Stanley and other companies agreed to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in penalties for other violations, the latest penalty showed another category of violation that had not been known about: the firm and its top officials sold shares in companies it had taken public after publicly promising the shares would not be sold.

headline: U.S. investors hesitate to buy global stocks
MESA AIR TO OPERATE MORE FLIGHTS FOR UNITED
abstract: United Airlines and the Mesa Air Group signed a five-year agreement under which Mesa will fly 30 more planes for United, helping United cut costs and exit bankruptcy. Mesa will begin the additional flights under the United Express brand in the fall, mainly from Chicago and Dulles International Airport outside Washington, a United spokesman, Jeff Green, said yesterday. Mesa, which is based in Phoenix, already provides flights for United from those airport hubs and from Denver. United, based in Chicago and a unit of UAL, has been revamping its contracts with commuter airline partners to lower costs so it can curtail losses. The new Mesa contract will help replace United Express flights currently operated by Air Wisconsin Airlines.

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Falls Unexpectedly in March
abstract: The U.S. trade deficit narrowed to $55 billion in March, defying Wall Street forecasts, in the largest monthly drop in over three years.

headline: Blair Calls Vote His Last
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair unveils his Labor Party's electoral promises, twinned with pledge that Britain's May 5 ballot would be his last (S)

headline: West's dilemma over China textiles
Over 30 Reported Dead in Attacks Around Iraq
abstract: At least 34 Iraqis and 2 American marines were killed in violence in central and western Iraq on Friday night and Saturday, and a series of Marine airstrikes in the western desert killed about 40 insurgents, Iraqi and American officials said.    Iraqi forces also reported finding the bodies of two Sudanese men in the capital, and in a firefight American soldiers fatally shot two Iraqis working as security contractors and wounded two others, an Interior Ministry official said.

headline: 12 insurgents killed in Afghanistan
Dissent rises in Germany over EU vote
An Opportunity for Arab News Media to Show Their Wider Reach
abstract: Arab news cameras and reporters join throng of Western cameras focused on St Peter's Square in days before Pope John Paul II's death; their reports focus on pope's impact in Arab world, but broader point is that Arab satellite channels, in particular, are working to be more competitive in covering non-Arab issues (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Software Group Backs Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft gained the support of an international group representing about 1,600 small and medium-size companies in its appeal against a European Union antitrust order. The International Association of Microsoft Certified Partners, representing companies that develop software based on the Windows operating system, asked the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg for permission to support Microsoft's appeal, said Per Werngren, the group's president. Microsoft, whose software runs more than 90 percent of the world's personal computers, was ordered by European regulators in March 2004 to sell a version of Windows without a music and video player and to license information on the inner workings of the operating system to competitors.

headline: Europe Leaves Modified Corn Inquiry to U.S.
abstract: European officials say they will let US take lead in untangling how unapproved corn entered Europe over last four years; Syngenta, Swiss biotechnology company that produced corn, said late in March that it had inadvertently mixed up two types of its genetically modified corn; one type, known as Bt-11, has been legal for years in US and Europe; similar strain, Bt-10, has never been tested or approved; main difference between two strains is that unapproved on contains gene that confers resistance to antibiotic ampicillin; environmentalists fear that introducing it into food chain could increase resistance to antibiotics; European Union says unapproved strain entered union countries in forms of animal feed, corn flour and corn oil (M)

headline: F.D.A. Restricts Access to Cancer Drug, Citing Ineffectiveness
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration stopped just short of withdrawing the lung cancer pill Iressa from the market yesterday, restricting access to the drug to existing or previous users and to patients in clinical trials.      The action follows the failure of the drug, developed by AstraZeneca, to prolong lives in two clinical trials.

headline: Parliament issues call for elections in July
The Subservient Chicken And Other Award Winners
abstract: Agencies are being recognized at presentations of awards intended to honor creative excellence.    Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami was named agency of the year at the annual presentation of the Clio Awards. The agency won 13 Clios, including a Grand Clio in the Internet ad category for the Subservient Chicken Web site it created for Burger King.

headline: Another View of News Bias, as Selling Point
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on view of some that news media are biased; cites study by Harvard economists Sendhil Mullainathan and Andrei Shleifer that the more competition there has been among news sources, the more discussion their has been of bias; they argue that consumers care about more than accuracy, that they prefer to hear or read news that are more consistent with their beliefs (M)

headline: TechBrief: BSkyB net is biggest in 2 years
Lehman Is Said to Agree to Buy 20% of Ospraie Management
abstract: Lehman Brothers acquires 20 percent of Ospraie Management, hedge fund that manages about $2 billion and invests primarily in basic industries and commodities (M)

headline: Some in Biotech Prefer an Acquisition to an I.P.O.
abstract: Growing number biotechnology companies are opting for acquisition by larger companies rather than issuing initial public offering; Peninsula Pharmaceuticals, four-year-old developer of antibiotics, agrees to be acquired by Johnson & Johnson for $245 million; Peninsula filed for initial public stock offering but postponed it while negotiating acquisition; TransForm Pharmaceuticals also agreed last month to be acquired by Johnson & Johnson for $230 million; other recent deals involving takeovers of private companies include Xcel Pharmaceuticals by Valeant Pharmaceuticals, Syrrx by Takeda Pharmaceuticals, Idun Pharmaceuticals and Agiosyn by Pfizer and ESP Pharma by Protein Design Labs (M)

headline: Recording industry raises pressure on pirates
Kyocera to outsource American production
Gazprom looks to buy leading Russian paper
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dissidents Describe Plan to Split Firm  The grumpy old men just got grumpier. After more than a month of silence, a dissident group of retired Morgan Stanley executives described in greater detail their proposal to split the firm in two, in a further assault on the leadership of Philip J. Purcell.    The plan, which has already been spurned by the firm's board, includes some ambitious assumptions. [Page C3.]    April Retail Sales Exceed Forecast  Retail sales climbed 1.4 percent in April, double economists' median forecast. [C12.]    Moody's Lowers Ford's Debt Rating  A week after Ford lost its investment-grade rating from Standard & Poor's, Moody's lowered its assessment of the automaker's debt to one step above junk. In addition, the chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said that he would not accept any compensation until profits from the automotive unit improved. [C5.]    Microsoft to Start Antivirus Service  Microsoft said it would enter the consumer antivirus business as part of a subscription service that it plans to offer next year. [C2.]    Dell said first-quarter profit rose 28 percent on strong sales outside the United States. [C2.]    Stocks Fall Though Oil Price Drops  The Dow fell 110.77 points, to 10,189.48, while the S.&P. 500-stock index dropped 11.75 points, to 1,159.36. The Nasdaq fell 7.67 points, to 1,963.88. The price of oil dropped to its lowest level since mid-February. [C6.]    Collins & Aikman Chief Resigns  The Collins & Aikman Corporation, the maker of car interior parts, said that its chairman and chief executive, David A. Stockman, had resigned. Mr. Stockman is a former budget director in the Reagan administration. The company said it was seeking a waiver from creditors because of lower-than-expected first-quarter results and ''liquidity issues.'' Trading of its shares was also suspended. [C3.]    New Chief for German Retailer  Thomas Middelhoff, who left Bertelsmann three years ago, was named chief of KarstadtQuelle, the struggling German retailer. [C4.]    2 Counts Against Scrushy Dropped  The judge overseeing the accounting fraud trial of the former HealthSouth chief executive Richard Scrushy dismissed 2 of the counts against him; 36 others remain. [C5.]    Training of Chinese Canceled  The Nieman Foundation at Harvard withdrew from a plan to train Chinese government officials on how to deal with the media when the Olympic games come to Beijing in 2008. [C6.]

headline: A Time for Mourning, but Also for Study and Very Quiet Politics
abstract: Pope John Paul II's funeral Mass begins nine days of spiritual mourning, but it also opens a political chapter--subtle campaigning before a gathering of cardinals in a conclave starting April 18 to elect a successor; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Sponsored Television in the Middle East is "Cheaper than an Invasion"
abstract: Many in the Arab world continue to view America as an imperialist power. But the US-based television station Al-Hurra is trying to change that.

headline: Wireless: Will cellphones ever replace the concierge?
Shell plans wind farm
How Haiti's Future May Depend on a Starving Prisoner
abstract: Once again, one man has become the center of a political storm that threatens to foil this country's uphill struggle for stability.    This time, it's not Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the former priest and charismatic slum leader who was deposed last year by an armed uprising and forced into exile. It is the man who rose and fell in Mr. Aristide's shadow, his former prime minister, Yvon Neptune.

headline: China's Problem With 'Anti-Pest' Rice
abstract: Some Chinese growers and foreign specialists say rice grown in some regions of China that farmers call 'anti-pest rice' has been genetically modified, which is illegal to sell on open market in China; environmental group Greenpeace, which had rice in Wuhan, China, tested by independent lab in Germany, says results show that some of rice was altered with gene that creates resistance to pests; photos (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   5.75   5.75   4.00       Federal Funds   2.75   2.82   1.00       3-month Libor   3.14   3.15   1.14       3-month T-bills   2.80   2.77   0.93       6-month T-bills   3.04   3.09   1.08       10-yr.
