headline: Off the Hill, and Leading the Charge on Trade
abstract: What most surprises Rob Portman, who served in Congress for six terms, is how much time he still spends dealing with politics on Capitol Hill as the new United States trade representative.    His days have been filled with long conversations, trying to sway lawmakers to approve a trade pact with Central America. He is figuring out a strategy with Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, on how to neutralize the sugar lobby.

headline: 'Oddball Rodent' Is Called New to Science
abstract: Wildlife Conservation Society announces identification of new species of rodent, Laonastes aenigmamus or Laotian rock rat; drawing; Dr Robert J Timmins explains discovery (S)

headline: By force or choice, Uzbeks return home
Australia reconsiders nonaggression pact with Asians
Boston Scientific Heads Back to Court
abstract: Wall Street analysts delicately refer to it as ''headline risk.''      Analysts are warning investors that Boston Scientific, the market leader in the $5 billion global market for stents, is at risk of losing one or more long-running legal battles this summer.

headline: Chair of Senate Intelligence Committee Believes North Korea Is Preparing Nuclear Test
abstract: WASHINGTON, May 8 - The chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today that he believed North Korea appeared to be preparing a nuclear test explosion, even as the head of the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency said he believed the North had five or six nuclear weapons in its possession.

headline: Stocks: IBM's weak results weigh on Wall Street
Bush Praises Palestinian; Tells Israel of Its Duties
abstract: President Bush on Thursday warmly praised the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, for what he called Mr. Abbas's commitment to democracy, then reiterated that Israel had obligations it must fulfill as both sides work toward a peaceful future for the Middle East.    In a news conference in the White House Rose Garden that provided Palestinians with the powerful imagery of Mr. Bush beside their newly elected president, Mr. Bush repeatedly emphasized the positive, and did not ask Mr. Abbas to move more aggressively to fight terrorist groups, as the administration said Mr. Bush had done in private.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Horizons To Buy Analysts International
abstract: Computer Horizons Corp, which provides personnel to install computers and manage networks, agrees to acquire Analysts International Corp for $88 million (S)

headline: We simply can't stop shooting
Who Says There's No Free Lunch on Planes?
abstract: EVERYONE knows that the airline business is a mess. United Airlines, operating in bankruptcy, just succeeded in punting four employee pension plans, covering 122,000 people, to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation -- and, hence, taxpayers. Delta Airlines lost $5.2 billion last year, its worst performance in 70 years of operations. Other airlines, including American, have been allowed by Congress to defer up to 80 percent of their pension obligations.     Pretty dire, all around.

headline: I.B.M. to Lay Off Over 10,000 in Struggle to Keep Up Profits
abstract: IBM to lay off 10,000 to 13,000 workers, mostly in Europe, as it struggles to keep its profits at time when global competition in technology business spreads beyond selling computers to providing services; cutbacks come after IBM reported disappointing quarterly earnings last month and price of its shares dropped; IBM portrays move as mainly evolution in its strategy of globalizing its operations by moving back-office work to low-cost locations and pruning operations in high-cost and slower-growth markets like France, Germany and Italy; job cuts are primarily in administrative offices; graph (M)

headline: Watch Your Back! It's Another C.E.O. Heading for the Exit
abstract: Many directors, once meek lambs who often followed a chief executive's will, have cast off their submissiveness with a vengeance, propelled into vigilance by a wave of corporate scandals. And when you toss in added scrutiny by shareholders, how do you stay at the head of a company these days?    Fewer people do, it turns out. Chief executive departures have been rising steadily this year, hitting 129 in March, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm. That matches the monthly record set in October 2000.

headline: CALPINE UPDATES OUTLOOK AND SHARES CLIMB 23%
abstract: The Calpine Corporation, seeking to allay concerns that it might be pushed into bankruptcy, updated its financial outlook yesterday and said that it had $800 million in cash at the end of March, setting off a 23 percent gain in its share price. The amount is enough, when combined with planned asset sales and other financing, to allow the company, a power producer, to make its required debt and interest payments this year, Wall Street analysts said. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif, said it expected to report a first-quarter loss of 38 cents a share, wider than the loss of 17 cents a share a year earlier. Calpine shares rose 34 cents, to $1.79.

headline: Kodak chooses new chief executive
Currencies: Ifo survey pushes dollar higher on euro
EU delegation visits Bush
Iraqi toll includes ex-judge
Entr'acte: For affirmative action, a daring test in the arts
Funds in Brief: Stock-market rally lifts income at Eaton Vance
Online Gambling Shares Climb 11% in Debut Day
abstract: The controversial online gambling company PartyGaming burst onto the London exchange Monday with a highly sought share offering that shot up 11 percent by the end of the day, valuing the company at more than $9 billion.     Several rival online casinos are expected to follow with stock offerings of their own, even though the Justice Department in the United States has declared the business illegal.

headline: The Truth About Cats, Dogs and Executives
abstract: JEFFREY P. ANSELL is definitely a corporate guy.    Otherwise, why wear a tie to Fred's, a casual restaurant on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that is rife with pictures of dogs? Why bring sales charts and such to lunch -- and have public relations people follow through with offers of more? And why sprinkle product plugs throughout a conversation, despite a reporter's pledge to keep those plugs from appearing in print?

headline: Obituary: Saul Bellow, 89, master of American novel
Japan venture for Microsoft
U.K. papersoffer choice of realities
At a Birmingham Pub, the Defense Is on the Defensive
abstract: The jury has been unable to reach a verdict so far in the federal fraud trial of Richard M. Scrushy. But the consensus at Lou's Pub and Package Store, the watering hole for this city's legal, political and business elite, is that Mr. Scrushy is guilty.     That makes life difficult at Lou's for Mr. Scrushy's defense lawyers, who show up regularly for a nightcap and check their professional egos at the door. The most recent visit was Friday evening, after the judge ordered the deadlocked jury to continue deliberations, which are expected to resume on Monday.

headline: Egyptian Reformers Take to Streets to Oppose a 5th Term for Mubarak
abstract: Egypt's fledgling political reform movement organizes demonstrations in 14 major cities; huge numbers of riot poilcemen and scores of detentions ensure gatherings are either minuscule or do not materialize; in Cairo, first protesters to arrive are forced into taxis and drivers are ordered to drive away; about 200 protesters, hemmed in by police, chant antigovernment slogans; their primary demand is that Pres Hosni Mubarak step aside after 24 years in power; photo (M)

headline: Spirit of revolt in France touches Havas
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Insurers Face F.B.I. Inquiry Into Accounting Practices  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is reviewing insurance practices to determine whether the accounting irregularities at American International Group are a pervasive problem, agency officials said.     The review could increase pressure on insurance companies to show that they are in compliance with accounting rules. [Page C19.]    Drug Is Found to Help With Strokes  An experimental treatment developed by AstraZeneca and Renovis has been shown to protect the brain from some stroke damage, drug industry executives and doctors said. [C3.]    New Top Lawyer for Morgan Stanley  Morgan Stanley named David W. Heleniak, left, a prominent mergers and acquisitions lawyer, to oversee its regulatory and legal matters. The move signals a renewed urgency on the part of Morgan Stanley's leaders to address the firm's awkward, often confrontational relationship with the legal and regulatory community. [C4.]    Inquiry Into Gifts at Fidelity  The United States attorney in Boston is looking into whether brokers from investment banks plied traders at Fidelity Investments with lavish gifts. [C2.]    Lazard Must Win Over Investors  Shares in Lazard were priced at $25, the low end of the estimated range, and will start trading today. Some investors said the stock might drop in coming weeks. Market Place. [C13.]    Plan for Radio-Tagging Patents  Intermec Technologies plans to license four portfolios of its radio-tagging patents on terms that it said should spur development. [C19.]    Confidence in G.M. Helps Stocks  Stocks rallied as investors were inspired by Kirk Kerkorian's plan to expand his stake in G.M. The Dow average rose 127.69 points, to 10,384.64. The S.&P. 500 gained 14.48 points, to 1,175.65, and the Nasdaq composite rose 29.16 points, to 1,962.23. [C13.]    Cheap Calls Over the Internet  Internet calling and videoconferencing from home are finally taking off, and there are many tools to choose from. Circuits. [C9.]    Ads at AOL Help Time Warner  Time Warner reported solid first-quarter growth at some units and strong advertising gains at AOL. The company beat Wall Street's earnings expectations of 17 cents a share by a penny. [C6.]    Rupert Murdoch, chief of the News Corporation, said he expected to resolve a dispute with Liberty Media soon. [C6.]    No More Nikes at Sears Stores  Nike's decision to stop selling its sneakers and clothes at Sears is most likely a result of Kmart's acquisition of Sears in March, analysts said. Advertising. [C6.]    Microsoft to Try Licensing Plan  Microsoft will license its home-grown ideas to venture capital firms and entrepreneurs. The move is intended to foster better relations between the company and start-ups. [C7.]    Florida Judge Punishes Boies's Firm  David Boies's law firm got a black eye last week in a case involving a dispute between gardening companies in Florida. [C6.]    Lose an Employee, Not the Business  Legal agreements cannot prevent workers from joining a rival firm, but they can limit the damage they do. Small Business. [C5.]

headline: Afghanistan Offers Amnesty to Wanted Taliban Rebels
abstract: The head of Afghanistan's peace and reconciliation commission held out an amnesty today for all rebels fighting U.S. and government forces.

headline: Determined to Find Guilt, but Expecting Acquittal
abstract: Willis G. Vest was convinced that Richard M. Scrushy, the former chairman of HealthSouth, broke the law. But he was not surprised on Tuesday morning to receive a phone call from the clerk of the federal court that the jury hearing the conspiracy and fraud case against Mr. Scrushy had acquitted him.     The jury reached its decision without Mr. Vest, who explained in an interview that he was one of two jurors favoring conviction until last Wednesday, when his chronic migraine headaches led the judge to replace him with an alternate juror.

headline: Justices Reject Auditor Verdict in Enron Scandal
abstract: Supreme Court, with brief, pointed and unanimous opinion, overturns Arthur Andersen's conviction for shredding Enron accounting documents as that company was collapsing in one of nation's biggest corporate scandals; holds that Judge Melinda Harmon's instructions to jury failed to require necessary proof that Andersen knew its actions were wrong; decision represents little more than Pyrrhic victory for Andersen, which lost its clients after being indicted on obstruction of justice charges and has no chance of returning as viable enterprise; firm has shrunk from 28,000 employees in United States to skeleton crew of 200, who are attending to final details of closing down partnership; legal experts say that Supreme Cuort did not ultimately settle question of whether Andersen had acted with criminal intent when it allowed many of Enron's accounting papers to be be destroyed; but but that it made clear that prosecutors went too far by pressing Harmon to set such a low hurdled for jury to reach guilty verdict; Chief Justice William H Rehnquist writes opinion for court; photo (M)

headline: Stocks: Growth prospects in U.S. send shares higher
Mexican Appeals Court Voids Conviction of Ex-President's Brother
abstract: A Mexican appeals court has ruled that Raúl Salinas, the brother of former President Carlos Salinas, was convicted on insufficient proof that he had ordered the killing of a powerful politician in 1994.     The ruling late Thursday cleared the way for his release from prison, where he has served 10 years of a 27-year sentence. His lawyers said his release could come as early as this weekend, although it might be delayed until next week. The government said it would not appeal the decision.

headline: Some Verizon Customers to Get Stand-Alone D.S.L.
abstract: Verizon Communications, in first step toward stand-alone digital subscriber line services in regions where it operates, will begin allowing current customers in 13 Northeast states to drop telephone service but continue high-speed Internet acess through DSL (S)

headline: Sun chief 'doubtful' over Microsoft remedy
Chess masters take on computers to test mettle
Gunmen in Baghdad Kill National Assembly Member
abstract: Iraqi legislator is shot to death by three men at front gate of her home in Baghdad; brazen daylight attack is first assassination of National Assembly member since elections Jan 30; victim, Sheikha Lameah Khaddouri al-Sakri, was high-profile human rights activist, one of 87 women in 275-member Assembly; she had survived two previous assassination attempts and had just been dropped off by her bodyguard at time of attack; photos (M)

headline: Swiss trains grind to halt in power failure
COURT ALLOWS FOOTSTAR TO CONTINUE SALES IN KMART
abstract: Court Allows Footsta

headline: Business Briefs | General Mills to Move a Production Plant From Boston
abstract: General Mills said it would relocate a portion of its retail frozen baked goods production from Boston to another plant to cut manufacturing costs. The relocation will result in a $30 million charge in the fiscal fourth quarter, and the elimination of about 175 jobs, the company said.

headline: L.A. elects Latino mayor for first time since 1872
Zimbabwe Takes Harsh Steps to Counter Unrest
abstract: Facing rising unrest over a collapsing economy, Zimbabwe's authoritarian government has apparently adopted a scorched-earth policy toward potential enemies, detaining thousands of people, burning homes and street kiosks and routing large numbers of people from makeshift homes in major cities.    The scope of the operation, which began in mid-May, is unknown, in part because a nationwide gasoline shortage has prevented some of those following events in Zimbabwe from monitoring the impact firsthand. But reports in the local press and from witnesses indicate that the police have detained or arrested as many as 30,000 residents in big cities and evicted hundreds of thousands more from shantytowns on the fringes of most cities.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: SOME VERY DIFFERENT retailers are intermingling within Manhattan neighborhoods. [C7.]    THE LUXURY Montage Hotel, a $211 million project, will rise soon in Beverly Hills despite a well-financed opposition campaign. [C6.]

headline: LG's shares rise despite fall in net
Profit Rises 19 Percent at Royal Bank of Canada
abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada said its quarterly profit increased 19 percent, helped by a move into the insurance business in Canada and cost cuts at its United States operations. The bank said that income in the quarter that ended April 30 rose to 907 million Canadian dollars ($722 million), or $1.37 a share. The increased earnings were underpinned by a 5.6 percent rise in profit at its Canadian consumer banking unit. The bank plans to raise its dividend 11 percent, and buy back up to 10 million shares of common stock.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: Obituary: John Walton, 58; billionaire and Wal-Mart family heir
A warning fromChina on textile trade curbs
Allies doubt future of North Korea talks
Ex-Officials Say Bolton Inflated Syrian Danger
abstract: Senate Finance Committee plans to start hearings on plans to overhaul Social Security system; 20-member panel appears to be just as divided--and stalled--as Senate at large; Pres Bush's proposal for private accounts may be ultimate test for committee that prides itself on being above partisan wars; Bush administration is in final week of 60-day push to sell its Social Security plan, and Democratic leaders hold rallies in New York to highlight their opposition; committee will showcase political arguments of both sides; four experts on Social Security from outside Congress are invited to present their plans for achieving 'sustainable solvency'; panel chairman Sen Charles E Grassley has reportedly called hearing to illustrate that any changes to strengthen Social Security financially, with or without private accounts, would have to include lower benefits, higher taxes or both (M)

headline: Avoiding potholes when renting a car
Iraqi leader speaks of 2 years to establish security
U.S. Agrees to Take Over Four Pension Plans at United
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp agrees to take over all four of United Airlines' employee pension plans, with shortfall of $9.8 billion, making it biggest pension failure since government began insuring benefits in 1974; agreement, if approved by federal bankruptcy judge, would remove obstacle to UAL Corp's emergence from bankruptcy protection; pilots' union has already agreed to move but flight attendants had hoped to preserve their plan (M)

headline: Pope seeks closer ties with other churches
Bush seeks to give Abbas some White House help
TechBrief: Eidos finds a buyer
A Mild Rally, Led by G.M. and Oil Prices
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 27.56 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,486.02; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 2.68 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,184.07; Nasdaq composite index slips 0.18 point, to 1,999.14; price and yield for 10-year US Treasury note noted; graph; chart on key US interest rates (M)

headline: Airbuslifts profit at EADS
Verizon to Issue New Shares
abstract: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it planned to issue 132 million new shares as part of its effort to buy MCI.    The information was part of a regulatory filing that started an estimated three-month process that would ultimately let MCI's shareholders vote on Verizon's $7.6 billion takeover bid.

headline: Thailand moves to revive economy
Storm over deportation to Syria
Reformists blocked from Iran vote
Israel Carries Out First Airstrike, in Gaza, in 3 Months of Truce
abstract: Israel carries out its first airstrike since truce was announced three months ago, firing on Palestinian cell that was firing mortars at Jewish settlements in southern Gaza Strip; one Palestinian militant is dead and several are wounded, as is one Israeli civilian; events reflect fragile nature of truce that has greatly reduced overall level of violence since Feb but has not silenced the guns (M)

headline: Clothier's Suit Says Saks Abused Markdown Deductions
abstract: International Design Concepts, apparel maker, charges in lawsuit that Saks Inc's abuse of markdown deductions caused it to fail by preventing it from paying its fees for its license to manufacture Oscar de la Renta clothes, its only source of revenue; says Saks Fifth Avenue made up 60 percent of its sales (M)

headline: Viacom to Hire Chief Financial Officer
abstract: Viacom is set to hire Michael Dolan, former advertising executive, as its new chief financial officer; succeeds Richard Bressler, who left company this year (S)0

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Government Health Team Found Dead
abstract: Four Peruvian medical workers working in a remote northern region have been killed, and the authorities are trying to determine if the killers are members of an Indian tribe. The team of doctors and nurses had been providing medical care to poor jungle communities when they were last reached by radio nearly two weeks ago. Villagers discovered their bodies in a single grave on Monday, The Associated Press reported.   Juan Forero (NYT)

headline: Wireless: Content is the challenge for cellphone companies
Turnout Is Key Issue as Iranians Vote for Next President
abstract: Iran's campaign season was defined by moderate, reform based platforms and yet was also marred by extraordinary violence.

headline: Waves of applause for a beloved pope
Hard-liners win easily in Ulster
New Twist Leaves Mayor of Mexico City Up in the Air
abstract: Case against Mayor Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador of Mexico City has fallen into limbo, little more than week after Congress voted to lift his official immunity so he could stand trial on felony charges of contempt of court; federal prosecutors say they will wait to seek arrest warrant until Supreme Court rules on his appeal; polls consistently show Lopez Obrador to be likely candidate to succeed Pres Vicente Fox; his aides say they suspect that government is trying to delay arrest warrant to make it even harder for him to meet deadlines that would allow him to compete in presidential election (M)

headline: Nokia hit with reprimand
Making the World Smaller
abstract: I WAS born in Gloucester, Mass., the first of six children. My father's parents came to Gloucester, one of the world's great fishing ports, around the turn of the century from what today would be Lithuania. My grandfather started a company that made oil skins for fishermen. During the Depression, my grandfather died, and two of his sons, my father and uncle, took over the company.    The two brothers had 12 children between them, but they made a strategic decision that none of us would be permitted to go into the family business. Their principal motivation was to keep peace within the family, but the decision also freed each of us to pursue our druthers.

headline: International Donors Pledge to Step Up Their Efforts to Provide Financial Aid for Iraq
abstract: The donors also urged Iraqi leaders to make more efforts to reach out politically to disaffected minorities supporting the insurgency.

headline: Judge Upholds Lilly Drug Patent
abstract: Federal Judge Richard L Young upholds Eli Lilly's patent on Zyprexa, treatment for schizophrenia that was among top-selling drugs in US last year, with $2.4 billion in sales; Lilly sued generic drug companies Zenith Goldline Pharmaceuticals, Dr Reddy's Laboratories, and Teva Pharmaceuticals, after generic companies claimed that patent was invalid because Zyprexa is too similar to other chemical compounds whose patents have already expired; verdict protects Lilly's monopoly on selling Zyprexa in US until 2011, when its patent expires (M)

headline: EU's problem with 'no'
Merck Asks for a Dismissal in First of Suits Over Vioxx
abstract: Merck asks for dismissal of first Vioxx personal injury lawsuit scheduled to come to trial, contending man who died of heart attack after being prescribed Vioxx never took drug; says man's widow has repeatedly lied and produced false evidence; suit was filed in August 2003 in Ashland, Ala, by Cheryl Rogers, widow of Howard B Rogers; contends Rogers died from heart attack on Sept 4, 2001, after taking Vioxx for shoulder pain (M)

headline: Outsourced All the Way
abstract: Small American companies are now turning to places like Sri Lanka, China, Mexico and Eastern Europe to make clothes, jewelry, trinkets and even software programs; many of smallest enterpreneurs are turning to low-cost labor abroad to get their businesses off the ground; some regulatory barriers discussed; Philip Chigos and Mary Domenico, who are building children's pajama business, comment on using foreign labor; photos (M)

headline: Charter 'not dead,' EU insists
50 feared dead in Sri Lankan rail crash
Italians wonder about their role in kidnapping
World View of U.S. Improves Slightly, Except Among Muslims
abstract: A new international opinion poll found lingering  fears and resentments about the United States, but a warming in a few countries.

headline: Hedge funds are seen as threat to central banks' role
Lawmakers Block Women From Voting in Kuwait
abstract: Conservative lawmakers in Kuwait Parliament create constitutional roadblock that effectively kills measure that would have allowed women to participate in City Council elections for first time; hours later, elections are called for June 2; action eliminates any chance that women will be able to take part in elections for another four years, when city council seats are again up for grabs; photo (M)

headline: South African Bank Accepts Barclays Bid
abstract: Absa Group accepts Barclays sweetened 328 billion rand ($5.4 billion) bid for 60 percent of South African consumer lender; Min Trevor Manuel approves bid on condition Absa has locally based South African chief executive and South African majority in its executive management (S)

headline: Telstra hires an outsider as its chief
In Airline Shift, More Nonstop Flights Make Schedule
abstract: Big airlines are starting to add nonstop flights between cities they have connected for decades only via hub airports; movement, driven by competition from low-fare airlines, could turn out to be one of biggest shifts in the industry since it first adopted hub-and-spoke approach after deregulation in late 1970's; already, major airlines have added 134 nonstop routes in last year; flights promise to be cheaper than they have been in past; charts; photo (M)

headline: A Time for Mourning, but Also for Study and Very Quiet Politics
abstract: Pope John Paul II's funeral Mass on Friday began nine days of spiritual mourning, but it also opened a political chapter -- the subtle campaigning before the gathering of cardinals in a conclave starting April 18 to elect a successor.    Each day of mourning is marked by a Mass, several of which will be celebrated by cardinals -- whose voices will be listened to closely for any hints about what direction they are moving in. The first is on Saturday afternoon, to be celebrated by Cardinal Francesco Marchisano, a career Vatican official who is the archpriest of St. Peter's Basilica.

headline: AMD plans IPO for lagging memory-chip unit
Profit lifts Oracle shares
Now, Audio Blogs for Those Who Aspire to Be D.J.'s
abstract: What do the pope and Paris Hilton have in common? They're both podcasters -- and you can be one too.    Ranging from the sublime to the ridiculous, podcasts are essentially do-it-yourself recorded radio programs posted online. Anyone can download them free, and, using special software, listeners can subscribe to favorite shows and even have them automatically downloaded to a portable digital music player.

headline: Aviation: Rival glimpses of the future at the Paris Air Show
Afghans Deny Making Deal For Release Of Italian
abstract: The Afghan government said Saturday that it had released the mother of a kidnapper of an Italian aid worker on Thursday, just before the Italian was freed. But Interior Minister Ahmed Ali Jalali insisted there had been no deal, even though one of the kidnapper's main demands was his mother's release.     The hostage, Clementina Cantoni, 32, was freed after being held hostage for 24 days by a criminal gang member known as Timur Shah, a suspect in several incidents of robbery and kidnapping in the capital.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Growth Forecast May Be Cut
abstract: Italy's economy minister, Domenico Siniscalco, says economic growth forecast for this year will probably be cut by close to half and deficit will most likely rise above limit set by European Union; photo (S)

headline: EU closer to rules on chemicals
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Sentiment Improves
abstract: Japan's consumer confidence index rose to 45.6 for first quarter from 45.5 for fourth quarter of 2004 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Heinz to Buy Danone Sauces
abstract: H J Heinz acquires several sauce brands from Groupe Danone for $855 million (S)

headline: Earnings: High oil prices lift profit
Bolivia Lawmakers Scramble for New Leader
abstract: Congress prepared to anoint President Carlos Mesa's successor, the senate president, whom protest leaders reject.

headline: Briefly: EU ministers warn Cuba on human rights
Obituary: Zhang Chunqiao, 88, member of Gang of Four
Funds in Brief: U.S. law would regulate marketing to military
Pope Vows to Try to End Split With the Orthodox
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI made his first official trip on Sunday, pledging at a huge outdoor Mass in this seaside city to work toward reuniting the long-divided Roman and Orthodox Catholic Churches.     ''I would like to confirm my willingness to assume as a fundamental commitment the work to reconstitute the full and visible unity of all the followers of Christ, with all my energy,'' he said in his homily to a crowd estimated at 200,000 people. ''How can we communicate with the Lord if we don't communicate among ourselves?''

headline: Cellular Service in Turkey Gets Another Bidder
Egypt Editor Quits
abstract: The resignation of Ibrahim Seada has fueled speculation that a major reshuffling may be planned within Egypt's state-run news media.

headline: National Magazine Awards Honor Journalism and Help Sell Ads
abstract: WHEN nominees for awards buy advertisements in trade publications, mail out media kits, postcards and other materials promoting their nominations, and distribute trinkets like View-Master toys preloaded with reels praising their merits, it must be nearing Oscar time, right?    Not quite, since the Academy Awards were bestowed more than a month ago. The description also fits the prelude to the 40th annual National Magazine Awards for editorial achievement, which are to be presented at a luncheon today by the American Society of Magazine Editors in New York in association with the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

headline: Ex-minister of France blames U.S.
G.M. Board Wants Cut in Benefits
abstract: General Motors Corp's board gives United Automobile Workers union until end of month to agree to cuts in its members' health care benefits; many local union leaders have said they are willing to make concessions, but not to extent that GM is seeking; GM is threatening to make cuts on its own if union and company cannot agree by end of month; union local president Eldon J Renaud hints at possible strike if company makes unilateral move (M)

headline: No Reason to Oversee Nielsen, F.T.C. Says
abstract: Critics of efforts by Nielsen Media Research to change way it measures television ratings meet with setback from Federal Trade Commission, which says it sees no reason to assume oversight of Nielsen or how ratings data are gathered (S)

headline: A Watch That Senses You're Ready to Get Up (and Tells You So)
abstract: Sleep specialists say it's more difficult to wake up from a period of deep sleep than from a light one. To improve on the traditional alarm clock -- which, if it jolts you awake from a deep sleep, could leave you feeling drowsy during the day -- an Atlanta company called Innovative Sleep Solutions has designed an alarm wristwatch called the Sleeptracker.     Available at www.sleeptracker.com, the $149 watch, which resembles a Timex digital, houses a device called an accelerometer that monitors your sleep pattern to determine your most comfortable wake-up time. You set a window of time in which you would like the alarm to sound, and the watch wakes you during a light-sleep period within that time frame.

headline: Even the French are fighting obesity
Bush Declares Sacrifice in Iraq to Be 'Worth It'
abstract: President Bush, facing a growing restiveness around the country and in his own party over the constant stream of casualties in Iraq, declared Tuesday night that the daily sacrifice of American lives in Iraq ''is worth it, and it is vital to the future security of our country.''    In an address to the nation from this Army base, in front of 750 members of the 82nd Airborne Division and the Army's Special Operations unit based here, Mr. Bush spoke in somber tones of the need for staying power in what has become a long conflict in Iraq. As he has in the past, the president melded the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks with the enemies Americans now face in Iraq.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,660 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    ARGEL, Derek, 28, Capt., Air Force; Lompoc, Calif.; 23rd Special Tactics Squadron.    CRATE, Casey, 26, Staff Sgt., Air Force; Spanaway, Wash.; 23rd Special Tactics Squadron.    DOWNS, William, 40, Maj., Air Force; Winchester, Va.; Sixth Special Operations Squadron, Hurlburt Field, Fla.    DRIER, Charles A., 28, Sgt., Army; Tuscola, Mich.; Third Infantry Division.    FISHER, Dustin C., 22, Specialist, Army; Fort Smith, Ark.; Third Infantry Division.    FRESQUES, Jeremy, 26, Capt., Air Force; Clarkdale, Ariz.; 23rd Special Tactics Squadron.    WALLACE, Jeffrey R., 20, Pfc., Army; Hoopeston, Ill.; Third Infantry Division.

headline: PITNEY BOWES TO ACQUIRE IMAGITAS FOR DIRECT MAIL
abstract: Pitney Bowes to acquire Imagitas, closely held marketing services company, for about $230 million to expand its direct-mail business (S)

headline: BOEING MUST BID AGAIN FOR $3 BILLION CONTRACT
abstract: Boeing Must Bid Again

headline: Ukrainian moguls appeal to European rights court
Woolworths shares drop after Apax withdraws bid
Jobs, lies and CVs: How far?
A mobile tale of three cities
At least 50 die in Japan derailment
Iraqi Army opens sweep on Baghdad insurgents
Guru of Sadism, Safely in Jail, Leaves Cult to Fend for Itself
abstract: Article on visit to Colonia Dignidad, German colony in Chile now renamed Villa Baviera, where Paul Schafer, former Nazi Luftwaffe medic turned lay preacher, is said to have sexually molested scores of young boys, and to have drugged and tortured those who angered him; Schafer dominated life of his 300 followers until his arrest in Mar after years on run; photos; map (M)

headline: Hollywood's Boogeyman Is Getting Bigger
abstract: As Hollywood moves to fight online film piracy, newly released tracking results show that more and more users have large video files on their home computers.    The NPD Group, a market research company, found an increase of about 60 percent over last year in the number of households with video files of 150 megabytes or larger, about the size needed to store a half-hour television program. And these households averaged about 16 such files, nearly twice as many as last year. The data come from monitoring computers of 40,000 volunteers.

headline: Not the Top of the Safety Priorities
abstract: Volvo has promoted the sturdiness of its cars' roofs since it ran advertisements in the 1970's showing seven Volvo sedans stacked up, asking, ''Are you in the market for a hardtop?''      And Volvo, in introducing its first sport utility vehicle in 2002, the XC90, had a promotional video claiming the strength of the roof ''exceeds the legal requirements in the U.S.A. by more than 100 percent.''

headline: 2 Former Bristol-Myers Executives Charged With Fraud
abstract: Two former executives of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company were indicted on conspiracy and securities fraud charges related to artificially inflating revenues.

headline: Travelocity to buy lastminute.com
Two Banks May Unite in Europe
abstract: Unicredito Italiano and HVB Group of Germany are discussing merger that would create Europe's first big cross-border financial powerhouses; deal could be valued at 16 billion euros, or about $20 billion (M)

headline: Bush-Sharon discord underlies Texas meeting
Tech Brief: C&W posts first profit in 3 years
Philips Shares Fall on Demand Forecast
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, the biggest maker of television sets and other appliances in Europe, said Wednesday that consumer demand in the region is slowing this quarter. His remarks led to the biggest decline in the company's share price in two years.    ''Europe in particular is suffering from a weakened consumer retail environment in the second quarter, hampering our growth ambitions in the short term,'' Gerard J. Kleisterlee, the chief executive, said in a statement. He and Jouko Karvinen, head of the medical systems unit, met with analysts here.

headline: Economic Calendar
Two to Leave Toys 'R' Us if Investors' Takeover Is Completed
abstract: Toys 'R' Us says its chief executive John H Eyler Jr and its chief operating officer Christopher K Kay will step down if company is acquired by private investors, as is expected; Toys 'R' Us shareholders are expected to approve $6.6 billion sale on June 23; buyers are equity firms Bain Capital and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and real estate developer Vornado Realty Trust (M)

headline: Berlusconi to Form New Italian Government by Early Next Week
Betamax déjà vu?
Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about finding hotel deals in Europe incorrectly described the ownership of Best Western hotels. They are independently owned and operated; they are not owned by Best Western.

headline: The Fed, Under a Microscope
abstract: IF you're a fan of economic news, you'll get your fill this week -- and then some. The Federal Reserve policy makers' meeting is on the agenda, along with widely followed snapshots of manufacturing, personal income and consumer confidence.    It's hard to find anyone who doubts that the Federal Open Market Committee will announce its ninth consecutive quarter-point increase in its short-term interest rate target, to 3.25 percent, when its meeting ends on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Russian pop star in tune with the U.S.S.R.
Chip switch could help Macintosh laptop sales
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Seven-Eleven Japan Profit Rises
abstract: Convenience store operator Seven-Eleven Japan Co reports net profit of 96.3 billion yen ($887 million) for year ended Feb 28, increase of 3.4 percent from year earlier, on 6 percent increase in revenue (S)

headline: European fund chiefs get more bullish on dollar
Car Bomb Near Baghdad Airport Interrupts Days of Calm
abstract: A car bomb exploded at an airport checkpoint on Wednesday, wounding 15 Iraqis and ending three days of relative calm in the capital.    A bomber drove a car packed with explosives into an area known as Checkpoint1, some distance from Baghdad International Airport, and detonated the vehicle about 9:30 a.m., an Interior Ministry official said. Insurgents then raked the area with gunfire. Soon after, American soldiers arrived and blocked off the scene. No Americans were hurt.

headline: China increases its cut of the diamond polishing market
Measure to Expand Political Rights for Kuwaiti Women Fails
Simmons Renews Vivendi Ties
abstract: Despite a company shake-up, Russell Simmons, the rap music mogul, has renewed his ties to the Island Def Jam music division of Vivendi Universal, which houses the pioneering rap label he created two decades ago.     Mr. Simmons has struck a deal to start a new label, the Russell Simmons Music Group, as a joint venture in partnership with Island Def Jam, a New York-based arm of the Universal Music Group. An official announcement is expected today.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Separatists Cross Border For Talks
abstract: Nine separatist leaders from the Indian-held part of Kashmir visited the Pakistani sector, walking across a recently constructed ''peace bridge'' to become the first Kashmiri separatist officials to set foot on the Pakistani side in 58 years. In a weeklong visit the nine are to hold talks with separatists from the Pakistan side and President Pervez Musharraf. Previously, Kashmiris had not been involved in any talks on the future of the territory.   Salman Masood (NYT)

headline: Mugabe Threatens to Meet Protests of Election in Zimbabwe With Force
abstract: Zimbabwean Pres Robert G Mugabe warns political opposition against taking to streets to protest Movement for Democratic Change's defeat in parliamentary elections, which Western governments, human rights groups and opposition have denounced as fraudulent; says 'mass action will be met with mass action'; Mugabe says his party is prepared to work with opposition in Parliament to deal with nation's difficulties; photos (M)

headline: Uzbek refugees go home - some willingly
Briefly: EU extends Gillette bid inquiry
Swiss Vote to Join Europe Plan to End Some Passport Controls
abstract: Swiss voters on Sunday approved plans to join the European Union's passport-free zone, an indication that Switzerland is moving away from its traditional isolation in the region.    In final results of the referendum, 55 percent of voters agreed to join the European Union's Schengen and Dublin accords, which Parliament ratified last year.

headline: Qwest Refuses to Concede in Bid for MCI
abstract: Qwest Communications is not giving up its efforts to stop Verizon Communications, its bigger rival, from acquiring MCI; Qwest requests MCI's shareholder list in move that could lead to protracted, if uphill, proxy battle that Qwest hopes will convince those holding majority of MCI's shares of superiority of its bid; Qwest's chief financial officer Oren Shaffer says there is clearly anger among some MCI shareholders; MCI's board says Qwest's $8.9 billion bid is not superior to Verizon's $7.6 billion offer; graph (M)

headline: MCI investors urge new Qwestbid
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chief Executive of Morgan Stanley Announces That He Will Resign  Philip J. Purcell, a Wall Street outsider whose leadership of Morgan Stanley has been marked by a series of legal clashes and bitter internal dissent, said that he would retire as soon as his successor was named. The announcement yesterday ended a public power struggle between Mr. Purcell and dissident former executives. [Page A1.]     Morgan Stanley's directors now must decide whether the firm's problem was Mr. Purcell, or his strategy to create a financial supermarket that served customers from retirees to multinational corporations. [C1.]    The names of at least 25 financial services executives are on the table to become the next chief executive of Morgan Stanley. [C5.]    Disparity in Disclosure of Flaws in Heart Devices  Even as sales of pacemakers and other widely used heart devices soar, uniform standards do not exist among manufacturers about when, or even if, to notify doctors and patients when the devices may have flaws. [C1.]    Companies Given More Freedom to Study Drugs  The Supreme Court gave pharmaceutical companies broad latitude to study and experiment with drugs covered by other companies' patents, a decision that might help speed the development of new medical treatments. [C1.]    OPEC Members Say They Are Ready to Raise Output  OPEC representatives said that they were prepared to lift oil production, but emphasized that strong international demand for oil limited their ability to influence markets. [C1.]    I.B.M. to Announce Radio Tag Offerings  I.B.M. Global Services plans to announce that its consultants will begin selling advice on consumer privacy issues surrounding the use of radio identification tagging of consumer goods. I.B.M.'s software division will also be introducing a ''starter kit'' intended to help clients more quickly develop ways to link data-generated radio scanners into existing corporate software that manage functions like order entry, shipping and inventory controls. [C9.]    Quest Diagnostics Investors First Worried, Then Relieved  Investors were nervous a week ago when Quest Diagnostics disclosed that it had received subpoenas from the Justice Department over its contracts. But they were relieved when they learned that another medical testing company was also part of the inquiry. [C3.]    Airbus Says Order Ensures Future of Airbus A350  Qatar Airways that it would buy 60 Airbus A350 long-range jets, a number that the chief executive of Airbus said was enough to ensure that the plane would be built. [C3.]    Wealthy Entrepreneurs Take Ambitions to Space  Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft co-founder who financed a manned rocket, is a member of a growing club of high-tech thrillionaires who find themselves with money enough to fulfill their childhood fascination with space. [F1.]    Sony Plans Changes on CD's to Prevent Piracy  Sony BMG Music Entertainment, which is owned by Sony and Bertelsmann, is outfitting some of its new CD's with software to restrict copying. [C2.]    Donations to Charity Rose Slightly in 2004  Charitable giving rose somewhat last year, reflecting economic stability and stock gains that helped lift foundation assets and corporate profits. [A12.]    Numbers Add Up to Very Crowded Travel Season  Forces are converging that could make this summer a particularly crowded and delay-ridden time to travel. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C7.]    W.T.O. Leader Says Talks on Services Are Moving Slowly  Negotiations aimed at producing a new global trade pact are moving very slowly on trade in services, but a comprehensive deal remains possible next year, the director general of the World Trade Organization, Supachai Panitchpakdi, left, said. Trade in services is especially important to countries like the United States, where the bulk of the growth in employment has tended to be in services and not in manufacturing or agriculture. [C6.]    Stock Market Gains Limited by Oil Price Rise  The stock market trimmed earlier gains as the price of oil rose. The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 9.93 points, to 10,522.56. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 2.71 points, to 1,200.82. The Nasdaq composite index was up 5.96 points, to 2,068.96. [C10.]

headline: Chief to Pass Reins Of Y.&R., the Agency
abstract: Ann Fudge, chairwoman and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Brands and its struggling advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, plans to cede title at agency as soon as successor is found; other executive changes at agency noted (M)

headline: Bank to Buy Credit Card Business for $6.45 Billion
abstract: Washington Mutual, which grew rapidly from a Seattle savings institution to a home loan giant, said yesterday that it would buy Providian Financial for $6.45 billion in cash and stock, its first major foray into the credit card business.

headline: G.E. Chief Urges U.S. to Adopt Clearer Energy Policy
abstract: WASHINGTON, May 9 - The chief executive of the General Electric Company, Jeffrey R. Immelt, pushed the company squarely into the global warming debate on Monday, asking the government for a clear energy policy and saying later in an interview that he expected Washington to eventually impose controls on carbon emissions.

headline: Business Briefs | Jury Awards $128 Million in Wireless Patent Case
abstract: Cingular Wireless, the mobile phone carrier, and the Boston Communications Group were ordered by a jury to pay $128 million in damages for infringing a patent owned by Freedom Wireless. The verdict, reached in the United States District Court in Boston, named Cingular, its AT&T Wireless unit, Boston Communications, Western Wireless and CMT Partners. The closely held Freedom Wireless sued Boston Communications and cellular carriers in 2000, claiming Boston Communications' prepaid wireless services infringed two patents. The dispute is over prepaid services that let consumers pay for calls upfront, rather than sign up for a monthly plan, and then use the calling minutes without having to enter a pass code. A Cingular spokesman, Mark Siegel, said the company intended to appeal.

headline: Briefly: Guidant issues new warning
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: British Land in Acquisition
abstract: British Land Co, property developer, agrees to buy Pillar Property for 811 million pounds ($1.5 billion) to acquire shopping centers; photo (S)

headline: In Selection of New Pope, Third World Loses Out
abstract: Roman Catholics in Latin America express some disappointment that one of their own was not chosen as next pope, but episcopal conferences of each country in region, which are dominated by theological conservatives appointed by Pope John Paul II, are notably ehtusiastic with choice of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger; photos and priests in Vatican City and nuns in Enugu, Nigeria, celebrating election of new pope (M)

headline: David Lague: Is peace 'within reach' while China is arming?
Chevron Says S.E.C. Approves Its Contested Offer for Unocal
abstract: SEC clears Chevron's $16.4 billion offer for Unocal, lifting last regulatory hurdle for proposed acquisition; China National Offshore Oil Corp has made $18.5 billion bid for Unocal; Unocal shareholders will vote on Aug 10 (M)

headline: UN commission condemns Sudan abuses
Morgan Stanley's Choices: New Direction or Better Execution?
abstract: Question that Morgan Stanley's must decide is whether its main problem was chief executive Philip J Purcell, who is retiring after continuing 'personal attacks,' or his strategy to create financial supermarket that served customers ranging from retirees living on fixed incomes to multinational corporations; board's answer will determine what kind of chief executive it chooses as replacement for Purcell and what parts, if any, of sprawling firm it will spin off (M)

headline: Falling Fortunes of Wage Earners
abstract: Wages for average worker fell in 2004, after adjusting for inflation, first such drop in nearly decade; many economists argue that increasing exposure of Aemrican economy to globalization, along with other foreces, including soaring health insurance costs that leave less money for raises, is putting pressure on wages that could leave millions of workers worse off; some economists say wage sluggishness is temporary and that real wages have slipped only because sudden increase in oil prices has briefly left workes behind curve; Bureau of Labor Statistics says wages fell 0.5 percent last year, after inflation; graph; photo (M)

headline: Nobelists meet in Jordan to tackle the big issues
Pope's Visitors Saw Serenity in Final Hours
abstract: Pope Pope John Paul II lay in wide, white-blanketed bed in sun-filled bedroom in final hours of his life; visitors to his bedside and official Vatican reports portray him as tranquil and comfortable in face of death; photo (M)

headline: The Churn
abstract: Deal Makers      Morgan Stanley and Lazard advised Viacom on its plan to split into two companies.    Lazard and the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft advised Pfizer in its planned purchase of Vicuron Pharmaceuticals for $1.9 billion in cash. Morgan Stanley and the law firm of O'Melveny & Myers advised Vicuron.     The private equity firm Blackstone Group is acquiring Wyndham International, the hotel company, for $1.44 billion. Bear, Stearns advised Wyndham, while Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison was legal adviser to Wyndham. Simpson Thacher & Bartlett was legal adviser to Blackstone.

headline: Indian outsourcers move to fix security
A camp is liberated: For inmates of Mauthausen, survival was a matter of luck
United Air Reaches Deal With Mechanics
abstract: United Airlines and its mechanics' union reach tentative agreement on five-year contract calling for $96 million in wage and benefit cuts; tentative deal with union, Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, leaves only one major union, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, without agreement; airline wants IAM to agree to cuts worth $176 million a year (M)

headline: Business Briefs | Application for Wider Use of Antipsychotic Drug Rejected
abstract: Johnson & Johnson, the drug maker, said federal regulators rejected its application to market the antipsychotic drug Risperdal as an autism treatment. The Food and Drug Administration sent the company a ''not approvable'' letter in response to the application, Johnson & Johnson said. Risperdal is Johnson & Johnson's second-best-selling drug after the Procrit treatment for anemia in cancer patients. A company spokesman, Doug Arbesfeld, said the company would decide on its next step after it finished evaluating the letter.

headline: Mexico City Mayor's Supporters Speak With Quiet March
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people march to Mexico City's main plaza to protest government effort against Mayor Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador that threatens to force him out of next year's presidential elections; march seen as dramatic illustration of seemingly growing support for Lopez Obrador and disappointment in Pres Vicente Fox; some in crowd depict him as traitor; situation has plunged his party and cabinet into open conflict; photo (M)

headline: HealthSouth to Settle S.E.C. Charges; Scrushy Jury Pauses
abstract: HealthSouth said Wednesday that it had reached an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to pay $100 million to settle securities charges related to a $2.7 billion accounting fraud that occurred under the company's former management.     A federal jury here completed its 12th day of deliberations Wednesday in the criminal fraud trial of Richard M. Scrushy, HealthSouth's former chief executive. The jury does not plan to resume work until Monday, a pace that has raised eyebrows among some legal analysts.

headline: A Bluetooth Plug-and-Chat Device Keeps Your Hands on the Wheel
abstract: Short-range wireless technology called Bluetooth has driven the popularity of wireless cellphone headsets; with updated EasyDrive car kit from parrot, ranks of cellphone users adopting Bluetooth hands-free speakerphones for ther cars may grow as well; photo (S)

headline: Palestinian Police Will Be Allowed to Carry Weapons in the West Bank
abstract: The move by the Israeli military is one of the few signs of coordination between the sides in recent weeks.

headline: Economic Calendar
World Business Briefing | Asia: Germany: Factory Orders Decline
abstract: Factory orders in Germany dropped in April for the third month in the last four, adding to signs of an economic slowdown in the euro region. Orders fell 2.9 percent from March, when they gained 2.1 percent, the government said. Economists had expected orders to fall 0.8 percent, a Bloomberg survey said. Demand from abroad fell 5.2 percent, while domestic orders slid 0.6 percent, the report said.

headline: Europa: A German conundrum over early elections
Deputy appointed to head Al Qaeda
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,675 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    BURRI, Eric T., 21, Specialist, Army; Wyoming, Mich.; 623rd Quartermaster Company, First Corps Support Command.

headline: EUaffirms state bans on seeds
Russia and Europeans Sign Pact, but Tensions Persist
abstract: Russia and European Union sign long-stalled accord to forge closer economic, political and social ties, summit conference, Moscow; Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin hails accord as step toward creating European continent with no dividing lines; scores Baltic nations for clinging to historic grievances over Soviet domination, television speech; his negative remarks about possible border demands by Latvia and Estonia sour otherwise cordial atmosphere (M)

headline: U.S. Embassy in Indonesia Closes as Web Site Plots an Attack
abstract: The United States Embassy was closed here on Thursday because of what officials would describe only as an unspecified security threat. But a Western counterterrorism official and a private security analyst said the decision had been made after a diagram of the embassy and details of how best to carry out an attack were posted on a Web site.    The diagram, which was posted on www.Istimata.co.nr by a group calling itself the Brigade Istimata International, showed the location of the ambassador's office, surveillance cameras and heat detectors.

headline: New Leaders at Magna
abstract: Magna International founder Frank Stronach steps down as interim chief executive; Donald Walker and Siegfried Wolf are named co-chief executives (S)

headline: Tracking hidden clues in e-mail
World Briefings
abstract: UNITED NATIONS.

headline: Mystery of the 2 Hotels Embroils Greeks, Jews and Arabs
abstract: Patriarch Eirinaois has denied report that Greek Orthodox Church has sold two modest, Palestinian-run hotels in Jerusalem's Old City to Jewish investors from abroad, but his claims are met with skepticism; episode touches some of most sensitive nerves in Holy Land; Palestinian politicians accuse Greek Orthodox Church of assisting Israel in ceaseless battle over city both sides claim as capital; Greek government, which has close relations with church, has sent committee to Jerusalem to investigate and is now hinting that patriarch should step aside; Jordan has twice summoned patriarch for explanation; as dispute unfolds, Israel has been conspicuously silent, mystery investors remain unidentified, and status of hotels is not clear; photos; map (Jerusalem Journal) (M)
