headline: Searchingthe e-mail with Google
Recruiting Goals
abstract: Among retired senior officers from the Army's recruiting command, who watched the speech in living rooms from Olympia, Wash., to Huntsville, Ala., the president received praise for highlighting the troops' sacrifice, and criticism for failing to offer specific proposals that would help veterans and recruiters persuade young people to join.    Maj. Gen. Evan R. Gaddis, who retired in 2000 as head of the recruiting command for the Army, said the speech made clear that ''we're not going to make this a half commitment, we're not going to make another Vietnam.''

headline: Funds in Brief: Firm brings a Tiger out of retirement
To Catch a Thief
abstract: Over the last eight months, there seemed to be at least 140 different men and women living in the same apartment at 2978 Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn. Every one of them appeared to have a credit card and an insatiable appetite for jewelry from the glittering collections hawked on ShopNBC, a shopping network based in this suburb of Minneapolis.    So it was particularly satisfying for Joan Radtke, the director of credit at ShopNBC, when a postal inspection agent in New York called to say that a 22-year-old man had been arrested Wednesday morning at the Nostrand Avenue address, partly on the basis of information provided by ShopNBC.

headline: Italians go to the polls in 13 regional elections
Crude oil futures hit all-time high, near US$60 per barrel
Ericsson net surges 73%
Citigroup to pay Enron investors $2 billion
CIA meeting with Sudan security chief angers some in U.S.
Power Rangers Meet Pac-Man in $1.7 Billion Deal
abstract: Bandai Co, which makes Power Rangers figures, agrees to buy Namco, which produced Pac-Man, in $1.7 billion deal that will create Japan's second-biggest toy and game company; new entity will be called Namco Bandai Holdings; Bandai's president Takeo Takasu will become president of new company, while Namco's vice chairman Kyushiro Takagi will be chairman; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poachers Kill All Of Reserve's Tigers
abstract: A government inquiry has found that not a single tiger remains in the famed Sariska national wildlife sanctuary in Rajasthan. ''The entire population seemed to have become extinct, primarily because of poaching'' the Forest Ministry said in a statement to Parliament. The inquiry was ordered after news reports about the park's plummeting tiger population. The last census, in 2002, turned up 22 tigers at the reserve. Conservationists have decried the slaughter in Sariska and are warning of similar poaching in other reserves.   Hari Kumar (NYT)

headline: When the Fed Is Tightening, a So-So Market Isn't Bad
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on so-so performance of stock market since Federal Reserve began raising rates in June; average increase in Standard & Poor's 500 earlier cycles, from month before rate increases began to month after they ended, was 3.5 percent; index has climbed 2 percent in current, not yet completed, cycle; graph (M)

headline: Briefly: EU gives Fortune Brands permission to buy new assets
In Germany, questions on who deserves a memorial
World Briefing | Middle East: Libya: French Offer To Help Develop Nuclear Energy
abstract: France has agreed to present Libya with a plan to develop a civilian nuclear energy program, the French Foreign Ministry said. A ministry spokesman, Jean-Baptiste Mattei, was quoted by Reuters as saying that for development of peaceful nuclear energy, ''the details are still being worked out, so we are still in an exploratory stage.'' In 2003, Libya pledged to give up nuclear weapons and agreed to dismantle installations that could be used for such weapons.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: Briefly: Speechless pianist remains unidentified
Corrections
abstract: The Money Trails column last Sunday, about the performance of hedge funds, referred incorrectly to a 10-year period in which such funds typically posted an average annual return of 11.97 percent, versus 10.26 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It was through April 2005, not through April 1995.

headline: Kabul Doubts Report of Death of Abducted Italian
abstract: A man claiming to have kidnapped an Italian aid worker in the Afghan capital, Kabul, announced Friday that he had killed her because his demands had not been met, Reuters reported. But a government spokesman said that she was alive and that negotiators had spoken to her.     The aid worker, Clementina Cantoni, 32, who works for CARE International, was seized from her car on Monday evening in central Kabul. Government officials have said they suspect a criminal gang, which has demanded that gang members be released from prison, to be behind the abduction. The foreign minister, Abdullah Abdullah, said Thursday that officials had spoken to Ms. Cantoni and that she was unharmed.

headline: Mix-and-Match Retailers for the Eclectic Shopper
abstract: Seemingly incompatible types of retailers are beginning to sit side by side in Manhattan, where stores of same sort used to cluster together; retailers cannot be as choosy as they once were, and some national retailers actually seek advantage in areas where their peers are scarce; other factors in trend are rapid upscale transformation of some neighborhoods and changing shopping habits; photo (M)

headline: In Britain, Apple's iTunes Fans Have Reason to Be Confused
abstract: Entrepreneur Benjamin Cohen, 22, battles ruling by British registry for Internet names that he surrender to Apple Computer, oprator of popular iTunes music download service, itunes domain name he registered in Britain two months before Apple launched its music store; he comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Briefly: Ex-president denies election-fraud charges
They May Be Mundane, but Low-Tech Businesses Are Booming
abstract: Biggest fields of opportunity for aspiring entrepreneurs are in low-tech businesses; Census Bureau figures show small-business low-technology sector grew by nearly 4 percent in 2004, latest year with statistics available, to 17.6 million, and their combined revenue increased by 5.5 percent, to $770 billion; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Has 'Credible' Word of Syrian Plot to Kill Lebanese
abstract: The United States has received ''credible information'' that Syrian operatives in Lebanon plan to try to assassinate senior Lebanese political leaders and that Syrian military intelligence forces are returning to Lebanon to create ''an environment of intimidation,'' a senior administration official said Thursday.    The official said that the information had come from ''a variety of Lebanese sources'' and that ''we assess it as credible.'' The information, he said, was gathered after the recent assassinations of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in February, and of Samir Kassir, a well-known journalist, a week ago.

headline: Anti-US protests spread to Pakistan
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ex-Deputy Facing Charges
abstract: The national prosecutor said he would charge the nation's recently fired deputy president, Jacob Zuma, with two counts of official corruption stemming from his ties to Schabir Shaik, a financial adviser convicted on fraud and bribery charges this month. President Thabo Mbeki fired Mr. Zuma after a Durban court concluded that Mr. Shaik had paid him bribes for several years, apparently in exchange for political influence on government contracts. Mr. Zuma has denied wrongdoing. His supporters applauded the prosecutor's decision, arguing that the Shaik conviction unfairly tainted him and that a separate trial would offer Mr. Zuma a chance to clear his name.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: THE RISING COST OF STEEL, copper, plywood, cement and other materials is wreaking havoc on construction costs. One project that has been scaled back is the Charles Street Jail in Boston, which is becoming a four-star hotel. [C8.]    SEVEN SPECIALTY BUILDINGS managed by Adams & Company Real Estate have dedicated 1.9 million square feet of space in Manhattan to specific segments of the fashion industry. [C9.]

headline: Quarterly Trade Gap Hits $195 Billion
abstract: The United States hit a record deficit of $195.1 billion in the first quarter in trade and capital flows with the rest of the world, the Commerce Department reported Friday. The news reignited worries that the economy cannot sustain the growing level of global debt.    If this pace continues, the United States' current account deficit could reach $780 billion this year, a sharp increase from last year's record of $617 billion.

headline: Protesters keep up La Paz blockade
Will the Next Version of Windows Be Worth the Wait?
abstract: Randall Stross column examines whether Windows XP Longhorn, Microsoft's next version of Windows operating system scheduled for release in 2006, is worth waiting for; computer analyst Michael Cherry says many PC users will not replace their computers if new Windows version is incompatible; analyst Rob Enderle predicts that Longhorn will provide 'vast improvements in security;' software engineer Mark Lucovsky comments on what it takes to create, improve or debug operating system; photo (M)

headline: Sales of Cancer Drug Help Roche Post Increase
abstract: Roche Holding reports 14 percent increase in first-quarter revenue; group sales rose to 8.09 billion Swiss francs ($6.8 billion) (M)

headline: Bush push for new refineries and nuclear plants
Court Orders A.I.G. to Safeguard Records
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission wins order to secure documents in investigation into various American International Group transactions with offshore reinsurance companies and privately held entities closely aligned with company; court order prohibits AIG's former chairman-chief executive Maurice R Greenberg, company itself and C V Starr, privately held insurance company that was owned and run by AIG executives and officers, from destroying any documents related to investigation; also puts into effect procedures for different participants to examine documents (M)

headline: SEC wants Molson Coors papers
France Télécom outlines goals
World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Microsoft Meets Deadline
abstract: European Union regulators said they would examine Microsoft's latest proposal for complying with a March 2004 antitrust order. Microsoft had until midnight Tuesday to present its plan to the European Commission, the E.U.'s regulatory arm, as to how it will make it easier for developers of free programs to work with Windows. ''Talks with Microsoft continued until late last night, and we will now analyze what is on the table,'' Jonathan Todd, the commission spokesman, said.

headline: Microsoft creates a home for the digital 'lifestyle'
Marconi net triples on tax credit
Stocks: Greenspan's comments on oil ease worries
Second Inquiry by Big Board
abstract: New York Stock Exchange is conducting second investigation of its market-making traders and may take action against group as large as 15 specialists who were charged with criminal fraud in April (S)

headline: IPO for British satellite operator
Croatia's EU chances dim as Hague says state is protecting war criminal
Ex-Hostage's Italian Driver Ignored Warning, U.S. Says
abstract: The car carrying the Italian journalist Giuliana Sgrena that was struck with a deadly hail of gunfire as it sped toward Baghdad International Airport on March 4 ignored warnings from American soldiers who used a spotlight, a green laser pointer and warning shots to try to stop it as it approached a checkpoint, the American military said in a report released Saturday evening.    The gunfire killed Nicola Calipari, an Italian intelligence agent who was in the back seat with Ms. Sgrena. The driver and Ms. Sgrena were wounded. Lt. Gen. John R. Vines, the ground commander in Iraq, has approved a recommendation that soldiers involved in the shooting not be disciplined, the military said.

headline: 13 linked to Qaeda, Spain says
World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Return Sought For 131 Who Fled
abstract: Uzbekistan is seeking the extradition from Kyrgyzstan of 131 survivors of the deadly crackdown last month in Andijon, claiming they have been charged in absentia with involvement in ''terrorist attacks.'' The United Nations and Western governments have been urging the Kyrgyz government to refrain from turning over any of the survivors to the Uzbek authorities, who have been condemned for their use of torture. Human Rights Watch said it was deeply concerned for the survivors and noted that 29 men had already been taken into Kyrgyz custody, a step it fears will lead to their extradition to Uzbekistan.   C.J. Chivers (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: First Lady Storms Newspaper Office
abstract: Lucy Kibaki, the wife of President Mwai Kibaki, stormed into the Nairobi office of The Nation early yesterday, confiscated notebooks, tape recorders and pens, and demanded to know the whereabouts of a reporter who had written an article that offended her. Mrs. Kibaki then camped herself for much of the night at the desk of the newspaper's editor, unleashing a fury of broadsides at the staff. When a local television crew arrived, she slapped a cameraman. The first lady was angry at an article that had appeared in a rival newspaper that described how she had three times interrupted a farewell party held by the departing country director of the World Bank to demand that music she said was too loud be stopped. ''This is Muthaiga, not Korogocho,'' she angrily told the crowd of diplomats and other notables at the party, contrasting the plush neighborhood where she lives with one of Nairobi's sprawling slums.   Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline: An American label: Made in Germany
World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: A Brooklyn Retiree's Last Trip to See a Special Friend in Rome
abstract: Stella Gryziec, Polish-American, recalls day when Cardinal Karol Wojtyla, who became Pope John Paul II, visited her church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 1969 (M)

headline: Constellation weighs bid for Allied Domecq
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: APPLEBEE'S INTERNATIONAL, Overland Park, Kan., the restaurant chain, said it had agreed to buy the assets of 12 Applebee's restaurants in Missouri, Kansas and Arkansas from the Ozark Apples, an existing Applebee's franchisee. Terms were not disclosed.    SUPERIOR PLUS INCOME FUND, a Canadian propane, chemical and building materials company, said it had agreed to buy a chloralkali business in Port Edwards, Wis., from Occidental Petroleum, Los Angeles, an energy company, for $29.5 million.

headline: Bush to meet South Korean leader
Some Big Companies Failed to Add to Pensions in 1990's
abstract: More than half of the nation's biggest companies with pension plans sailed through the boom of the late 1990's and the bear market that followed without putting any cash into their pension funds, using loopholes in federal law to skirt a requirement for annual contributions, according to a new study by the investigative arm of Congress.    The study, issued yesterday by the Government Accountability Office, examined weaknesses in the federal pension rules in an effort to prevent cataclysmic failures like the one at United Airlines. United, which sponsors four large pension plans for its employees, followed the letter of the pension law, records at the Labor Department show, but the airline still ended up with a $10 billion shortfall in its plans.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Europeans Renew Call For Inquiry
abstract: The 55-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe strongly criticized the Uzbek government for its crackdown in Andijon last month, saying that the use of force was excessive and indiscriminate and that Uzbek forces might have executed unarmed civilians. It estimated that 300 to 500 people were killed and renewed its call for an international investigation. In Washington, Representative Lloyd Doggett, a Democrat from Texas and member of the House Ways and Means Committee, announced that he would introduce an amendment to the 2006 defense appropriations bill seeking to limit American military expenditures in Uzbekistan. Meanwhile, Human Rights Watch said that 29 Uzbek refugees had been detained by Kyrgyz authorities and that it feared that the refugees could be turned over to Uzbek security forces for torture. Four others have already been sent back.   C.J. Chivers (NYT)

headline: In a Real Estate Boom, Many Try Life as a Landlord
abstract: THREE years ago, Stacey Wunsch, 34, bought a one-bedroom apartment in Jersey City for $285,000. Its building had a health club and views of Manhattan.    When she married last year and then became pregnant, she needed more space. In September, she and her husband moved to a three-bedroom ranch home in the nearby suburb of Haworth, N.J.

headline: Jerky Pictures and Sound Are History. Videoconferencing Is All Grown Up.
abstract: When Kevin Callahan started offering classical guitar lessons over an Internet video link, he wanted the sound to be as close as possible to being in the same room. After experimenting, he built a system that channeled three guitars, a microphone, and an orchestral synthesizer through a professional mixing board to his Macintosh. From there, he blended the sound with Apple's GarageBand software before sending it out over the Internet.    ''It's not necessary,'' he explained a bit nonchalantly, ''but it gives me quite a bit of flexibility.''

headline: Polish resignation rejected
Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 23 at Baghdad Restaurant
abstract: The attack targeted a busy restaurant near the heavily fortified Green Zone government compound in Baghdad today.

headline: Stalking the Internet, an army on the rise
M&S offers warning
GE contract at risk amid Thai scandal
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Disk Drive Maker Raises Outlook
abstract: Stock of Western Digital Corp, maker of hard disk drives, rises 14 percent after company raises its earnings outlook for current quarter (S)ÿ

headline: Saks Reopens an Inquiry of Deductions
abstract: Three weeks after the Securities and Exchange Commission expanded its inquiry at Saks Fifth Avenue to include chargebacks -- deductions merchants take on their payments to clothing suppliers for mistakes the suppliers are said to have made -- Saks announced yesterday that it would reopen its own inquiry.    Besides chargebacks, yesterday's announcement from Saks Inc., the parent company, said the investigation would look at the chronology of when such deductions were taken and in which fiscal quarter they were recorded.

headline: Ex-Chief of US West to Lead Australian Telephone Giant
abstract: Telstra, the dominant telecommunications provider in Australia, said yesterday that it had hired Solomon D. Trujillo , the Wyoming native who ran US West and later the European cellular operator Orange, to be chief executive as the government prepares to sell its $23 billion stake in the company.    Mr. Trujillo will receive an annual salary of 3 million Australian dollars ($2.3 million), as well as a 2.5 million Australian dollar signing bonus, the company said. He is scheduled to take over July 1 from Zigmunt E. Switkowski. In December, Telstra decided to replace Mr. Switkowski after a series of disastrous expansions that cut the value of the company's stock in half.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Hospitalized
abstract: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, was briefly hospitalized for tests after his family said he might have had a small stroke. General Pinochet, 89, has in the past been declared incompetent to face trial on charges of rights abuses because he suffers from senile dementia stemming from such previous attacks. An appeals court is currently weighing a ruling that would strip him of his legal immunity from trial in connection with $17 million he is said to have illegally obtained and deposited at Riggs Banks and other financial institutions in the United States.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: Chief of Unit Files Lawsuit Accusing G.E. of Racial Bias
abstract: Marcel T Thomas, chief executive of GE Aviation Materials, files lawsuit accusing General Electric of underpaying African-American managers, denying them promotions and retaliating when they raise objections; GE denies allegation (S)

headline: FUNERAL HOME COMPANY REDUCES PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Service Corporation International, owner of funeral homes and cemeteries, records pretax charge of $310 million and reduces its profit forecast for year as result of shift in accounting (S)

headline: Mexico Labor Case Grows for Maker of Barbie Gowns
abstract: There was not much that Guadalupe Ávila Jiménez liked about her factory job making children's costumes, including flowing Barbie gowns for little girls who like to play princess.     ''They shouted at us, they did not let us go to the bathroom, they gave us food that made us vomit,'' said Ms. Ávila, 21, reciting a litany of indignities she said she had suffered at the factory, in Tepeji del Río. About the only thing she did like were the costumes the workers made. ''What we made was really pretty,'' she said.

headline: Iraqi legislator killed in suicide bombing
World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Seeks Retirement Change
abstract: Worÿ

headline: Chief of Havas Agency Quits After Clash With Big Investor
abstract: French advertising group Havas says chairman and chief executive Alain de Pouzilhac is stepping down, after public clash with big investor, Vincent Bollore; independent director Richard F Colker will act as chairman and chief executive; de Pouzilhac will retain his seat on company's board; de Pouzilhac's exit ends almost yearlong battle with Bollore, head of manufacturing company, Bollore Groupe, which became Havas's largest shareholder after amassing 22 percent of company; photo (M)

headline: Syria Ally Re-elected to Lebanon's No. 3 Post
abstract: The first Parliament with an anti-Syrian majority convened Tuesday and promptly re-elected one of Syria's staunchest allies as its speaker.    The sectarian straitjacket that controls politics here reserves the office for a Shiite Muslim, and so it was virtually foreordained that Nabih Berri, the leader of the Amal movement, would keep the powerful post he has held for 13 years. His alliance of Amal and the other main Shiite group, Hezbollah, took an estimated 80 percent of the Shiite vote and 35 seats in elections held on June 19.

headline: Limits on Mortgage Portfolios Have Support on House Panel
abstract: House Financial Services Committee chairman Michael G Oxley says committee ahs 'good chance' of approving bill that would direct new regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to reduce their $1.5 trillion loan holdings; committee hears testimony from Treas Sec John W Snow, who warns that without cuts in mortgage portfolios, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac could create financial market instability (M)

headline: BIG PROVIDER OF HOUSING FOR THE ELDERLY BUYS RIVAL
abstract: Big Provider of

headline: Shares Up for a Fourth Day as Oil Prices Keep Falling
abstract: Stocks rose yesterday for a fourth day, extending their biggest rally in six months, as oil prices dropped below $47 a barrel and technology shares advanced.    The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 5.52 points, or 0.5 percent, to close at 1,191.08. The Nasdaq composite index rose 11.93 points, or 0.6 percent, to 2,042.58. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 28.74 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,493.19.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: A Different Bird Flu
abstract: United Nations official announces outbreak of H7 avian influenza in North Korea; although type of flu has greater chance for human to human transmission compared with other bird flu, it produces less serious illness than H5N1 strain (S)

headline: Falling in Love With Elvis
abstract: CBS and large number of marketing partners are spending some $10 million to $20 million to promote new round of entertainment programming about Elvis Presley; CBS will air Elvis mini-series and Elvis by the Presleys documentary; CBS's Viacom siblings also plan copious cross-promotion; interest in Presley seems bigger now among advertisers, agencies and media companies than it was during his life; other current Presley projects noted; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Provisional Release For Kosovar
abstract: Ramush Haradinaj, a former guerrilla fighter who until his surrender to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in March as a war crimes suspect was the prime minister of Kosovo, will be allowed to return to Kosovo immediately until the start of his trial, expected in 2007. Mr. Haradinaj, 36, is a former Kosovo Liberation Army chief and the most senior Kosovar to be indicted by the tribunal. The judges who granted his release forbade him to participate in politics or to make public appearances for the first 90 days after his return. Prosecutors had tried to block his return, arguing that in recent trials held in Kosovo involving former guerrillas, witnesses there have been intimidated, and some killed.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: All work/All play: In this case, the deal really is the art
Pakistan Lifts Travel Restrictions on Rape Victim
abstract: Under pressure from Washington, the Pakistani government on Wednesday lifted its travel restrictions on Mukhtar Mai, whose gang-rape and its aftermath set off worldwide outrage at the treatment of women in Pakistan.     Mukhtar Mai, also known as Mukhtaran Bibi, was to visit the United States last week at the invitation of human rights groups, but she found her name on the government's list of people barred from traveling abroad. The restriction met with bitter protests from human rights advocates, here and abroad, as well as objections from the State Department.

headline: Wolfowitz confirmed in new post
TIME TO REBOOT?
abstract: Xybernaut, which has gotten much attention but relatively few orders for its ''wearable computers'' over the years, concedes it is plagued by a cash shortage, the absence of an outside auditor, a lack of timely financial statements and the dismissal of half its work force.    Headaches aplenty for its new C.E.O., Perry L. Nolen? You bet.

headline: France's Leaders Bicker as the Public Tunes Out
abstract: French Interior Min Dominique de Villepin's recent comment that France might need new prime minister, and that he is available, sets off conflict with Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin; Raffarin assures public there is no crisis in government, but battle has become nasty; duel between two men underscores how edgy political elite in France has become as poll after poll indicates that voters are poised to reject European Union Constitution when referendum takes place on May 29; Pres Jacques Chirac has lobbied hard for its passage; photo (M)

headline: On Board the Message Board
abstract: These days, you would be hard pressed to find many travelers who say the airlines are paying close attention to their customers' concerns. But there are at least 274 Continental frequent fliers who would have to concede that the company's top brass at least listened to their complaints -- in person, over dinner and drinks.    Early in April, Continental Airlines played host at a gathering in Houston for members of FlyerTalk.com, a travel Web site best known for its message boards where travelers discuss, dissect and often complain about pretty much anything related to travel, but mostly airlines and their frequent-flier programs.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-Official Admits To Bribes
abstract: Ludwig-Holger Pfahls, a high-ranking defense official in the government of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl who is accused of bribe-taking and corruption, surprised a court in Augsburg by confessing that in 1990 he had accepted about one million euros, or $1.2 million, for facilitating the sale of armored vehicles to the United States. Mr. Pfahls, who was arrested in Paris last year after five years on the run, is actually on trial over a separate matter: accusations that he accepted bribes of nearly $2.4 million from a weapons lobbyist in an arms sale involving Saudi Arabia in 1991. Mr. Pfahl's lawyers said they would like to invite Mr. Kohl and the former foreign ministers Klaus Kinkel and Hans-Dietrich Genscher to testify about the deal.   Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: Personal Data for 3.9 Million Lost in Transit
abstract: CitiFinancial, consumer finance subsidiary of Citigroup, says box of computer tapes containing information on 3.9 million customers was lost on May 2 by United Parcel Service, while in transit to credit reporting agency Experian in Allen, Tex from Weehawken, NJ; Citigroup says tapes have not been seen since; says there is no indication that tape were stolen or that any data on them has been compromised; photo (M)

headline: Earnings: Alstom loss chopped in half
Sharon offers more towns if violence ends
As Britain Votes, Tight Races for Older Voters Hold the Key
abstract: Labor Party is expected to be overall winner in British elections, but lackluster win would have far-reaching political consequences for Prime Min Tony Blair; key to outcome is likely to be in places where Labor Party has only slender lead on Conservatives and where older people are far more likely to determine outcome of vote than young; photo (M)

headline: Apple's book ban leads to bigger print run
No clear trend emerges from French EU polls
Headbanger's Buds Pump Subwoofer Bass (Best for Dry Ears)
abstract: Audio aficionados look down on those who use the ear buds that come with an MP3 player, judging the level of sound quality they produce to be close to that of a cheap clock radio.    Better sound systems add depth by pumping up the bass, so Headbanger Audio has created ear buds with a small subwoofer. These make songs sound more like something played through a real stereo system than through two tin cans attached by a string.

headline: SEARS ADDS WOMEN'S CLOTHING DESIGNED BY MAX AZRIA
abstract: Sears Holdings Corp will begin selling women's clothing brand by designer Max Azria to bolster declining apparel sales at its Sears department stores (S)

headline: Flat screens help Sharp's profit jump
World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Developer's Profit Rises
abstract: CapitaLand, Southeast Asia's biggest developer, said first-quarter profit rose 43 percent, helped by developments in China and in its Raffles Holdings unit, which owns the 118-year-old Raffles Hotel in Singapore. Profit rose to 70 million Singapore dollars ($42.8 million) as sales increased 18 percent, to 904.9 million Singapore dollars. CapitaLand is based in Singapore.

headline: Bomb Derails Russian Train, Injuring 15
abstract: A bomb derailed a passenger train traveling from Chechnya to Moscow on Sunday, injuring at least 15 people in what officials described as a terrorist attack.    The bombing occurred around 7 a.m. as the train approached Uzunova, a village roughly 90 miles south of Moscow, officials cited by news agencies said. Nikolai N. Zakharov, a spokesman for the Federal Security Service, said in televised remarks that ''an improvised remote control device'' was found about 50 yards from the site of the explosion.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MOLSON CANADA, Montreal, a beer brewer, said it bought Creemore Springs Brewery Ltd, Ontario, a beer brewer. Terms were not disclosed.    CONTAINER STORE, Dallas, a retailer of storage and organizing products, said it sold a 10 percent stake of its stock to the Fort Worth financier Robert M. Bass and two other investors. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: New Capabilities Breed New Accessories
abstract: FOR years, pundits foresaw a PC-centric future for all digital devices, a technotopia described in a single buzzword: convergence. Perhaps nowhere is this more apparent than on the cellphone front, where gadgets and services previously known in other domains are fighting for a spot next to mobile dial pads. Here is a sample of what is new, and what is next, for the dialed-in.    CELLPOD -- Camera phones are just bad enough that users generally do not care how well they frame a self-portrait or group shot in which they want to be included. But with two- and three-megapixel camera phones working their way toward the American market, users will likely be more demanding of such shots -- and that's a problem, because it is easier to make an egg sit up straight than a cellphone.

headline: Palestinian Leader to Meet Bush in Washington Next Week
abstract: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, is now scheduled to meet President Bush in Washington on May 26, after trips to China and Japan, Palestinian officials said Saturday.    Mr. Abbas held off on the visit to Washington in order to be able to demonstrate serious progress to the Americans in his efforts to reform the Palestinian security services, end violence against Israeli civilians, clean up Palestinian finances and prepare for the Israeli transfer of the Gaza Strip to full Palestinian control in late August.

headline: Hong Kong Leaders Ask Beijing for Ruling on Term Limit
Poland's Plea to Europe: Can We All Get Along?
abstract: Poland seen as symbol of risks that many in richer countries of European Union believe to be posed by ever bigger and more integrated Europe; EU is divided between rich countries beginning to see ever-expanding Europe as danger to their well-being and still enthusiastic poorer countries wondering if club they were invited to join is still willing to live up to its vision; photo (M)

headline: China to End Its Taxes on Textile Exports in Retaliation for U.S. and European Quotas
abstract: China said Monday that it was lifting self-imposed textile export tariffs in reaction to quotas on the exports by the United States and European Union.     The Commerce Ministry said it was removing duties it had placed on 81 products early this year.

headline: Barroso survives no-confidence vote
New to the Starbucks Menu: Exclusive Dylan
abstract: Starbucks plans to announce today that it will exclusively sell ''Bob Dylan: Live at the Gaslight 1962,'' further encroaching on the turf of traditional music retailers by offering a recording that has been prized by fans as a bootleg for decades.      Over the last year, the chain has become a force in the music business with the success of the Grammy-winning album of Ray Charles duets, ''Genius Loves Company.'' Starbucks sold more than 750,000 copies of the album.

headline: Transportation: Farther? Faster? Cleaner?
Relations Sour Between 2 Hispanic Broadcast Giants
abstract: Grupo Televisa, Mexican television empire, hints that it wants to withdraw from agreement under which it provides Univision Communications, largest Spanish-language broadcaster in US, with most of its prime-time lineup; has filed $1.5 million suit for back royalties; contends Univision is getting its premium soap operas on the cheap under 1992 sales agreement that lasts through 2017; may soon decide if it can broaden suit to include charges that might constitute grounds for breaking programming agreement; photos (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today and an auction of four-week bills and a five-year note on Wednesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 2.77 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 3.12 percent, and on the four-week issue was 2.59 percent.

headline: Power Struggle in Ecuador Static; Ex-Leader Is in Asylum Limbo
abstract: Pres Alfredo Palacio's fledgling government says it will take its time to decide whether to permit former Pres Lucio Gutierrez to leave Ecuador for Brazil, which has granted him asylum (M)

headline: White House Opposes Bill That Would Cut U.N. Dues
abstract: House Republican leaders are backing a bill that would cut in half the U.S. dues to the U.N. if it does not enact several reforms.

headline: Mubarak Opponent, in Court, Rejects Charge of Electoral Forgery
abstract: Ayman Nour, the most prominent opposition candidate in the election for president of Egypt this fall, pleaded not guilty to forgery charges on Tuesday in a chaotic trial that he and his supporters said was intended to blacken his reputation before the campaign.     Prosecutors accused him of forging more than 1,000 petition signatures needed to get his Tomorrow Party registered, and they sought to paint Mr. Nour, 40, as an accomplished counterfeiter, calling into question various aspects of his résumé, including his doctorate in constitutional history. He faces up to 15 years in prison; if found guilty, he could not run for president. But he said he was determined to persevere.

headline: Clerics Urge Sunni Arabs to Join Iraq's Police and Army
Loose Lips Let Slip Agent's Name at Hearing
abstract: Senators Richard G Lugar and John Kerry inadvertently refer to undercover CIA officer Fulton Armstrong by name during Senate hearing on John R Bolton's nomination to be United Nations ambassador (M)

headline: World Bank Vote Confirms Wolfowitz Unanimously
abstract: Paul D Wolfowitz is unanimously confirmed as new president of World Bank in vote by institution's executive board; his reputation as early advocate for invasion of Iraq brought loud criticism from Europe and some private groups, but board's approval of him was never in doubt and no country offered alternative candidate (M)

headline: Mexican Standoff: Staying Power May Shape Election
abstract: The streets of this capital city were quiet on Friday as both sides in the struggle over whether its leftist mayor will ever get a chance to run for president girded for a long public relations fight.    A day after Congress voted to begin a legal process that is likely to force Mayor Andrés Manuel López Obrador off the ballot in the election for president next year, the mayor's political enemies were counting on public apathy, while his supporters were hoping that he will become a cause célèbre, especially if imprisoned.

headline: Airbus Says Its New Flagship Jet Will Be Delayed
abstract: Airbus, in the middle of an escalating trans-Atlantic trade battle with Boeing, ran into trouble on two other fronts on Wednesday, pushing back the delivery of its flagship A380 superjumbo jet and delaying the expected announcement of a new chief executive.    Airbus confirmed that it would push back delivery of the A380 to its first set of customers by as much as six months. The delay, which Airbus said was a result of industrial and design modifications to the plane, could force it to pay steep penalties to those airlines.

headline: China tries to block Japan at UN
World Briefing | Europe: Child Pornography Raid In 8 Countries
abstract: The police in eight European countries detained dozens of people in raids this week in connection with a child pornography ring on the Internet. The total number was not available, but officials in France said that about 20 people had been arrested there, with 10 more placed under investigation. Besides France, hundreds of officers took part in raids in Denmark, Italy, Malta, Norway, Poland, Sweden and the Netherlands, seizing thousands of pornographic pictures and hundreds of videos.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: If the Old Merger Was a Disaster, Why Not Try Another One?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on internal problems at Morgan Stanley that dates to 1997 when Morgan Stanley ageed to merge with Dean Witter; says Morgan Stanley has not been hired bhy any of parties in MCI merger contest with Qwest and Verizon and may miss out on bonanza, but that may be just as well because Morgan Stanley bankers have other battles to wage; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Slip
abstract: Machinery orders in Japan fell for the first month in three in April as high oil prices prompted manufacturers to rein in investment. Private machinery orders, excluding shipping and utilities, fell a seasonally adjusted 1 percent, to 1.02 trillion yen ($9.3 billion) from the previous month, after climbing 1.9 percent in March, the Cabinet Office said. The decline was less than the 2 percent decline expected by economists.

headline: Ulster Vote Seen as a Victory for Hard-Liners on Both Sides
abstract: The moderates who had negotiated the landmark Belfast peace accord were nearly eliminated in the British vote.

headline: Free Flow: Tinkering with model of success
Briefly: Forbes rates Abramovich as richest Russian billionaire
Hoping to Steal Some Talent, Rivals Circle Morgan Stanley
abstract: Market Place column on efforts of investment banking rivals to lure away Morgan Stanley's top managing directors in wake of abrupt departure of top investment bankers Vikram S Pandit and Joseph R Perella; some Morgan bankers reportedly have accepted offers and tentatively plan to resign in coming weeks, while others are weighing offers but may decide to stay at firm; number of departures for rival firms seen key test of chief executive Philip J Purcell's ability to unite firm; only one of 10 bankers who have left so far has decamped to rival (M)

headline: OECD warns of wider global economic gaps
Reflections of Those, and on Those, Who Met Him
abstract: Pope John Paul II's humility is mentioned over and over by friends and acquaintances in loving television tributes to him; but his death has not always brought out humility in others; reporters, commentators and clergymen alike can be heard telling personal anecdotes about pope that, mostly, reflect favorably on themselves (TV Watch column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israel Arrests Palestinians In Bomb Plot
abstract: Israeli security sources said that a number of Palestinian adults and eight teenagers from refugee camps in the Nablus area in the West Bank were arrested in the final stages of planning a suicide attack in Israel. The security sources said they belonged to a cell affiliated with Fatah militants. Some acted as recruiters while others, including youths ages 15 and 16, were prepared to carry out the attack, the sources said. They did not give the number arrested or say when the arrests took place.   Christine Hauser (NYT)

headline: Iranian Parliament backs nuclear step
Next Pope Faces Concerns Over Poverty, Islam and Technology
abstract: Cardinals who will choose next pope will discuss not only who should lead, but what church's priorities are; choice may be imbodied in whom they select; if they choose candidate from Africa or Latin America, it may signal their primary concern is with church in Southern Hemisphere; candidate chosen from Europe could speak convincingly to West about its growing religious indifference; church under Pope John Paul II focused its major interfaith and ecumenical initiatives on mending relations with Jews and Orthodox Christianity; crucial and delicate challenge for next pope is relations with Islam at time when militant Islam is on rise; another challenge facing global church is how much autonomy priests and bishops should be given to adapt church teaching and liturgy to their own cultures; photos (M)

headline: Still Going Fast in Aviation
abstract: Since retiring as chairman and chief executive of Northrop Grumman in 2003, Kent Kresa has been a man on the go. Sometimes he is on the Los Angeles freeways, driving to work in loaner Corvettes and other glamour cars, courtesy of General Motors, where he is a director.    He is also on the boards of Avery Dennison, Eclipse Aviation, Fluor, MannKind and the Trust Company of the West. But the office where he can be found most often -- several days a month, anyway -- is at the regional headquarters of the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, in West Hollywood, Calif. Carlyle, which has sizable investments in aerospace, retains Mr. Kresa as a senior adviser.

headline: The Rock-and-Roll Saviors
abstract: Twenty years after the "Live Aid" concerts, Bob Geldof and other musicians are once again asking fans to attend a major benefit event. Beginning this Saturday, millions of people in eight cities will be called upon to help Africa. But the plan and its purpose are highly controversial.

headline: Latin Nations Resist Plan for Monitor of Democracy
abstract: The major nations of Latin America have told the United States that they cannot support an American plan to establish a permanent committee of the Organization of American States that would monitor the exercise of democracy in the hemisphere, Latin American diplomats said Sunday.    Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who arrived here on Sunday afternoon to serve as chairwoman of an O.A.S. meeting where the American plan is on the agenda, expressed frustration with their view, saying, ''We have to have a discussion of how the organization can be effective if it does not have a mechanism that can help at times of crisis.''

headline: Havas moves to fill post of chief executive
Blast at School in Japan
abstract: A high school student in southern Japan threw an explosives-filled bottle into a classroom on Friday, injuring about 50 students, the Kyodo News agency reported.

headline: Briefly: Laura Bush, on visit, backs Afghan women
Currencies: Dollar steady; market waiting on Fed chief

headline: If 22 Million Chinese Prevail at U.N., Japan Won't
abstract: China's expected effort to prevent Japan's membership on United Nations Security Council would be most direct confrontation between Asia's leading powers since they re-established diplomatic ties in 1972; organizers and analysts say grassroots Chinese campaign to keep Japan out of Security Council has gathered 22 million signatures; relations between two countries have sharply deteriorated in recent weeks, strained by competition for energy resources, disputes over way history textbooks assess Japan's role in World War II, Japan's pledge to aid United States in defending Taiwan and recent incursion of Chinese submarine into Japnese waters (M)

headline: Shortfall fears keep oil pricesnear record
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Barclays To Buy Stake In Fiat Unit
abstract: Barclays will buy controlling stake in financing arm of Iveco, commercial truck unit of Fiat, for 66.5 million pounds ($125 million) (S)

headline: More Deadly Bombings as Iraqis Debate Last Cabinet Posts
Personal Data for the Taking
abstract: Forty-one graduate students at Johns Hopkins University spend semester working in groups of three or four collecting as much personal data as they can on Internet using only legal, public sources of information, replicating on small scale what big data brokers can do with resources to buy all the databases they want; groups were allowed to spend no more than $50, but several of them manage to gather well over a million records, with hundreds of thousands of individuals represented in each databases; Prof Aviel D Rubin, who conceived project, has used his graduate courses before to expose weaknesses in electronic voting technology and other aspects of society that is increasing dependent on digital technology; is pleasantly surprised that his students turned up fewer Social Security numbers than he expected; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Book Report: Art trumps logic
Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   6.00   6.00   4.00        Federal funds   3.25   3.07   1.09        3-month Libor   3.48   3.47   1.59        3-month T-bills   3.08   3.08   1.35        6-month T-bills   3.22   3.25   1.67        10-yr.
