headline: DRIVEN
abstract: It is hard to tell who is in the driver's seat at the Rite Aid Corporation, at least in a literal sense.

headline: For the Business Traveler, a Laptop That's Easy on the Arms
abstract: Dell introduces Latitude XI, small laptop weighing 2.5 pounds with 12.1-inch screen, intended to appeal to business traveler with need for wireless access; photo (S)

headline: Diller Stake in NBC Unit Is Being Sold
abstract: IAC/InteractiveCorp, controlled by Barry Diller, agrees to sell its 5.4 percent stake in Vivendi Universal Entertainment for about $3.4 billion, allowing Diller to focus on his Internet businesses; Vivendi Universal is part of NBC Universal, which is 80 percent owned by General Electric and 20 percent owned by Vivendi Universal; NBC Universal is putting up about $900 million to buy Diller's stake in entertainment unit; Diller sounds relieved and pleased with deal, conference call with analysts; photo (M

headline: At Sunbeam, Big Guys Won, Public Lost
abstract: Floyd Norris column says public investors who received Sunbeam shares when it acquired Coleman Co, appear to be the only victims of accounting fraud that caused those shares to become worthless; notes that they do not share in $1.45 billion award Ronald O Perelman has won against Morgan Stanley, which advised Sunbeam and underwrote junk bonds and bank loans that financed Coleman acquisition; says Albert J Dunlap, Sunbeam's chief executive when Sunbeam went bankrupt, has also escaped unscathed, neither indicted nor named in Perelman lawsuit; photo (M)

headline: U.S. clears marine in mosque shooting
New French cabinet ousts foreign minister
Ad firm chief may resign
A Big Splash, Ripples to Follow
abstract: Standard & Poor's announcement that it is cutting its credit ratings for General Motors and Ford Motor Co sets off selling spree in corporate bond market; rating cut to below investment grade begins process of adjustment that could ripple through, and roil, fixed-income markets for weeks; some investors--like pension funds that prefer investment-grade bonds or are restricted to only such securities--will sell their GM and Ford bonds to those that invest in high-yield or junk bonds and to other investors, including hedge funds that favor so-called distressed securities; potential redistribution is enormous, with some $292 billion in outstanding GM bonds and $161 billion in Ford bonds; graphs; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Future of Self-Regulation Of Exchanges Is Debated  The New York Stock Exchange's plan to acquire an electronic trading system has called into question the future of the self-regulation system that exchanges use.     At issue is whether self-regulation works in light of recent history, with examples being a price-fixing scandal at Nasdaq and the floor-trading investigations and indictments at the Big Board. Market Place. [Page C2.]    Wireless Helps Verizon Profit  Shares of Verizon Communications jumped more than 3 percent after it reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings because of healthy demand for its wireless and broadband services. Verizon Wireless generated 41 percent of the company's sales. Revenue at Verizon Wireless, which is jointly owned by Verizon and Vodafone, grew 20.4 percent, to $7.4 billion in the quarter. [C7.]    Details on A.I.G. Tax Shelters  Court papers indicate that American International Group helped wealthy individuals make use of questionable tax shelters intended to shield profits from federal taxes. [C6.]    Chiron Expects Enough Flu Vaccine  Chiron said it thought it could produce 25 million to 30 million doses of flu vaccine. Authorities said the expected production from Chiron should be enough to stave off a severe shortage of vaccine this winter. [A17.]    U.S. Accounting Rules Criticized  European regulators have said some companies that use accounting rules developed in the United States, Canada and Japan should be required to provide additional information to investors if they want their securities to continue trading in Europe. [C4.]    Microsoft Chief Is Chided in Europe  Neelie Kroes, left, Europe's top antitrust official, told Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, that the company must comply with Europe's antitrust ruling ''urgently and in full.'' More than a year has passed since the European Commission found Microsoft guilty of abusing its dominant position in the European software market, and the company has yet to comply with two orders to change its business practices. [C7.]    2nd Bid Expected for Allied Domecq  Constellation Brands, Brown-Forman and two private equity firms, the Blackstone Group and Lion Capital, are considering making a joint bid for Allied Domecq. Pernod Ricard has offered $14.1 billion for the liquor maker. [C4.]    A Bigger Quarterly Loss at Sony  Sony's loss widened in the latest quarter, and the company said profit for the year would decline as pricing pressures continue. [C4.]    Apple Supported in Online Dispute  Apple Computer gained the support of Intel and Genentech in its effort to make online publishers disclose their sources of confidential information about new Apple products. [C17.]    Stocks Gain as Oil Prices Decline  The Dow Jones industrials gained 47.67 points, to 10,198.80. The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 4.64 points, to 1,156.38. The Nasdaq composite increased 2.99 points, to 1,930.43. [C11.]    Combating Gadget Theft  As gadgets shrink in size and grow in popularity, theft has grown, too. A look at how to deter theft of laptops, phones and other portable devices and how to recover them. Circuits. [C9.]    Economists Rediscover Bubbles  Experts try to explain why bubbles occur. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. [C2.]

headline: Oil Is Down, Sales Are Up, but Shares Still Fall Back
abstract: The stock and bond markets moved against expectations yesterday while the dollar did just what one would think it would do.    At a time when investors have been worried about slowing economic growth, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales jumped 1.4 percent in April, twice the Wall Street forecast. It was a disappointing 0.3 percent gain in retail sales in March that helped heighten the fears of slower growth, so it looked like a big rebound would help. But it did not.

headline: Blair warns that EU will fail if it does not modernize
F.D.A. Approves a Heart Drug for African-Americans
abstract: Food and Drug Administration takes controversial sep toward new frontier of personalized medicine, approving first drug ever intended for one racial group, African-Americans; drug, heart failure therapy called DiDil, makes it easier for heart to pump by relaxing blood vessels; study of 1,050 African-American heart failure patients showed that BiDil reduced deaths by 43 percent; drug's maker NitroMed says it will begin marketing product almost immediately; tablets are being manufactured for NitroMed by Schwarz Pharma Manufacturing; DiDil was discovery of Dr Jay N Cohn, University of Minnesota cardiologist (M)

headline: On Eve of Talks, North Korea Thought to Test Missile
Trump Hotel Bankruptcy Plan Accepted
abstract: US Bankruptcy Judge Judi

headline: Drug Violence Paralyzes a City, and Chills the Border
abstract: There was nothing secretive about the death threats against Guadalupe García, a crime reporter here in this busy border city. Her stalkers broadcast their intentions over the police radio.    ''You are next, Lupita,'' a growling voice would blurt into the emergency communications system. ''We are coming for you.''

headline: Prince Rainier of Monaco Dies at 81
World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Fuel Supplier In Court Fight
abstract: China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corp, jet fuel supplier that collapsed in 2004 after losing $550 million trading oil-related derivatives, files affidavit opposing motion by Energy Asia, creditor, to oust its management; Energy Asia wants China Aviation placed under court-appointed manager; China Aviation's parent, China Aviation Oil Holding, has threatened to withdraw financial support for company's restructuring if lawsuits proceed against company (S)

headline: From Adman to Builder
abstract: Having spent his advertising career burnishing the brands of others, John J. Kinsella is now building a brand name for himself.    A former chairman, president and chief executive of the Leo Burnett Company, Mr. Kinsella, 76, now owns Kinsella Development Inc., a Chicago company that builds single-family houses that sell for $500,000 to $1 million.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bill Blocks Election Of Independents
abstract: Lower house of Russia's parliment adopts legislation to end direct elections for half its members and tighten election rules for smaller parties to enter the body; Pres Vladimir V Putin proposed changes after wave of terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Strikes urged in France over plan to abolish holiday
Taking 1950's Miami Beach Chic to the Desert
abstract: By design and by legendary reputation, the Fontainebleau hotel in Miami Beach is truly one of a kind. The Fontainebleau, South Florida's largest hotel, opened in 1954 with its Morris Lapidus-conceived curves that accented the resort's shoreline as surely as a sheer dress clinging to a fashion model.    Hollywood came calling in the 1950's and 1960's, when Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr. and Dean Martin played, on stage and off. Those were the heady days when Jackie Gleason based his hit TV variety show there. And Sean Connery as 007 roamed the pool deck in ''Goldfinger.''

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indian Kashmiri Separatists Agree To Visit Pakistan
abstract: A separatist faction from the Indian side of Kashmir said it would accept an invitation by President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan to visit the Pakistani side next month. Mir Waiz Umar Farooq, viewed as a moderate leader of the separatist alliance All Parties Hurriyat Conference, said the delegation would apply for travel documents with the Indian authorities and travel on the new bus line that connects the two Kashmirs. A faction of hard-liners who have been critical of the bus and other measures to ease the long-running dispute between Indian and Pakistan have yet to decide whether to accept the invitation. Nor has India said whether it will allow the separatists to travel.   Hari Kumar (NYT)

headline: DataBank; Worries Galore Keep Investors on the Sidelines
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite index decline for week, but S&P 500-stock index manages slight gain; charts, tables and graphs (M)

headline: Marketing Research Back in Style
abstract: Advertising research is suddenly back in vogue as clients increasingly hold agencies accountable for effective ads; research industry is intensifying its efforts and looking at issues like trying to determine return on investment for advertising spending, improving measurement of audiences, helping agencies identify most efficient media outlets and increasing role research plays in reaching consumers; these topics are being discussed at American Research Foundation conference, New York City (M)

headline: A Vision in Print
abstract: Richard Robinson, chairman, president and chief executive of Scholastic Corp, writes The Boss column on his career; photo (M)

headline: Speaking fees paid to Blair's wife ignite a war of words
The Smoking Broccoli, and Other Travelers' Tales
abstract: I was staying three nights at the Hilton Garden Inn on the southern border of Los Angeles International Airport. It's one of those good midlevel business hotels with rooms that have kitchenettes equipped with microwave ovens. Around 6 p.m., too tired to find a restaurant, I drove up the road to a Ralphs supermarket and purchased the following standard provisions for a business traveler with a kitchenette:    One 8.5-ounce box frozen Healthy Choice Chicken Fettuccini Alfredo. One 16-ounce plastic container Sweet Dreams Premium California Strawberries. One 10-ounce box Ralphs Frozen Fresh Broccoli Spears. One six-pack ice cold beer.

headline: Briefly: Waterford to cut 1,800 jobs
Roy Disney Outlines His Plans for Board
abstract: Roy E. Disney will nominate an alternative slate of directors for the Walt Disney Company if his lawsuit to vacate the company's recent election is successful, his lawyer told a judge considering the suit Wednesday.    In the suit, Mr. Disney and his financial adviser, Stanley P. Gold, accuse the Disney company of holding a sham search for a successor to the chief executive, Michael D. Eisner.

headline: U.S. Says Drug Seems Effective Against Heart Failure in Blacks
abstract: The drug BiDil by NitroMed seems effective in treating black people with heart failure, federal regulators said yesterday, moving closer to the first drug approval in the United States based on race.     The Food and Drug Administration posted its staff's review of NitroMed's application on its Web site yesterday. NitroMed will seek backing for BiDil today from a committee of F.D.A. advisers meeting in Gaithersburg, Md. A study found that black people taking the drug with other heart failure medicines were less likely to die than those given a placebo.

headline: Oil-for-Food Scandal Broadens With New Charges
Euro pays heavy price for political bickering
A Fast Track to Sainthood? Polish Pilgrims Insist on It
abstract: Many of hundreds of thousands of Poles who converged on Rome had one more item left on their agenda after Pope John Paul II's funeral; they want to see John Paul II beatified--immediately (M)

headline: Brazilian Growth Slows, Restrained by 19% Interest Rates
abstract: Brazil's economy grew at its slowest pace in more than a year last quarter, as soaring interest rates began to discourage consumer spending and capital investment.    The government said Tuesday that the economy expanded 2.9 percent from January through March compared with the quarter a year earlier -- well below most forecasts for about 3.5 percent growth. Compared with the last quarter of 2004, Brazil's economy, South America's largest, grew just 0.3 percent, its weakest performance since the second quarter of 2003.

headline: He's Learning To Love Risk
abstract: What do you do after you've run a small regulatory agency and prevailed over the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac? If you are Armando Falcon Jr., former director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, you consult.    Mr. Falcon, who stepped down in May and turned 45 this month, is the newest partner at the Canonbury Group, a firm in London that advises investors and governments about risks. His focus will be housing policy and capital markets.

headline: Israeli Security Forces Evict Jewish Protesters in Gaza
abstract: The scene was part of a confrontational campaign against the planned evacuation of Jewish settlers from the coastal territory.

headline: Filipino workerscall for Arroyo's removal
Again, Tooting Horns on Madison Ave.
abstract: MOST people already hear plenty from the advertising industry, which chases consumers in places ranging from cellphone screens to bathroom stalls -- all on behalf of its clients.    But the organizers of last fall's Advertising Week in New York, an industry promotion that included parades and networking events, say the business still does not do enough to promote itself. They are forging ahead with a second annual Advertising Week, planned for Sept. 26 through Sept. 30 of this year.

headline: Currencies: Fed chief's outlook on rates hits dollar
Beijing's new celebrity: Siren of the morning rush hour
Play 'Stairway to Heaven' Longer
abstract: A TUB brimming with synthetic human sweat sounds like something a third-grader would dream up to win a gross-out contest. Yet such fetid containers do exist, at the laboratory of Elixir Strings in Elkton, Md.     In testing the company's new Anti-Rust Plated Plain Steel Strings for electric guitars, Elixir's engineers submerged prototypes in vats of the liquid: a solution of urea, acetic acid, salt and other corrosive chemicals.

headline: Stocks: Wall Street wallows in lower territory
Israel Launches Air Strike Against Palestinian Cell in Gaza
abstract: The air force fired today on a Palestinian cell launching mortars at Jewish settlements in the southern Gaza Strip.

headline: A Political Dispute Puts a City in the Dark
abstract: American energy giant AES Corp was dragged into middle of ugly political fight when its Brazilian unit Eletropaulo cut lights at 85 buildings owned by city government of Sao Paulo; Electropaulo claims city owes it 636 millino reais (about $246.1 million) in unpaid bills; Eletropaulo's decision to cut off power to city came three months after new mayor took office, setting off public outcry from city officials who argued that move was politically motivated; at heart of dispute is political tug of war between city's new mayor, Jose Serra, of Social Democratic Party, and his predecessor, Marta Suplicy, member of Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's Workers' Party; Serra, who ran for president in 2002 and lost to da Silva, says he inherited city on verge of bankruptcy with about 8 billion reais (about $3 billion) in short-term debt to array of utilities; he has also accused Suplicy's administration of violating federal fiscal responsibility law by not leaving enough money in city's coffers to cover upcoming debt payments, something Suplicy has angrily denied; photo (M)

headline: French mount big push for the EU constitution
Skirmish at holy site reminds of tensions
Siebel Board Ousts Chief as Market Share Declines
abstract: Siebel Systems board ousts J Michael Lawrie and names board member George T Shaheen to succeed him as director; announcement comes shortly after Lawrie announces that company's first-quarter results could be its worst in five years; photo (M)

headline: Let the beatification begin, and promptly, Poles urge
Big Payment From G.M. Helps Fiat Post Its First Profitable Quarter in 3 Years
abstract: Fiat posts profit of 295 million euros in first quarter after receiving 715 million euros from General Motors to dissolve their partnership; had loss of 390 million euros a year earlier; GM will pay Fiat another 550 million euros in May; photo (S)

headline: To French workers, minutes add up
Consumers More Optimistic This Month
abstract: Consumers became more optimistic this month as the job market improved and gasoline prices receded from record levels, a private report showed yesterday.     The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for June rose to a five-month high of 94.8 from 86.9 a month earlier.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Ex-Premier Arrested
abstract: Former Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba was arrested after failing to appear before a royal anticorruption commission. He was appointed prime minister by King Gyanendra last year and dismissed by him on Feb. 1, on the ground that he had failed to combat a Maoist insurgency. Established by the king, the commission sought to question Mr. Deuba about the distribution of public funds. He refused to answer the summons.   Somini Sengupta (NYT)

headline: Charter for the European Union Meets Resistance
abstract: For a quarter of a century, it has been pretty much assumed in the half-dozen founding countries of the now 25-member European Union that popular support for an ever bigger and more unified Europe would be virtually automatic.     Not anymore. At least not if large segments of public opinion in the founding states of France and the Netherlands matter.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deadline for Beverage Offer
abstract: A consortium led by Constellation Brands, the world's largest wine producer, has until June 29 to make a bid for the beverage company Allied Domecq, British regulators said. Allied Domecq agreed to be bought for about $14 billion by Pernod Ricard of France in April. Constellation, working with Brown-Forman, the maker of Jack Daniels bourbon, and two private equity firms, said it might make a higher offer. If the Constellation group does not make a formal bid by deadline, the consortium must wait six months before trying again.   Heather Timmons (NYT)

headline: A Bad Year for the Chief (but Not for the Bonus)
abstract: Return of big bonuses for chief executives is underscored by fact that three executives who stumbled badly this year, Carleton S Fiorina at Hewlett Packard, Raymond V Gilmartin at Merck and Michael D Eisner at Walt Disney Co, were still awarded hefty bonuses: $1.57 million, $1.38 million and $7.25 million, respectively; median bonus of chief executives was worth over $1.9 million in 2004, up 38 percent from previous year; trend reflects various factors, including tax changes; Eisner photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Alcan Doubles Profit
abstract: Alcan, the aluminum producer, said it more than doubled its first-quarter profit from the comparable period a year ago, citing strong demand for aluminum from China. The company, based in Montreal, said it earned $218 million, up from $106 million. Sales fell to $5.17 billion, from $6 billion, largely because Alcan spun off its rolled aluminum products business. Adding to its earnings were operating cost savings from the closing of several European plants formerly owned by Pechiney of France, which Alcan acquired last year.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: Briefly: No hasty action on textiles
Parmalat Founder Indicted
abstract: Calisto Tanzi, the founder of Parmalat, the Italian dairy giant, and 16 others were indicted Saturday by a judge in Milan on charges including market manipulation for their role in causing Italy's biggest bankruptcy.     Mr. Tanzi faces a maximum of 15 years in prison if convicted on all the charges. Judge Cesare Tacconi handed down the indictment one month after Milan prosecutors rejected a plea bargain agreement with Mr. Tanzi. The trial will start Sept. 28.

headline: Europeans Clash With Blair Over Union's Future
abstract: The president of the European Commission, JosÃ© Manuel Barroso, put himself on collision course with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain today.

headline: China Moves to Crack Down on Protests Against Japan
abstract: China, in orchestrated effort to clamp down on rising nationalist anger, announces that it will tolerate no more anti-Japanese protests and urges its citizens not to boycott Japanese products (M)

headline: Spanish cardinal fills empty seat
World Court to Investigate Darfur Violence
abstract: Prosecutors for the International Criminal Court announced Monday that they had begun an investigation into war crimes in Sudan, opening the door for indictments and warrants for those considered most responsible for the ethnic violence and starvation that has exterminated hundreds of villages in Darfur.     But the Sudanese government, blamed by a United Nations inquiry for much of the violence, has said it will not accept the court's jurisdiction. It has already begun to try to delay legal action by using some of the safeguards built into the court's rules, like insisting that it is conducting its own investigations and will hold its own trials.

headline: Finally, Sisyphus, There's Help for Those Internet Forms
abstract: EVERYONE who has used the Internet has had a version of this frustrating experience:    A week ago I was at the Minneapolis airport, with three hours to wait for a delayed flight. That's not the frustrating part. I wanted to connect my laptop to the airport's Wi-Fi Internet system, which meant filling out many spaces in an on-screen registration form. Name, home address, phone and e-mail contact, credit card details and so on -- plus my requested user name for the network.

headline: China Said to Step Up Religious Persecution of Minority in Its West
abstract: Human Rights Watch and Human Rights in China say China has stepped up campaign of religious persecution against its minority Ulghur population in western region of Xinjiang even though government has already eliminated any organized resistance to Beijing's rule there; cite range of new policies that tighten controls on religious worship, assembly and artistic expression among eight million Turkic-speaking Muslims, including strict rules on teaching religion to minors (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Mitsui Names President
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group appoints deputy president Teisuke Kitayama as president, succeeding Yoshifumi Nishikawa; also appoints Masayuki Oku president of group's core banking unit; photo (S)

headline: Guidant Agrees to Pay for Defibrillator Replacements
abstract: In a policy reversal, the Guidant Corporation has begun telling doctors that the company will cover the cost of a new defibrillator if the physician and the patient decide that a replacement is needed for a model that has failed in at least 26 cases, including one recent death.    Guidant officials found themselves in a medical and public relations controversy after it was disclosed that they did not tell doctors for more than three years that the device could short-circuit when needed. A defibrillator, which is implanted under the skin, emits an electrical shock to jolt a chaotically beating heart back into a normal rhythm.

headline: Disappearances investigated in Asia
Bad Business For Magazines About Business
abstract: WHEN the Meredith Corporation announced its purchase of Gruner & Jahr's women's magazines last Tuesday, Meredith said that Gruner's business magazines, Fast Company and Inc., were not ''material'' to the sale. What that means is that two magazines that sold for more than half a billion dollars four years ago now have a value of zero.    As it flees toward its exit from a billion-dollar experiment gone horribly wrong, Gruner & Jahr, a division of the German media giant Bertelsmann, may salvage a few dollars, if not its dignity, by selling Inc. But Fast Company, always more of an idea than an actual magazine, is probably gone for good.

headline: At Tyco Trial: Same Stage, New Scenes, Hazy Ending
abstract: Fraud trial of L Dennis Kozlowski, former chief executive of Tyco International, and his lieutenant, Mark H Swartz, departs in significant ways from original trial, which ended in mistrial, even though principals, courtroom and facts in case are unchanged; prosecution puts on decidedly stronger case by focusing on charges of grand larceny and throwing out much of entertaining testimony about Kozlowski's conspicuous consumption; defense has also tightened its case and made some points stronger, and Kozlowski's own testimony has injected huge new factor into case; photo (M)

headline: And Now, the News in Latin America's View
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela is promoting and largely financing Latin America Telesur, regionwide television station that he says is aimed at counteracting 'media dictatorship' of international news networks; venture also involves Argentina, Cuba, Brazil and Uruguay; station is scheduled to begin broadcasting in July; critics say Chavez's intention is to stifle dissent rather than broaden coverage with propaganda machine financed by ideologically driven government flush with oil money; photo (M)

headline: 2 Top Lawyers for Hollywood Stars Join Forces
abstract: Two of the best-known litigators in Hollywood are joining forces, as Howard L. Weitzman -- whose clients have included Michael Jackson, O.J. Simpson, Madonna and Courtney Love -- is leaving the Proskauer Rose law firm in New York to join the Los Angeles firm of Bertram H. Fields.    Like Mr. Fields, Mr. Weitzman has represented scores of celebrities in civil and criminal cases for decades. Mr. Fields -- a partner at Greenberg Glusker Fields Claman Machtinger & Kinsella -- brought Mr. Weitzman onto Mr. Jackson's legal team in 1993, after he was first accused of child molestation. When Mr. Fields quit the case, Mr. Weitzman, along with the late Johnnie Cochran, negotiated the settlement of a civil suit by a 14-year-old boy, whose mother and lawyer were witnesses in Mr. Jackson's current trial.

headline: U.N. Forces Using Tougher Tactics to Secure Peace
abstract: United Nations peacekeeping forces are mounting most aggressive operations in their history in Congo and elsewhere in attempt to overcome past peacekeeping failures; in Congo, peacekeepers in armored personnel carriers return fire of enemy sniper attacks, use attack helicopters to swoop down over trees in search of tribal fighters, and surround villages in militia strongholds, searching hut by hut for guns; peace missions in several other countries--each with their own rules of engagement--have also moved well beyond traditional notion of peacekeeping; Security Council adopted notion of 'robust peacekeeping' after rebels in Sierra Leone killed some peacekeepers and took hundreds more hostage in 2000; UN review of situation called for show of 'credible force' by peacekeepers in future missions; current UN peacekeepers' mission in Congo detailed; photos; map (M)

headline: A Blog for Baseball Fans Builds a League of Sites
abstract: Markos Moulitsas Zuniga, founder of left-leaning political blog Daily Kos, has branched out into series of sports Web sites through his SportsBlogs; notes blogs are effective for partisan audiences like sports fans; Athletics Nation, blog dedicated to Oakland Athetics and moderated by Tyler Bleszinski, is his flagship site; SportsBlogs now owns 17 baseball sites and splits ad revenue with writers; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Yellow Pages Deal
abstract: Yell Group, British yellow pages publisher, plans to buy TransWestern Publishing, which owns 18 yellow pages directories in Houston area, from Thomas H Lee Partners, CIVC Partners and Providence Equity Partners for $1.58 billion (S)

headline: Raytheon Offers $12 Million to Settle an S.E.C. Inquiry
abstract: Raytheon Co offers to pay $12 million to settle investigation into its accounting practices by Securities and Exchange Commission, and says it has reached agreement to pay $39 million to settle class-action lawsuit brought by shareholders over sales of assets in 2000; settlement would resolve inquiry into practices at Raytheon's commuter aircraft division from 1997-2001 (M)

headline: Far right is courted by Sarkozy
Bolivian President Offers to Resign
abstract: With Bolivia paralyzed by protests, President Carlos Mesa announced his resignation on Monday night in a nationally televised address. Explaining that road blockades and marches had made Bolivia ungovernable, he said, ''My responsibility is to say this is as far as I can go.''    ''For that reason, it is my decision to present my resignation as president of the republic,'' he said in the speech, which was carried live by CNN en Español.

headline: Iran and Europeans Jockey for Meeting on Nuclear Issue on Wednesday
abstract: Iranian and European negotiators hold preliminary talks to try to salvage nuclear agreement following Iran's threats to resume activities banned under 2004 agreement (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Coal Producer Offering Is Priced at Low End
abstract: China Shenhua Energy, China's biggest coal producer, sold $2.95 billion of stock, less than it sought, after concerns that coal prices would end a three-year rally. Shenhua sold 3.063 billion shares at 7.50 Hong Kong dollars (96 cents) each in the world's largest initial public offering this year, the sale's arrangers said. The company, which is based in Beijing, marketed the stock at 7.25 to 9.25 Hong Kong dollars. Record coal prices and electricity shortages in big cities prompted China to curb lending to industrial projects last year and shift investment to mining and transportation.

headline: 2nd Chip Maker Admits Guilt in a Price-Fixing Conspiracy
abstract: Federal prosecutors announce second big maker of computer memory chips, Hynix Semiconductor of South Korea, has agreed to plead guilty to participating in global conspiracy to fix prices and will pay $185 million fine, largest criminal penalty assessed during Bush administration; photo (M)

headline: Rights Group Cites Rumsfeld and Tenet in Report on Abuse
abstract: A human rights group issued a report on Saturday calling for a special prosecutor to examine the conduct of Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and the former director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, in issues related to the abuse of detainees.    Drawing largely on news reports and publicly available military reviews, the group, Human Rights Watch, concluded that there was ''overwhelming evidence that U.S. mistreatment and torture of Muslim prisoners took place not merely at Abu Ghraib, but at facilities throughout Afghanistan and Iraq as well as at Guantánamo and at 'secret locations' around the world in violation of the Geneva Convention and the laws against torture.''

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: U.S. Warns Of Hotel Attacks
abstract: The American Embassy warned that extremists were planning to bomb the lobbies of Jakarta hotels frequented by Westerners. In a posting on its Web site, the embassy said the bombings would occur at noon on an unspecified date. It provided no further details. The Australian government said it was forwarding the warning to its citizens in Indonesia.   Evelyn Rusli (NYT)

headline: Your Internet Search Results, in the Round
abstract: Groxis, pioneer in displying textual data in visual maps, will begin letting computer users who access Yahoo search engine through its Web site view search results as series of categories set in circular map; will rely on revenue from advertisements placed by Yahoo ad placement service instead of from software sales; analysts say company faces uphill challenge in persuading people to use its maps; photo (M)

headline: Rome lashes out at Prodi
Old Lions of Banking, Out on Their Own
abstract: Boutique investment banks run by men who achieved fame more than 20 years ago are latest trend on Wall Street; Robert F Greenhill, 68, is basking in glow of stock market success of his firm, Greenhill & Co, whose shares have doubled since its public offering last year; Eric J Gleacher's firm, Gleacher Partners, has also been on roll, advising series of deals involving sectors as diverse as military industry and talent agencies; Joseph R Perella, mergers and acquisitions banker who was at center of some of largest deals of 1980's, seems likely to join exclusive club after his resignation from Morgan Stanley; chief executives and boards are placing new value on independent advice from boutique investment banks that are free from conflicts and competing pressures at time when larger investment banks have been ensnarled in corporate scandals; chart; photo (M)

headline: Pope's Funeral Is Set for Friday
Afghan Trips Over Rules He Upheld to U.S. Senate
abstract: Rahim Bariek, Virginia financier from Afghanistan, is charged with operating illegal money-transmittal business; federal prosecutors say he used his business to send nearly $5 million to Iran, Pakistan and parts of Afghanistan that were under control of Taliban in 2001 and 2002; Bariek appeared as witness before Senate panel after Sept attacks and spoke of how important it was for business people like himself, who operate an informal money-exchange system known as hawala, to follow the law (M)

headline: A Front-Runner at Microsoft, but There's No Race Yet
abstract: Microsoft's senior vice president Eric Rudder is seen as possible heir to co-founder Bill Gates and chief executive Steven A Ballmer; both Gates and Ballmer are only 49, and neither has suggested that he wants to step aside soon; Rudder has led Microsoft's fast-growing business for server products for two years; Gates and Ballmer, by putting Rudder in charge of business earmarked for near-term growth, have singled him out as likely front-runner among next generation of leaders; graphs; photos (M)

headline: G-8? GEE WHIZ!
abstract: Setting aside decades of practice as a diplomat, Richard C. Holbrooke, former ambassador to the United Nations, had some pointed advice for President Bush last week at the Asia Society's annual dinner in New York: Update the Group of 8.     Mr. Holbrooke, chairman of the Asia Society and vice chairman of Perseus, a private equity firm, called next month's G-8 summit in Scotland a ''complete anachronism'' because it would not include two of the most dynamic economies on earth.

headline: Stocks: Confused outlook puts investors on sidelines
At PartyGaming, Everything's Wild
abstract: AS a rule, companies don't often draw attention to business practices that could land their executives in jail. But for PartyGaming PLC, potential illegalities aren't just a secret hidden in its business plan -- they are the centerpiece of its business plan.     A giant in the online gambling business, PartyGaming is an often-overlooked megasurvivor from the dot-com crash of the late 1990's. As hundreds of profitless commercial sites disappeared into the digital ether, PartyGaming's popular gambling sites -- like PartyPoker.com -- soared, with revenues and profits growing exponentially year after year.

headline: Brand Content Named Lead Agency for Monster
abstract: Monster, the job search Web site operated by Monster Worldwide in Maynard, Mass., said yesterday that it had named Brand Content in Boston as the lead creative agency for its United States account. Spending was estimated at $40 million.    Brand Content assumes duties that were handled by Deutsch in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which continues to handle media planning and buying for Monster.

headline: Bin Laden Bribed Afghan Militias for His Freedom, German Says
abstract: Head of German intelligence agency August Hanning says Osama bin Laden evaded capture after American invasion of Afghanistan by paying bribes to Afghan militias who were ostensibly working with invasion coalition to find him; other officials have acknowledged that Afghan militias allowed leaders of Al Qaeda and Taliban to escape, but Hanning is top intelligence official to say bin Laden was among them (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rising Bond Rates and Falling Mortgage Rates Make a Puzzle for Economists and Policy Makers  The Federal Reserve has been conducting a relentless campaign to raise interest rates for the last year, but the rates that matter the most to many people -- mortgage rates -- have fallen to near 30-year lows, a conundrum that benefits Americans across the economic spectrum but vexes economists and policy makers. [Page A1.]    Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a congressional panel that the economy is on a ''reasonably firm footing'' but expressed concern about the ''negligible'' rate of personal savings, the huge trade deficit and growing evidence of risky speculation in the housing market. [C1.]    A Medicine's Withdrawal Shows Drug Agency's Problems  The saga of Propulsid, a heartburn medicine pulled from the market in 2000, illustrates the difficulty that the Food and Drug Administration has in regulating drugs after they have been approved. [A1.]    Three senators plan to block a vote on the nomination of a candidate to head the Food and Drug Administration because of issues related to the morning-after birth control pill and condoms. [A13.]    Eli Lilly agreed to pay $690 million to settle 8,000 lawsuits filed by people who claimed they developed diabetes and other diseases after taking Zyprexa, a medication for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. [C1.]    Shares in Biogen surged after reports emerged that its Tysabri drug for multiple sclerosis might be brought back to the market. [C3.]    Two senators sent letters to 18 major drug makers asking for information about grants they have given in recent years to state officials and other organizations that may have influenced drug purchases by federal Medicaid and Medicare programs. [C6.]    Boston Scientific said a Dutch court ruled in a patent suit that a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary can be forced to end production of its Cypher stents in the Netherlands and to halt sales of the drug-coated devices there. [C4.]    China Considers a New Standard for Its Currency  China's political leadership is considering breaking the 11-year link between the dollar and China's currency, the yuan, and tying its value instead to a group of currencies. [C4.]    Banker Acquitted in Mutual Funds Trading Case  A former broker with Bank of America, Theodore C. Sihpol III, was acquitted of most of the charges of improper trading in mutual funds in the first major legal defeat for Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. [C1.]    An executive of the General Re Corporation plans to plead guilty today to criminal fraud charges, according to a court document and individuals briefed on an inquiry into insurance abuses. [C1.]    Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $2.7 million for violating rules in connection with initial public offerings. [C14.]    A former chief executive of AremisSoft Corporation, a defunct software company, has agreed to settle fraud charges for $200 million. [C3]    Corporate Troubles in China Parallel Those in the U.S.  Big corporations are having trouble making money, they have big debts, and they have obligations to provide pensions, adding up to trouble for corporate America and, in a remarkable parallel, corporate China. [C1.]    Union Would Accept Only Minor Benefit Cuts at G.M.  A United Auto Workers leader said the union would accept only modest cuts in health benefits in response to General Motors' plea for bigger cuts. [C3.]    Investor Wins Board Seat at French Ad Concern  The investor Vincent Bolloré, left, won a showdown with the management of Havas, the French advertising company. Mr. Bolloré, who owns 20.7 percent of Havas, was elected to the board, along with three other executives representing his investment firm. The Havas board, led by chief executive Alain de Pouzilhac, had urged shareholders to reject Mr. Bolloré's bid for the board. Advertising. [C8.]    Australian Phone Company Hires a Chief Executive  Telstra, the dominant telecommunications provider in Australia, hired Solomon D. Trujillo, who ran US West and later the European cellular operator Orange, to be chief executive. [C4.]    AOL Plans Ad Campaign With Its Competitors  In its attempt to attract users to its free Web sites, AOL will spend millions of dollars to advertise on popular search engines like Google and Yahoo, the very competitors it is trying to lure users away from. [C3.]    Intel Raises Revenue Forecast as Chip Sales Surge  The Intel Corporation raised its second quarter revenue forecast because of strong sales of notebook computers that use its Centrino chip. [C3.]    Pathmark Shareholders Accept a Takeover Bid  Shareholders of Pathmark Stores approved a $150 million offer from the Yucaipa Companies, a private equity firm, to buy a 40 percent stake and warrants to purchase more shares. [C2.]    Stocks Rise After Remarks by Federal Reserve Chairman  Stocks gained in response to a bullish statement on the economy by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26.16, to 10,503.02. The Standard & Poor's 500 index was up 6.26, at 1,200.93. The Nasdaq composite index added 16.73, to 2,076.91. [C8.]

headline: Job huntingin Germany? Set your price.
Fraud-Trial Jury Is Told to Restart for an Alternate
abstract: Judge in fraud trial of former HealthSouth chief executive Richard M Scrushy replaces ill juror with alternate and orders members of jury to destroy their notes and begin mulling case anew; jury had been deliberating for 24 weekdays in case that went to trial in Jan and seems unwilling to end; jurors look weary and impatient as Judge Karon O Bowdre reads her instructions, mostly repeated verbatim from orders she read last month; authorities on cases of accounting fraud against corporate executives say behavior of Scrushy jury now might depend largely on personality of new juror; chart (M)

headline: Senior cleric is murdered in Kandahar
Siemens sees profit take a slide
24 Go on Trial in Madrid for Links with Al Qaeda and 9/11
Airbus Chief Says Order Ensures Jet Will Be Built
abstract: Qatar Airways said Monday that it would buy 60 Airbus A350 long-range jets, a number that Noël Forgeard, chief executive of Airbus, said was enough to ensure that the plane would be built.     Qatar Airways also announced that it would buy 20 Boeing 777 wide-body jets, the first Boeing aircraft to enter Qatar's all-Airbus fleet. The Airbus order is worth $10 billion and Boeing's is $4.5 billion at list prices, though airlines rarely pay full price.

headline: Krakow and Beyond: Prayers, Tributes and Awe: Los Angeles; Learning Forgiveness
abstract: Lucy Ngoc Nguyen, 44, a Catholic from Southern California's large Vietnamese immigrant population, was at work as a manicurist at her brother's business, Nail Affairs, in Santa Monica when she learned of the pope's death. She spent the rest of the workday with tears in her eyes.     ''I loved this pope,'' she said. ''He reached out to the poor and to the youth. He always worried about what the youth wanted.''

headline: Pay-Disclosure Law Advances in Germany
abstract: Germany inches closer to American-style corporate governance with approval by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's cabniet of law that would require public companies to disclose salaries of their most senior executives (M)

headline: Brown prods oil-rich
World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: U.N. Envoy Cautious Of New Initiative
abstract: A United Nations envoy returned from a trip to Greece, Turkey and Cyprus and told the Security Council that there was neither a level of mutual confidence nor a disposition to compromise in the region to justify mounting a new attempt to reunite Cyprus, divided since 1974 between Greek and Turkish Cypriots. A reunification plan collapsed last year when Greek Cypriots voted it down and then took their new place in the European Union in the name of the whole island. Recalling that high-profile failure, the envoy, Kieran Prendergast, said that ''launching an intensive new process prematurely would be inadvisable.''   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Strong rand prompts a strike
Chinese Bank Takes Lead in Privatizing
abstract: Back in the 1980's, it was known as the People's Construction Bank of China, and like other state-owned banks here its role was to help finance the government's big construction and infrastructure projects.    For now, at least in the immediate future, the China Construction Bank has a different role: it is expected to lead the way as the first of China's four big state-owned banks to go ahead with an initial public offering of stock, a move that could help radically transform the nation's banking sector.

headline: Beijing cuts Hong Kong chief's term
Is a Trip to McDonald's Just What the Doctor Ordered?
abstract: Dr Dean Ornish, advocate of low-fat diets, comments on his work as paid consultant to McDonald's Corp; many leading nutrition scientists have started working for large food companies, either as consultants or members of health advisory boards, in recent years as companies face increased Congressional scrutiny and threat of suits over diet-related illnesses; Ornish and others defend their controversial dual roles as efforts to improve American diet from within; photos (M)

headline: A public end for an extraordinary papacy
Spain seizes 13 suspects in bombing
Doubts Rising About a Venture to Import Chinese Cars
abstract: The future of Visionary Vehicles, the upstart company that announced in January it would bring the first Chinese-made automobiles to the United States by 2007, appears to be in some doubt.     Two top executives said in interviews on Monday that they had recently left Visionary, a privately held company based in New York, after only short stays. After just three months on the job, Pierre Gagnon, the president and chief operating officer and the No. 2 executive at Visionary, said Monday that he had resigned that day. But he added that he had had a falling out six weeks ago with the head of Visionary, Malcolm Bricklin.

headline: A blog flogs its own 'best of' CD
Dutch Voters Solidly Reject New European Constitution
abstract: Dutch voters overwhelmingly rejected a new constitution for Europe on Wednesday, following France in undermining the region's ambitions to play a stronger role on the world scene. The French repudiated the treaty on Sunday, setting off a crisis in the 25-member European Union.    According to unofficial results, 61.6 percent voted against the constitution and 38.4 percent in favor of it -- a larger margin than in France, where 55 percent voted no.

headline: N. Koreais said to test missile
Tradition of dowries changes
Accounts
abstract: Ad account changes are announced by Zale Jewelers, Frito-Lay, Delta Faucet Co and Tishman Speyer Properties (S)

headline: Israeli Newscaster's Documentary Courts Controversy
abstract: A new documentary by Haim Yavin, who has been the calm, objective face of Israeli news for 40 years, is a pessimistic look at West Bank settlements.

headline: Spotlight: In Ireland, a hands-on approach pays off
Pipeline Done, Oil From Azerbaijan Begins Flowing to Turkey
abstract: A long-awaited $3.6 billion pipeline linking the Caspian Sea to the Mediterranean took its first flow of crude oil from Azerbaijan on Wednesday, opening a conduit that may help reduce Western dependence on Middle Eastern oil.    Heads of state from the neighboring countries of Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkey were on hand for the inauguration ceremony not far from Baku, the Azerbaijan capital. The United States energy secretary, Samuel W. Bodman, and Lord Browne, chief executive of the British energy giant BP, which led the pipeline investment consortium were also there.

headline: Morgan in Talks to Bring Back Ex-President
abstract: John J. Mack, the former president of Morgan Stanley who left after a power struggle in 2001, is locked in discussions with the board over his return as chief executive.     But Mr. Mack has told the board that he wants two former executives who left during Philip J. Purcell's management shake-up to return with him, people briefed on the search process said yesterday.

headline: NBC's Fall Roster Leans on Comedy and 'The Apprentice'
abstract: NBC is expected to unveil schedule of new comedies to try to reinvigorate its prime-time lineup in fall, and it will rely even more heavily on its reality franchise The Apprentice; photo (M)

headline: Top Catholics question condom ban
Kiev reveals bone marrow trafficking
Bill to Create Asbestos Disease Fund Goes to Senate for Vote
abstract: Legislation to create a $140 billion fund for victims of asbestos exposure gained considerable momentum on Thursday when it was overwhelmingly approved by a Senate committee after weeks of debate.    The measure would restrict asbestos victims from bringing their claims into court and would limit the liability of makers and insurers but force them to make contributions to the fund. It would set up a schedule of payments, based on the severity of the illness, ranging from $25,000 for breathing impairments to as much as $1.1 million for victims of mesothelioma, a lethal cancer of the lungs. Fees for lawyers would be capped at 5 percent of the final award.

headline: Illegal Rice Found Again in China's Food Supply
abstract: Genetically altered rice, which is not approved for human consumption anywhere in the world, has been found again in China's food supply, this time in one of the country's biggest cities, the environmental group Greenpeace said on Monday.    Researchers for Greenpeace say bags of rice purchased in the southern city of Guangzhou were tested by an independent laboratory and found to contain genetically altered rice, which is illegal to sell on the open market in China.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Auto Sales Rise
abstract: Automobile sales in Brazil rose 30 percent in March from previous month, to about 150,000 vehicles, bouncing back from slow start to year; production also rose 17.5 percent in March from February, to 220,000 vehicles; production is up 12.5 percent so far this year (S)

headline: Iran opposition group is accused of torture
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Knight Trading Group, Jersey City, the trader of Nasdaq-listed shares, agreed to buy Direct Trading Institutional Inc., Irving, Tex., to add software and services for electronic stock and options trading. Terms of the all-cash transaction were not disclosed.    Source Interlink Cos., Bonita Springs, Fla., which provides fulfillment and marketing services, signed a letter of intent to acquire the magazine wholesaler Chas. Levy Circulating Co., Chicago, for about $30 million.    United Parcel Service Inc., Atlanta, the package-delivery company, has tripled the capacity of its Philippines sorting center. The expansion lets the center process 7,500 packages an hour, UPS said in a statement.

headline: Thinking twice about the garbage
DELTA SAYS PENSION COSTS TOTAL $3.6 BILLION THROUGH 2008
abstract: Delta Air Lines expects to contribute total of $3.6 billion to its employee pension plans in 2005 and next three years; Mesa Air Group agrees to operate as many as 30 regional jets for Delta (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Anti-Syrian candidates headed for majority in Lebanon elections
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Surges
abstract: Inflation in Brazil in April was at its fastest pace in nine months, pushed higher by an increase in pharmaceutical prices and a drought in the southern part of the country that drove up food costs. The government's statistics agency said its consumer price index, the central bank's main gauge in setting interest rates, rose 0.87 percent last month after climbing 0.61 percent in March. That lifted the accumulated inflation rate over the last 12 months to 8.07 percent, well ahead of the government's year-end inflation target of 5.1 percent. To curb the price increases, the central bank has raised its benchmark lending rate eight times since September, to 19.5 percent.   Todd Benson (NYT)

headline: Tech Brief: Tape a film and go to jail in U.S.
Newsletters That Are as Classy as the Ritz
abstract: Article on Nota Bene, Andrew Harper's Hideaway Report, Passport Newsletter and other guides to hotels, restaurants and destinations worldwide for discerning travelers; Nota Bene, for example, priced at $450 for 10 issues, is devoted to one destination per issue; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Foreign Automakers Expanding U.S. Plants As Domestic Companies Fight for Market Share  As American automakers have struggled to maintain market share and avoid laying off employees, foreign automakers have been expanding and hiring more workers at their plants in the United States. [Page C1.]    The Ford Motor Company said it would cut about 1,700, or 5 percent, of its white-collar jobs in North America. It also said that it would no longer give bonuses to employees in those positions or make matching contributions to their 401(k) plans. [C5.]    Federal Regulators Investigate Credit Card Processor  Federal banking regulators confirmed that they have started an investigation into CardSystems Solutions, the payment processor that held credit card data that was compromised, putting millions of consumers at risk of credit card fraud. [C1.]    Tape Recording Puts Odd Twist on Grasso Pay Case  The legal battle over the compensation of Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, took a odd twist yesterday, pitting political allies against each other, at least briefly [C1.]    Regulators Warn Medtronic of Device Report Omissions  Federal regulators have warned Medtronic that it has failed to complete legally required steps to deal with reported flaws in one of its best-selling external defibrillators. The device, known as the Lifepak 12, is used by emergency response teams and in hospital emergency rooms to deliver jolts of electricity that can sometimes restore normal heartbeats to people whose hearts have suddenly stopped. [C10.]    A Delaware jury said Boston Scientific's major stent models had infringed patents owned by Johnson & Johnson, its archrival in the multibillion-dollar market for the life-saving devices. [C10.]    Venture Firms Show Interest in Alternative Energy  Venture capital firms are showing interest in the alternative energy sector to capitalize on the growing worldwide demand for energy at a time of rising energy costs. [C1.]    The Senate passed an amendment to pending energy legislation calling for voluntary reductions in some emissions and spending money to promote technology for the effort. [A12.]    AMC Entertainment and Loews Cineplex Agree to Merge  Two privately held movie theater operators, AMC Entertainment and Loews Cineplex Entertainment, will merge creating a company that will have 5,900 movie screens, rivaling the 6,200 screens operated by the industry leader, Regal Cinemas. The terms were undisclosed. [C1.]    Warner Brother Pictures announced that it had entered into a tentative agreement to co-produce 25 movies with Legendary Pictures, a newly formed production company financed by a consortium of Wall Street investors. [C6.]    S.E.C. Ordered to Evaluate a Rule on Board Membership  The Securities and Exchange Commission must produce a cost benefit analysis to justify its June 2004 rule requiring mutual fund boards to have independent chairman and a minimum 75 percent independent directors, a federal court ruled yesterday. [C3.]    Krispy Kreme Says Six Executives Are Leaving  In an attempt to clean house and engineer a turnaround, Krispy Kreme yesterday announced the departure of six executives who held leading positions in the company's operations, finance, business development, and manufacturing and distribution divisions. [C3.]    Winn-Dixie Stores to Cut 22,000 Jobs and Close Stores  Winn-Dixie Stores, the southern supermarket chain said it would cut 22,000 jobs, or 28 percent of its work force, and close 35 percent of its stores as part of its latest plan to reorganize and emerge from bankruptcy protection. Peter Lynch, the chief executive, left, said a smaller, but more profitable store base will best position Winn-Dixie for long-term financial health. [C3.]    The Kroger Company said that its first-quarter profit rose 12 percent, spurred by the biggest gain in comparable store sales at its groceries in nearly five years. [C3.]    Blue Chip Stocks Fall but Nasdaq Issues Post Modest Gain  Crude oil prices near record levels and mixed earnings forecasts weighed on the blue chip stocks but technology stocks rose after a brokerage upgrade lifted semiconductor shares. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.44 points, to 10,599.67. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index dropped 2.49 points, to 1,213.61. The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.94 points, to 2,091.07. [C10.]    EADS Selects Site in Alabama for a New Facility  The European military contractor EADS has selected Mobile, Ala., over sites in three other Southern states as the location for a new engineering and manufacturing facility, people involved in the negotiations said. [C3]

headline: Anti-Syrian Alliance ClaimsVictory in Lebanese Election
abstract: Anti-Syrian alliance claims stunning majority victory in final round of Lebanon's parliamentary elections; bloc led by Saad Hariri wins at least 21 of 28 contested seats in northern Lebanon, last polling area, giving it majority in next 128-seat Parliament; assassination of Hariri's father, former Prime Min Rafik Hariri, touched off demonstrations and rebellion four months ago; election is first to be held in nearly 30 years without presence of Syrian troops; but results do not appear strong enough for anti-Syrian opposition to achieve its goal of ousting Emile Lahoud, Lebanese president handpicked by Syria, whose term was extended by constitutional amendment ordered by Syria last Sept; photo; map (M)

Despite Grimness, Foreign Aides See Hope for Ballot in Haiti
abstract: Despite clear failures by the police and 8,000 United Nations peacekeepers to make the streets here safe from violent gangs, Assistant Secretary of State Roger F. Noriega and special envoys from Canada, France and Brazil expressed confidence during a visit here on Thursday that Haiti's political transition was on course. They said they expected national elections to be held in four months, as planned.     ''We want to send a strong message,'' said Ambassador Daniel Parfait of France. ''We want elections in Haiti. And we want them to happen on time. We know that the elections will not change everything, but without them, nothing will change.''

headline: Spaniards Protest Bill on Gay Marriage
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through downtown Madrid on Saturday evening to protest the recent approval by Parliament of a bill to legalize gay marriage, a measure that critics and supporters say would make Spanish laws on same-sex unions the most liberal in Europe.    The march, which was organized by the Spanish Forum for the Family, a conservative group allied with the Catholic Church, called on Parliament to rescind the bill, which was passed in April and would give homosexual couples the same rights as heterosexual ones, including the right to marry and to adopt children.

headline: Army Faltered in Investigating Detainee Abuse
abstract: Despite autopsy findings of homicide and statements by soldiers that two prisoners died after being struck by guards at an American military detention center in Bagram, Afghanistan, Army investigators initially recommended closing the case without bringing any criminal charges, documents and interviews show.    Within days after the two deaths in December 2002, military coroners determined that both had been caused by ''blunt force trauma'' to the legs. Soon after, soldiers and others at Bagram told the investigators that military guards had repeatedly struck both men in the thighs while they were shackled and that one had also been mistreated by military interrogators.

German approval is expected to give a lift to a French referendum on the charter on May 29.   Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: Drug Makers Prepare to Argue Against a Patent
abstract: US Supreme Court to hear arguments in patent lawsuit arising from cell biologist Dr Erkki Ruoslahti, who will be receiving prestigious Japan Prize and about $230,000 for fundamental discovery he made in 1980's; case pits New Jersey medical device company Integra LifeScience against German drug maker Merck; central question is how much leeway drug companies have in using patented inventions in drug development without illegally infringing on those patents; some big pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies take Merck's side in arguing that considerable leeway should be allowed, if future drug research is going to produce innovative new medicines; similar positions are taken in friend-of-the-court filings by AARP and Ralph Nader group, which are often on opposite side of issues from big drug companies; view is opposed by supporters of Integra, including some universities and smaller biotechnology companies that make scientific tools used in pharmaceutical research; Dr David A Cheresh did reseach on peptides and protein in 1990's at Scripps Research Institute; Ruoslahti patented family of peptides and certain ways to use them in 1980's; when Integra learned of Cheresh's work it asked Merck to pay for license; Integra sued Merck in 1996 for patent infringement after those talks failed; federal jury in 2000 ruled in favor of Integra and ordered Merck to pay $15 million, which has since been reduced to $6.4 million; appeals court upheld decision in 2003; photos (M)

World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Political Turning Point
abstract: Mayor Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico City praised the decision by President Vicente Fox on Wednesday night to conduct a new review into the government's legal actions against him and guarantee that he would be allowed to participate in the race for president next year. Meanwhile, leaders for the two political parties that pushed the unpopular case against the popular mayor began trying to repair the damage to their organizations. Interior Minister Santiago Creel, who hopes to run for president from Mr. Fox's conservative National Action Party, spent most of the day in radio and television interviews saying that the government was ready to put the case aside and get back to work. Roberto Madrazo, another presidential hopeful and the president of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which ran the country for more than seven consecutive decades, said his party looked forward to competing against Mayor López Obrador and his leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution at the polls.   Ginger Thompson (NYT)

Mr. Denton said, ''which is pretty pathetic.''     Don't ask him about his business plan, either. He says he never had one. The only reason he formed the company, he said, was to make his network of blogs -- which includes Gawker, the flagship chronicle of Manhattan news and gossip; Fleshbot, the thinking person's diary of smut; and about 10 other titles -- more attractive to advertisers.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Home Prices Soared to $206,000 in April, An Increase of 15.1% in the Last Year  The median price for a home rose to $206,000 last month, up 15.1 percent over the last year. Prices continued to increase most rapidly in the places where they are the highest, including Florida, the Boston-Washington corridor and the West Coast. [Page A1.]    For Budding Shoppers, the Great Malls of China  China has embraced America's shop-till-you-drop ethos and is in the midst of a mall frenzy. By 2010, China is expected to be home to at least 7 of the world's 10 largest shopping malls. [A1.]    Flaws Noted in Anti-Terrorism Campaign  The Department of Homeland Security's effort to extend its antiterrorism campaign overseas is flawed and may make it easier to smuggle weapons of mass destruction into the United States, Congressional officials say. [A6.]    Berkshire Hathaway Is Buying an Electric Utility  Berkshire Hathaway, which is controlled by Warren E. Buffett, agreed to buy the electric utility PacifiCorp for $5.1 billion. [C1.]    Fitch Cuts General Motors' Rating to Junk  Fitch Ratings cut its rating on General Motors below investment grade, becoming the second of the three major debt ratings agencies to do so. [C3.]    The Fed Says Rates Will Continue to Rise  The Federal Reserve brushed aside evidence of an economic slowdown and made it clear it would keep raising interest rates in the months ahead. [C1.]    Union Leaders Support Visteon Revamping  Shares of Visteon, the cash-strapped auto parts maker, rose earlier this month on hopes that the company could win support from its largest union for an overhaul plan that would allow Visteon to shed a quarter of its work force and nearly all of its plants in the United States. Under the agreement, Visteon's former parent company, Ford Motor, would reabsorb about 17,700 Visteon workers and assume control of 15 plants, most of them in the Midwest. [C11.]    Jurors in Scrushy Trial Cannot Agree  Jurors in the trial of Richard M. Scrushy, the founder of HealthSouth accused of securities fraud and lying to government investigators, signaled they were having difficulty agreeing on a verdict. [C1.]    F.D.A. Meets With Guidant About Defibrillator  Officials of the Food and Drug Administration and Guidant discussed a company defibrillator that has partially failed or been disabled on 26 cases. [C1.]    An Early Front-Runner for Leadership at Microsoft  Eric Rudder, a 38-year-old senior vice president at Microsoft, has led the company's fast-growing business for server products for the last two years and could be a future leader of Microsoft. [C1.]    A Call for Lower Borrowing Costs in Europe  Jean-Philippe Cotis, left, the chief economist of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said the European Central Bank must consider cutting borrowing costs by at least another half-point to stimulate growth. The recommendation came as the O.E.C.D. cut its growth forecast for the economy of the 12-member euro region to 1.2 percent for this year. The notion of trimming rates has been rejected by the European Central Bank, and it comes as differences in performance are widening among Europe, Asia and the United States. [C6.]    Bertelsmann Selling American Magazines  The Gruner & Jahr unit of Bertelsmann agreed to sell Family Circle, Parents, Child and Fitness magazines to Meredith for $350 million. Gruner & Jahr will also try to sell two business titles, Fast Company and Inc. [C10.]    A Bit of Miami Beach Goes to Las Vegas  The Fontainebleau hotel, which has been a fixture of Miami Beach since 1954, is going west to Las Vegas. [C8.]    Overseas, REIT's Are Gaining Favor  With real estate investment trusts cooling in the United States, some investors are shifting their attention to the nascent markets overseas. [C9.]    Dow Slips as Investors Take Some Profits  Investors locked in profits in the market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.88 points, to 10,503.68. The Standard & Poor's 500 increased 0.21 point, to 1,194.07, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 4.97 points, to 2,061.62. [C11.]

abstract: BKF Capital Group, a publicly traded investment firm locked in a battle with hedge funds looking to replace members of its board, announced yesterday that it would remove its poison pill and make it easier to replace its board, among other changes.    The moves were aimed at quelling the proxy fight, which has shaped up as a colorful confrontation between an established money manager and young hedge fund managers.

headline: U.S. and Iraqi Troops Capture a Top Militant Leader in Mosul
abstract: Mohammed Sharkawa, the militant leader who leads Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's operations in northern Iraq, was seized Tuesday afternoon in a home in western Mosul after aerial reconnaissance and a tip from a local resident helped pinpoint his whereabouts, American military officials in Mosul and Baghdad said Thursday.     Mr. Sharkawa, a former Republican Guard member and onetime cigarette smuggler, commanded a force of several hundred insurgents and was directly responsible for at least 50 car bombings and 150 beheadings and assassinations in recent months, the officials said.

headline: Novartis buys drug for lung disease

Auditors: Too Few to Fail
abstract: CAN you believe this KPMG thing? A mere three years after Arthur Andersen -- once the most upright accounting firm in the land -- was indicted for obstructing justice in the Enron scandal, KPMG has come this close to suffering the same fate for peddling illegal tax shelters. The Andersen indictment effectively put the firm out of business (even though the Supreme Court later overturned its conviction), costing thousands of jobs and shrinking the number of major accounting firms to four from five. Without question, the same fate would await KPMG were it to be prosecuted; accounting firms simply cannot withstand an indictment. Can anyone say ''The Big Three?''     If you've been following the KPMG story, you know two things. First, its actions were truly reprehensible. A 2003 investigation by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations leaves no ambiguity: the firm absolutely knew the shelters it was devising would probably not pass muster with the Internal Revenue Service, but sold them anyway. Everything about these products and the way they were marketed was sleazy. The smallest of the Big Four, KPMG used them to bolster revenue -- they are said to have generated $124 million in fees for the firm -- and the executives involved were rising stars. In the Enron debacle, Andersen's fundamental sin was spinelessness; its auditors weren't willing to stand up to a high-paying client determined to bend (and break) accounting rules to post fictitious profits. Though it affected fewer people, KPMG's behavior was more mendacious.

headline: Lost in Translation via E-Mail
abstract: Lost in Translation Via E-Mail    Q. I have been trying to send an e-mail message in Spanish to Mexico but I don't know enough Spanish to type it myself. Are there any free translation programs I can use?    A. A number of Web sites can translate a small amount of text from English to Spanish, including Google's Language Tools page (google.com/language--tools) and the Babelfish translator at babelfish.altavista.com. But these sites may not be the most accurate when you need to take nuance, colloquialisms and regional variations into account.

headline: And Wall St. Was Filled With Settlements and Lamentations
abstract: JUDGMENT DAY arrived this week for several big names in business and finance, including J.P. Morgan Chase and Bristol-Myers Squibb. General Motors, meanwhile, warned its labor unions to expect their own retribution unless they help the company control its labor costs.    FALLOUT FROM ENRON -- J.P. Morgan Chase agreed to pay $2.2 billion to compensate about 50,000 investors hurt when Enron collapsed in an accounting scandal in 2001. The investors -- including institutions, individuals and Enron employees who had bought the company's stock or bonds from September 1997 to December 2001 -- had sued the bank, accusing it of helping Enron to create off-balance-sheet partnerships that hid its overwhelming debt and ultimately precipitated its collapse.
