headline: Asian Reaction to Unocal Bid Is Muted
abstract: While the Chinese bid for Unocal has brought calls for a national security review in the United States, the reaction in Southeast Asia, where Unocal has most of its assets, is much more muted.      Unocal seems to have put aside political uncertainty and controversy to develop energy assets from gas fields in the Gulf of Thailand to oil wells and gas platforms off the eastern coast of Borneo in Indonesia. Unocal, based in California, has assets in Thailand, Indonesia, Myanmar and Vietnam that account for more than half of its worldwide reserves and 60 percent of its global production.

headline: A Sudanese City of Refugees With No Plans to Go Home
abstract: Population of a refugee camp in Abushouk, Sudan, has grown by almost 50 percent since Dec 2004 to about 100,000 people; they are living solely on international aid; some aid workers are concerned that none of two million refugees in Darfur camps have any intention of leaving; map (M)

headline: Judge throws out Abu Ghraib guilty plea
A witness's plea to end Myanmar abuse
Activities show IRA still potent, panel says
Its Profit Down 30%, Daimler Still Exceeds Wall St. Forecasts
abstract: Its Profit Down 30%

headline: Pathmark Vote Tests Wider Issues of Shareholder Control
abstract: Shareholders of Pathmark Stores are voting on purchase of potentially controlling stake in company by Yucaipa Companies, investment firm run by supermarket magnate Ron Burkle; $150 million deal will initially give Burkle's company 40 percent interest in Pathmark, if it goes through; Yucaipa would also receive warrants to buy additional Pathmark shares that would increase firm's stake to 60 percent; Pathmark's directors have recommended that shareholders approve transaction; none of Yucaipa money will go to Pathmark shareholders; it will go to company, which will use it to renovate some of 142 Pathmark stores, build new ones and pay down debt; if shareholders say yes to Yucaipa, Burkle's company will receive five board seats and will be in position to prevent any future bidders from taking over company; some Pathmark shareholders question why company's board continues to recommend Yucaipa deal over competing bids that are far higher and that would put money in its owner's pockets; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Bolivian Congress Names New President
abstract: Bolivia's Congress accepted the resignation of President Carlos Mesa late on Thursday night and swore in the head of the Supreme Court as the new president, an appointment expected to defuse more than three weeks of protests that have paralyzed the nation.    Eduardo Rodríguez, who as president of the Supreme Court was third in the line of succession, succeeded Mr. Mesa after the two congressional leaders who were first and second in line dropped out. The two politicians, Hormando Vaca Díez, the Senate president, and Mario Cossío, the House of Delegates president, were seen by protesters as emblematic of Bolivia's failed ruling class.

headline: Blair and Chirac Clash on European Budget
abstract: With two days to go before the leaders of the European Union convene in Brussels to tackle the crisis over the defeat of a constitution, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said Tuesday that he and President Jacques Chirac of France were ''in sharp disagreement'' over the union's budget and he expressed doubt that a compromise could be reached this week.    After meeting with Mr. Chirac for 90 minutes at Élysée Palace, Mr. Blair said, ''I think it is difficult to see the differences being bridged'' at the talks, on Thursday and Friday.

headline: Police make 2 arrests in killing of Ulster man
Sony BMG Tries to Limit Copying of Latest CD's
abstract: The world's second-biggest music corporation is rolling out its latest answer to digital piracy.    The company, Sony BMG Music Entertainment, which is owned by Sony and Bertelsmann, is outfitting a broad selection of its latest CD's with software that restricts copying.

headline: Mobile payment firm closes
Venerable Barron's Changing Its Look For a Speedier Read
abstract: Barron's, venerable financial magazine, is being redesigned to give readers quicker way to see what's inside magazine and let them re-enter later at their leisure; editor Edwin A Finn Jr says circulation remains fairly steady, but that Barron's wants to keep readers by helping them navigate more quickly through in-depth material; average reader now spends over two hours with magazine; photo (M)

headline: Blackout Disrupts Moscow After Fire in Old Power Station
abstract: The most serious blackout in recent memory struck Moscow on Wednesday, disrupting the lives of nearly two million residents in large sections of the city and outlying areas and stranding people in subways, elevators and trains. By late Wednesday evening, electricity still had not been fully restored.    The power failure struck at just after 11 a.m. amid record high pre-summer temperatures of 86 degrees. A fire in a transformer set the blackout in motion.

headline: Shares Are Broadly Lower Amid Unease on Hedge Funds
abstract: Stocks fall as speculation increases that hedge funds may be taking on too much risk; Dow Jones industrial average drops 103.23 points, to 10,281.11; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 12.62 points, to 1,166.22; Nasdaq composite index falls 16.90 points, to 1,962.77; Russell 2000 index of smaller-capitalization stocks falls 7.87 points, to 595.04; price of 10-year Treasury note rises 20/32 to 98 13/32; yield drops to 4.20 percent from 4.28 percent; graph (M)

headline: On Way to Baghdad Airport, Death Stalks Main Road
abstract: Iraqis call it Death Street. To American soldiers, it is ''I.E.D. Alley,'' after the improvised explosive devices -- bombs -- that are lethally common on the 10 miles of expressway and city streets that make up Baghdad's airport road.    Suicide bombers in cars packed with explosives lurk at on-ramps, waiting for American convoys or other targets.

headline: Rival views on the future of Europe
Listing Perks, but Not as an Endangered Species
abstract: Companies are disclosing more of perquisites they give their executives on top of their salaries, bonuses and stock awards, but these perks are not being reined in on that account; money goes most often to enhance corporate officers' health care benefits and retirement accounts, but there are other popular perks that stretch beyond office, like annual bill for chief executive's membership in some expensive club; graph shows cost of providing company cars to executives and managers; cartoon (M)

headline: 'Great Crime' at Abu Ghraib Enrages and Inspires an Artist
abstract: Fernando Botero, Latin America's best-known living artist, shocked the art world last year when he broke sharply from his usual depictions of small town life to reveal new works that depicted Colombia's war in horrific detail.    Now, Mr. Botero, 73, who lives in Paris and New York, has taken on an even more explosive topic: the torture of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib. Forty-eight paintings and sketches -- of naked prisoners attacked by dogs, dangling from ropes, beaten by guards, in a mangled heap of bodies -- will be exhibited in Rome at the Palazzo Venezia museum on June 16.

headline: Burying China's complicity in the killing fields
TD Waterhouse USA Is Sold to Ameritrade
abstract: Toronto-Dominion Bank agrees to sell its TD Waterhouse USA brokerage unit to Ameritrade Holding Corp in stock-and-cash deal valued at about $3.3 billion; Ameritrade stockholders will receive special $6 a share dividend; Toronto-Dominion will acquire 32 percent stake in combined operation, which will be known as TD Ameritrade (M)

headline: Companies Unable to Settle BlackBerry Suit
abstract: Final talks in a patent infringement lawsuit involving the popular BlackBerry e-mail messaging device have reached an impasse, the two companies involved said Thursday, raising the possibility that the BlackBerry service could be banned from the United States market.    The two companies, Research in Motion of Waterloo, Ontario, which makes the BlackBerry, and NTP, a small patent-holding company in Arlington, Va., reached a settlement in March to end an infringement suit that is three and a half years old. R.I.M. agreed at the time to pay NTP the unusually large sum of $450 million to end the suit.

headline: Sun Agrees to Buy Data Storage Company for $4.1 Billion
Year in U.S. shifts Muslim teens' views
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Demand For Photojournalist's Remains From Iran
abstract: Canadian Foreign Affairs Min Pierre Pettigrew announces that he has demanded Iranian authorities release body of Zahra Kazemi, photojournalist who died in police custody after being arrested for taking photographs of protest outside Tehran prison in 2003; holds Canadian government wants to perform independent autopsy on cause of death; Iranian doctor, who is now living in Canada, says Kazemi was beaten, tortured and raped while in custody (S)

headline: Pessimistic investors focus on health shares
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,624 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:      SCHAMBERG, Kurt D., 26, Sgt., Army; Euclid, Ohio; 10th Mountain Division.

headline: Zimbabwe Frees 62 Coup Suspects
abstract: Zimbabwean authorities belatedly free 62 suspected mercenaries whom it jailed 14 months ago after their jet stopped in Harare, apparently to pick up weapons for coup in Equatorial Guinea; coup's collapse in Mar 2004 created international sensation because of involvement of several well-known figures, including Sir Mark Thatcher, son of former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher; Mark Thatcher has paid $500,000 fine for supporting foreign military activities (M)

headline: Donaldson Announces Resignation as S.E.C. Chairman
abstract: William Donaldson expanded the agency's staff and budget, helping to restore morale. Still, his tenure has been controversial.

headline: U.N. Nominee Is Accused of Seeking 2nd Dismissal
abstract: A former national intelligence officer for Latin America has accused John R. Bolton and another Bush administration official of trying to remove him from his post to warn others against not cooperating on intelligence matters, according to Democratic staff aides of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.    The aides made public on Saturday their summary of an interview with the intelligence officer, Fulton T. Armstrong. They say Mr. Armstrong has charged that Mr. Bolton and Otto Reich, a former assistant secretary of state for Latin America, had sought to press the intelligence community to make its analysis conform with their hard-line policy views on Cuba. The committee is considering the nomination of Mr. Bolton to be ambassador to the United Nations.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
abstract: Orders for Japanese machinery rise 4.9 percent in February from January (S)

headline: Few See Taint in Service By Pope in Hitler Youth
abstract: Historians and Jewish groups agree that new Pope Benedict XVI's wartime membership in Hitler Youth, mandatory for high school students at time, has little if any significance now and certainly suggests no sympathy for Nazis; photo; young Ratzinger, like John Paul II growing up in Poland, turned to deep Catholic faith at least partly in response to wartime experiences; Ratzinger has acknowledged 'insufficient' Christian response to atrocities and anti-Judaism in Christians; his hometown of Traunstein joined others in conservative Bavaria in enthusiastic embrace of Nazis, but turned as party became more anticlerical in deeply Catholic region; Ratzinger family reportedly was strongly anti-Nazi, causing father's demotion as policeman and several moves during war; son was drafted into antiaircraft group in 1943 but later deserted and entered seminary when war ended (M)

headline: Pernod wants to be world No. 1 in liquor
Key Rates

headline: Inquiry Into French Insurer
abstract: AXA, French insurer facing scrutiny over its role in reinsurance deal with MBIA, says Justice Department is examining transaction and with other matters involving AXA's use of nontraditional insurance (S)

headline: Iraqis name a Shiite as new prime minister
2 Mobile Phone Makers Report Declines in Profit
abstract: Samsung Electronics and Sony Ericsson, world's leading mobile phone makers, report huge declines in first-quarter profit; Samsung's net profit dropped 52 percent, to 1.50 trillion won, or $1.47 billion; sales declined 4.2 percent, to 13.81 trillon won, or $13.55 billion; Sony Ericsson's net earnings declined 61 percent, to 32 million euros, or $41.02 million, while sales were 1.29 billion euros, or $1.65 billion, down 4 percent (M)

headline: Visit suggests a break in Kashmir acrimony
I.B.M. Expands Efforts to Promote Radio Tags to Track Goods
abstract: Many giants of the computing world, like Microsoft, Oracle, SAP and Sun Microsystems, have been vying to gain recognition as technology leaders in the drive to use radio tags to identify consumer goods. None have been more aggressive than I.B.M., which plans to start yet another marketing salvo today.    The company's consulting practice, I.B.M. Global Services, plans to announce that its consultants will begin selling advice on consumer privacy issues related to the use of radio identification tagging of consumer goods.

headline: Killing of journalist raises stakes in Lebanon election
Some Ways to Pinch Euros on Summer Hotel Stays
abstract: WHEN Edgar Rice was planning the two-week trip to Spain he took this month, he used the Internet to find the accommodations he wanted at the right price.     In addition to using Google to find sites that specialize in hotels in Spain, he searched a variety of general travel sites, as well as www.venere.com, which specializes in European hotels, bed-and-breakfast inns and apartments.

headline: Berlusconi and the Right Lose in Regional Ballots
abstract: Italian Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi's conservative coalition suffers staggering setback in local elections, losing several regions; Berlusconi, anticipating results, blamed Italy's sluggish economy for voter disillusionment (M)

headline: Ecuador's Congress Backs Court Move
abstract: Ecuadorean Congress dismisses interim Supreme Court's 31 judges in effort to neutralize political tumult threatening Pres Lucio Gutierrez's rule; current crisis was set in motion in Dec, when pro-government lawyers dissolved Supreme Court and installed new one (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Andersen Agrees to Pay $65 Million to End Lawsuit  Arthur Andersen has agreed to pay $65 million to resolve a class-action lawsuit brought by investors who bought WorldCom stock and bonds before the company filed for bankruptcy protection in 2002.    In addition to the cash, Andersen would give the investors 20 percent of any amount it distributes to its partners. [Page C4.]    Constellation Brands May Make Bid  Shares of Allied Domecq rose after Constellation Brands said it was considering making a counterbid to the £7.4 billion ($14.1 billion) offer from Pernod Ricard and Fortune Brands. The Pernod-Allied merger would create a two-tier industry, with Diageo and the new Pernod dwarfing rivals like Bacardi. [C8.]    Valero to Become Top Refiner  Valero Energy has agreed to buy Premcor in a transaction valued at $6.9 billion. [C2.]    Many Offers for Neiman Card Unit  Some of the nation's largest credit card companies, including American Express and Citigroup, are bidding for the credit card business of Neiman Marcus. [C7.]    2 Found Liable in Fraud Case  A federal judge has found Kenneth Winger, the former chief executive of Safety-Kleen, and Paul Humphreys, the former chief financial officer, liable for $200 million for their role in an accounting fraud at the company. [C4.]    G.M. Recalls Two Million Vehicles  General Motors issued several recalls involving more than two million vehicles, including some of its sport utility vehicles. [A12.]    Airlines Are Caught Unprepared  Few airlines bought hedging contracts to lock in lower prices for oil, meaning they are bearing the full brunt of higher prices. [C2.]    New Financial Chief at Microsoft  Microsoft has hired Christopher Liddell, left, as its chief financial officer, replacing John Connors. Mr. Liddell was previously chief finance officer at International Paper. Microsoft also announced that it would begin selling versions of its Windows operating system that take advantage of the high-performance computers that run 64-bit processors. [C3.]    A Good Review for Genentech Drug  Studies found that a Genentech drug can lower the risk that breast cancer will return. [A12.]    Barclays May Make Bid for Absa  Barclays said that it might bid $5.3 billion for a stake in Absa, a South African bank. [C8.]    J.&J. Adds Death Data to Package  Johnson & Johnson has added data about deaths to the package insert of its heart-failure treatment Natrecor after studies in two medical journals raised questions about an increased risk of fatal kidney problems in those treated with the drug. [C4.]    I.B.M. Is Set to Buy Healthlink  I.B.M. is expected to announce that it is buying Healthlink, a leader in the business of helping hospitals convert to electronic records. [C3.]    Stocks Continue to Gain  Stocks rose, with the Dow Jones industrials jumping 84.76 points, to 10,242.47; the S.&P. 500 was up 9.98 points, to 1,162.10; and the Nasdaq gained 18.59 points, to 1,950.78. [C10.]    Perplexed Over Security Measures  Travelers still experience inconsistencies at checkpoints. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C7.]

headline: Alleged BTK killer pleads not guilty
Peres urges no razing of settlements
Blair Endorses Going to U.N. if Iran Proceeds on Nuclear Plan
abstract: The prime minister said Britain would support U.S. moves to invoke the U.N. Security Council "if Iran breaches its obligations and undertakings."

headline: Major Carriers Gain
abstract: Accenture survey finds network carriers are reclaiming bigger share of business travelers from low-cost carriers; corporate travel managers are uneasy about State Department's plan to introduce passports later this year that will have tiny radio tags for transmitting personal and facial-biometric information, to expedite processing of travelers through border controls and Customs checkpoints; domestic hotels are slowly following lead of airlines in giving customers options for automated check-ins; Hilton Hotels last year tested self-service kiosks at several major hotels, and by year's end had them installed in 44 hotels; others installing or testing kiosks are Global Hyatt Corp, Starwood Hotels and Resorts and Holiday Inn; photo (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: When Google and reality aren't clicking
Insurgents unleash third day of deadly attacks in defiance of Iraq's new government
CITIGROUP SEEKS DAMAGES FROM EX-MANAGER IN BRAZIL
abstract: Citigroup is seeking at least $300 million in damages from its former investment manager in Brazil, Daniel Dantas, accusing him of working against bank's interests while overseeing its private equity fund there; Citigroup says Dantas tried to sell bank's stakes in two wireless companies without authorization, obstructed auditors and entered into agreements in fund's name for his own benefit; Federal police in Rio de Janeiro charge Dantas with criminal conspiracy, breach of confidentiality and corruption for his rlole in espionage scandal; Dantas denies any wrongdoing (S)

headline: Ford to rescue Visteon, taking over 24 facilities
Amid Tensions, Bush and Putin Conduct Meeting in Russia
abstract: The leaders met in what was widely expected to be a tense encounter, but advisers to both men moved swiftly to pronounce the meeting a success.

headline: For Bulgarian voters, worries about EU entry date
Talking Loudly to the TV Set, and Maybe Getting a Response
abstract: At least two companies, OneVideo Technology Corp and Agile TV, are developing speech-recognition products that will let television viewers change channels with voice prompts; Comcast Corp and other cable companies are testing systems; devices would make it easier for consumers to order advertised products, eliminating need to dial toll-free numbers or scroll through menus on television; photo (M)

headline: Aviation: Gains in technology bring enhanced safety margins
Long-Exiled General Battles Warlord in Lebanon Voting
abstract: The last time Gen. Michel Aoun and the now-imprisoned Christian warlord Samir Geagea faced each other, in 1990, more than 600 people were killed and more than 2,000 were wounded in one of the climactic battles of Lebanon's long and bloody civil war.    On Sunday, they faced off on campaign posters here and all over the central Mount Lebanon region, the steep, lush hills overlooking the Mediterranean, in the critical third phase of parliamentary elections that are being held on four successive Sundays, one for each region of the country.

headline: Berlusconi resigns amid turmoil
Former Official Denies Stealing From Tyco
abstract: Tyco International's former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz, testifying at his fraud and larceny trial, says he never stole any money from company; Swartz and former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski are on trial for defrauding company and shareholders (M)3

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Reverses Loss
abstract: The largest airline in Japan, the Japan Airlines Corporation, rebounded to a net profit of 30.1 billion yen ($285 million) for the fiscal year that ended March 31, from a loss of 88.6 billion yen a year earlier, on an increase in flights abroad. The airline, however, forecast that its profit would drop 43 percent, to 17 billion yen, this year because of rising fuel costs. Separately, the airline said its chairman, Isao Kaneko, above, would resign after a recent string of safety mishaps. Just a day earlier, a Japan Airlines flight from New York to Tokyo made an emergency landing in northern Japan after cabin pressure in the jumbo jet dropped suddenly.   Todd Zaun (NYT)

headline: Chief Urges World Bank to Pick Leader More Openly
abstract: James D. Wolfensohn, the departing World Bank president, said on Tuesday at his farewell news conference that the bank should change the way it selects its leader.    Instead of allowing the United States alone to appoint a candidate, as has been the case throughout the history of the World Bank, Mr. Wolfensohn said the president of the bank, the world's largest development agency, should be selected from a range of candidates and in a transparent way.

headline: Briefly: UN envoy will assess demolition campaign
Iranians Deny Leader Is Tied to Hostage Standoff
abstract: WASHINGTON, June 30 - A new cloud appeared over the United States relationship with Iran today as President Bush said that many questions had been raised by the allegations of six former American hostages that the president-elect of Iran was among their captors after radicals seized the American Embassy in 1979.

headline: Krakow and Beyond: Prayers, Tributes and Awe: Toronto; A Leader Lost
abstract: In a small neighborhood of Toronto known as Little Poland, people gathered to pray at St. Casimir's Catholic Church, where in the basement children attend the Pope John Paul II Judo School. The Rev. Janusz Blazejak said the pope was an important figure in the tightly knit Polish community, and represented for many a tie to their home country.     ''What the pope means to our community is what the pope means to Poland, maybe a little more,'' he said, sitting in his rectory office. ''I can't imagine the world without the pope. It's a great loss and a sadness. We shouldn't be ashamed of the tears. God gave us a wonderful gift. Polish people will not forget him.''

headline: Forensic officers search for clues amid debris of Indonesian bombs
Harvard cuts Sudan business tie
A Robot for the Home, Brains Not Included
abstract: Robotics has always been an esoteric and expensive pursuit, with few avenues for the home dabbler to create a robot that can venture around the house or out into the world. The White Box Robotics Model 914 PC-BOT, however, aims to change that.    The PC-BOT ($1,199, whiteboxrobotics.com) is essentially a PC case on wheels. The chassis is pressed steel, and the basic PC-BOT includes two 12-volt rechargeable batteries as well as a Webcam, microphone and object-avoidance sensors. It has rubber drive wheels with independent suspension.

headline: Court giving Khodorkovsky verdict adjourns until Tuesday
Peter Jennings Diagnosed With Lung Cancer
To Soothe Dutch-Muslim Nerves, Try a Jewish Mayor
abstract: Mayor Job Cohen of Amsterdam, who is Jewish, has made it his task to keep peace between city's Muslims and Christians; long-simmering tensions between conservative Muslim immigrants and city's liberal traditions have been exposed since 9/11 terror attacks in United States; photo (M)

headline: Searching the Web for clues on papal vote
World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Rabbi's Wife And Son Indicted
abstract: An Israeli court indicted the wife and son of Israel's chief Sephardic rabbi in connection with the suspected beating of a teenage boy who was dating the rabbi's daughter, Ayala. The rabbi, Shlomo Amar, was questioned by the police but is not a suspect in the case. His wife, Mazal, and their son, Meir, along with two Arab accomplices, face charges that include kidnapping, assault and wrongful imprisonment, according to the Justice Ministry. The indictment alleges that the assault took place after the young man refused to stop seeing 18-year-old Ayala.   Greg Myre (NYT)

headline: China Tries to Isolate Taiwan's President
abstract: Beijing steps up campaign to isolate Taiwan's independence movement; invites Taiwan's two main oppostion leaders to China for highest-level dialogue since Communist Party took power in 1948, but rules out talks with Pres Chen Shui-bian unless he accepts 'one China' formula under which Beijing claims sovereignty over Taiwan, condition Chen has rejected; China's overture to opposition groups puts Chen's government on defensive, forcing it to cede ground to politicians who tend to take softer line on relations with government in Beijing; Hu Jintao, China's Communist Party chief, is pursing strategy to halt what mainland sees as steady drift toward formal independence by Taiwan (M)

headline: Iranian Court Frees Dissident Jailed for Opinion Poll About U.S.
abstract: A prominent Iranian dissident, jailed for more than two years for conducting an opinion poll that found that the majority of people here favored better relations with the United States, was released after the Supreme Court dismissed espionage charges against him, his lawyer said Friday.     Abbas Abdi, a supporter of President Mohammad Khatami and an influential member of the Participation Front, the reformist party led by the president's brother, was arrested in late 2002. Five judges unanimously rejected charges that he was ''selling information to the enemy,'' a reference to the United States, and ''propagating against the regime,'' his lawyer, Saleh Nikbakht, told the ISNA news agency.

headline: 3 photographers face new trial in Diana crash
Palestinians and Militants Agree on Security Jobs
abstract: About 700 Palestinian militants in the volatile West Bank city of Nablus have agreed in principle to join the Palestinian security forces.

headline: Boeing earnings sag 14% in quarter
Wealth Management: Offshore centers toe the line

headline: Defects in Heart Implants
abstract: St Judge Medical, maker of implantable defibrillators, says patients with two of its heart devices need software upgrades to correct two defects (S)

headline: In pursuit of pleasure and profit
W.T.O. Talks Moving Slowly, Chief Says
abstract: Negotiations aimed at producing a new global trade pact are moving very slowly on trade in services, but a comprehensive deal remains possible next year, the director general of the World Trade Organization said here on Monday.    Earlier rounds of global trade talks, including the Uruguay round that ended in 1994 and created the W.T.O. in 1995, focused mainly on trade in manufactured goods and agriculture, although the Uruguay round also covered some service industries like banking.

headline: Election in north Lebanon crucial for opposition parliamentary majority
World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chechens Held In Van Gogh Killing
abstract: Two Chechens have been arrested in connection with the killing of the filmmaker Theo van Gogh on an Amsterdam street in November, Dutch prosecutors said. Bislan Ismailov, 25, was detained in Tours, France, on an international arrest warrant on May 18 and French authorities said he would be extradited to the Netherlands. The second man, identified only as Marad, 22, was arrested in the Dutch city of Schiedam last month, the police said. They said the men were wanted because their fingerprints had been found on items that belonged to Mohammed Bouyeri, the Dutch-Moroccan who has confessed to the killing. The three men, who knew each other in Amsterdam, are believed to belong to the same group of Islamic radicals.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES TO SELL GEAR UNIT TO CARLYLE
abstract: United Technologies sells its Falk Corp gear and coupling unit to Rexnord Corp, part of Carlyle Group, for $295 million (S)

headline: A literal blow to investors in Indonesia
Thousands March in Anti-Japan Protest in Hong Kong
3 sentenced in France for Kashmir terrorism links
Egypt stages a roundup after 2 attacks on tourists
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gay Soldiers Wed At Base
abstract: The military confirmed that a sergeant and a warrant officer, both men, were married last month in a ceremony at a military base in Nova Scotia. It was the first time the military has presided over a same-sex marriage, now legal in almost all of Canada following a series of court decisions over the last two years. The soldiers were married by a United Church minister after the base chaplain, an Anglican, refused to officiate for religious reasons. The guidelines of the armed forces treat same-sex couples the same as unions between men and women. Legislation to expand marriage rights to gay couples nationwide is awaiting enactment in Parliament and has the support of Prime Minister Paul Martin.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)

headline: CORNING DEBT IS RAISED TO LOWEST INVESTMENT GRADE
abstract: Debt rating of Corning is raised by Standard & Poor's to investment grade, ending three years of junk status, after company improves its profit and cash levels (S)

headline: Gas utility in France presses on with sale
Reports of Mishandling Koran Bring Protest Worldwide
abstract: Thousands of Muslims joined hands Friday in waves of protest across the Muslim world to denounce reports that American interrogators at the prison camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, had desecrated the Koran.     Islamic parties called for anti-American rallies in Pakistan, Egypt, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Middle East, mostly centered on Friday Prayer gatherings. Protesters chanted slogans and American flags were burned at some of the rallies. Still, most of the demonstrations were peaceful, according to news service reports.

headline: Winemaker Ends Acquisition Plan
abstract: Constellation Brands and three partners said yesterday that they would not pursue an acquisition of Allied Domecq, clearing the way for a purchase by Pernod Ricard.     Constellation, the world's largest winemaker, determined that an acquisition would not add value for shareholders, the company said. Constellation, the Brown-Forman Corporation, Lion Capital and the Blackstone Group had planned to bid about £7.75 billion ($14.1 billion) for the company, according to executives involved in the negotiations.

headline: DaimlerChrysler to Scale Back Mini-Car Unit
abstract: How did a pint-size car named Smart manage to make DaimlerChrysler look, well, dumb?     On Friday, the company announced that it would drastically scale back its troubled Smart division, eliminating two models and cutting 700 employees, at a cost of up to 1.2 billion euros ($1.55 billion).

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Call To Arm Border Agents
abstract: A Senate report recommended arming Canadian customs officers posted along the 4,000-mile border with the United States. Senator Colin Kenny, the chairman of the Senate Committee on National Security and Defense, which made the report, said that customs officers should be armed with guns for their own security and that the current practice of calling local police forces to respond to threats along the border takes too long, especially at more remote crossings. While United States customs officers and border patrol agents already carry firearms, Canadian border officers are currently armed with just batons and pepper spray.   Colin Campbell (NYT)

headline: Iraqi Forces Stage a Raid and Rescue 2 Hostages
abstract: Iraqi troops raiding a house in Baghdad on Wednesday rescued a 63-year-old Australian hostage, Douglas Wood, from nearly seven weeks of insurgent captivity. The raid, which also freed an Iraqi hostage, was a rare case of military action successfully ending one of the scores of hostage-takings that have been a major insurgent tactic in Iraq.    But the freeing of the hostages was accompanied by another surge of violence that killed 24 Iraqi soldiers and policemen in two suicide bombings in Baghdad and Khalis, a city 40 miles northeast of the capital. A mortar attack that struck outside a crowded restaurant in the southern Baghdad district of Beyaa at dinnertime killed five Iraqi civilians, according to the Interior Ministry, and the local police said another mortar blast, in the northern city of Tal Afar, killed seven civilians.

headline: 8 Dissidents at Morgan Seek Meeting With Board
abstract: Eight dissident executives fighting for control of Morgan Stanley submit third letter to firm's directors, asking for meeting to discuss their criticism of chief executive Philip J Purcell; letter poses 14 questions to directors, raising doubts about conduct of board and Purcell with relation to recent departure of several executives, proposed spinoff of Discover credit card unit and regulatory and legal scrapes that have embroiled Morgan Stanley; letter comes amid signs that some public pension funds may join campaign against Purcell's leadership; California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, says it is 'concerned about the issue' and that it is considering asking for meeting with Morgan Stanley; Calpers owns 5.9 million shares of company; such meeting would follow critical comments from Orin S Kramer, hedge fund manager who handles $70 billion New Jersey pension fund; letter also asks if board approved Purcell's decision to force resignations of Vikram S Pandit, John P Havens and Stephan F Newhouse, senior executives who left in days after Purcell's management shake-up; photos (M)

headline: Guantánamo Comes to Define U.S. to Muslims
abstract: In one of Pakistan's most exclusive private schools for boys, the annual play this year was ''Guantánamo,'' a docudrama based on testimonies of prisoners in Guantánamo Bay, the United States naval base in Cuba.     The cast was made up of students between 16 and 18 years old, each playing the role of a prisoner being held on suspicion of terrorism. To deepen their understanding of their characters, the boys pored through articles in Pakistani newspapers, studied the international press and surfed Web sites, including one that described itself as a nonsectarian Islamic human rights portal and is called cageprisoners.com.

headline: Telecom Italia Mobile makes new offers in bid for 3G clients
Europeans Cut Estimate of '05 Growth to 1.6%
abstract: European Commission reduces its 2005 growth forecast for euro zone to 1.6 percent from 2 percent, second cut in six months, because of record oil costs and rising unemployment; also trims its 2006 forecast to 2.1 percent, from 2.2 percent, and says risks to projection are 'titled to the downside'; predicts lengthening jobless lines and slowing expansion will push budget deficits of Germany, Italy, Greece and Portugal over European Union limit of 3 percent of gross domestic product this year; Germany will have worst-performing economy in both euro region and 25-nation European Union, with growth of 0.8 percent; Ireland is predicted to be euro zone's fastest-growing economy for second year, with 4.9 percent expansion; Latvia will be top performer, expanding at projected 7.2 percent; commission predicts growth in US of 3.6 percent this year (M)

headline: Citigroup to Pay $208 Million in Funds Case
abstract: Citigroup will pay $208 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it shortchanged mutual fund investors by denying them certain discounts, instead reaping $100 million in profit at the funds' expense over five years.     Citigroup Global Markets Inc. and Smith Barney Fund Management, an investment adviser to Smith Barney mutual funds, profited by recommending to the mutual fund boards that they contract with a Citigroup affiliate to be an administrator for the fund.

headline: It's Moore's Law, but Another Had the Idea First
abstract: Roles played by computer industry pioneers Gordon E Moore and Douglas C Engelbart noted in light of 40th anniversary of publication of Moore's celebrated article predicting number of transistors that could be placed on silicon chip would continue to double at regular intervals for forseeable future; Engelbart had made similar observation even earlier; Moore, Intel co-founder, and Engelbart, leading developer of many technologies that underlie both personal computer industry and Internet, represent twin Silicon Valley cultures that have combined to create digital economy; photos (M)

headline: In a World of Car Builders, Thailand Relies Heavily on a Pickup
abstract: Since starting Able Autopart Industries nearly 20 years ago, Yeap Swee Chuan has ridden the success of Thailand's bid to become the Detroit of the East. Now, after building a $176-million-a-year company that supplies every major carmaker from DaimlerChrysler to Toyota, Mr. Yeap has seen the future of Thailand's automotive industry. And, he says, it is in China.    ''The Thai market will plateau in two to three years,'' Mr. Yeap said. Last year his company, now called Aapico Hitech, shifted with the trend, buying an auto parts company near Shanghai.

headline: I'm in Love. Why Shouldn't I Be Paid?
abstract: David Carr column on changes in way movie stars, pop music idols and other celebrities are being covered in fan magazines and on entertainment television shows, particularly with regard to their love lives; notes how Britney Spears, Brad Pitt and others have learned to profit from sale of intimate interviews, photo opportunities and videos; says magazines, for their part, are going for unposed photography to give their readers the down-low, juicy and not-yet-known about celebrities (M)

headline: Tyco cuts earnings outlook for year, sending shares down
Australia softens rules on refugee detentions
Serbs seeking general's surrender
Goldman Had Conflicts? O.K., What's the Problem?
abstract: A LOT of ink has been spilled in recent days on the role that Goldman Sachs played in the New York Stock Exchange's planned acquisition of Archipelago Holdings. Goldman, you'll recall, is an adviser to both companies, an investor in Archipelago and a Big Board specialist -- conflicts so blatant that they are almost laughable.    Of course, it is easy to blame Goldman Sachs for not recusing itself from at least one side of the deal, something it should have done if for no other reason than to avoid the appearance of a conflict -- and, more important, to prevent any doubt from being cast on the deal. After all, Goldman Sachs holds itself, and its advice, as above reproach.

headline: Turkey's Growing Sex Trade Snares Many Slavic Women
abstract: The women arrive here by ferry from across the Black Sea, sometimes dozens at a time. Whatever their real names, they are known in Turkey as Natashas, and often end up working as prostitutes in this country's growing sex trade, sometimes against their will.    Turkey, with its now booming economy and lax visa requirements, is becoming the world's largest market for Slavic women, one of the most visible exports of the former Soviet Union's struggling new states. ''Think of many rivers flowing into one sea,'' said Allan Freedman, who coordinates countertrafficking programs at the Ankara bureau of the International Organization for Migration, an independent body that works closely with the United Nations. ''That sea is Turkey.''

headline: Newsweek Vows to Curb Anonymity
abstract: Newsweek says it will tightly limit use of unnamed sources in wake of retracted report about Koran being flushed down toilet at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Delay In Final Verdict For Tycoon
abstract: A Moscow court continued to plod through a recitation of the verdict against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, an oil tycoon and once the country's richest man, and Platon Lebedev, his business partner, on charges of fraud, conspiracy and tax evasion. But, as they did on Monday, the court's three judges adjourned for at least another day, leading the defendants' lawyers to speculate that the final verdict and sentence were being delayed to exhaust media attention. Both men face up to 10 years in prison in a case that has shaken investor confidence in Russia and tarnished President Vladimir V. Putin's democratic credentials.   Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

headline: Analysis: U.K. road to digital TV isn't all clear
Morningstar Chief to Buy 2 Magazines
abstract: Gruner & Jahr USA said over the weekend that it had agreed to sell two of its business magazines, Inc. and Fast Company, to Joe Mansueto, the founder and chief executive of Morningstar, a mutual fund information service.

headline: Free Flow: Rail freight lumbers up EU agenda
Ecuador's President Vows to Ride Out Crisis Over Judges
abstract: Pres Lucio Gutierrez of Ecaudor says he would not resign; charges that political opponents are trying to remove him because of his struggle to create what he calls independent, corruption-free judiciary; crisis caused by firing of Supreme Court by his allies in Congress appears to have no end in sight; photo of demonstrators with anti-government slogans (M)

headline: Verizon Buys Stake in MCI to Bolster Takeover Bid
Israeli defense minister rejects doubts over withdrawal
In Moscow, U.S. Strives for Greater Share of Oil Exports
abstract: Samuel W. Bodman, United States energy secretary, met with Kremlin officials Tuesday to relay the concerns of American energy companies about Russia's investment climate, and added that Russian oil exports to the United States should be ''10 times'' what they are currently.    In an effort to revive flagging energy cooperation between the two countries, Mr. Bodman met with his counterpart, Russia's minister of industry and energy, Viktor B. Khristenko, and the economic development and trade minister, German O. Gref, regarding critical issues.

headline: Democratic chief's fiery speeches draw praise and criticism
Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Wife defends Hong Kong reporter
Beijing Puts 2-Year Limit on Term for Hong Kong's Acting Leader
abstract: Chinese authorities order that next chief executive of Hong Kong serve only remainder of term of Tung Chee-hwa, who resigned on Mar 12; order seen as further erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy by critics of mainland policies toward territory; Donald Tsang, acting chief executive, is favored to be selected for two-year term when city's Election Committee convenes July 10; limiting his term will give China more influence over Tsang, who is distrusted by some pro-Beijing politicians (M)

headline: Peace pledge by Laura Bush
World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Meeting With Defector Condemned
abstract: North Korea described a defector President Bush met with in the White House last week as ''human trash'' and said the ''cheap charade'' threw ''a wet blanket'' over efforts to restart talks on North Korea's nuclear ambitions. On June 13, Mr. Bush met for 40 minutes with the defector, Kang Chol Hwan, who was imprisoned with his family in a North Korean prison camp and wrote the book ''The Aquariums of Pyongyang: Ten Years in the North Korean Gulag.'' After Mr. Bush read it this spring, administration officials started to include human rights as part of any package solution to halt North Korea's nuclear weapons program.   James Brooke (NYT)

headline: Obituary: Karol Wojtyla, 1920-2005
Mystery man talks only via piano
Global Crossing Settles Inquiry
abstract: Global Crossing, the long-distance network operator, and three former officials have settled a federal regulatory investigation into the company's accounting in the years before its bankruptcy filing.    The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday ordered each of the officials to pay a $100,000 fine and demanded that the company and the executives not commit future violations.

Marshall's and Napster Pick New Agencies
abstract: Two big brands have named new agencies.    The Marshall's retail chain, based in Framingham, Mass., and owned by the TJX Companies, named the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, to create broadcast commercials, an assignment that had been handled for 14 years by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at more than $35 million. Hill, Holliday continues to handle most media duties for TJX retail chains.

headline: Resolution elusive in Microsoft-EU standoff
Briefly: Berkshire to buy GE unit
Popular Demand
abstract: ''Everybody Loves Raymond,'' a season and series finale, easily leads the pack. The series finale of ''M*A*S*H'' in 1983 holds the all-time record, with a 60.2 percent rating.

headline: U.S. Report Finds Fault With British Security Company in Iraq
abstract: A British security company with a $292 million American contract to protect aid officials and contractors in Iraq failed to ensure weapons training for its agents and did not properly assess Iraqi guards for loyalty, United States federal monitors reported Friday.    The audit report, released by the Office of the Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction, said that the company, Aegis Defense Services Ltd., had not complied with several parts of its contract, but that the deficiencies were being corrected.

headline: Correction
World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: American Dead In Cairo Bombing
abstract: Death toll from presumed suicide bombing in Cairo's main bazaar rises to three after American tourist dies of his injuries (S)

headline: Fund-Raiser Says Investor Donated Space
abstract: Alberto W. Vilar, the philanthropist and investor arrested on fraud charges last week, not only gave away tens of millions of dollars to arts institutions, but he also donated office space to at least five of his favorite charities.     Mr. Vilar is in jail after his arrest last week on charges that he defrauded a longtime customer of $5 million. According to the charges, some of that money went to his pet recipients, including $177,000 to the American Academy in Berlin.

headline: A French Couple's Travails Go From Whispers to Political Fodder
abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy, the party leader who wants to be France's next president, and Cecilia, his wife, have worked long and hard to portray themselves as the ultimate power couple of France.    But rumors have swirled for days in the usually discreet French news media that the couple's marriage is in trouble.

headline: Entr'acte: Videoletters - Knitting loose ends in Balkans
Saudi Reformers: Seeking Rights, Paying a Price
abstract: First of series of articles on prospects for democracy in Middle East examines Saudi Arabia, which ranks among the most closed Arab countries (Stirrings in the Desert); around Saudi Arabia, reformers tend to be isolated dissidents, sometimes labeled heretics; even those who pursue mildest forms of protest are slapped with long prison sentences; right to assemble does not exist, political parties are banned along with nongovernment organizations, and ruling princes constantly tell editors what they can print; local television is almost all clerics; Islamic theological institutions that maintain rule of Saud princes determine parameters of any public debate, evaluating everything through prism of Wahhabi teachings unique to Saudi Arabia, vehemently rejecting any alternative; many reformists seek freedom of speech, giving it far higher priority than elections or other formal ingredients of Western democracy; princes argue that reform is en route, but must proceed at measured pace; some reformers describe their activities and prices they paid for their efforts; photos (L)

headline: Japan does the most with least oil
EU is coming to the aid of family of Ulster victim
Morgan Stanley chief defends reorganization
Taliban Attack Afghan Officials
abstract: Taliban fighters attacked and overran the administration offices and police station of a remote district in southern Afghanistan, and they captured the police chief, district chief and 11 police officers in a separate attack, Afghan officials confirmed Saturday.    The attacks were a blow to the government as it is struggling to contain a resurgent rebellion.

headline: Palestinian police can carry guns
World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sanofi Loses Patent Case
abstract: Sanofi-Aventis, the European drug maker, said its loss of a court ruling in the United States might allow Amphastar Pharmaceuticals to sell a copy of Sanofi's best-selling Lovenox anticoagulant. Shares of Sanofi fell 5 percent. The decision, issued Wednesday by the United States District Court for the Central District of California, might result in the lifting of a 30-month stay on marketing approval to sell a generic version of Lovenox, Sanofi said. Sanofi, based in Paris, said it would appeal the ruling, which involved the patent on the drug. Amphastar is privately held.

headline: Let's Make Some Magic, With No Strings Attached
abstract: WIRELESS technology has always had a glamorous aura. The word ''glamour,'' after all, originally referred to a magic spell, an illusion that makes things look different from what they really are.    Wireless technology does just that, through means as occult to most people as any witchcraft. It bestows on ordinary mortals the power to pluck from the atmosphere unheard voices and unseen images, whether broadcasted or recorded. Wireless communication creates the illusion of proximity, immediacy, even intimacy. It transports us from our real surroundings.

headline: Saudi Aramco plans IPO for joint venture

3 Accused of Fraud in Newspaper Circulation
abstract: Three former circulation employees of Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, and Hoy, the Spanish language paper, were arrested yesterday in connection with schemes to inflate circulation figures at the newspapers and cheat advertisers out of millions of dollars. Two of them pleaded not guilty, while the third is to be arraigned within the next 10 days.    The United States attorney's office in Brooklyn, which announced the arrests, said they were the first in an investigation into fraudulent circulation schemes at Newsday and Hoy from 2002 to 2004. All three executives were fired by the Tribune Company, which owns both publications, after its own internal investigation last year.

headline: U.K. attracts surge of EU newcomers
Briefly: FedEx profit falls short
After Saying It, Making It So
abstract: BOTH my parents are Corsican. Corsicans are generally reserved, discreet and absolutely loyal to their given word. If we say we will do something, we do it, even if it's difficult -- I should say especially if it's difficult.    I was born in Paris but we moved to Versailles when I was 3. I am named after my paternal grandfather, Cyril, who died the year I was born, but who nonetheless had a powerful influence on me. He was an engineer and active in the formation of France's Socialist Party.

headline: Shares Take a Heavy Hit as Oil Briefly Touches $60
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 166.49 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,421.44; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 13.15 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,200.73; Nasdaq composite index declines 21.37 points, or 1 percent, to 2,070.66; US Treasury bond prices decline; 10-year note falls 3/32, to 101 13/32; yield rises to 3.95 percent, from 3.94 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: Siemens bid for firmis rejected by Russia
DataBank; Stocks Climb as Inflation Fear Recedes
abstract: The stock market rose last week on optimism that the economy would grow without setting off serious inflation.     The government reported on Thursday that economic growth in the first quarter was stronger than expected. That spurred a rally in shares of homebuilders and computer chip makers -- companies that often thrive during rapid economic expansion. The report also showed that personal consumption expenditures, excluding food and energy, were contained during the quarter, suggesting that inflation was under control.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Defends Timing of Fund Vote
abstract: William H. Donaldson yesterday defended his decision to put a proposed rule regarding the independence of mutual fund boards up for a vote the day before he steps down as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.     He said the commission had spent a year debating the merits of the rule, which would require greater independence among the directors of mutual funds. He expressed trepidation that the newly constituted commission could kill the measure.

How a Titan of Insurance Ran Afoul of the Government
abstract: Career profile of Maurice R (Hank) Greenberg, 79, legendary insurance executive ousted from American International Group in accounting probe; he has suffered public and humiliating end to career and faces possible civil suits and criminal probes; reportedly reacts with mixture of bewilderment, rage and self-pity; his associates say he failed to recognize changes in business world shaken by recent corporate scandals and clung to model of imperial chief executive; photos (M)

abstract: Article on BabyGund brand jewelry for babies that includes 'birth diamond' necklaces starting at $620, 'baby blossom' earrings with emeralds, at $280, and tiny necklaces and bracelets with pink sapphire hearts for hundreds and thousands of dollars; photo (M)

Italy disenchanted by cult of Berlusconi
From Thousand-Year-Old Sentinel to Traffickers' Booty
abstract: The majestic tree that gives this town its name is one of Chile's principal national symbols. Streets, schools, suburban housing developments, hotels, gas stations, taxi fleets and even a record company and a brand of cellphone -- all invoke and honor the towering and sturdy ''sequoia of South America,'' as the alerce is sometimes called.    But here in Alerce, as in many other parts of southern Chile, there are scarcely any alerce trees to be found these days. Predatory cutting and burning in defiance of laws meant to protect the species have reduced its range and numbers by half and created a lucrative black market in which alerce timber can fetch as much as $5,000 per cubic yard, if successfully spirited abroad.

headline: Funds in Brief: China central bank chief upbeat on stock markets
Europe to Issue Guide on Textile Imports
abstract: European Union is not yet considering action to stem surge in textile imports from China that followed end of quotas last year; European Commission will complete set of guidelines to determine whether and how to step in; guidelines will set parameters, possibly on market share or unit volume, thata could ultimately set off safeguards; Peter Mandelson, European trade commissioner, will meet with senior Chinese officials to discuss, among other things, distortion in textile trade; photo (M)

Judicial nomination nears vote as Senate agrees to end debate
G.I. Is Charged in Iraq Deaths of 2 Superiors
abstract: The United States military charged a New York Army National Guard member yesterday with murdering his commanding officers last week at a base near Tikrit, Iraq.     The officers, Capt. Phillip T. Esposito, 30, and First Lt. Louis E. Allen, 34, of the 42nd Infantry Division, New York Army National Guard, were first believed to have died after indirect fire hit the window of a building they were in on June 7.

headline: An MTV Host Moves to Radio, Giving Voice to Audible Blogs
abstract: Adam Curry, former MTV host, will produce and host four-hour program every weekday on Sirius Satellite Radio devoted solely to podcasts, homemade radio shows originally formatted for digital audio players; has developed software that lets people automatically get these programs on Apple's iPod and other players; will help choose material for satellite broadcast from thousands of amateur shows; photo (M)

headline: Kuwait Grants Political Rights to Its Women
abstract: Kuwait's Parliament grants full political rights to women, making way for them to vote and run for office in parliamentary and local elections for first time in country's history; this ends decades-long struggle by women's rights campaigners for full suffrage, and promises to redefine Kuwait's political landscape (M)

headline: Israelis Arrest 3 Palestinians Trying to Smuggle Explosives
abstract: Israeli troops on Friday arrested three Palestinians who were trying to smuggle explosives through checkpoints in the occupied West Bank, the Israeli Army said.    One of the Palestinians, Thair Abu Assap, 20, was stopped at the Beit Iba checkpoint west of Nablus on Friday afternoon when he was considered to be acting suspiciously, the army said. Mr. Assap was carrying four pipe bombs with 4.4 pounds of explosives and two batteries fashioned into an explosive belt of the kind typically used by suicide bombers, the army said.

headline: Iraqi leaders break deadlock with Sunnis over constitution talks
Franchisees With Advanced Degrees
abstract: Let's just come out and talk about it. An increasing number of business school graduates and corporate executives are going into low-technology franchises like Dunkin' Donuts and gas stations. The format lets them run their own show just like full-fledged entrepreneurs while providing a corporate security blanket that keeps the risk of failure low.     There is just one catch: running a Subway or 7-Eleven lacks cachet. In some business circles, franchising is referred to as the F word.

abstract: Amazon.com says net income fell in first quarter despite 24 percent rise in revenue; profit fell to $78 million from $111 million year earlier; revenue rose 24 percent, to $1.90 billion, from $1.53 billion in first quarter last year; chief executive Jeff Bezos comments (M)

headline: Buffett Steps Up; Another Step Down for G.M.
abstract: GOOD news abounded this week. Americans were all a bit wealthier, at least if they own homes; the economy grew faster, rebounding from a bit of a slowdown early in the year; and markets rose.    Yet there were developments to give one pause. Oil prices popped above $50 a barrel on news of low inventories ahead of the summer driving season. Analysts warned of weak auto sales. And, come to think of it, are endlessly booming house prices really such a good thing?    FROTHY EXUBERANCE? -- People who think the housing market is robust and those who think it is scary each had a little more evidence this week to make their case.

Pakistani Diplomat, Missing in Iraq, Tells Embassy He Is Captive
abstract: Malik Muhammad Jaweed, Pakistani diplomat missing in Baghdad, makes contact with his embassy to say he was kidnapped; Pakistan appeals for his release; has no troops or peacekeepers in Iraq; last July, two Pakistanis working for Kuwaiti company were kidnapped and beheaded by insurgents; Iraqi government announces that security forces have capture Ibrahim Sabawi, son of Saddam Hussein's half-brother Sabawi Ibrahim al-Hassan al-Tikriti; says Sabawi, who once worked as deputy for Hussein's elder son, Uday, had been helping to finance insurgency; photo of American soldiers at scene of car bombing near military convoy in Baghdad that injured four civilians (M)

headline: IMF sees world economy set for more growth
World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Governor Vetoes Wall Around Rio Slums
abstract: The governor of Rio de Janeiro has revoked a plan approved by the state legislature to build a six-and-a-half-foot wall along some main thoroughfares in Rio to block them off from squatter slums. Lawmakers had endorsed the proposal to shield motorists from the gun battles that often break out between drug trafficking gangs in the slums and to obstruct robbers who assault commuters. But the governor, Rosinha Mateus, said in her veto of the measure that the plan ''would be a form of discrimination against good citizens who make up the vast majority of these communities.''   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: Yukon town remains true to its frontier roots
Nominee to U.N. Defends Record at Senate Panel
abstract: John R Bolton, at his Senate confirmation hearing, rebuts attacks from Democrats on his fitness to serve as ambassador to United Nations; pledges to bring about 'close partnership' with organization and denies ever trying to get anyone dismissed for disagreeing with him on intelligence matters; Sen Lincoln Chafee, lone doubting Republican on Senate Foreign Relations Committee, says he is generally satisfied with Bolton's answers and is 'inclined' to vote to approve him; Bolton seeks to turn his criticism of UN to his advantage, saying his views make him right person to help restore credibility to organization and make it more effective; next person scheduled to testify about Bolton will be Democrats' star witness Carl W Ford Jr, former State Dept official who clashed with Bolton in 2002; photos (M)
