headline: Getting Movies When You Want
abstract: Getting Movies When You Want    Q. I've been hearing a lot about video-on-demand technology with cable television but I'm clueless as to how it actually works. Is this the same thing as the old pay-per-view, except with a different name?    A. Both video-on-demand and pay-per-view are services for delivering specialized or premium content like commercial-free movies, and many cable television companies offer them. But the two services use different technology to bring movies to the small screen.    Movies featured on pay-per-view cable channels typically start at preordained times as scheduled by your cable television provider. When you order and pay for a film showing on a pay-per-view channel through your provider, the cable company unscrambles the channel at the time your selected movie is playing so you can watch it.

headline: India and China Are Poised to Share Defining Moment
abstract: Chinese Prime Min Wen Jiabao begins four-day visit to India; China is India's second largest trade partner, and trade is growing by 30 percent each year to estimated $14 billion this year; there is talk of free trade agreement and joint oil exploration, but competition is as much byword as cooperation; World Bank credits their combined growth with cutting share of world's population living in extreme poverty to 20 percent in 2001 from 40 percent two decades earlier, but China enjoys good 15-year head start in economic reform over India; political delays slow development in India while China's future success may depend on democratic reforms; photo (M)

headline: Intel Officer Says High Taxes Could Send Plant Overseas
abstract: Intel president Paul S Otellini warns President's Advisory Panel on Federal Tax Reform that because of high tax rates in US, his company may build its next $3 billion semiconductor factory overseas; Otellini, who will become Intel's chief executive in May, testifies before panel that over 10-year life of modern chip factory, company would save $1 billion by placing factory in Asia or Europe rather than in US; says Intel will make its decision this year; photo (M)

headline: In Indonesia, survivors revisit site of disaster
MORNINGSTAR SAYS NO SETTLEMENT WITH S.E.C.
abstract: Morningstar, provider of mutual fund analysis and data, says talks with Securities and Exchange Commission about suspected misrepresentations of fund returns has concluded with no settlement; investigation relates to incorrect data published by Morningstar for Rock Canyon Top Flight Fund in 2004 (S)

headline: Chinese Oil Giant in Takeover Bid for U.S. Corporation
abstract: State-controlled Chinese oil company makes $18.5 billion unsolicited bid for Unocal, signaling first big takeover battle by Chinese company for American corporation; bid by China National Offshore Oil Corp (CNOOC) comes two months after Unocal agreed to be sold to Chevron for $16.4 billion; it is expected to incite potentially costly bidding war; China is eager to have its own energy resources; its bid for Unocal is likely to provoke fierce debate in Washington about nation's trade policies with China and role of two governments in growing trend of deal making between companies in countries; recent efforts by Chinese to acquire other American companies recalled; deal making and bidding wars involve Chinese companies taking on American multinationals and being advised by Western lawyers and investment bankers, many of whom are betting hundreds of millions of dollars on China's rise; CNOOC's bid faces uphill battle; photo (M)

headline: Mbeki fires deputy over bribe case
Ratzinger elected as new pope
A New Workhorse's Heavy Load
abstract: Joint Strike Fighter, joint project of US and eight nations, is over budget, behind schedule and with big cuts in number to be produced; at cost of more than $256.6 billion and counting, it is also most expensive figher jet program in history and most complicated; program's costs rose by $11.8 billion in last three months of 2004; production begins in 2007, with Lockheed Martin Corp as prime contractor; US has invested $16 billion in first phase of development; Britain, which has invested $1.8 billion in program and is America's closest ally, has expressed frustation at red tape and bureaucratic barriers; none of foreign countries participating in program--Britain, Netherlands, Italy, Canada, Denmark, Norway, Turkey and Australia--have committed themselves to ordering craft yet; deadline for decision is December 2006; charts; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ex-President Joins Race
abstract: Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, left, the still influential former president, said he would run again for the top post in the June 17 election to choose a successor to President Mohammad Khatami. ''The issue of the presidency is my current preoccupation, and I thought I would like somebody else to take this responsibility but I think I should take this bitter medicine,'' the news agency INSA quoted Mr. Rafsanjani as saying. Widely regarded as a pragmatic conservative, Mr. Rafsanjani served as president from 1989 to 1997 and is currently the head of the powerful Expediency Council. Mr. Khatami is constitutionally barred from a third term.   Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: One Of Two Women In Leader's Race Bows Out
abstract: After polls indicated that a conservative candidate was drawing votes from her, Soledad Alvear, left, the Christian Democratic Party's candidate in the presidential election in December, withdrew from the race. Ms. Alvear, a former foreign minister, was one of two women seeking the nomination of the center-left coalition that has governed Chile since the fall of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in 1990. Her pullout leaves Michelle Bachelet, a Socialist and former defense minister, as the only candidate on the now-united left and makes her the favorite to defeat the two men who are battling for support on the right.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: The End User: A 'buy' sign on the song
Currencies: Drop in Japan prices undermines the yen
A lingering Soviet shadow over Europe
Briefly: Gazprom controls Izvestia
A growing appetite in U.S. for natural gas
Visa Job Is Said to Go to Shepardson Stern
abstract: Visa Job Is Said to Go.

headline: Philips's net declines on flat-screen unit's loss
Kyrgyz Police Oust Protesters at Capital Offices
abstract: Several hundred protesters stormed the main government building in Bishkek on Friday in support of a minor presidential candidate, but riot police officers using tear gas and batons retook the building hours later.     In events reminiscent of the ousting of President Askar Akayev in an uprising on March 24, a crowd of around 2,500 supporters of the candidate, Urmatbek Baryktabasov, a wealthy businessman, rallied in the capital to demand that he be allowed to run in the July 10 elections. Then an estimated 500 forced their way inside the building.

headline: Rumors Put Oil Traders on Edge
abstract: A hint of a terrorist threat in Nigeria, a major supplier of crude oil to the United States, and worries about a lack of refining capacity drove energy markets into a frenzy on Friday, pushing oil over $58 a barrel, a record.     Crude oil for July delivery climbed to $58.60 a barrel before settling at $58.47, up $1.89. Some traders said oil might reach $70 a barrel, driven primarily by demand in China and the United States. Fears over what might affect the supply, rather than what is actually affecting it, appeared to inject anxiety into the market.

headline: Sun pays $4.1 billion for StorageTek
New faces for stamps
Corrections
abstract: An article on May 15 about annuity sales practices omitted a word in some copies, thus reversing the meaning, in citing a company's response to a California officials' lawsuit accusing one of its units, among other defendants, of tricking retirees into using their retirement investments to buy annuities. The company, the AmerUs Group, said that while it was taking the accusations very seriously and had strong sales and compliance practices, it did not comment on pending legislation.

headline: China's Divided Catholics Unite, if Just to Mourn
abstract: Several million Catholics in China worship in illegal underground churches that retain allegiance to pope, separate from 'official' Catholic churches that ultimately answer to Communist Party; all of China's 12 million Catholics are mourning death of Pope John Paul II, but his passing is reminder of division of Chinese Catholics from rest of church, and from each other; Chinese Catholics were divided from universal church, and each other, in 1951 after Mao Zedong established 'patriotic' association to oversee Catholic churches; association rejected papal authority and placed church affairs like appointments under government control; many Chinese Catholics went underground; persecution of underground priests and bishops continues; two elderly priests in Hebei Province have been detained in past two weeks; normalizing relations with China will be challenge for next pope; map (M)

headline: Why Is Chappelle's Show at a Halt? Not Because of Drugs, an Aide Says
abstract: Representatives of the comedian Dave Chappelle yesterday denied rumors that drugs were involved in the suspension of production of his acclaimed sketch comedy show, ''Chappelle's Show.''     Matt Labov, Mr. Chappelle's publicist, categorically denied speculation that drug use -- a frequent topic of Mr. Chappelle's stand-up comedy routines -- played any part in his client's problems with delivering the show on time. The third season's premiere had already been delayed twice.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Flying Solo On The National Airline
abstract: The state-run airline got off to a ruinous start on its new round-trip service from Harare to Dubai two weeks ago, carrying but 49 outbound passengers in a 205-seat Boeing jet on its inaugural flight and flying the 3,396 miles back home with but a single patron, the state-run newspaper The Herald reported. A Transport Ministry official told the newspaper that the airline suffered from incompetent managers who had not determined whether the route was economically sustainable before starting it. Shunned by Western travelers, Air Zimbabwe has tried to make money by turning east, serving Beijing and Singapore as well as Dubai. But Zimbabwe's poor economy and the airline's generally creaky planes have dissuaded customers. Not long ago, its in-flight magazine ran an article assuring ticket-holders that rumors that the airline was not safe to fly were unfounded.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: False Sales Make a Better Bottom Line, but Only for a While
abstract: A HOUSE of cards ultimately collapses. And the channel-stuffing scheme at the pharmaceutical company Bristol-Myers Squibb was no exception.    For several years, Bristol-Myers paid wholesalers to stockpile goods, which the company booked as legitimate sales. The practice is called channel stuffing.

headline: A Dour Scot on Blair's Team, Eager for Him to Go
abstract: He has been waiting his turn, with an impatience that ebbs and flows, for more than 11 years. And now that the Labor Party has secured its third term in office, the question for Gordon Brown, Britain's transparently ambitious chancellor of the Exchequer, is when will Prime Minister Tony Blair finally step aside for him?      That Mr. Brown is the heir apparent to the throne that has been occupied by Mr. Blair for so long is not in dispute. But it is unclear when the much awaited transfer of power might take place. While Mr. Brown would prefer it to be sooner rather than later, Mr. Blair -- victorious but diminished after Thursday's election -- is not so focused in his thinking.

headline: G.M.'s Brands to Cut Back on Variety
abstract: General Motors outlines new product development and sales strategy under which only Chevrolet and Cadillac will offer full lineup of vehicles, with other six brands focusing on narrower selection of segments; GMC and Hummer will continue to sell trucks. Pontiac, Saab and Saturn will focus mostly on cars and smaller SUV's; Buick will offer some of both; GM is apparently trying to wean itself from what has been highly criticized product development strategy of keeping costs down by developing the same basic vehicle for many of its brands; plan will probably mean consolidation of company's more than 7,000 dealers; suggests GM may push United Automobile Workers to agree to close some plants, because company is already producing significantly more cars and trucks than it can sell; photo (M)

headline: By Playing at 'Rage,' China Dramatizes Its Rise
abstract: Demonstration by thousands of Chinese outside Japanese consulate in Shanghai can be seen as government-sponsored festival of runaway nationalism; most of those protesting are too young to recall China's brutal subjugation by Japan, and they have little experience of mass organized protests; for many, current protest bears echoes of mass manipulation of students of another era, Cultural Revolution; photos (Letter from Asia) (M)

headline: Pro-Syrian named as Lebanon leader
Britain Suspends Referendum on European Constitution
abstract: Deepening a crisis, Britain said Monday that it would suspend plans for a referendum on the European constitution, which was rejected last week by voters in France and the Netherlands.    The announcement to Parliament by Jack Straw, the foreign secretary, laid bare the gulf between nations like France and Germany that want to keep alive a sense that the constitution can be rescued, and Britain, where the government is under pressure to declare it dead. The move seemed to make ratification of the constitution, a cornerstone of European unity, all the more remote.

headline: Report Says China's Currency Policy Poses Risk of Inflation
abstract: Economists at a Paris think tank say China's economy is overheating despite government attempts to regulate it.

headline: Americans Trade Fire With Insurgents in Western Iraq
abstract: American tank fire boomed across this dusty village in western Iraq on Saturday, and insurgents sporadically lobbed mortar shells in return as about 1,000 marines continued a day-old offensive amid a warren of dirt streets in an effort to return the area to Iraqi government control.    Laundry fluttered from clotheslines outside what appeared to be mostly abandoned houses, and a single white flag flew above one rooftop in a town that was almost silent except for the firing and the rumble of American humvees. By Saturday afternoon, most of the remaining resistance appeared to come from a single position in the western part of Karabila.

headline: AUSTRALIANS TO INVESTIGATE BERKSHIRE UNIT
abstract: General Reinsurance Australia, unit of Berkshire Hathaway, will be investigated by Australian regulators examining reinsurance policies disguised as loan to prop up earnings; Estelle Pearson of Finity Consulting is hired to investigate General Re's complex financial products (S)

headline: Some Pain Relief for Merck's Boss
abstract: When Merck's board accepted Raymond V. Gilmartin's resignation as chief executive last week after the fiasco over the pain reliever Vioxx, it sought to take some of the sting out of his departure. It made him a

headline: On Advertising: A new force to promote 'Star Wars'
At These Prices, the Poor Get Poorer, the Rich Get College
abstract: For the college-bound, today is generally the last day to decide which college. No more second thoughts, no more waffling. It's time for a decision already!     Then reality hits. No longer do colleges pull out all the stops to woo accepted students -- ''Please, please, come here. We're the best school ever. We promise you ideal roommates, the ultimate fitness center, the career of your dreams!'' Now the mailings from the chosen college carry more mundane messages, like, say, when exactly you should take every cent you have and mail it in.

headline: Instead of Reading This, Maybe You Should Take a Nap
abstract: ACNielsen survey finds that 34 percent of adults go to bed after midnight during week and 19 percent regularly sleep six hours or less a night; graphs (M)

headline: Bush takes aimat logjam overSocial Security
Blair Unbowed as Iraq Emerges as Big Issue in British Campaign
Obituaries: Jack Kilby, Cardinal Jaime Sin
Surprise for EU chiefs: voters' urge to say no
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Meeting Set On Fox's Comment
abstract: Responding to the outrage stirred by his remarks about black Americans last weekend, President Vicente Fox invited the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson to meet him on Wednesday to discuss ways Mexicans and African-Americans can work together on issues of mutual concern. On Friday, President Fox said that Mexicans in the United States take jobs that ''not even blacks want to do.'' In an interview before his flight, Mr. Jackson said that President Fox's statements had ''touched a raw nerve'' because of the animosity -- and even violent clashes -- between blacks and Hispanics, who often compete for America's lowest-paying jobs and limited educational opportunities. But he said he was satisfied that President Fox regretted the statement.   Ginger Thompson (NYT)

headline: At Least 18 Killed in Blast at Muslim Shrine in Pakistan
abstract: The explosion, possibly set off by a suicide bomber, ripped through a crowd at a Muslim shrine on the outskirts of Islamabad.

headline: Bohemian Border Town Blues: The Euro's to Blame!
abstract: Membership in European Union has hurt business for merchants of Zelezna Ruda, Czech Republic town on German border; it has rapidly erased difference in prices between Czech Republic and Germany, depriving merchants of ability to lure German tourists with cut-rate products; since last May 1, when Czech Republic became member state, its currency has risen 8 percent against euro; merchants fear things will get worse, not better, when country adopts euro; photos; map (M)

headline: Jurors Report a Deadlock in the Trial of Scrushy
abstract: The jurors in the federal fraud trial of Richard M. Scrushy said on Friday that they were deadlocked on all counts, prompting the judge to issue a stern order to resume deliberations in an effort to reach a unanimous verdict in the case.     Judge Karon O. Bowdre presented what is known as an Allen charge -- special last-resort instructions given when a jury is unable to decide on a verdict and the judge is trying to avoid a mistrial. The 12 jurors in the trial of Mr. Scrushy, the former chief executive of the HealthSouth Corporation, have indicated they are in disagreement and confusion since hearing closing arguments last month.

headline: India's Darwinian side
Air France-KLM reports mixed results
Somber farewell for Prince Rainier
Free Flow: Asia trade reviving a shortcut
Lightweight listening
Chinese defector says U.S. turned him away
Newspapers Find National Ads a Tough Sell
abstract: Many newspapers have been ailing as readers defect to other sources of news and advertisers seek new ways to attract potential customers; biggest challenge comes from Web sites and search engines like Google and Yahoo; newspaper Web sites still benefit from classifieds and other ads that once belonged almost solely to newspapers; their ad revenue pales in comparison with that of big Internet search engines and portals; recent financial results suggest that big newspapers are suffering more than smaller ones; Dow Jones says ad revenue at domestic and international print publications, including Wall Street Journal, fell 10.8 percent during first quarter compared with year earlier; New York Times says ad revenue rose 0.8 percent at unit that includes New York Times, New York Times on the Web and International Herald Tribune; but ad revenue at its regional media group, which includes newspapers like Tuscaloosa News in Alabama and The Press Democrat in Santa Rosa, Calif, increased 7.2 percent; companies that own primarily small or midsize newspapers reported better results on whole; ad figures for Knight Ridder, Tribune Co, Lee Enterprises and Gannett, which publishes USA Today, noted; New York Times president-chief executive Janet L Robinson says big newspapers could fight their way out of slump; chart; photos (M)

headline: Disney bows to feng shui
Briefly: Disney drops shark's fin soup
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: General Motors Reports $1.1 Billion Quarterly Loss  General Motors reported a $1.1 billion first-quarter loss, its worst quarterly performance since 1992, citing a stark reversal in its North American operations.      The company said it was no longer certain enough of its outlook to provide earnings guidance for the year, backing away even from the bleak revisions it made last month. [C8.]    In Asia, General Motors' profits plummeted in the first quarter, but the first hints of a rebound are starting to become visible in China, its most important Asian market. [C8.]    Court Limits Basis for Stock Suits  The Supreme Court ruled in a closely watched fraud case that an accusation that a company's misrepresentations caused an inflated share price was insufficient as a basis for a lawsuit. Justice Stephen G. Breyer, left, writing for the court, said that the purpose of permitting private suits for securities fraud was ''not to provide investors with broad insurance against market losses, but to protect them against those economic losses that misrepresentations actually cause.'' [C3.]    New Food Pyramid Has 12 Forms  The Agriculture Department introduced a food pyramid that comes in 12 versions, depending on activity level and caloric need. [A23.]    Stocks Gain on Earnings News  Stocks rose as companies' earnings beat analysts' estimates. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 56.16 points, to 10,127.41. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 6.80 points, to 1,152.78. The Nasdaq composite index rose 19.44 points, or 1 percent, to 1,932.36. [C9.]    Core Inflation Rate Is Modest  The government reported a smaller-than-expected increase in prices excluding energy and food. Another report that said that home construction plunged last month. [C20.]    Longtime Producer to Join Disney  Scott Rudin, a longtime producer whose films last year included ''The Stepford Wives'' and ''Closer,'' said he would end his long-standing deal with Paramount Pictures and begin making movies for Walt Disney Studios when his contract expires in 2006. [C4.]    Time Out New York Editor to Leave  Cyndi Stivers, the founding editor in chief of Time Out New York, said that she was stepping down as president and editorial director to join Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia as an executive vice president. [C4.]    Coca-Cola Earnings Fall 6 Percent  In its first-quarter earnings announcement, Coke reported sales growth in Asia, Africa and Latin America that far outweighed growth in the United States and Europe. These positive results allowed Coke's chief executive, E. Neville Isdell, to project a note of optimism amid otherwise lackluster results. Coke's overall earnings fell 6 percent, to $1.5 billion, slightly exceeding forecasts. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $5.3 billion. [C20.]    Pfizer reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings, while Johnson & Johnson, reported a doubt-digit earnings increase. [C2.]    Merrill Lynch said that its first-quarter earnings fell 3 percent from a year earlier, exceeding analysts' estimates. It also announced a $4 billion stock buyback program. [C20.]

headline: CBS Says It Will Lead in Sales
abstract: CBS said yesterday that it expected to become the leader in the sale of commercial time ahead of the coming fall season, surpassing NBC, when final tallies are completed, perhaps as soon as early next week.    CBS, owned by Viacom, said that it was almost finished selling commercial time in the yearly bazaar known as the upfront market that occurs before the fall season.

headline: Two Koreas resume talks after 10-month hiatus
New pay plan (and perks) for EU legislators
Guilty plea is offered on 9/11
World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Angers Finns
abstract: All the manly charms of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi were not enough to keep Italy's ambassador to Finland out of trouble. The ambassador was summoned to the Finnish Foreign Ministry after Mr. Berlusconi revealed his techniques for persuading the Finnish president, Tarja Halonen, to give up her country's bid, in favor of Italy, as home of the European Union's food safety office. ''I had to use all my playboy tactics, even if they have not been used for some time,'' Mr. Berlusconi said at the opening of the new office in Parma on Tuesday. In 2001, in the midst of the duel over which country would be assigned the office, Mr. Berlusconi staked a claim to Italian culinary supremacy, saying, ''Finns don't even know what prosciutto is.'' On Tuesday, he disparaged Finnish food again. ''I've been to Finland and I had to endure the Finnish diet, so I am in a position to make a comparison,'' he said. News accounts differed on whether he was most offended by smoked reindeer or smoked herring.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Iran's President Says He'll Move Forward With Nuclear Program
abstract: Iran's conservative president-elect, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, insisted today that the program was a matter of national pride.

headline: A Parting Gift at PeopleSoft
abstract: People who start companies that eventually grow big are routinely enriched when they sell them to competitors. But it's unusual for these executives to take financial responsibility for the many workers displaced in the consolidation that follows.    David A. Duffield, the founder and former chief executive of PeopleSoft, a business software company, isn't just walking away from the thousands of workers who have been laid off since the Oracle Corporation acquired it last December after a bitter takeover battle.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Accuride, an initial public offering of 5.6 million shares. Citigroup Global Markets, Deutsche Bank and UBS.

headline: The Pacifier Isn't for the Client
abstract: Travel Industry Association of America says of 163 million business trips taken in 2003, 10 percent included children; figure has grown steadily in large part because more women hold high-profile jobs that require travel; some mothers comment on experience of traveling with young child; photo (M)/

headline: Pathmark Posts Loss for Quarter
abstract: Pathmark Stores posts fourth-quarter loss of $262.3 million, compared with net income of $9.6 million year earlier; reports 1.6 drop in sales, to $996.8 million (S)

headline: Profit falls at Toyota as it expands
World Briefings
Bolton flouted agency's rules, officials say
Fed Raises Rates but Bobbles Delivery
abstract: Federal Reserve raises its benchmark short-term interest rate by quarter-point, to 3 percent, and signals that it is more concerned about rising prices than about slower growth; muddles its message for nearly two hours by inadvertently omitting crucial sentence from its original statement noting that it believes inflation expectations are still 'well contained'; omitting phrase, which has been standard in Fed statements in recent months, initially suggests to Fed watchers that officials might be more worried about return of self-perpetuating inflationary psychology of 1970's and 1980's; about five minutes before stock markets close at 4 pm, central bank announces it made mistake and issues new statement that includes traditional reassurance about 'well-contained expectations'; acknowledges that sharp rise in oil prices has taken toll on economy, but cites continued rise in employment, trend that reduces pressure to spur consumer spending with low borrowing costs; graph (M)

headline: AstraZeneca faces EU fine
Deloitte to Pay $50 Million to Settle Adelphia Case
World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Profit Declines At Airline
abstract: Singapore Airlines posted its first profit decline in eight quarters as fuel prices surged and an increase in the number of low-fare competitors caused ticket prices to fall. Net income in the three months that ended March 31 fell 38 percent, to 297.8 million Singapore dollars ($181 million) from 477.9 million Singapore dollars a year earlier, the airline said.

headline: North Korea unloads atom fuel
Wanted: Deft Turnaround Artist
abstract: Morgan Stanley's board had been contemplating a successor for Philip J. Purcell for several weeks. Now it actually has a job to fill.    Mr. Purcell said yesterday that he had agreed to step down as Morgan Stanley's chairman and chief executive, ending an intense battle with a group of former senior executives who had been calling since March for his ouster. About that time, the board told Spencer Stuart, the global executive search firm, to start keeping its eye on potential directors who might be able to succeed Mr. Purcell, according to a person close to the process.

headline: Kashmiris seek united peace effort
Canada's Liberal Chief Wins Conservative Ally for Do-or-Die Vote
abstract: Prime Minister Paul Martin lures Belinda Stronach, leading conservative, into his cabinet, giving him crucial ally for budget vote on which government will survive or fall; Stronach says she could no longer serve in Conservative Party because it had aligned itself with separatist Bloc Quebecois to defeat Martin government (S)

headline: The Cellphone That Does Everything Imaginable, at Least Sort Of
abstract: David Pogue article on Samsung's new MM-A800 cellphone for Sprint that scan scan business cards, record 90-minute videos, play TV shows and even transcribe dictatated speech; drawing (M)

headline: 'Most dangerous' in China: An editor
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,726 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:    CHARETTE, Holly A., 21, Lance Cpl., Marines; Cranston, R.I.; Second Marine Division.    PINEDA. Carlos, 23, Cpl., Marines; Los Angeles; Second Marine Division.

headline: Union and Fund Join Forces in Bid for Canadian Steel Maker
abstract: United Steelworkers of America and Tricap Management, reorganizing fund led by Brascan Corp, form partnership in effort to take control of bankrupt Canadian steel maker Stelco; move comes despite decision by Stelco management not to sell to outside investors; value of Tricap and union proposal is put at 1.35 billion Canadian dollars (M)

headline: Drop That Ledger! This Is the Compliance Officer
abstract: DAVID C. FARRELL held up a half-inch-thick document titled ''Enron Code of Ethics 2000,'' and stared across a table at four colleagues sitting in a conference room at Sun Microsystems' campus-style office complex here in Silicon Valley.    ''I wave this around at meetings to make a point,'' Mr. Farrell said. ''It's not enough just to write a code of ethics. The management and the people who work at a company have to lead by example. We call it 'the tone at the top.'''

headline: People
abstract: Trevor Beattie, chairman and creative director at the London office of TBWA Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, left to open a new agency, Beattie McGuinness Bungay, London, that will focus on branded entertainment, product placement and sponsorship. Andrew McGuinness, chief executive at TBWA London, and Bill Bungay, deputy creative director there, left with Mr. Beattie to form the new agency. Paul Bainsfair, president at TBWA Europe, assumes the additional posts of chairman and chief executive at TBWA London.    Jason Press, senior partner and director for client services at the flagship New York office of G2 Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group division of the WPP Group, was promoted to president for New York. He succeeds Steven Gilliatt, who left, the agency said.    David Simpson was named general manager of a new United States office of Duval Guillaume, Brussels, to be opened in New York. He had been senior vice president for business development at Pedone & Partners, New York.    Lily Siu was named managing director for a new Chinese operation of JWT Specialized Communication, part of the JWT division of the WPP Group, overseeing offices in Shanghai and Hong Kong. She had been country manager for Greater China at TMP Worldwide, part of Monster Worldwide, based in Shanghai.

headline: Shipments of children, a darkly growing trade
Balance Sheet: Auditors make easy targets
Merck's Chief Steps Down; Company Insider Replaces Him
abstract: Richard T. Clark was promoted to replace Raymond V. Gilmartin, who presided over mounting Vioxx suits and falling revenues.

Pope John Paul Appraised as Pope, Not Rock Star
abstract: Critic's Notebook: panoramic television coverage of death of Pope John Paul II has described him, almost compulsively, as a rock star; what is harder to divine in television images is his identity as Roman Catholic (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WORLDWIDE RESTAURANT CONCEPTS INC., Sherman Oaks, Calif., a restaurant operator, said it agreed to be bought by closely held Pacific Equity Partners, an Australian investment company, for about $208 million in cash.    WEST PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC., Lionville, Pa., a maker of rubber and plastic parts for the drug and consumer industry, said it agreed to buy the closely held Tech Group Inc., Scottsdale, Ariz., a maker of molds for plastic drug-delivery systems, for $140 million in cash.

headline: Changes at the Exchanges BringTheir Self-Regulation Into Question
abstract: New York Stock Exchange's plan to acquire Archipelago Holdings, operator of electronic trading system, calls into question future of self-regulation system that exchanges use to oversee their markets and conduct of their members; at issue is whether self-regulation works, given recent history, with prime examples being price-fixing scandal at Nasdaq and floor-trading probes and indictments at New York Stock Exchange; NYSE-Archipelago deal says regulation will come from independent not-for-profit oprganization (Market Place column) (M)

French vote could push the ECB to lower rates
Lender's Shutdown Upheld
abstract: A New York State appellate court has upheld a lower court ruling that closed a high-cost-loan operation marketing to military families near Fort Drum in upstate New York.    The business, N.Y. Catalog Sales, had portrayed itself as a legitimate business that sold gift certificates for catalog merchandise and allowed its customers to write and cash checks for more than the amount of their purchases.

headline: Spain's Parliament legalizes gay marriage
France Is Offering Stake in State-Owned Gas Giant
abstract: French government in defiance of furious trade unions, puts about one-fifth of Gaz de France up for sale to help pay down national debt and help company tackle foreign challenges; government is expected to raise up to 4 billion euros ($4.8 billion) by selling 22 percent of company; Gaz chief Jean-Francois Cirelli comments; photo (M)

headline: F.B.I. Is Accused of Ignoring Abuse of 2 Americans in Pakistan
abstract: Human Rights Watch charges FBI agents repeatedly interrogated two Pakistanis with US citizenship when they were illegally detained in Pakistan and did nothing to stop them from being tortured by Pakistani authorities; Zain and Kashan Afzal were arrested at their Karachi home last August and held in secret detention for eight months; photo; Zain says he and brother were trained in 1999 to fight in Kashmir but did not do so; they were questioned about Al Qaeda links, which they deny (S)

headline: U.S. blocks KLM flight to Mexico
India's national carriers fly under heavy burden
U.S. Automakers Lose Ground to Rivals
abstract: Auto sales rose in March, though domestic carmakers continued to lose ground to foreign competitors; sales at General Motors fell 1.5 percent and were down 4.9 percent at Ford Motor from month year earlier, while Nissan Motor reports 12.6 percent increase, first time company sold more than 100,000 cars and trucks in US in one month; sales at Toyota Motor and Honda Motor were up 12.3 percent and 6.9 percent, respectively; auto sales over all rose 0.8 percent in March, to seasonally adjusted rate of 16.8 million cars and trucks; outlook for nation's largest auto parts supplier, Delphi Corp, continue to darken with report that FBI and US Postal Service have joined Securities and Exchange Commission in probing widening accounting scandal that has already led to ouster of some of company's top executives; charts (M)

headline: Time Warner and Comcast Are Cleared to Buy Adelphia
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Robert Gerber clears say for Time Warner and Comcast to proceed with acquisition of Adelphia Communications; approves $440 million breakup fee, payable to Time Warner and Comcast, if another bidder should better their $17.6 billion offer (M)

headline: Cinderella Pitches Booster Seats
abstract: Buena Vista Home Entertainment has teamed up with the Advertising Council to create new public service advertising that features scenes from its classic cartoon ÂCinderellaÂ and promotes the use of car booster seats by young children.

headline: Guilty plea is expected in General Re inquiry
Investors Force Out German Market's Top Leaders
abstract: Foreign hedge funds brought down two of Germany's most visible business figures on Monday, as the chief executive and the supervisory board chairman of Deutsche Börse resigned in the face of unrelenting opposition from funds that own company shares.    The investors had taken aim at the company's leaders after its chief executive, Werner G. Seifert, announced a $2.5 billion takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange in December. A barrage of protests from Deutsche Börse shareholders forced Mr. Seifert to withdraw the offer in March.

headline: Land of the Free, Home of the Blog
abstract: As PepsiCo's president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi has given all sorts of speeches. None, though, fired up passions like the one she gave last month at the Columbia Business School.    In trying to extol the benefits of cultural sensitivity when doing business abroad, Ms. Nooyi employed the metaphor of a hand and compared America's reputation to that of the middle finger. ''If used inappropriately -- just like the U.S. itself -- the middle finger can convey a negative image,'' she said.

headline: Asia Letter: About a kidnap victim, DNA testing and doubt
PartyGaming shares hit jackpot, rising 11%
Annan rebuffs India's hopes for an expanded UN role

4 bomb attacks kill 8 as Iran readies for vote
Pension Loopholes Helped United Hide Troubles
abstract: Analysis by Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp shows loopholes in federal pension law allowed United Airlines to treat its pension fund as solid for years, when in fact it was dangerously weakening; findings will be presented at Senate Finance Committee hearing; second report, by comptroller general, finds that most companies that operate pension funds are using same loopholes; those loopholes give companies says to make their pension plans look healthier than they really are, reducing amount of money companies must contribute; chart; photo (M)

headline: Basque vote may force showdown over autonomy plan
Print Insists It's Here to Stay
abstract: Fanciful views of what lies ahead on futuristic magazine covers are part of $40 million, three-year Magazine Publishers of America campaign to win advertisers and try to convince them that magazines will continue to survive; Newspaper Association of America has also begun multimillion-dollar, three-year drive to make over its image in eyes of advertisers from stodgy to contemporary; it is first time that magazines have joined together in large-scale marketing effort; photos (M)

headline: Seoul warns North against nuclear test
Video Marches On, Without a Standard
abstract: Absence of standard for next generation of high-definition DVD's, players and recorders does not prevent Tweeters, high-end consumer electronics chain, from ordering disc player that Toshiba plans to release this year; Toshiba's machine, costing upwards of $1,000, will be able to play only 89 movies from three studios, but Tweeters believes hard-core video fanatics will buy them all the same; Toshiba, Sanyo and NEC are championing HD DVD format; Sony, Matsushita and Hewlett-Packard back rival Blu-ray format; photo (M)

headline: Polishing Up Chicago's Theater District
abstract: The final phase of a decade-long effort to establish a theater district in the Loop, the central business district here, has begun with a $36 million project to restore the historic Shubert Theater and to convert the upper floors of the Majestic Building, which houses the Shubert, into a hotel.     The Shubert has been a prime venue for Broadway shows -- including ''South Pacific,'' ''A Chorus Line'' and ''Rent'' -- and most recently for the pre-Broadway run of ''Monty Python's Spamalot.''

headline: Judge in Italy Sentences 11 in Collapse of Parmalat
abstract: A year and a half after the collapse of the Italian food company Parmalat, a judge in Milan has convicted and sentenced 11 people on charges of market manipulation, obstructing a regulatory investigation and falsifying audits.     The sentences meted out on Tuesday -- the first in the case -- ranged from 10 months to two and a half years. All 11 had made plea bargains and none are likely to spend time in prison; nine of the sentences were suspended.

headline: Is It Time to Upgrade?
abstract: A new study by the Consumer Electronics Association shows that American homes spent $1,250, on average, for electronics last year. Though it may sound like a lot, that is barely enough for a medium-size flat-screen TV. So even gadget-crazy Americans have to weigh priorities -- deciding what older gear they can still live with and what demands an upgrade.    For shoppers, it can be a difficult decision: buy products on sale that have last year's technology, or get the latest even if it means paying more. (Or perhaps wait even longer, for the next generation.)

headline: Betting It All (Literally) to Make a Dream Film
abstract: With almost $3 million riding on his latest movie, the producer Robert Newmyer has broken an unwritten rule of Hollywood film financing: always use other people's money.    Mr. Newmyer, 48, is no dilettante. He has had big commercial successes with ''Training Day'' and ''The Santa Clause'' and critical acclaim (generally much less profitable) with ''Sex, Lies and Videotape.'' More recently, his Outlaw Productions produced ''Mindhunters'' and ''The Thing About My Folks,'' which was shot on high-definition tape and cost about $3 million (of somebody else's money) to make.

headline: Telecom Italia Is Said to Sell a Phone Stake
abstract: Texas Pacific Group and Apax Partners, private equity firms, reportedly will acquire Telecom Italia's controlling stake in Greek phone company TIM Hellas Telecommunications for $1.4 billion (M)

headline: European Union Leaders Seek to Calm Nerves After 2 Defeats
abstract: European leaders have not properly explained to their people why their countries need radical economic change, two top European officials said a day after the European Union was tipped into crisis by the second rejection of its proposed constitution.    The European commissioner for economic affairs, Joaquín Almunia, attributed the hostility of voters in France and the Netherlands, who rejected the constitution by wide margins on Sunday and Wednesday, to a basic communications gap between the public and its leaders.

headline: Prominent anti-Syrian journalist killed in Beirut
Little Bang From Bullish Comments by Fed Chairman
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said this week that the economy was on a ''reasonably firm footing'' and argued that even a decline in housing prices would not have a substantial impact on the economy.    But the stock market did not get much of a boost when Mr. Greenspan testified before Congress on Thursday. The market's three main gauges were little changed yesterday, leaving the market with minimal gains for the week.

headline: Indonesians mourn rescuers killed in crash
E.W. Scripps to Buy Shopzilla
abstract: The media company E.W. Scripps said yesterday that it intended to buy Shopzilla, a privately held online comparison shopping site, for $525 million.    The announcement came just days after eBay, the online marketplace, said it would buy Shopping.com, a Shopzilla rival, for $620 million.

headline: Currencies: Worries on Europe strengthen dollar
Much looks familiar in Kyrgyz regime
Demand for Natural Gas Brings Big Import Plans, and Objections
abstract: International energy companies, Bush administration and governments in gas-rich countries aggressively promote global market for natural gas as more plentiful and less polluting than oil, at time when US is already running low on production and facing need to import vast amounts of liquified natural gas in tankers; Pres Bush endorses legislation to allow Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to overrule states wary of big LNG terminals, but faces opponents like California Sen Dianne Feinstein; energy companies want to construct more than forty such terminals costing $500- to $1-billion each; photo; graph of imports; map showing East and West Coast ports where communities are wary of LNG terminals and Gulf of Mexico ports more friendly to projects; natural gas, which accounts for 24 percent of US energy consumption, is expected to overtake coal and rival oil as leading fossil fuel in world by 2025; advantages of convenience, cost and possibly supply explained; Qatar, set to become world's largest LNG exporter, joins 12 other gas-rich nations including Iran, Egypt, Nigeria and Venezuela in setting up Gas Exporting Countries Forum, with goal of keeping prices satisfactorily high (M)

headline: Preserving Our Readers' Trust
abstract: Last fall, roughly a year after your acceptance of the Siegal Committee recommendations on our newsroom's culture, you asked us to take a fresh look at some of the steps we had taken to increase readers' confidence in The Times. You asked about anonymous sources and whether the paper had done everything possible to minimize their occurrence and maximize our candor when using them. You asked whether we could cut our error rate by a significant amount and thereby give readers greater confidence in our reliability. You asked us to look beyond our walls and investigate our industry's best practices: Are other leading papers taking steps that we should adopt to reinforce our readers' trust in us? And you were notably concerned about the din of outside criticism, about what seemed to be an unceasing drumfire from both left and right, amplified by the passions of the presidential election campaign and the wondrous reach of the Internet. Was it any longer possible to stand silent and stoic under fire?

headline: Álvaro Cunhal, 91, Portuguese Communist leader
Profit Down 13% at Canadian Bank
abstract: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Wednesday that profit fell 13 percent in the second quarter.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Approves New Home for Evacuated Gaza Settlers
abstract: Israel's cabinet approves plan for new community along country's Mediterranean coast for Jewish settlers who will be removed from Gaza Strip when Israel withdraws from area this summer; move is intended to persuade settlers, all staunchly opposed, to cooperate with evacuation; in southern Gaza, Israeli security forces scuffle with about 100 Jewish settlers and supporters as army demolishes 11 derelict beach cottages that supporters planned to occupy while helping settlers demonstrate against planned evacuation; confrontation seen as precursor to larger showdowns that could occur when security forces move in to uproot nearly 9,000 settlers in mid-Aug; photo; map (M)

headline: A Pageant of Accessories. And Video Games Too.
abstract: Video game accessories are seen gaining new prominence as video game market matures, and as its prime movers, including Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo, are striving harder to make electronic entertainment more mainstream; at Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, annual video game trade show being held in Los Angeles this week, game peripherals, as such products are generally known, are being introduced with almost as much fanfare as games themselves; NPD Group, market research firm, reports $1.1 billion in sales of accessories for console and portable video games in United States last year; photos of some new accessories (L)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: Correction Appended

headline: Haggling Continues on Bolton Vote, Now Planned for Monday
abstract: With his nomination to be ambassador to the United Nations hanging in the balance, John R. Bolton made a hurried trip to Capitol Hill on Thursday afternoon to meet with two of his chief Democratic critics.     The Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, delayed a vote on the Bolton nomination until Monday.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: 5 Teenagers Die In School Bus Collision
abstract: Five teenage girls were killed and dozens of other students hospitalized when their school bus collided with two cars, fell on its side and slid off the road in Navan, outside Dublin. Many of the students had to be pulled from the wreckage by emergency services. Transport Minister Martin Cullen promised to investigate the cause of the accident.   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: Rebels claim control of Uzbek border town
Japan and South Korea Brace for a Tense Meeting
abstract: Pres Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea and Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi of Japan will hold what is expected to be tense summit meeting after months of strained relations over disputed territory and Japan's militaristic past; Roh is expected to state his objections to Koizumi's visits to shrine where 14 war criminals are deified, and to urge Tokyo to build separate war memorial (M)

headline: Europeans Fast Falling Away From Church
abstract: Urgent need to revitalize Catholic Church in Europe is cited as major reason why world's cardinals may choose European as new pope; only 90 priests wereordained in all of France last year, forcing many priests to cover several parishes; Pope John Paul II tried in dozens of trips around Continent to bring back European Catholics who had fallen away, but it was disappointing exercise; those attending Mass weekly number only 10 percent of all Catholics in Netherlands, 12 percent in France, 15 percent in Germany and Austria, 18 percent in Spain and 25 percent in Italy; photos (M)

headline: European Court Urges Turkey to Grant Kurdish Leader a New Trial
abstract: European Human Rights Court upholds earlier decision that 1999 trial of Kurdish separatist leader Abdullah Ocalan was unfair and that Turkey should reopen case; cites extended period of time he was held before standing trial and limited time given for him to prepare defense; Turkey could jeopardize its application to join European Union if it refuses to revisit case; many people in Turkey worry that reopening case could reignite fires of Kurdish nationalism; it could also rekindle sense of Turkish nationalism, which could further complicate country's efforts to join EU; although court is not European Union body, defying its wishes could put Turkey in breach of European Convention on Human Rights, to which all EU members must belong (M)

headline: Omnicom Creating Third Media Agency
abstract: Omnicom Group is starting third media agency, Prometheus Media Services, to be based in Chicago (S)

headline: Pakistan and Indiaremove a barrier
New round of peace talks starts for Aceh
EU offers China hope on embargo
Book Report: Tales of hubris
Rally by Israeli Rightists Is Foiled
Bus hits rebel land mine in Nepal
Wireless: Cellular 'callback service' eliminates roaming shock
On Screens, but Not Store Shelves: Casual Games
abstract: In recent years "casual games," sold only online and downloaded into personal computers, have quietly found major audiences.

headline: GE to invest more in 'green' technology
U.S. open to negotiation
Wieden Spot for Honda Wins New York Award
abstract: Advertising Club of New York presents annual International Andy Awards; London office of Wieden & Kennedy wins top prize (S)

headline: Associated Press Aims to Expand Its Horizons
abstract: Associated Press's chief executive, Tom Curley, seeks to raise revenue by offering new products and expanding globally; plans to introduce Internet database system, called eAP, that will deliver news, photographs, video and sound clips with identifying codes that enable AP to track how many times articles are used by client; plans to charge newspapers for republication of its articles online, move that could be backed with enforcement unit; has shaken up foreign bureaus with forced retirements and departures of top editors, many in their 50's and 60's who were not covered by union contracts; photos (M)

headline: Camcorder Weds Hard Drive, Photos to Follow
abstract: New JVC camcorder uses no removable recording medium, just a large hard drive; photo (M)

headline: On the horizon: Higher-risk funds
9 Are Reported Killed in 4th Day of Afghan Protests
abstract: Anti-American violence continued across Afghanistan today, as at least nine people were reported to have been killed in a fourth day of demonstrations and clashes with the police.

headline: Hundreds Protest Mugabe's Victory in Zimbabwe's Election
Bluetooth, Uniting Computer and Printer
abstract: A Bluetooth Path To the Printer    Q. Is it possible to print wirelessly over a Bluetooth connection?    A. Bluetooth, the wireless technology named after a 10th-century Viking king who united Denmark and Norway, can indeed be used for printing -- if you have the right equipment on both sides of the connection. Although it was sometimes confused with Wi-Fi wireless networking when first introduced, Bluetooth is intended to replace the cables used for short-range connections, like those from a computer to a printer or from a personal organizer to a laptop.

headline: EU oversight for new media?
As Technology Transforms Music, Billboard Magazine Changes, Too
abstract: Billboard, music industry magazine, has undergone redesign, with less cluttered cover and expanded coverage of topics like marketing and unsigned bands; president and publisher John Kilcullen says he expects eye-catching covers to help newsstand sales; photos (M)

headline: As the cookie crumbles, winners galore in lottery
White House opposes plan to trim UN dues
New era for videoconferencing software
Court Says Cable Operators Don't Have to Give Access to Rivals
abstract: The ruling is a blow to consumer groups who want more competition in Internet services and to the leading providers of dial-up Internet service.

headline: China can control AIDS, prime minister tells UN
Accommodations Improve for Arriving Cardinals
abstract: Behind Vatican's guarded gates, 117 cardinals arriving from all around world to elect pope's successor will stay at Santa Marta Residence, $20 million hotel built by pope for that purpose; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: No-Shows Extend Political Morass
abstract: Kyrgyzstan Parliament fails to get enough delegates to accept resignation of Pres Askar Akayev, who is in exile in Moscow, Russia; Omurbek Tekebayev, parliamentary speaker, reports that he will remain president (S)

headline: U.S. copter crash kills 4 crew and 12 others
Sudan Poses First Big Trial for World Criminal Court
abstract: United Nations Security Council asks International Criminal Court to investigate atrocities in Sudan, placing court in international spotlight three years after it opened over United States opposition; new institution in The Hague is still wrestling with mechanics of how to carry out mandate to deal with large-scale human rights abuses; it faces high expectations but lacks practical experience; it is under pressure to act swiftly on conflict in Darfur, where as many as 300,000 people have been killed and more than two million others displaced; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Holiday For Hirohito
abstract: Japanese lawmakers overwhelmingly voted to honor Emperor Hirohito by renaming a national holiday to be celebrated in his honor starting in 2007. Showa Day, as it will be called, will be held on Hirohito's birthday, April 29, which is now a holiday called Green Day. Hirohito, whose rule lasted from 1926 until his death in 1989, is regarded by most Asians and some Japanese as a symbol of Japanese militarism and aggression in Asia, and he is still a revered figure for Japanese nationalists. But most Japanese now associate him with the postwar years of the Showa era, during which Japan rebuilt itself and became the world's No.2 economy. Two previous attempts to rename the holiday, in 2000 and 2002, were shelved in consideration of Asian sensitivities, but growing nationalism allowed the law's enactment this time. The holiday had been known as Emperor's Day before Hirohito's death, but was changed to Green Day to avoid an Asian reaction and to honor the emperor's interest in nature.   Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

headline: U.S. Panel's Report Criticizes U.N.and Proposes Overhaul
abstract: Congressionally mandated task force reports that United Nations suffers from poor management, 'dismal' staff morale and lack of accountability and professional ethics; urges United States to support broad changes proposed by Secretary General Kofi Annan; panel says UN should install corporate style oversight bodies and personnel standards to improve performance; it calls on UN to create rapid reaction capability from its member states' armed forces to prevent genocide, mass killing and sustained major human rights violations before they occur; bipartisan task force includes former diplomats, military and intelligence officials and leaders of conservative and liberal political institutes; co-chairmen are Republican former House speaker Newt Gingrich and Democratic former Senate majoriy leader George J Mitchell (M)

headline: Pop culture takes aim at North Korea's Kim
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stock Exchange to Buy Electronic Trading Firm  The New York Stock Exchange announced that it would acquire a leading electronic trading system in a deal that allows the exchange to become a public company and casts doubts on its 213-year old system of auction trading.     The exchange will merge its operations with Archipelago, one of the biggest electronic trading operators, to form the N.Y.S.E. Group. The deal will give the exchange's 1,366 seat holders $400 million in cash and 70 percent of the shares of the combined, publicly traded company. [Page A1.]    Inflation Fears Cause Stocks to Fall  Fears of rising inflation sent stocks to new lows for the year after the government reported a sharp increase in consumer prices that all but guaranteed the Federal Reserve will continue to push interest rates higher even as the economy may be slowing. [A1.]    NBC Names New Leader for ''Today''  NBC named Jim Bell executive producer of its troubled ''Today,'' promising new energy and fresh ideas to reinvigorate the program. [C7]    Earnings at Ford Decline 38 Percent  Citing rising gasoline prices and falling sales, Ford Motor said that its first-quarter profit fell 38 percent, to $1.2 billion. Ford said it would break even at best in the second quarter by cutting production of cars and trucks by 5 percent in Europe and North America. Executives also said the company was considering selling its Hertz rental car division, or other alternatives related to the business, to shore up its cash reserves. [C3.]    Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, said its first-quarter profit almost tripled. [C18.]    Ebay said profits rose 28 percent in the first quarter and revenues topped $1 billion, slightly beating analyst expectations. [C5.]    Judge Rules Against Oil Companies  A judge said oil companies must defend dozens of lawsuits accusing them of fouling groundwater by using a gasoline additive. [C2.]    Eight Traders Leave Morgan Stanley  Morgan Stanley was shaken by another round of defections as eight senior traders left the firm for Deutsche Bank. [C3.]    Acelas Set to Run Again in Summer  Amtrak said that its Acela Express trains, which were found to have faulty brakes, would return to service sometime in the summer, and that in the meantime it was bringing back its Metroliners to replace them. [A16.]    Deal Near for Allied Domecq  Pernod Ricard and Fortune Brands are set to announce that they are proceeding with plans to jointly acquire Allied Domecq. [C4.]    Japan Still Closed to U.S. Beef  Six months after American negotiators thought they had a deal to resume beef exports to Japan, the market remains closed, because of a one case of mad-cow disease detected in Washington State in December 2003. [C4.]    Growing Tension Over China Policy  After nearly two years of fruitless ''financial diplomacy'' toward China on exchange rates, the White House faces a growing rebellion from Congress. Senate Democrats are threatening to block President Bush's nominee for United States trade representative, Congressman Rob Portman of Ohio, above. [C11.]    When Consumers Become Inventors  How users of products become innovators. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. [C2.]    Against Odds, Starting Magazines  More people are starting magazines, and some are even succeeding. Small Business. [C6.]    All-in-One Entertainment Devices  New multimedia systems can record, store and manage music, movies and television shows, and showcase them on high-definition screens and in surround-sound audio, all with a click of the remote. Circuits. [C9.]

headline: Nortel's No. 2 Resigns After Three Months
abstract: The Nortel Networks Corporation said on Friday that its No.2 officer had resigned after three months because of professional differences with the chief executive.    The executive, Gary Daichendt, had been president and chief operating officer. The chief technology officer, Gary Kunis, who was recruited by Mr. Daichendt, also quit.

headline: Ex-official says he has copies of Arroyo tape
DaimlerChrysler Must Pay Kerkorian
abstract: While the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian lost his billion-dollar fraud lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler last month, a judge says he is entitled to $556,061 from the company for failing to produce crucial documents until late in the trial in 2003.    ''Sanctions are warranted,'' Judge Joseph J. Farnan Jr. of Federal District Court wrote in his 10-page ruling, which was dated April 20.

headline: Karzai demands justice for abused prisoners
Mourners In Many Lands Watch Funeral Of Globetrotter
abstract: Millions of people around world watch Pope John Paul II's funeral; huge outdoor screens are set up in nearly every community in Poland; 800,000 people gather in Krakow at field where pope had celebrated Masses; photos (M)

headline: Facing a digital world
3 Killed in Kurdish Rebels' Attack in Turkey
DataBank; Stock Markets Tumble to New Lows for the Year
abstract: Roundup of stock market performance for week; Dow Jones lost 373.83 points, or 3.6 percent, to 10,087.51; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 38.58 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,142.62; Nasdaq composite index dropped 91.20 points, or 4.6 percent, to 1,908.15; graphs (M)

headline: Push for autonomy develops in Iraqi south
A Race to Save Sudan's Past From Progress
abstract: Far north of Khartoum, where modern steel bridges cross this legendary river, the architecture goes way back in time -- thousand-year-old temples, towering pyramids, elaborate cities from civilizations that lived and died and were then buried by the surging sand.    The uncovering of these ancient wonders has proceeded slowly but steadily over the last century as archaeologists have sifted through the earth for clues of the great Nilotic cultures that once flourished in Sudan.

headline: Your Child Got Into an Ivy! Do You Have to Say Yes?
abstract: Hubert Herring column explores question of whether parents should bankrupt themselves to put their children through Ivy League schools; drawing (M)

headline: After Winning One Campaign, Blair Is Facing Another Against Him, in His Own Party
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain is confronting widening debate about his tenure in office, just three days after national vote that gave him historic third term; issue that has emerged since his re-election is whether Labor Party is so riven by doubt after hearing voters' complaints about him that party rebels will now be able to undermine his tenure (M)

headline: Cable's New Pitch: Reach Out and Touch Someone
abstract: LIKE most people, Jay Fields took his phone service for granted. He paid more than $100 a month -- no questions asked -- to Verizon Communications for a local and long-distance plan and a host of services like call forwarding and caller ID.    But when he saw advertisements for a newfangled Internet-based phone service that his local cable provider, Cablevision, was offering, he had no bones about switching five months ago. His says his new connection sounds just as good as his old phone, yet he pays just $34.95 for unlimited local and long-distance calling, as well as call waiting and a half-dozen other services.

headline: Israeli Arab uses feet to bridge a gap
Investors back Gillette
Forget About Milk and Bread. Give Me Gossip!
abstract: Tired of celebrity coverage? Millions of readers can't get enough -- and neither can advertisers. Publishers of celebrity magazines that once looked to newsstand and checkout-aisle sales for almost all of their revenue are now experiencing surges in subscriptions and ad sales, bringing in the kind of money that could make a movie star jealous.    Us Weekly's ad pages are up nearly 25 percent in the last year, and at Star Magazine, ads are up almost 17 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. In Touch Weekly's ads have risen nearly 22 percent.

headline: U.S. weighs recourse to UN Council on N. Korea
Corporate Rules in Europe Have Been Flexible, but Change Is Coming
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on growing number of European nations that are adopting corporate governance rules similar to those being adopted by American companies in wake of enactment of Sarbanes-Oxley Act; says in Spain, some previously voluntary parts of code are now mandatory; holds German government, not happy that many big German companies chose to ignore code provision calling on them to disclose pay of top executives, says it will pass law requiring disclosure by most companies; says British government has announced plans for new law, to be passed if Labor government is re-elected next month, to change corporate law in ways that may make British legal scene closer to American one; graph (M)

headline: Obituary: Percy Heath, 81, of Modern Jazz Quartet
Why the Baby Boomers Won't Wreck the Market
abstract: YOU'VE probably heard the predictions that a prolonged bear market will begin as the baby boomers retire and sell their stocks. While the historical record provides some support for such a view, a new study suggests that the consequences of the population's aging will not be anything nearly that bad.    The study, by James M. Poterba, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has found that changes in the proportion of retirees in the population have only a modest impact on stock market returns. So while the market is likely to come under some downward pressure from the retirement of boomers over the next couple of decades, he says he believes that there is no reason to expect the effects to be severe.

headline: Next Challenge for the Church: Choosing a Successor
Iraqis Expressed Ambivalence About Direction of Country
abstract: Their feelings were often murky - an indication of the ever-shifting nature of the war and the fog over the political landscape.

Separating the elite from the chaff
World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Calls For A New Rights Body
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan announces that current 53-nation Human Rights Council needs to be replaced by smaller more dedicated group chosen for strong human rights records; suggested change is part of current reforms package (S)

headline: In Small Trial, Gene Therapy Is Seen as Aid in Alzheimer's
abstract: Ceregene founder Mark H Tuszynski reports small clinical trial produced preliminary evidence that gene therapy may slow decline in mental functioning in patients with early-stage Alzheimer's disease; company says trial is first of gene therapy for Alzheimer's; gene involved controls production of nerve growth factor, protein that can protect brain cells from death (M)

headline: Paris firm takes a global leap
Stocks: Rise in oil price adds to jitters on Wall Street
Seven aid group workers killed in Afghanistan
Limited Brands' Earnings Decline
abstract: Limited Brands, owner of the Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works chains, said yesterday that profit for the fourth quarter fell 1.3 percent because of costs to correct lease accounting.    Net income dropped to $382.5 million, from $387.6 million a year earlier, Limited said. Profit rose to 87 cents a share, from 74 cents, because the company bought back stock. Limited had said in a preliminary earnings statement Feb. 24 that profit climbed to $415.8 million, or 95 cents a share.

headline: At the BBC, the weather has blown up a storm
French utility settles its differences with Italy
When the Entire Game Is Too Much
abstract: Some of most successful online offerings from professional sports organizations let casual sports fans view most exciting moments of events; sports leagues are opening their video vaults online to fans who just want highlights; such tools can be critical in maintaining, or increasing, overall league revenues; photo (M)

headline: Indian airlines lead in deals at air show
Iraq Takes Step Toward New Government
abstract: Iraqi national assembly appoints speaker and two deputy speakers, taking first step, toward installing new government; speaker is Hajim M al-Hassani, prominent Sunni Arab, and deputies are Hussain al-Shahristani, Shiite Arab, and Arif Taifour, Kurd; although steps are more symbolic than substantive, it shows that various parties could at least resolve their differences on minor issues; first significant move will occur if assembly agrees on president and two vice presidents; photo (M)

headline: Free Flow: A new look for U.S. air security?
Bristol-Myers Seen Settling Case by U.S.
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb is expected to agree to pay nearly $300 million to end Justice Department criminal investigation into its accounting practices; that would be on top of $389 million in civil settlements reached with investors in last year and $150 million company was fined by SEC; in addition, agreement is said to require Bristol-Myers to establish government-supervised compliance and disclosure and ethics programs to prevent type of accounting manipulation that prompted investigation, 'channel stuffing,' in which company paid incentives to its wholesalers to stockpile inventory, making it appear as if sales were higher than they actually were (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nortel Posts Loss
abstract: Nortel Networks reported a loss of $49 million in the first quarter on higher expenses and $21 million in charges, after posting a profit of $59 million in the period a year ago. Sales rose 3.8 percent in the quarter to $2.54 billion. The filing, which was released late yesterday afternoon without comment from the company, brings the telecommunications equipment maker's financial reporting up to date for the first time since March 2004. Nortel has been through a series of delays and restatements after a financial scandal led to the dismissal of several senior executives, including its chief executive, Frank Dunn. The company is still the subject of criminal and securities investigations in both the United States and Canada.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: Consumers power 3.5% growth in U.S.
Sent to Rescue Shiite Hostages, Iraqi Troops Find None
Italian Vote to Ease Fertility Law Fails for Want of Voters
abstract: A law that imposes strict rules on assisted fertility will remain on the books, after the failure on Monday of a hard-fought referendum that rubbed into one of Italy's sorest spots: the relationship between church and state.    The fight leading up to two days of voting on Sunday and Monday mobilized the nation's political and religious establishments like few others, as the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church -- including the new pope, Benedict XVI -- urged Italians to boycott the referendum.

headline: Obituaries: Eddie Albert, 'Green Acres' star and character actor, 99
Murbarak Rival in Egypt Pleads Not Guilty to Election Fraud

headline: Vintage postersframe a stylish past
Can 'Made in Europe' survive?
On the 'last frontier' of banking, cash rules
Stocks: Summer doldrums set in on Wall Street
Hundreds in Cairo Protest Assaults on Women
abstract: Several hundred people gathered in downtown Cairo on Wednesday to protest assaults last week on advocates of political change during the country's referendum about direct presidential elections.    Assaults on women in particular and sexual harassment of them had led to anger. Demonstrators contended that the attacks were sanctioned by the government. ''Our female colleague's honor is the nation's honor,'' read one of the banners in the protest on Wednesday.

headline: German warns EU it may lose strength
Bush teamurges vote on Bolton
Minivans power Honda's profit
Never Mind Justice. How About Just Deserts?
abstract: John Schwartz essay on difference between court justice and 'sublime justice'--in which investors crave more satisfying justice that comes from seeing somebody get what they think he truly deserves; offers example of former Enron chairman Kenneth Lay, who faces trial on fraud charges and who has paid Google to place ads that link searches about Enron and related topics to site that gives his side of story; some former employees repeatedly click on link just make Lay pay a little bit; drawing (M)

headline: Citigroup Is Acquiring Card Portfolio of Store Chain
abstract: Citigroup said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the credit card portfolio of Federated Department Stores, continuing a string of acquisitions that Citigroup has made to bolster a business in which it has been struggling to retain market share.    The bank will gain 17 million accounts as a result of the deal, a boon for Citigroup at a time when the credit card business over all has grown more competitive, with fewer consumers opening accounts.

abstract: International Labor Organization says at least 12.3 million people worldwide work as slaves or in other forms of forced labor, 2.5 million of them having been trafficked across borders and 1.2 million in sex trade; author Lee Swepston notes trafficking increase as border controls ease, especially in Europe, and more women are victimized (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: 18 New Cases Of Polio Found
abstract: Eighteen new cases of polio have been found in Yemen, and the country is ''now facing a major epidemic,'' Dr. David L. Heymann, the chief of polio eradication for the World Health Organization, said in Geneva. Four cases were identified in the Red Sea port of Al Hudaida on April 20, but the new ones have been found across the country, including in the capital, Sana. Yemen had been polio-free since 1996. Dr. Bruce Aylward, who coordinates the W.H.O. eradication campaign, said testing ''quite clearly'' showed that the strain had arrived recently and had come from Kano, in Nigeria, by way of Chad and Port Sudan, across the Red Sea. Yemen, worried about outbreaks in Sudan and Saudi Arabia, held a vaccination day for children this month, and more are planned. Health authorities are using a new monovalent oral vaccine that needs fewer doses to create immunity to type 1 polio, the strain circulating in Yemen.   Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesian Airline Picks Boeing
abstract: The Boeing Company is expected to sign a purchase agreement today with Lion Air of Indonesia, the company said. Amanda Landers, a spokeswoman for Boeing, which is based in Chicago, declined to comment about details of the order. Lion Air was expected to decide on as many as 60 Boeing 737's or Airbus SAS A320 planes as a replacement for its fleet of MD-80 aircraft, Joseph Nadol, an analyst at J.P. Morgan Securities, wrote in a report.

headline: Hollywood Hardball
abstract: Hollywood studio executives are outraged at aggressive proposal being shopped for film version of popular Microsoft Xbox video game Halo; studio executives, known for their lavish spending, winced at Microsoft demands, including $10 million upfront fee for rights, approval over cast and director, and 60 first-class plane tickets for Microsoft representatives and their guests to movie's premiere; DreamWorks SKG and Paramount Pictures have dropped out of bidding; two that remained, 20th Century Fox and Universal Pictures, balked at price; Microsoft, Universal and Fox have tentatively agreed to complex arrangement on reduced financial terms, though all parties say creative issues could still scuttle deal; chart; photos (M)

For Insurance Regulators, Trails Lead to Dublin
abstract: Financiers have helped transform Dublin into one of world's most innovative insurance providers; they have also turned Dublin into unlikely hot spot in growing insurance scandal that has toppled chief executives and even pulled investing legend Warren E Buffett into its orbit; at center of investigations is General Re Corp, unit of Berkshire Hathaway, holding company that includes Buffett's insurance operations; investigators are exploring General Re in connection with possible financial manipulation at some of world's largest and most prestigious insurers; General Re, which has substantial presence in Dublin, is one among dozens companies that have enjoyed surge in business since first venturing to Dublin in early 1990's; city's insurance industry is based in 40-acre self-contained business park, International Financial Services Center, where Irish government offers corporate tax rate far below rates other large European Union members impose on companies; center is home to hundreds of concerns that employ about 16,000; photos (M)

The future of the Varvatos brand, known for its mildly avant-garde approach in the typically conservative world of designer men's wear, had grown cloudy after the 2003 takeover of its parent company, Nautica Enterprises, by the VF Corporation.
