Morgan Stanley Plans toRehire Its Ex-President
abstract: Morgan Stanley's board is expected to elect John J Mack as chairman and chief executive, succeeding Philip J Purcell, man who forced him out as president in bitter power struggle in 2001; Mack's triumphant return seen as resounding victory for Morgan Stanley bankers and traders whose revolt against Purcell's leadership forced recalcitrant board to abandon its longstanding support of him; Purcell's status as outsider and Mack's renown as ultimate Morgan Stanley insider paved way for his return; several crucial matters remain unresolved; Mack has told board he wants return of former Morgan Stanley executives who left firm after management shake-up in Mar, including Vikram S Pandit; return of Pandit would antagonize Zoe Cruz, whom Purcell appointed co-president in Mar; managing rift between Pandit and Cruz will be severe test of Mack's skills as executive; photo (M)

Lawmakers in Mexico Approve Absentee Voting for Migrants
abstract: Mexican lawmakers gave final approval on Tuesday to a bill that would allow millions of immigrants living in the United States to vote by mail in the election for president to be held here next year.    The vote in the lower Chamber of Deputies ended a long political struggle over whether Mexicans living abroad should be able to influence the outcome of elections in their homeland. Migrants are legally allowed to vote and have dual citizenship, but they have been hampered by the lack of an absentee ballot system.

Freud and Schwarzenegger Can't Both Be Wrong
abstract: SOMETIMES a cigar is just a cigar, but not if one is a connoisseur like James E. Cayne, chairman and chief executive of Bear Stearns, and David G. Bronner, chief executive of the Retirement Systems of Alabama. For them, a cigar serves as ''protection and a weapon in the combat of life,'' as Sigmund Freud, who smoked up to 20 fat trabucos a day, once said.    That was demonstrated with Freudian ritualism last December when Mr. Cayne flew from New York to Montgomery, Ala., to discuss a lawsuit brought by Dr. Bronner's pension system against Bear Stearns over losses in WorldCom securities investments. Upon arriving in Dr. Bronner's office, Mr. Cayne sat down in a cushy armchair and lighted up. ''He had some kind of fancy cigar,'' Dr. Bronner recalled. ''He wouldn't even tell me the name of it.''

abstract: Rogers Communications, Canada's biggest cable television company and a leading wireless provider, made a stock-swap bid Wednesday for Call-Net Enterprises, which operates under the Sprint Canada name, that values the company at 330 million Canadian dollars ($267 million).    Call-Net, which is based in Toronto, has been Canada's most aggressive seller of alternative local telephone service. It also offers long-distance and Internet services to both consumers and businesses and owns a fiber optic network that covers most of Canada and portions of the United States.

headline: EU to investigate finance and energy

BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Google's Revenue Doubles On Sharply Higher Profit  Google's reported that its revenue for the first quarter nearly doubled from the comparable period a year ago, and its profits increased more than fivefold.    The fastest growth came from Google.com and other sites owned by the company, but it also posted sharp increases in revenue it receives from selling ads and placing them on other sites. [Page C3.]    Nokia, the largest maker of cellphones, reported a bigger-than-expected jump in profit and increased its sales forecast. [C5.]    AT&T and BellSouth topped Wall Street forecasts for the first quarter. [C3.]    $17.6 Billion Deal to Buy Adelphia  Time Warner and Comcast Corporation agreed to acquire Adelphia Communications for $17.6 billion in cash and stock, a deal that indicates that Time Warner is betting heavily on growth in its cable unit. As a result of the acquisition and several swaps with Comcast, Time Warner will end up with 85 percent of its subscribers in five regions with strong pockets of its systems in Texas and a dominant position in Los Angeles. [C4.]    Qwest Raises Offer for MCI  Qwest Communications has raised its takeover offer for MCI by 9 percent, to $30 a share, in its latest effort to wrest control of the long-distance carrier from Verizon Communications. [C3.]    Drug Companies in $1.6 Billion Deal  Shire Pharmaceuticals Group has agreed to pay $1.6 billion to acquire Transkaryotic Therapies, which has developed a version of an anemia-fighting protein. [C2.]    Raising the Curtain on Advertisers  Product placement has come to Broadway, with Hormel, maker of Spam canned meat, for example, endorsing the musical ''Monty Python's Spamalot.'' [A1.]    Pernod Seeks Further Expansion  Pernod Ricard of France plans to use its $14 billion purchase of Allied Domecq as a springboard to become the world's largest liquor company. [C5.]    Hynix Admits Guilt in Fixing Prices  Federal prosecutors announced that Hynix Semiconductor of South Korea had agreed to plead guilty to participating in a global conspiracy to fix prices and would pay a $185 million fine. [C3.]    Greenspan Urges Federal Restraint  Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged lawmakers to scale back promised benefits for both Social Security and Medicare ''sooner rather than later.'' [C2.]    Index of Leading Indicators Drops  The composite index of leading economic indicators fell 0.4 percent last month. [C2.]    Trade Nominee Answers Critics  Representative Rob Portman of Ohio, President Bush's nominee to be the trade representative, answered mounting criticism of the administration's trade policies by promising that he would take a stricter approach to China if he is confirmed [C2.]    House Approves Energy Bill  The House approved energy legislation that seeks to improve the electrical grid's reliability, increase domestic energy production and extend daylight saving time. [A14.]    Fuel Costs Hurt Airlines' Results  Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines reported steep first-quarter losses on higher fuel costs, while JetBlue Airways posted a modest profit. Gerald Grinstein, left, Delta's chief executive, asserted that despite its heavy losses, Delta was making major progress with its turnaround plan. [C4.]    First Phase of Tobacco Trial Ends  The government's racketeering case against cigarette companies reached the end of its first phase as lawyers disputed whether the companies had misled the public. [A19.]

headline: Wireless and Broadband Lift Verizon Profit by 47%
abstract: Verizon Communications says profit rose 47 percent in first quarter thanks to healthy demand for its wireless and broadband services; earned $1.8 billion compared with $1.2 billion year earliler; revenue grew 6.6 percent, to $18.2 billion, in quarter (M)6

headline: 'Far Side' Fans Hear Echo at The New Yorker
abstract: Last week's cartoon caption contest in The New Yorker could have been an example of art imitating art, or simply more proof to fans of Gary Larson that all roads lead to ''The Far Side.''     The winning entry, for an illustration showing two monster-movie dinosaurs speaking while devouring a city, was ''Remember that time you made me laugh and people came out of my nose?'' The punch line bore a marked similarity to a ''Far Side'' quip from 1985, although in the original, it was lions with antlers coming out of their noses.

headline: Saudis lobby to limit chemical liability

2 'No' Votes in Europe: The Anger Spreads
abstract: News Analysis: rejection of European Union's proposed constitution by French and Dutch voters will frustrate efforts of Europe's leaders to move to next stage of integration; impasse could stall efforts to develop common foreign policies and push euro, potent symbol of unification, into downward spiral; beyond issue of constitution, vote shows disaffection, perhaps rebellion, against political elites in France, Germany and Italy; many see idea of expanded Europe as challenge to cradle-to-grave social protections; they do not believe governing parties of left and right that claim painful, free-market economic reforms are only way toward rejuvenation, more jobs and better future (M)

headline: Car Bomb Kills Another Anti-Syria Politician in Beirut
abstract: Chillingly precise car bomb in Beirut kills George Hawi, sharp critic of Syria; photo; former Communist Party head has been campaigning for opposition candidates in final round of elections; small but deadly bomb under passenger seat appears identical to one that killed journalist Samir Kassir on June 2; both cause little other damage, with even Hawi's driver uninjured; Lebanese widely blame Syrian operatives, as in murder of Rafik Hariri in February (M)

headline: Polo Warns of Possible Problem With Credit Card Information
abstract: Fashion giant Polo Ralph Lauren says credit card information of some customers may have been put at risk; announcement comes after banking conglomerate HSBC begins sending letters to its GM-branded MasterCard holders of 'security breach' at unidentified 'national retailer' that may have compromised their accounts between June 2002 and December 2004 (M)

headline: Clear Channel in a Stealth Promotional Campaign
abstract: To the average listener, Radio Free Ohio has all the earmarks of pirate radio. For weeks, it sounded as if amateurs had been bleeding their voices into the broadcasts of stations in Akron, Ohio, owned by Clear Channel, the corporate radio giant. At the Web site www.radiofreeohio.com, there was a manifesto about ''corporate-controlled music playlists'' that took potshots at several local Clear Channel stations. But there was no information about who had posted the screed, or what exactly Radio Free Ohio was.    But last week it came out that Radio Free Ohio was not a prank on Clear Channel but in fact a prank by Clear Channel. Tomorrow, an AM station the company owns in Akron will switch formats from sports talk to progressive talk, and Clear Channel would very much like anyone suspicious of corporate media to tune in.

headline: With Interest: France's costly obsession
New Miniature Game Boy Due in Fall From Nintendo
abstract: Nintendo unveils Game Boy Micro, miniature version of its Game Boy Advance console; photo; gives only sketchy information about successor to its GameCube console, currently named Revolution (M)

A Quiet Life Touched by Scandal
abstract: John Houldsworth, former chief executive of Cologne Reinsurance, Dublin subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway that is suspected of helping American International Group manipulate accounts, is at center of investigation, suprise to colleagues and acquaintances who describe him as circumpsect and reserved; financial investigators want to know aobut transaction he helped arrange in 2000 between General Reinsurance, which owns Cologne Re, and AIG; that transaction is critical to broader probe that has hit highest levels at both companies (M)

A Crucial Window for Iraq: 15 Weeks to Pull Together
abstract: News Analysis: Prime Min Ibrahim al-Jaafari and his newly sworn-in cabinet face daunting challenges in eight-month period before fresh elections for full, five-year government in Dec; issues basic to Iraq's future and its prospects of emerging as stable democracy can no longer be papered over; issues include role of Islam and Shariah law, division of powers and oil revenues between central and regional governments, geographical boundaries to be granted to proud and wary Kurds (M)

World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Power Failure Shuts Rail Network
abstract: The state rail network ground to a halt for four hours because of an electric failure, stranding hundreds of thousands of commuters during the evening rush hour. People were left on platforms or stuck in carriages on a day when temperatures soared to 90 degrees. ''Trains are halted across the whole network,'' Swiss Federal Railways said in a statement. The shutdown was caused by a power failure at 5:45 p.m. local time on part of the track in the southern Italian-speaking part of the country. The trains were back running at 9:30 p.m. but with delays. The system normally runs like clockwork, and the Swiss are among the world's most avid rail travelers. Earlier this year, the state network introduced a timetable to help shave minutes off journeys.   Tom Wright (NYT)

headline: Google Unveils a Search Tool for Business Users
abstract: Google, most frequently used Internet search engine, releases a product that can find files and e-mail messages on business computers, effort to have its software installed on corporate personal computers and guie more users to its site (S)

headline: Blackstone Switches Sides and Private Equity Deal Makers Take Note
abstract: APPARENTLY just a handshake is no longer enough.     The clubby world of private equity investing is buzzing after the Blackstone Group switched sides last weekend in the bidding for a European telecommunications company worth more than $15 billion.

abstract: Ormet Corp, closely held aluminum producer, exits bankruptcy protection under court-approved reorganization plan; former creditors, led by investment group MatlinPatterson Asset Management, will become shareholders under plan (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Constitutional Changes Approved
abstract: A constitutional assembly voted to approve a package of measures, including one that constitutional referendums must receive the votes of a majority of all eligible voters to pass, not just a majority of those casting ballots. The rule could make it hard for President Chen Shui-bian to make constitutional changes moving the island toward greater independence. The measures also include halving the legislature, to 113 members, and abolishing the assembly itself, specifying that public referendums should be used in the future.   Keith Bradsher (NYT)

headline: France seeks to spur new exchange
In Political Step, Pope Confronts Law on Fertility
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI endorses call by Italian bishops for boycott of referendum in Italy on medically assisted fertility; referendum seeks to overturn key provisions in most restrictive law on medically assisted fertility in Europe; law, passed last year, bans donations of sperm and eggs, defines life as beginning at conception, and allows fertility treatment only to married heterosexual couples; effort to roll back many provisions is shaping up as important battleground for Roman Catholic Church, energized by new pope with strong views on social issues; many in Italy, which is overwhelmingly Catholic, support law and church's engagement to protect it; others worry that church is making disturbing intrusion into politics; photos (M)

headline: Fed Raises a Key Rate by a Quarter Point, as Expected
World Briefing | Europe: France: Mitterrand's Wine Goes On The Block
abstract: The personal wine collection of François Mitterrand, the former president who died in 1996, was auctioned in Paris, fetching almost $18,000. His widow, Danielle, put the collection -- about 50 bottles of wine, Champagne and brandy, including an 1865 Cognac -- up for sale to raise money to convert the family wine cellar into an art studio for her daughter-in-law. The most expensive item was a magnum of Armagnac bottled especially for Mr. Mitterrand in 1982. It went for $1,856.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: In Iran, election poses a dilemma
Between laptop and Net, a wireless maze
Dutch deliver a huge 'no' on EU constitution
Bolivia Installs New Leader With Very Long 'To Do' List
abstract: Bolivia's new president, Eduardo Rodríguez, began his first day in office on Friday pledging to convene early elections while working with Congress to address the demands of angry citizens for the nationalization of the energy sector and the drafting of a new constitution to give the Indian majority more rights.    Mr. Rodríguez, 49, was the unassuming, little-known president of the Supreme Court until late Thursday, when Congress chose him to replace President Carlos Mesa, who resigned after failing to quell potent nationwide protests. A Harvard-educated administrator with no political affiliation, Mr. Rodríguez, the third in line for the presidency, was seen as the best choice to defuse the furious uprisings that have paralyzed Bolivia for three weeks.

headline: ChevronTexaco Agrees to Acquire Unocal for $16.4 Billion
New Bush? Aides say he's just feeling good
Justices Reinstate Suits on Internet File Sharing
abstract: Supreme Court unanimously decides to reinstate copyright-infringement suit against two file-sharing services, handing major victory to entertainment and recording industries; court strongly suggests that Grokster and StreamCast Networks should be found liable for vast copyright infringement committed by those using their software to download music and movies; court finds two lower federal courts in California had dismissed cases based on seriously flawed legal analysis; Justice David H Souter, in his opinion for the court, suggests that evidence against two companies is so strong that entertainment-industry plaintiffs might be entitled to summary judgment; says plaintiffs--MGM Studios, Recording Industry Assn of America, Motion Picture Assn of America and class of 27,000 music publishers and songwriters--are at least entitled to trial to prove their claim that file-sharing companies are in business primarily to enable and induce computer users to find and download copyrighted material (M)

headline: Taiwan Communication Plan Stirs New Hopes for a Thaw
abstract: Pres Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan calls for China and Taiwan to set up procedure to improve communications between their military and security forces to reduce risk of misunderstandings or even unintended conflicts; proposal is latest in series of moves awakening hopes of possible thaw in relations; photo (M)

abstract: Judge Karon O Bowdre, who overseeing criminal accounting fraud trial of former HealthSouth chief executive Richard Scrushy, dismisses two counts against him; 36 others remain in case, which could go to jury by May 16 (M)

World Briefing | Asia: India: H.I.V. Infections Slow
abstract: India, which is estimated to rank second, after South Africa, in the total number of AIDS cases in the world, announced that H.I.V. infection rates in the country had slowed substantially. The Health Ministry reported that 28,000 people became infected in 2004, compared with 520,000 in 2003. India seized on the data to argue that its prevention efforts have paid off. Critics here and abroad have criticized India for not tackling AIDS early and aggressively enough.   Somini Sengupta (NYT)

headline: Morgan to Explore a Discover Spinoff
abstract: Morgan Stanley chief executive Philip J Purcell, in abrupt strategy reversal, says its board has authorized him to pursue spinoff of company's Discover credit card business; Daniel B Strickler Jr, former Morgan Stanley top executive, writes letter to Morgan's board, demanding that Purcell step down; letter paints picture of Purcell as manipulative and out-of-reach chief executive; Strickler's 3.8 million shares make him larger shareholder than any of eight retired Morgan Stanley dissidents; his stake also exceeds 2.9 million shares Purcell owns, although Purcell also owns another 2 million in options; Morgan's board releases letter supporting Purcell; five retired Dean Witter executives also wrote letter to board last week, defending Purcell's leadership; graph (M)

headline: Telefónica buying 51% of Czech telecom company
World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Acquits Two British Reporters
abstract: Two British journalists arrested outside polling station during Zimbabwe elections are aquitted of working without state license; contend they were on vacation and not working on story for employer Sunday Telegraph of London (S)

headline: Egyptian Judges Demand Independent Election Role
abstract: Thousands of Egyptian judges pledged Friday to stymie the country's presidential elections next September by refusing to oversee polling unless they are granted full independence in their oversight of the process.     The pledge added more steam to the rapidly growing opposition movement's demands for free, fair and contested election if President Hosni Mubarak seeks his fifth straight term.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Lawmakers Allow Abortion In Limited Cases
abstract: Parliament approved a bill to allow abortion in the first four months of pregnancy if the life of the mother is in danger or if the fetus is malformed. The bill requires the consent of both parents and approval by three doctors and the coroner's office. The measure still needs approval from the watchdog Guardian Council before it can become a law.   Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline: Power and gas workers planning to strike again
American makes a difference in East Timor

abstract: On the last stop of a five-day trip, the president asserted that the sovereignty of Georgia "must be respected by all nations."

abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp says it will replace Royal Dutch/Shell Group in developing Mukhaizna oil field in Oman at cost of over $2 billion; Occidental and partner Liwa Energy of Abu Dhabi have committed to raising output from deposit to 150,000 barrels a day from current 10,000 within few years (S)

headline: Pakistan to deport Qaeda suspect
A Currency Afloat (for All of 20 Minutes)
abstract: The Bush administration has been pressing the Chinese government for years to allow its currency, which is pegged to the dollar, to trade more freely. It got its wish on Friday -- but only for 20 minutes.     A freely trading Chinese yuan would probably rise in value against the dollar, making Chinese exports to the United States more costly. That, in turn, would give relief to American manufacturers battered by low-priced Chinese goods as the American trade deficit has been growing faster with China than with any other country. It would also be a political victory for the Bush administration.

headline: Days of Tax-Free Online Sales May Be Numbered
abstract: A recent court decision, along with other efforts by state tax collectors to focus on Internet sales, could signal that the era of tax-free online sales is nearing an end.

headline: Rumsfeld warns Iraqis against cronyism
U.S. Rejects Venezuelan Move on Extradition of Bombing Suspect
abstract: The Justice Department on Friday rejected Venezuela's request for the arrest of a Cuban exile wanted for an airplane bombing as a preliminary to his extradition, saying it had not provided proper supporting evidence.    A State Department official said the Venezuelans were told that their request, which called for the arrest of Luis Posada Carriles to prevent his escape as a first step to extradition, did not contain sufficient information regarding the facts and circumstances of his involvement in the 1976 bombing. The midair explosion of a Cuban airliner off the coast of Barbados killed 73 people, including several Venezuelans.

headline: POPE BENEDICT XVI: Roots of Conservatism; Turbulence on Campus in 60's Hardened Views of Future Pope
abstract: For all Pope Benedict XVI's decades as a Vatican insider, it may have been the crucible of a university town swept by student radicalism in the late 1960's that definitively shaped the man who now leads the Roman Catholic Church.     During his Bavarian childhood under the Nazis, Joseph Ratzinger became convinced that the moral authority based in Catholic teachings was the sole reliable bulwark against human barbarism, according to friends, associates, and his biographer, John L. Allen Jr.

headline: Drop That Cellphone, You Celebrity. It's a Film Premiere.
abstract: The publicity blunders leading up to the release of Paramount Studios' "War of the Worlds" turned into a cellphone pratfall on Thursday.

headline: Yields on Treasuries Plunge; Slower Global Growth Is Seen
abstract: Ten-year Treasury notes have their biggest price gain in almost seven months on speculation that slower global economic growth will cause Federal Reserve to end series of interest rate increases sooner than previously expected; yield on 10-year note falls 0.10 percentage point, to 3.94 percent; price of 4 1/8 percent note due in May 2015 rises more than 7/8, or $8.75 per $1,000 face amount, to 101 17/32; chart on key US interest rates (M)

headline: AOL offering free e-mail tied to instant messaging
WTO tops Vietnam's U.S. agenda
Anglicans Consider Divesting in Solidarity With Palestinians
abstract: The Anglican Church's international advisory body voted Friday to urge the church to consider withdrawing its investments in companies that support the occupation of Palestinian territories.    The move, presented as a message of solidarity with Palestinian Christians, immediately came under attack by Jewish groups, with some calling it ill timed and predicting a likely chill in Anglican-Jewish relations.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Bomb Kills 14 In Kashmir
abstract: At least 14 people were killed and 50 wounded by a car bomb explosion near a high school in Pulwama, 16 miles south of Srinagar, in Indian administered Kashmir. The blast appeared to have been intended for an Indian security base near the school, where students were taking exams in an open courtyard. The dead included a student. The blast came just days after several Kashmiri separatist leaders appealed to hard-liners to join negotiations for peace in Kashmir. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.   Hari Kumar (NYT)

headline: Putin assails 'terrorizing' business
Investing: Europe redux
TNK-BP disputes tax claim
At Tyco Trial No. 2, Similarities to No. 1
abstract: Jury deliberation in second trial of Tyco International's former chief executive, L Dennis Kozlowski, was marked by some of same kind of conflict that ultimately led to mistrial in first trial, but when Judge Michael J Obus received two notes from jurors on June 8, he quickly closed courtroom to public and sealed notes so he could share their contents with prosecutors and defense lawyers without tipping off press; Audrey Hodge, reported source of frustration within jury room, says she needed to see more evidence and hear more testimony before being convinced of guilt of Kozlowski and his co-defendant, Mark H Swartz; many of jurors say Kozlowski and Swartz would have been better off not testifying because they were not believable; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
Rainier, 81, transformed Monaco
Canada Chief Spends Freely in Effort to Remain in Office
abstract: Prime Minister Paul Martin and his cabinet have begun crisscrossing the country dishing out generous helpings of social spending as part of an effort to avert a snap election, or win one if the government loses a confidence vote in Parliament in May.    Struggling to shake off the political impact of a Liberal Party scandal, the government has announced more than $700 million in dozens of new programs from Newfoundland to British Columbia with money for dredging ports, expanding urban parks, new farmers markets, and road, bridge and sewer construction.

headline: Briefly: Germany searches 4 airlines
A U.A.W. Chief Awaits a G.M. Showdown
abstract: UAW president Ron Gettelfinger is headed for showdown with General Motors Corp; Gettelfinger's willingness to compromise with GM on wages and health care benefits will have broad implications for future of American auto worker and help determine whether Big Three automakers can slash costs to compete against Toyota and other foreign rivals with lower labor costs; Gettelfinger says he is willing to offer some help to GM, but will not be pushed into corner and will not reopen company's labor contract before it expires in 2007; whether outcome leads him to settle or strike is open question; chart; photos (M)

headline: A Case, but No Arrest, for Mexico City Mayor
abstract: Mexican federal prosecutors send case against Mexico City Mayor Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador to judge but allow friends of Pres Vicente Fox to put up bail, apparently to deny more partisan advantage to fiery leftist; Lopez Obrador holds political rally in home state of Tabasco, accusing Fox and political leadership of trying to keep him out of presidential race next year to protect powerful business interests; says charge that he flouted judge's order to stop building of hospital access road is trumped up (M)

headline: Reversal of Misfortune: Things Are Looking Up for a Bold Financier
abstract: Financier Ronald O Perelman's fortunes are looking up after jury awards him $604 million from lawsuit against Morgan Stanley tied to his investment in Sunbeam; Revlon, cosmetic company that is his most prominent holding, is also in better shape these days, having reduced its debt sharply over last year, and shares of some of Perelman's lesser-known investments are holding their own; recent developments could mark renaissance for Perelman, who after developing reputation as one of most fearsome raiders in 1980's, suffered embarrassing string of losses; photo (M)

headline: Turnout appears high as Ethiopians go to polls
Colombia passes disputed law disarming death squads
Saudi King Hospitalized; Condition Is Called Serious
abstract: King Fahd, the ailing ruler of Saudi Arabia, was hospitalized in Riyadh on Friday, the official Saudi press agency reported, and an official reached by telephone said the king was in stable but serious condition.     Some members of the government were asked to delay vacations, but the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the news, denied reports that a state of alert had been declared.

headline: Protesting Russian prisoners said to mutilate themselves
Sri Lankan leader vows to let rebels help with aid
A Friar Speaks, and Lightning Strikes
abstract: THE REV. JOHN CELICHOWSKI, a Franciscan friar from Milwaukee, found out last week that corporate boards sometimes move in mysterious ways.    Just a week before, he had appeared at Merck's annual meeting in North Branch, N.J., on behalf of the Capuchin Order of St. Joseph, a shareholder, to call for a management shake-up. He proposed that the company should separate the roles of chairman and chief executive, arguing that too much power was vested in the man who wore both hats, Raymond V. Gilmartin.

headline: You've Been Scammed Again? Maybe the Problem Isn't Your Computer
abstract: Dear Reader,    We urgently need to verify your subscription status. Please submit your name, current address, telephone number, date of birth, Social Security number, mother's maiden name, all bank account numbers (include PIN's), and whatever cash is currently in your pocket.

headline: Moderation is urged for Taiwanese
G.M. to Halt Ads in The Los Angeles Times
abstract: General Motors will stop advertising in Los Angeles Times 'until further notice'; GM spokeswoman characterizes decision as culmination of long-running dispute between automaker and newspaper over how GM is portrayed (S)

headline: Thais asking Malaysians for help in restive south
Higher Gas Prices Cut Consumer Spending
abstract: Commerce Department reports retail sales in March rose 0.3 percent, to $339 billion, slower rate than 0.5 percent increase in February and significantly below Wall Street's forecasts; slower sales linked to higher gas prices; gas stations drew nearly 0.9 percent of consumers' spending at $29.6 billion, 2.1 percent increase; graph (M)

headline: 20,000 flee new Togo violence
EU sanctions on U.S. to start May 1
France jails 3 for helping Qaeda kill Afghan leader
Treasury Bills Set for Auction
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.99 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 3.13 percent, and the four-week issue's was 2.78 percent.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Parachutist Dies At Eiffel Tower
abstract: A 31-year-old Norwegian man died Monday night when he tried to parachute from the Eiffel Tower in a publicity stunt, according to the police. He jumped from the second level, 380 feet above the ground, but his parachute caught in the tower and came loose, and he crashed into the first level. Two other Norwegian men apparently planned to film the jump for a commercial promoting a line of clothing. Earlier Monday, four Norwegians were stopped by security agents at the Montparnasse Tower in Paris. Officials said two of the men were going to jump from the top of the building while the others filmed them.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: Bashing the Rich, Then Celebrating at a Hub of Commerce
abstract: TriBeCa Film Festival premiere of The American Ruling Class, documentary that frequently casts money-making in muddy light at best, will be followed by after-party on New York Mercantile Exchange trading floor; exchange official Madeline Boyd comments; Lewis Lapham, featured in film, says film is not assault on commerce; photos (M)

headline: China guards Japanese Embassy amid public anger
Worker shortage in China: Arehigher prices ahead?
A Black-Latino Coalition Emerges in Los Angeles
abstract: Mayor James K. Hahn thought he was doing a service to the people of Los Angeles when he engineered the removal of Bernard C. Parks as chief of police in 2002. He may have: police morale appears to be up and crime is down by many measures under the popular new police chief, William J. Bratton.    But in pushing out Mr. Parks, who is African-American, Mayor Hahn may also have sealed his own political downfall and created a watershed moment in racial and ethnic politics in the nation's second-largest city.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore Advises China And Japan To Cool Off
abstract: Tiny Singapore stepped forward to counsel peace between Asia's quarreling giants, China and Japan. ''The two countries have not reconciled and come to terms with the history of the Second World War, the way Germany and France have done,'' Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, told Japanese business leaders on a visit to Tokyo. Friction ''is inevitable'' as their influence grows, he said, but a ''collision is not inevitable.'' Both sides, he said, ''need to moderate nationalist sentiment.''   James Brooke (NYT)

headline: Watching the Schiavo Story
abstract: Nielsen Media Research reports ratings spiked on some cable networks following several major announcements in Terri Schiavo case; ratings graphs; photo (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: The Red Cell division of the WPP Group, London, acquired a majority stake in Sra. Rushmore, Madrid, which has clients including Coca-Cola, Diageo and ING Direct.

headline: Investigators Raid Fruit Companies in Europe
abstract: European antitrust officials raided the offices of banana and pineapple suppliers this week, after a tip that the companies may have conspired to fix prices for many years, the European Commission said Friday.    Chiquita Brands International, the United States fruit giant based in Cincinnati, said Friday that it had alerted the commission after discovering that some of its own employees in Europe had been part of a cartel scheme.

headline: Uzbek crackdown is denounced
Benedict encourages Italy to ignore ballot
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Minister Testifies In Syria Torture Case
abstract: Defense Minister Bill Graham said he was frustrated by the assertions of United States officials, including the former secretary of state, Colin L. Powell, that someone in Canada had ''given them the go-ahead'' to deport Maher Arar, the Syrian-born Canadian detained in New York in 2002 and sent to Syria for 10 months, where, he said, he was tortured. Mr. Graham, who was then the foreign affairs minister, told a federal inquiry into what role Canadian officials played in Mr. Arar's deportation that he could not verify the American claims with Canadian police and security officials, although he added that he had some uncertainty about the quality of the briefings he was getting. Mr. Graham also testified that he did not know Mr. Arar's whereabouts in the months after he was deported by the United States.   Colin Campbell (NYT)

headline: India's Political Spotlight Burning Bright on Endangered Tigers
abstract: On Monday, one year and a day after becoming prime minister of India, Manmohan Singh traveled to Ranthambore National Park, the celebrated sanctuary of India's national animal: the tiger.    The visit to Ranthambore was less a warm and fuzzy photo opportunity than an attempt to take on a budding political crisis. The tiger, as endangered worldwide as it is iconic in this country, is vanishing from India's tiger parks.

headline: In Mutual Funds, Risk Is One Thing and Security Quite Another
abstract: Article on security and reliability of mutual funds data in event of fire, flood or terrorism; most mutual fund companies moved away from paper recordkeeping long ago and now record data on magnetic or optical media; it is important to know whether your mutual fund company backs up data regularly; Securities and Exchange Commission has imposed stricter compliance rules, including requirement for disaster planning and procedures (M)

headline: China and Japan at stalemate; stocks slide
De Villepin's Speedy Plan for France Is Savaged at the Start
abstract: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin announced a plan on Wednesday to restore public trust in the government in 100 days, but opposition leaders in response tore apart the plan and criticized the government for failing to respond to the needs of France.    In his maiden speech as prime minister before the National Assembly, Mr. de Villepin, a 51-year-old poet-diplomat, was both applauded and booed as he laid out proposals to create jobs and jump-start the sluggish economy.

headline: Riot Police Called In to Calm Anti-Japanese Protests in China
abstract: Mass demonstrations in Beijing against Japan turn unruly and protesters try to storm Japanese ambassador's residence before riot police break up confrontation; estimated 10,000 demonstrators join march calling for boycott of Japanese goods, making it one of largest protest events authorized by government in years, but gatherings at embassy and ambassador's residence seem to be unauthorized; Japan's vice foreign minister makes official protest against violence (M)

headline: Briefly: Appeals court sides with Cheney in lawsuit
One last time: Handshakes, smiles and thanks
In a Spotlight, Baath Congress Opens in Syria
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad opened a landmark Baath Party congress on Monday, promising modest political reform and calling for a renewed focus on the economy. But the most dramatic change likely to come out of the meeting is the transformation of the party from a pan-Arab movement to a Syrian one.     The changes are likely to emphasize a loose Arab federation and trade connections, delegates said, as well as raise the Syrian character of the party. Instead of creating a single government, the party will seek something more akin to the European Union, said George Jabbour, a member of Parliament.

headline: Australia investigates General Re
World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Missile Smuggling Confirmed
abstract: President Viktor A. Yushchenko confirmed that his country had illegally sold six nuclear-capable cruise missiles to Iran and six to China in 2001, under his predecessor, Leonid Kuchma. ''I confirm this, though I do so with bitterness,'' he told NBC-TV in an interview, remarks of which were carried by news agencies. The Soviet-era Kh-55 cruise missiles, which have a range of 1,860 miles, were smuggled out under fake contracts.   Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

headline: Iranian Envoy in Iraq for Talks, as Rebels Battle U.S. Gunships
abstract: The minister said he will tackle a number of issues, including closing out unfinished business from the Iran-Iraq war.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sanyo Electric Selects Executives
abstract: Sanyo Electric names former TV anchor, Tomoyo Nonaka, as its chairwoman and chief executive; Toshimasa Iue, son of current chairman, Satoshi Iue, and grandson of founder, Toshio Iue, is appointed president, succeeding Yukinorio Kuwano (S)

headline: Gadgets of the week: Writing lives in ThinkPad
The Perils of Hiring Out the Company's Paperwork
abstract: Article on pitfalls that may occur when small business owners hire professional employer organizations (PEO's) to handle paperwork; PEO's are responsible for taxes, workers' compensation and benefits packages and often provide management training; businesses maintain day-to-day oversight and retain some responsibilities; examples of business owners who have been embezzled by unscrupulous PEO's discussed; photo (M)

headline: Blair, on Defensive, Releases a Secret Memo on Iraq War
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair publishes full text of advice he received on legitimacy of Iraq war, in effort to defuse dispute that has derailed his re-election strategy one week before British elections; full document shows that while Lord Goldsmith, Britain's attorney general, said publicly in Mar 2003 that imminent invasion of Iraq was unambiguously legal, private advice he gave Blair 10 days earlier showed far greater concerns about legal consequences of going to war; that memo warned against naming regime change as objective of military action; Blair portayed war's objective as disarming Saddam Hussein of chemical and biological waepons, and was severely criticized when no banned weapons were found in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: The Workplace:For French, cheap labor is a threat
Briefly: GE profit rises 25%
New Scrutiny on Auditing of Pensions
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board is preparing overhaul of how companies calculate financial impact of their pension plans; corporations are likely to oppose revisions because new pension standard could lead to significant changes in how corporate earnings are reported; there could also be major changes in employee benefits and how pension funds invest workers' retirement money; current rules allow companies to report that investments in their pension funds have earned money, even in years when they did not, and to factor illusory pension gains into their operating profits; can also 'smooth' pension values by spreading year-to-year changes over several years; these accounting practices have come under criticism because they can mask health of company and pension plan; graph (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.D.A. Expands Warnings On Popular Painkillers  Federal drug regulators issued sweeping warnings that many popular painkillers could hurt the heart, stomach or skin, and they persuaded Pfizer to withdraw its once hot-selling pain pill, Bextra.    Tough warnings about heart risks will soon dominate the labels for many prescription painkillers, and the labels of popular over-the-counter pills like Advil and Aleve will have to cite risks to the heart, stomach and skin, the agency said. [Page A1.]    Ruling Favors DaimlerChrysler  A federal judge ruled against the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian in his fraud lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler. [C2.]    MG Rover Near Insolvency  The British government said the country's last major car producer, MG Rover, was nearing bankruptcy after the collapse of takeover negotiations with the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation of China. [C2.]    Wal-Mart Tries a New Focus  Wal-Mart announced that it was upgrading its merchandise, while trying to maintain the loyalty of its core customer, the woman who is struggling to provide for herself and her family. [C3.]    The nation's retailers reported mixed sales in March as cold weather kept many shoppers indoors, but analysts said consumers' willingness to spend nonetheless appeared robust. Wal-Mart, the largest retailer, said its sales at stores open at lease a year rose 4.3 percent. [C3.]    Limits on Internet Gambling Upheld  An appeals panel of the World Trade Organization ruled that the United States can maintain many of its restrictions on Internet gambling, largely reversing an earlier ruling. [C14.]    Oil Prices Hurt European Economy  With crude oil trading well above $50 a barrel, the European Central Bank said that the high price was ''very unwelcome,'' pulling down Europe's growth and pushing up inflation. [C2.]    Opinion on Tax Refunds in Europe  A member of Europe's highest court offered a preliminary opinion that could lead to billions of euros in tax refunds to companies at a time when many European governments can least afford them. [C2.]    N.Y.S.E. Elects a Chairman  The New York Stock Exchange elected Marshall N. Carter, a former chief executive of the institutional investment firm the State Street Corporation, as its new chairman. He succeeds John S. Reed, who was brought in after the departure of Richard A. Grasso. [C6.]    Major Stock Indicators Show Gains  Stocks rose as oil prices fell. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 7.07 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,191.14, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 60.3 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,546.32. The Nasdaq composite index added 19.65 points, or 1 percent, to 2,018.79. [C6.]    '60 Minutes II' Wins Major Award  One of the George Foster Peabody Awards for excellence in electronic media went to ''60 Minutes II'' for an exclusive, reported by Dan Rather, left, and produced by Mary Mapes, about abuses at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq. Several months after that report ran, Ms. Mapes was fired and Mr. Rather retired as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News'' earlier than planned, in the wake of another broadcast, on President George W. Bush's National Guard service. Also winning a Peabody Award was ''The Daily Show with Jon Stewart,'' for its comedic coverage of the 2004 presidential race. [C6.]    Half a Minute Can Be So Confining  Three decades after the 30-second spot became the standard way to sell products on TV, marketers are increasingly willing to buy commercial time in different lengths.Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

headline: Conference of Nations Promises to Revive Efforts to Aid Iraq
abstract: The conference urged Iraqi leaders to make more efforts to reach out politically to minorities supporting the insurgency.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Top Fugitive Arrested In Italy
abstract: Authorities announce arrest in Italy of Apostolos Vavilis, one of Greece's most wanted men; he is wanted for drug trafficking, and is central figure in series of scandals that have engulfed Greek Orthodox Church (S)

headline: China Trade Surplus With West Still Rising
abstract: Chinese customs officials report exports in first quarter rose to $155 billion, up 35 percent from some $116 billion a year ago; figures show China continues to run big trade deficts with Asian trading partners like Japan, Taiwan and South Korea but that its surpluses with United States and western Europe are rapidly widening; surplus with US jumped to $21 billion in quarter, up 73 percent from about $12.4 billion in 2004 period (M)

headline: Rice urges Arab allies to reform
Pope issues an invitation
The Insurance Scandal Shakes Main Street
abstract: Article on adverse impact on thousands of medical doctors and lawyers in South and Midwest in wake of collapse of malpractice insurer Reciprocal of America; those who relied on Reciprocal, and held malpractice policies that evaporated without warning, say they feel betrayed; demise of Reciprocal has emerged as signature case in series of investigations of insurance abuses; photos (L)

headline: THOMAS H. LEE PARTNERS TO SELL ITS STAKE IN AXIS CAPITAL
abstract: Thomas H Lee Partners will sell its stake in insurer Axis Capital Holdings to Morgan Stanley for about $302 million (S)

headline: Authorities raid Canal Plus offices
Briefly
Public Service Spots Find New Ways to Hold Their Own
abstract: PICTURE the last public service announcement that you saw on television. You were up late that night, weren't you?    About a third of the public service spots distributed last year by the Advertising Council, the biggest producer of public service campaigns, appeared on TV from 1 a.m. to 6 a.m. Despite the council's best efforts, the story remains the same today.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 5 Lawmakers Resign In Fraud Scandal
abstract: Five legislators of the governing party, the African National Congress, resigned from Parliament after striking plea-bargain agreements on charges of fraud stemming from the misuse of their official travel funds. Twenty-one of Parliament's 450 legislators, mostly from the party, have been accused of diverting the money after an investigation by the national prosecutor. A party spokesman said the resignations were an ''demonstration of remorse'' for wrongdoing and showed the party's zero-tolerance stance on corruption. Opposition politicians were less forgiving, saying that the five legislators were lucky to escape prosecution.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: Awards Announced by Art Directors Club
abstract: Awards Announced.

headline: Italian authorities seek CIA agents over alleged abduction
CUMMINS, THE DIESEL ENGINE MAKER, RAISES '05 OUTLOOK
abstract: Cummins raises its earnings forecast for 2005; says it earned $97 million compared with $33 million year earlier (S)

headline: Currencies: Euro recovers losses, ending dollar's rally
U.S. Fines Swiss Company Over Sale of Altered Seed
abstract: Swiss agrochemical company Syngenta is fined $375,000 by US Agriculture Department for inadvertently selling unapproved genetically altered corn seed; department also requires Syngenta to develop training program to keep mix-up in seeds from happening again (M)

headline: Blair polishes cabinet as challenge looms larger
Wipe Egg Off Face. Try Again. Voilà!
abstract: Article on efforts by Edgar Bronfman Jr, heir to Seagram fortune, and fellow investors, including Thomas H Lee Partners, Bain Capital and Providence Equity to recoup $2.6 billion they paid for Time Warner's flagging Warner Music division and turn company around; group is working on The Biz, Web-based reality show about record industry that they hope to run on America Online as early as this spring; is preparing initial public offering that is likely to value company at $4 billion; critics wonder if Bronfman, whose sale five years ago of Seagram and its entertainment assets for shares of Vivendi that later imploded, is more interested in cashing in and making up for past blunders than he is in Warner's future; photos (M)

headline: Explosions outside British Consulate in New York
Key Rates
