headline: Irish firm may return drug to market
Stocks: Investors gain courage from new mergers
Customs pact seeks to stiffen security
TiVo Posts Smaller Loss as Sales Increase
abstract: TiVo, a maker of digital video recorders that can pause and replay live television, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter loss narrowed as sales rose.    TiVo said the net loss was $857,000, or a penny a share, compared with a loss of $9.07 million, or 11 cents in the year-earlier period.

headline: Hundreds of Palestinian prisoners released
Online training: It's not personal
Taking stock in religious investing
MONSANTO RECEIVES SUBPOENA FOR PRICING DOCUMENTS
abstract: Monsanto says Illinois attorney general has subpoenaed information about pricing and licensing gene-modified seeds; some of requested documents pertain to 1999 federal antitrust lawsuit in which courts consistently ruled for Monsanto (S)

headline: Russia blames Chechen in journalist's killing
Along the Syria-Iraq Border, Victory Is Fleeting in an Effort to Rout Out Foreign Fighters
abstract: American marines climbed atop the collapsed roof of the final house to be searched this week in an operation to clear this desert town of foreign militants and declared victory. Almost one hour later, they left.     When asked if the foreign fighters would be back, Sgt. Wayne O'Donnell of Company K, the unit that made the final push to the tip of the town, replied in a tired voice as he walked away, ''Oh, definitely.''

headline: Anti-bribery efforts fail to stop executives from greasing palms
Loss Is Posted in First Report by Kmart-Sears Combination
abstract: The Sears Holdings Corporation posted a $9 million loss in its first quarterly report yesterday, sending the shares down the most since the company was formed in March when the Kmart Holding Corporation bought Sears, Roebuck & Company.     The retail company, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., posted a loss of 7 cents a share on sales of $7.63 billion. The results, which were reported yesterday in a regulatory filing for the quarter that ended April 30, included 13 weeks for Kmart and 5 weeks for Sears.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Patent Ruling In Chip Case
abstract: Shares of Mosaid Technologies, Canadian designer and tester of semiconductors, fall 24 percent after US Federal Judge William J Martini throws out most of company's claims that rival Infineon Technologies did not infringe its patents (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Guinea-Bissau: Exiled Leader Returns
abstract: Former Guinea-Bissau President Joao Bernardo Vierira, who has been living in exile in Portugal since losing power in 1999 military coup, returns to country amid speculation that he might try to participate in upcoming elections; is barred from participating in politics, but has strong support within Guinea-Bissau; photo (S)

headline: NCR, A MAKER OF A.T.M.'S, RAISES PROFIT ESTIMATES
abstract: The NCR Corporation, whose chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, left for the top job at Hewlett-Packard, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit would be at least 16 cents a share, higher than an earlier forecast of 2 cents to 5 cents a share, because of strong sales of its automated teller machines, checkout scanners and data warehousing products. NCR, which will report first-quarter results on April 28, also raised its full-year earnings expectations. NCR said it expected to report quarterly revenue of $1.34 billion, up 4 percent from the same quarter last year. Mr. Hurd, who was named chief executive of Hewlett-Packard on March 29, cut costs and increased sales of higher-profit software at NCR. The company is based in Dayton, Ohio.

headline: Interpublic Tries Again To Start Media Agency
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Cos is again creating media agency to handle accounts that would present conflicts with clients at existing Interpublic media agencies; names Jamie Korsen president of agency, G Media, which is being spun off from Avrett Free Ginsberg (M)

headline: Ex-deputy president faces corruption trial
U.S. Chief Executives Fare Well in Job Security, Survey Finds
abstract: Survey of world's biggest companies shows that turnover of chief executives at American companies has held relatively steady for last few years and that turnover abroad has accelerated; findings suggest that increased shareholder activism and new vigilance among corporate boards in US has had only muted impact on top executive turnover and that European and Asian boards are generally quicker to remove underperforming managers; graph (M)

headline: No Privacy in Your Cubicle? Try an Electronic Silencer
abstract: Maxwell Smart's ''cone of silence'' is finally a reality.    Two people in an office here were having a tête-à-tête, but it was impossible for a listener standing nearby to understand what they were saying. The conversation sounded like a waterfall of voices, both tantalizingly familiar and yet incomprehensible.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Italian President Visits Pope
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI met at the Vatican with President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi of Italy in his first official meeting with a head of state since he was elected pope two weeks ago. He is scheduled soon to make his first visits to important institutions of his office: the Basilica of St. John's in Lateran, in his role as bishop of Rome, and Castelgandolfo, the summer papal residence outside Rome. On May 29, he will make his first trip, a one-day visit to Bari in southern Italy.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Briefly: Alcatel president resigning
S.E.C. to Revisit Fund Rule
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission will meet June 29 to reconsider rule requiring mutual funds to have independent chairman (S)

headline: Hardline mayor wins Iran election
Accidents Reveal Troubles at Mexico's Oil Monopoly
abstract: Juan González Durán, who like nearly everyone in Nanchital works for Pemex, the state-owned oil monopoly, had no doubt about who was responsible for his brother's death last month when a work crew cut into the wrong pipeline and six men died in a blast of ammonia gas.     Mr. González blamed a Pemex engineer who had been overseeing the job but left just before the accident.

headline: Spanish diplomat uses spy-chief skills
South Korean soldier kills eight colleagues
Stocks: Hope for slower Fed moves bolsters shares
Under Pressure, Uzbek President Raises Death Toll From Clashes
abstract: Uzbekistan acknowledges that its crackdown last week on antigovernment demonstration and prison break had been far more violent than it previously described, saying 169 people had been killed, including 32 government troops;: Pres Islam A Karimov had previously said that only 10 soldiers and larger but unspecified number of 'rebels' had been killed; one opposition group says it compiled list of 745 dead; maps; photo (M)

headline: Chief of 'Millennium' Aid Fund Is Quitting
abstract: Two days after a group of African leaders complained that the Bush administration's signature program to aid poor nations had proved slow, the head of the program told his staff on Wednesday that he would resign.    Paul V. Applegarth, the chief executive of the Millennium Challenge Corporation for the last 13 months, will step down at a date yet to be determined, an official there said. The corporation administers the Millennium Challenge Account, established by President Bush to provide financial assistance to poor nations that show progress in establishing what the United States considers stable democratic governments and pursuing sound economic and social welfare policies.

headline: Media industry poised to grow
Rights Group Defends Report
abstract: Shrugging off White House criticism, an Amnesty International official said the word gulag was deliberately chosen to describe the Guantánamo Bay prison camp.   Page A5.

headline: Taiwan to send mayors to China
Turks to Fight 'Honor Killings' of Women
abstract: In a nondescript building in a remote part of Istanbul, a young woman sat in front of a television on a recent day watching a chilling scene unfold. Panning across the dank walls of a cave, the camera stopped on a primitive drawing of a female form, then dissolved into a modern crime scene showing the chalk outline of a woman's body on a road.     ''Every year, dozens of women fall victim,'' said the menacing voice of Atilla Olgac, an actor who plays the most fearsome character on Turkey's most popular television drama. ''Don't be a part of this shame; don't turn a blind eye to murders committed in the name of honor.''

headline: Australia and U.S. Barring Him, Chinese Says
abstract: The high-ranking Chinese diplomat who defected here two weeks ago only to be rebuffed by the Australian government says he also sought political asylum at the United States Embassy, and was turned away there as well.    The defector, Chen Yonglin, a 37-year-old career diplomat, said in his first interview with a foreign journalist that he had called the American Embassy in Canberra and followed up with a fax.

headline: Emerging-market investors start to fret
Cutting Here, but Hiring Over There
abstract: IBM plans to increase its payroll in India this year by more than 14,000 workers, even as it proceeds with layoffs of up to 13,000 workers in Europe and US; numbers are telling evidence of continuing globalization of work and migration of some skilled jobs to low-wage countries like India; IBM senior vice president Robert W Moffat explains buildup in India is attributable to surging demand for technology services in thriving Indian economy and opportunity to tap many skilled Indian software engineers to work on projects around world; Marcus Courtney, president of Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, or WashTech, group that seeks to unionize such workers, says winners are richest corporations in world, and American workers lose; graph; photo (M)

headline: Discussions on the EU's future
At Least 16 Are Killed in Copter Crash in Afghanistan
Tense topics for Bush and Putin in Moscow
U.K. subsidy push falls on shallow French soil
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sony Sells 500,000 PSP's In 2 Days
abstract: Sony says it sold more than 500,000 units of PlayStation Portable in its first two days on North American market; machine generated $150 million in sales during first week (S)

headline: Rebels asked for deal on tsunami aid
Pfizer touts cancer drug
World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: U.S. Wants Warlord Extradited
abstract: Federal prosecutors in New York said they had filed papers with Colombian authorities for the extradition of Diego Fernando Murillo, a paramilitary leader wanted on suspicion of conspiring to import cocaine into the United States. He surrendered in Colombia last month, accused of ordering the killing of a local politician. His detention at a ranch in northern Colombia has raised concerns that the government of President Álvaro Uribe is soft on right-wing death squads.   Juan Forero (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economy Slows to 5.2%
abstract: Russia's economy grew at annual rate of 5.2 percent in first three months of year, slowest rate in almost three years (S)

headline: RealNetworks Tries Giving Away Music
abstract: RealNetworks introduces version of its Rhapsody music service that allows nonsubscribers to listen to 25 songs free each month; users are welcome to listen to one song 25 times or any 25 songs from its library once, or any combination; Real hopes that making it as easy to try its service as it is to obtain songs illicitly through file-sharing network like Kazaa will draw new paying customers; Real is also introducing $14.99 version of Rhapsody that lets subscribers copy as many songs as they like onto certain portable music players (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Market Braces for Earnings After Sharp Fall in Stocks  After last week's market plunge -- when America's three main stock gauges fell more than 3 percent -- investors will be looking to the flood of corporate earnings this week that are likely to set the near-term course of a nervous market.     Whether or not earnings are an antidote, it is clear that the mood of the investors has changed dramatically, They finally seem to believe that high crude oil and gasoline prices are curtailing consumer spending, slowing economic growth and cutting into corporate earnings. [Section A.]    Questioning Eziba's Decisions  When Eziba, an online retailer, declared bankruptcy last year, hundreds of its suppliers were left unpaid. Some of the company's critics are now questioning Eziba's decision to forgo payments. Suppliers from around the world included Rwandan widows, above, who weaved baskets for Eziba last year in Gashoga village. A debt to them was paid by Overstock.com, which bought Eziba's assets. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C6.]    Intel Has Chip for Wireless Signals  The Intel Corporation is expected to announce that it has begun selling a computer chip designed to pick up long-range, high-speed wireless Internet signals. The technology, known as WiMax, is seen as both a complement and successor to WiFi transmissions, which send data over shorter distances. [C4.]    Equity Firms Make Bets on Satellite  While many investors remain wary of the fiber optic industry, private equity firms have taken big stakes in satellite operators including PanAmSat, Intelsat and New Skies Satellites Holdings. [C4.]    Cellphones for the Preverbal Set  As mobile television gains ground, a group of entertainment companies is working to turn the cellphone into a high-tech pacifier. The target customers are children who may be incapable of coherent telephone conversation but will cuddle with a portable phone and view entertainment by Sesame Street characters or the Teletubbies. [C10.]    Britain to Examine Rover Finances  The British government has ordered an investigation into the accounts of MG Rover amid contentions that directors stripped money from the failed company. [C6.]    Insurance Chief Set to Urge Change  The chief executive of one of the largest insurance brokerages is expected to open a conference with a call for major changes in how the industry does business. [C2.]    Fox Turns to Fans to Save Show  Fans often conduct grass-roots campaigns to persuade television networks to spare their favorite programs from cancellation. Now a campaign seeks to save ''Arrested Development,'' the Fox comedy, which has low ratings despite winning three Emmy Awards last September. But in this case, the campaign is being run by Fox itself. Above, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Jason Bateman on a recent episode. [C8.]    Marketing Research Back in Style  For years, advertising research was seen as a staid field with little practical relevance. Now, as clients increasingly hold agencies accountable for effective ads, the researchers are in demand. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C10.]

headline: Bush to demand breakup of terrorist organizations
Uzbek leader arrives in China
Khodorkovsky sentenced to nine years in prison
The New Executive Bonanza: Retirement
abstract: Corporations are fattening retirement packages of their chief executives; it is not uncommon for retired executives who were paid tens or even hundreds of millions dollars during their tenures to receive $1 million or more in pension benefits every year for as long as they live; unlike executives' salary or stock options, cost of retirement packages is rarely laid out for shareholders; table of retirement packages received by 20 top executives; photos (L)

headline: Decision is sought on Myanmar's Asean role
Forstmann Agrees to Buy Fitness Chain
abstract: Theodore J Forstmann, head of Forstmann Little & Co, acquires 24 Hour Fitness Worldwide, world's largest privately owned chain of fitness centers; chain, based in San Ramon, Calif, has 345 clubs in 15 states with 2.8 million members, most on West Coast, and another 15 clubs in Asia; revenue was more than $1 billion in 2004 (M)

headline: Thousands gather to pay homage to pontiff
Extent of New Breach Unclear
abstract: The largest credit card issuers were still uncertain which customer accounts had been affected by a computer security breach reported by MasterCard. Page C4.

headline: Superjumbo delay traced to Airbus plant in Germany
Don't Believe the Hype. A Hip-Hop Mogul Says It's Propaganda.
abstract: Russell Simmons, co-founder of Def Jam Recordings label, gives deposition in which he concedes that he was exaggerating when he said publicly in early 2003 that his Phat Fashions business was doing $350 million a year in sales, since company's revenue for preceding year was only $14.3 million; deposition arose from civil case in which Def Jam and Lyor Cohen, then its chairmen, were held liable for reneging on deal to let another label release CD featuring Def Jam artist; his words and various written statements provide glimpse into economics of apparel, where labels like Phat Farm make money by charging fees or royalties amounting to percentage of revenue generated by manufacturers who license their names; photos (M)

headline: New World Bank Chief Says Aiding Africa Is His Top Goal
abstract: When he becomes president of the World Bank on Wednesday, Paul D. Wolfowitz says, Africa will be his top priority.     ''Nothing would be more satisfying than to feel at the end of however long a term I serve here that we played a role in changing Africa from a continent of despair to a continent of hope,'' he said Tuesday at his first news conference.    To underline that commitment, he will travel to Africa in June.

headline: For Japan and China, new era of bad feeling
Pfizer halts arthritis drug after warning on risks
A Wounded Blair, Rivals Strengthened, Begins Third Term; Tory Leader to Step Down
abstract: Britain's political landscape was redrawn on Friday after a tumultuous election that gave Prime Minister Tony Blair a third term with a severely reduced majority, strengthening rivals within and outside his Labor Party, and hastened the departure of Michael Howard as the leader of the opposition Conservatives.    Mr. Howard announced that he would step down ''sooner rather than later'' after he increased his party's representation in the 646-seat Parliament but failed to ignite broader appeal beyond the bedrock Conservative base.

headline: European firms bloom by shifting to services
Stocks: Oil hits U.S. stocks after positive CPI report
Ukraine set to drop barter trade
Arms Equipment Plundered in 2003 Is Surfacing in Iraq
abstract: Equipment plundered from dozens of sites in Saddam Hussein's vast complex for manufacturing weapons is beginning to surface in open markets in Iraq's major cities and at border crossings.    Looters stormed the sites two years ago when Mr. Hussein's government fell, and the fate of much of the equipment has remained a mystery.

headline: Cable Shows Are Stealing Male Viewers From Broadcast TV
abstract: Ratings success of Cartoon Network late-night programming and of Daily Show with Jon Stewart on Comedy Central are part of trend in late-night television in which young men are slowly turning from broadcast networks to cable television; late-night time slots, although they draw smaller numbers, are prized by advertisers because they tend to draw consistent audiences throughout week; broadcasters say late-night pie is growing and that they are not losing viewers to cable; numbers suggest small shift; graph; photos (M)

headline: High court expands home seizure right
Tanzi seeks to avoid prison
Voters to the barricades
Big anti-terror drill begins on East Coast
Research Finds That Red Is for Winners
abstract: British researchers report that wearing red increases chance of victory in sports; study is published in journal Nature (M)

headline: Does the Reality Show Make the Designer?
abstract: OVER kaleidoscopic images of striped shirts, red-white-and-blue logos, flashing lights and a zooming red Ferrari, a man's disembodied voice intones: ''If you've ever turned on a television, opened a magazine or gone shopping, you know who I am.''    As the television show unfolds, the camera cuts to the speaker. ''My name is Tommy Hilfiger,'' he says. ''People around the world know the name and know the fashion. But the road to fame wasn't easy.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monopoly Law Toughened
abstract: Japan's upper house of Parliament passes series of amendments to country's antimonopoly laws in first major revision to statues in nearly 30 years; new laws increase penalties for bid-rigging and other cartel activity and gives Fair Trade Commission increased powers to investigate suspects, including right to search their offices (S)

headline: 3 new polls forecast an EU 'no' in France
Berlusconi trims stake in Mediaset
Afghans Catch 2 Taliban Figures Sought in Violence and Bombings
abstract: Afghan Army forces captured two senior Taliban commanders whom they blame for a string of violence and bomb attacks in western Afghanistan, Gen. Zaher Azimi, an army spokesman, said Sunday. The two were immediately handed over to American forces, he said.    One of those captured was Hajji Sultan, the former Taliban military commander for the western zone covering Farah and Nimruz Provinces and the Shindand region. ''He is accused of assisting in the construction and emplacement of improvised explosive devices in western Afghanistan,'' the United States military said in a statement. ''He is also accused of harboring a large cache of weapons stolen while he was a division commander under the Taliban government and having ties to narcotics smuggling operations.''

headline: Shaky middle ground loses appeal in Ulster
India gives newspapers freer reign
Sweeping constitutional changes adopted in Taiwan
Briefly: Sex offenders contest limits to their mobility
An Early Advocate of Stock Options Debunks Himself
abstract: Interview with Michael C Jensen, professor emeritus at Harvard Business School, on why he has soured on idea, which he pioneered 15 years ago, that stock options should be big component of top management's pay; photo (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: EU plansnew rules on state aid
People
abstract: Dean Bastian, senior vice president and group creative director at McCann Erickson Worldwide, is named executive vice president and director for creative development, new post; Patrick O'Neill, group creative director of Absolut vodka account at TBWA/Chiat/Day, is leaving next month; Janet Scardino is named to new post of executive vice president and global head of marketing for media business at New York office of Reuters; Christine Petrillo is named publisher at Inside TV, celebrity magazine to be introduced April 21 by Gemstar-TV Guide International (S)

headline: Australian leader won't negotiate on hostage release
Prada Begins Talks to Sell Unprofitable Helmut Lang Brand
abstract: Prada, which turned a black nylon backpack into a must-have fashion accessory, said Tuesday that it had entered talks to sell its unprofitable Helmut Lang brand.    The proceeds of the sale would help shore up Prada's balance sheet at a time when the luxury goods industry is confronting a slowing world economy and a flood of inexpensive Chinese products.

headline: Iraq Tries to Complete Cabinet, but a Sunni Rejects Nomination
abstract: The parliament approved appointments for six new cabinet spots, but a Sunni chosen as human rights minister declined the post.

headline: Can Yahoo's New Music Service Earn a Profit?
abstract: THE announcement by Yahoo on Tuesday that it is starting a discount online subscription music service sent competitors in the business reeling.    Shares of RealNetworks plunged 21 percent yesterday to close at $5.76, while Napster fell nearly 27 percent to close at $4.65. Apple Computer, whose iTunes music service has a 70 percent share of the online music market, declined 2 percent, closing at $35.61.

headline: For Buffett, the One That Got Away
abstract: TOMORROW morning, Warren E. Buffett and his board will gather in Omaha to consider the merits of three executives he considers likely to succeed him one day as Berkshire Hathaway's chief executive. Their names are still a closely guarded secret, but all the candidates work for Berkshire and none are older than 60.     The directors' conclave is routine, part of an assessment of potential successors that Mr. Buffett conducts after Berkshire's annual meetings, the most recent of which was yesterday. But as Mr. Buffett approaches his 75th birthday, the financial powerhouse he began assembling 40 years ago confronts challenges that are anything but routine.

headline: Greenberg, in Exile, Plots His Next Move
abstract: MAURICE R. GREENBERG has come late to a love of lacrosse. Cut off from managing American International Group, the insurance juggernaut he cherished and fiercely controlled, the strong-willed Mr. Greenberg now spends part of his time cheering his grandchildren at their prep school sporting events.    Subjected to the uncertainties and indignities of a sprawling insurance investigation that is engulfing him, Mr. Greenberg also shuttles between various lawyers' offices and his own temporary command center at 299 Park Avenue in New York. Ousted as A.I.G.'s chairman and chief executive in March, he is tightly focused on mounting his legal defense and is mulling how best to wield his remaining levers of power to recapture his lost glory at the top of corporate America's food chain.

headline: TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Sampling of recent deals in commercial properties; photo (M)

headline: Valero deal to create top U.S. oil refiner
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,686 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    ALLEN, Louis E., 34, 1st Lt., Army National Guard; Milford, Pa.; 42nd Infantry Division.    ARIZOLA, Roberto Jr., 31, Sgt., Army; Laredo, Tex.; 297th Military Intelligence Battalion, 513th Military Intelligence Brigade.    BIRCH, Dustin V., 22, Lance Cpl., Marine Reserve; St. Anthony, Idaho; Fourth Marine Division.    CHAVEZ, Daniel, 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Seattle; First Marine Division.    CROWE, Terrence K., 44, Lt. Col., Army Reserve; New York City; 98th Division.    ESPOSITO, Phillip T., 30, Capt., Army National Guard; Suffern, N.Y.; 42nd Infantry Division.    FASNACHT, Michael J., 25, First Lt., Army; Columbus, Ga.; Third Infantry Division.    KEELING, Thomas O., 23, Lance Cpl., Marine Reserve; Strongsville, Ohio; Fourth Marine Division.    SEYMOUR, Devon P., 21, Lance Cpl., Marine Reserve; St. Louisville, Ohio; Fourth Marine Division.    SQUIRES, Brad D., 26, Cpl., Marine Reserve; Middleburg Heights, Ohio; Fourth Marine Division.    TUCKER, Marc L., 24, Lance Cpl., Marines; Pontotoc, Miss.; Ninth Engineer Support Battalion, Third Force Service Support Group, Third Marine Expeditionary Force.

headline: MORE ON THE ELECTION
abstract: CHALLENGE FOR U.S. -- With the election of a hard-liner in Iran, the Bush administration is bracing for confrontations over Tehran's nuclear programs and terrorism.   PAGE 10    MODEST ROOTS -- The mayor of Tehran appealed to voters by emphasizing his background as the son of a blacksmith, not his revolutionary credentials.   PAGE 11

headline: Guidant Shares Fall Sharply on New Warning on Heart Device
abstract: Guidant, already under scrutiny for delaying disclosures about flawed products, urged doctors today to stop implanting its most sophisticated heart devices.

headline: Top Aide to Brazil's Leader Quits After Scandal Charge
abstract: Brazil's deepening corruption scandal has claimed its first prominent victim, with the chief of staff to President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva stepping down after allegations that he knew of and encouraged a multimillion-dollar scheme to buy votes in Congress.    ''I am not ashamed of anything that I did,'' the aide, José Dirceu de Oliveira e Silva, said Thursday evening after his resignation was accepted by the president, whose own political future has been threatened by the crisis.

headline: Ethiopia's governing party claims a victory
Briefly: MCI goes for sweetened bid from Qwest over Verizon
Briton Accused of Raising Terror Funds Can Be Extradited
abstract: A computer programmer is accused in the U.S. of using Web sites to raise funds for the Taliban and other terrorists.

headline: India gives its image problem an airing
EU court won't rule in drug case
As Egypt ponders elections, Rice makes case for democracy
Convenience, but Not for Everyone
abstract: Even during peak travel times, the line at the American Airlines ticket counter in Philadelphia moves quickly for most business travelers. But not for Peggy Elliott, who waited nearly an hour to check in for a recent flight.      ''People were zipping past me because they could use the self-service kiosks,'' said Ms. Elliott, a lawyer from Grinnell, Iowa. ''I had to stand in a long line to wait for a ticket agent.''

headline: G.E. to Help Restart Power Plant in India
abstract: General Electric will team up with two state-owned Indian companies to find ways to restart the Dabhol power plant, which has been shut down since 2001, the company said Monday.     Scott R. Bayman, president of GE India, said in a statement that his company would join with officials from National Thermal Power and Bharat Heavy Electricals to ''determine a course of action for restarting and completing the Dabhol Power Project.''

headline: Appraisal:Fear in a soaring tower
STMicro plans to cut more jobs
World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: War Crimes Prosecutor Resigns
abstract: A prosecutor at the international court that is trying Rwandan war crimes suspects in Tanzania resigned after court authorities learned that he had been charged in his native South Africa with attempted murder and robbery, officials said. The prosecutor, Bongani Dyani, was hired by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in 2003, two years after the charges against him were filed.   Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline: VERIZON TO SHUT WI-FI ACCESS SPOTS IN NEW YORK CITY
abstract: Verizon Communications plans to shut public sites that provide high-speed wireless Internet access in New York City because of a lack of use. Verizon, which is based in New York, has begun shutting 380 so-called Wi-Fi hot spots in Manhattan and Brooklyn and will phase out the service over the next two months, the company said on Wednesday. The move lets Verizon concentrate on an expansion of a fee-based service provided by its mobile phone division, Verizon Wireless.

headline: MCI Endorses Qwest's Latest Takeover Bid
Blair Calls May Election as His Party Slips in Polls
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair calls May 5 election in which he will ask British voters to give him record-setting third consecutive term; new polls find him losing ground to Conservatives under Michael Howard; Blair tells voters in Dorset he will keep economic progress going; photo (M)

headline: Electronic Data Systems Posts a Profit Aided by Cost Cuts
abstract: Electronic Data Systems posts first-quarter profit of $4 million; net income was 1 cents a share, after loss of $12 million, or 2 cents a share, year earlier; sales declined to $4.94 billion (M)

headline: Europe Isn't Working, but Investors Are Not as Worried as Politicians
abstract: Floyd Norris column on economic problems within European Union; says reality is that Europe is not working, at least not way it was supposed to when politicians were campaigning for ratification of Maastricht Treaty, which led to adoption of euro in much of Continent; says there are signs that inability to adjust exchange rates within euro zone is making some areas, notably Italy, less competitive relative to Germany, which itself is facing stagnation; holds dream of European Union was to make Europe strong player, able to compete with Japan and US; says Europe may do better if that dream is downsized, leaving each country with responsibility to put its own house in order; graph (M)

headline: Budget clash heralds battle over EU's economic future
ABC's Schedule Emits That 'Housewives' Vibe
abstract: ABC is expected to tell advertisers at upfront market on May 17 that it will add six dramas and five comedies to its prime-time schedule in next television season; sales in upfront market are expected to toatal $9.4 billion; NBC unveils strategy to improve its weeknight offerings at 8, where it did badly this past season (M)

headline: Briefly
Microsoft seals new China deal
World Briefing | Asia: Agreement On Last Leg Of Border
abstract: Russia and China's foreign ministers signed a final agreement on their 2,700-mile border, which had been a point of contention for 40 years, at a meeting in Russia's Far Eastern city of Vladivostok. The document, an addition to an accord signed during President Vladimir V. Putin's visit to China last year, deals with a small stretch of the border running through several islands along the countries' eastern border.   Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

headline: Vying for wine ofMitterrand
European firms bloom by shifting to services
Elbowing into a busy Japan market
With Interest: Fate of 'national champions' in new EU
Expansionaids SingTelin beatingforecasts
A Paleopuzzle: Chomping With No Chompers
abstract: Scientists speculate that toothless skull of early human ancestor discovered in Georgia in Caucasus may attest to evolution's oldest known example of compassion for elderly; note that well-preserved skull belonged to 40-year-old man; say companions in his meat-eating society might have helped him by finding soft plant food and hammering raw meat so he could 'gum' his dinners; other experts caution that it might be stretch to interpret fossil as evidence of compassion; findings are reported in journal Nature (M)

headline: Child Car Seat Safety System Sometimes Fails, Study Says
abstract: Study by Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports, shows four models of child car seats performed poorly in crash tests when used with new federally required safety system; safety system, known as Latch, for lower anchors and tethers for children, is intended to make it easier to attach child car seats to vehicles; Combi Avatar child seat, made by Combi USA, fared worst in study; other child seat that came unhooked during crash tests is Evenflo PortAbout 5, Combi model Tyro and Britax International's Britax Marathon (M)

headline: An Office and a Gentleman
abstract: SHORTLY before the terrorist attacks of 2001, Gen. H. Hugh Shelton, then the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the top military adviser to President Bush, met at an undisclosed location in California with Gen. Richard B. Myers, who later succeeded him in that job, and Gen. Michael E. Ryan, the Air Force chief of staff.    For eight hours, a special Pentagon representative briefed them on matters of strategy and the future. But the briefing was not about national security. Rather, it was about their own financial future -- how to get seats on corporate boards, what kinds of pay packages to ask for, how to approach future employers and how to gain perks, stock options and lucrative consulting contracts.

headline: Avian flu fears heightened in China
Consensus May Be Elusive in U.S.-Italy Inquiry, Berlusconi Says
U.S. Told in Report to Do More to Protect Officials Abroad
abstract: GAO report says that while US has done much in recent years to safeguard diplomatic posts more must be done to protect Americans abroad in residences, schools, places of worship and other 'soft' targets; terrorists have attacked 32 American officials, 23 fatally, outside embassies since1968 (M)

headline: Goldman Seals a Deal, and Its Status
abstract: Goldman Sachs' merger of Archipelago, electronic stock market, and New York Stock Exchange cements Goldman's longstanding role as premier Wall Street firm, and one with most sway over Big Board's future; Goldman has become forceful voice for modernization; other Wall Street firms, including Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, pressed exchange to allow more electronic trading, which would let firms cut number of traders on exchange floor and lower their costs; but none of firms pushed as hard as Goldman did; Big Board's chief John Thain was president of Goldman and was centrally involved in firm's drive to invest in electronic exchanges; merger is fitting coda to Thain's first major initiative as chief executive of exchange; photo (M)

headline: EU strives to avoid trade duel with China
Spotlight: Microsoft's European statesman
Choice for Paris post is a Bush confidant
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,639 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    COLLINS, Randy D., 36, Sgt. First Class, Army; Long Beach, Calif.; 11th Armored Cavalry.    WIMBERG, David N., 24, Sgt., Marine Reserve; Louisville, Ky.; Fourth Marine Division.

headline: Anti-Syria Coalition's Victory in Lebanon Raises New Tension
abstract: Anti-Syrian coalition's election victory in Lebanon revives religious hostilities that seemed buried after assassination of former prime minister Rafik Hariri; Hariri's son Saad, a Sunni Muslim, acknowledges difficulties and dodges questions about whether Pres Emile Lahoud, ally of Syria, would be replaced; Hariri's chief rival is former army commander Michel Aoun, Maronite Catholic whose bloc has 21 seats in Parliament; he accuses Hariri's movement of voter fraud; photo (M)

headline: Dirty Secret: Coal Plants Could Be Much Cleaner
abstract: ALMOST a decade ago, Tampa Electric opened an innovative power plant that turned coal, the most abundant but the dirtiest fossil fuel, into a relatively clean gas, which it burns to generate electricity. Not only did the plant emit significantly less pollution than a conventional coal-fired power plant, but it was also 10 percent more efficient.    Hazel R. O'Leary, the secretary of energy at the time, went to the plant, situated between Tampa and Orlando, and praised it for ushering in a ''new era for clean energy from coal.'' Federal officials still refer to the plant's ''integrated gasification combined cycle'' process as a ''core technology'' for the future, especially because of its ability -- eventually -- to all but eliminate the greenhouse gases linked to global warming.

headline: Wall Street Scrambles to Analyze Cable Deal
abstract: Investors and analysts are wondering what Dolan family is really up to with its surprise $7.9 billion offer to buy out public shareholders of Cablevision Systems and spin off company's entertainment assets; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Briefly: UN's nuclear chief wins acceptance from U.S.
China Warmly Welcomes Taiwan Opposition Leader
China and U.S. hold textile talks
Your Body Is Trying to Tell You Something. So Start Listening.
abstract: Even for the well intentioned, keeping track of exercise can be a difficult task. The devices, like pedometers, commonly used to monitor physical activity provide only a crude measurement or are not something most people would wear all day.    The Bodybugg is an attempt to create an activity monitor that people would be willing to wear during most of their waking hours.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 4 Iraqis and Wounds at Least 7
Business Briefing | Extension in Case of China Aviation Oil Executives
abstract: Singapore's High Court gave two executives from the failed fuel trader China Aviation Oil (Singapore) more time to respond to charges against them in connection with the company's failure last November, with $550 million in derivatives trading losses. After lawyers for the suspended chief executive, Chen Jiulin, and the former finance chief, Peter Lim, asked the court for more time to review prosecution documents, the court gave them until July 7 to enter pleas. Mr. Chen has been charged with 15 separate offenses, including forgery and insider trading. Mr. Lim faces five charges, including making misleading statements. Two of the other three company directors charged -- Jia Changbin, China Aviation Oil's chairman, and Li Yongji -- were allowed to return to China after the Chinese government said that it would guarantee their return for a hearing scheduled for Thursday.   Wayne Arnold (NYT)

headline: For the Auditors of A.I.G., a Delicate Balancing Act
abstract: PricewaterhouseCooper's audit of American International Group has become balancing act--moving carefully to satisfy themselves and moving quickly to satisfy their client; auditors are at various AIG units, reviewing statements of company coping with multiple investigations of its accounting; are trying to make sure that they understand transactions AIG completed and that accounting of deals is correct--for their protection as well as AIG's (M)

headline: Morgan Says Dissident Role Would Cost Ex-Executives
abstract: Morgan Stanley said in a filing yesterday that Joseph R. Perella and Tarek F. Abdel-Meguid, two senior executives who resigned last month, would have to forgo bonus payments of $6.4 million each if they joined the eight dissident executives opposed to Philip J. Purcell this year.    The restriction, together with additional language about joining a competing firm, is part of a ''good behavior'' clause that expires at the end of the year.

headline: Sudan Offers Familiar Pledge on Darfur
Asians setswap-grid expansion
In Apparent End to Family Showdown, Cablevision to Shut Its Voom Satellite Service
abstract: Cablevision Systems decides to shut its Voom satellite business, but will continue to own and sell rights to 21 high-definition television channels; action appears to resolve standoff between Cablevision chairman Charles F Dolan and his son, James L Dolan, chief executive, over whether to finance satellite business (M)

headline: MCI Backs Qwest Over Verizon
abstract: MCI, the long-distance phone company at the heart of a pitched takeover battle, raised the ante yesterday by declaring a sweetened bid from Qwest Communications to be superior to an offer it had already accepted from Verizon.    In so doing, MCI's board, for the first time during the two-month bidding war, sided with Qwest. The decision gives Qwest a chance to wrest control of the company from Verizon, but that outcome is by no means certain because Verizon still has the legal and financial upper hand. Earlier this month, MCI's board accepted a takeover offer from Verizon worth $23.10 a share, or 30 percent less than Qwest's new bid.

headline: Corrections
Flight to Quality Cuts Yields
abstract: WHILE there are several explanations for the surprising drop in Treasury yields in the last two weeks, the one cited most often has been what fixed-income traders call a flight to quality.    That happens when investors want protection from some negative event that has occurred or one that may be around the corner. Concerns about some unexpected, significant losses in the hedge fund world have been bubbling up since Standard & Poor's cut the credit rating of General Motors and Ford Motor to junk bond, or high-yield, status on May 5.

headline: Is the Check-In Kiosk in the Lobby for Real?
abstract: DUST collectors. That is what employees at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers call their new automated check-in kiosks, as one guest who has repeatedly tried to use them found.     ''I was checking in, and try as hard as I might, the kiosk wouldn't cooperate,'' Henry Harteveldt recalled. He flagged down a staff member and said, ''This doesn't seem to work.''

headline: Airbus Says Its New Flagship Jet Will Be Delayed
abstract: Airbus, in the middle of an escalating trans-Atlantic trade battle with Boeing, ran into trouble on two other fronts on Wednesday, pushing back the delivery of its flagship A380 superjumbo jet and delaying the expected announcement of a new chief executive.    Airbus confirmed that it would push back delivery of the A380 to its first set of customers by as much as six months. The delay, which Airbus said was a result of industrial and design modifications to the plane, could force it to pay steep penalties to those airlines.

headline: If You Ask Small-Business Owners, the Economy Is Improving
abstract: Ted Farnsworth, founder and chief executive of XStream Beverage Network, has grand plans this year for his company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a maker of products like Yohimbe, an energy drink that sells for $2 a can.     He expects to add 40 workers to his staff of 67 and invest $200,000 in technology, and he projects an increase in revenue, to $30 million, from $9 million in 2004 and $3 million the year before.

headline: Los Angeles Times and Wall Street Journal Each Win Two Pulitzer Prizes
Protests Escalate as Bolivia Seeks New President
abstract: Tens of thousands of Indians and miners, many of them setting off dynamite, poured into the Bolivian capital.

headline: Transportation: Europe's freight trains pick up speed
Italians Angry Over Inquiry on Iraq Death
abstract: Tensions between the United States and Italy surged Tuesday, as Italian politicians and citizens reacted furiously to leaked reports in the Italian news media that a joint investigation into the shooting death of an Italian agent in Baghdad would absolve American soldiers of guilt in the incident.    The United States ambassador to Rome, Mel Sembler, met twice with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and his top aide at the government's headquarters to try to avert a crisis that could cost the United States one of its staunchest European allies in the Iraq conflict.

headline: S. & P. Cuts Debt Ratings for G.M. and Ford to Junk Status
abstract: The move will reduce the U.S. automakers' avenues for raising funds as they struggle with global competition and healthcare costs.

headline: Israel sets Holocaust damages at $240 billion
Currencies: As EU leaders talk, the dollar benefits
Russia to end Gazprom share curbs
Upstart in Iran Election Campaigns as Champion of Poor
abstract: Mahmud Ahmadinejad, presidential candidate in Iran, casts himself as simple, religious man who, if elected president, will fight for poor; his critics say he would usher in Taliban-style government and impose strict Islamic values; front-runner Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani is promoting his many years of experience in Iran's government as his credential for election; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia rejects UN's aid for Aceh
World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Profit Triples
abstract: Vivendi Universal, three years after reporting the largest corporate loss in French history, said its first-quarter profit tripled, increased by gains at its phone-services units and as music and video games returned to profit. Net income rose to 502 million euros ($508 million), or 44 cents a share, the company said. All five of its units were profitable in the quarter after job cuts last year in music and video games.

headline: Israel moves to soothe settlers
British Election Debates Spotlight Immigration Fears
abstract: The issue of immigration moved to the center of Britain's election debate on Friday but here, among the grocers of Surrey Street market and the downtown shopping malls, many people seemed to have already drawn their conclusions.    This town on London's southern fringe is widely known as the headquarters of the British Home Office immigration authority, located in a bleak high-rise called Lunar House.

headline: In Japan,bank hintsof tighteryen policy
Chinese Official Cuts Short Japan Trip to Protest Shrine Visit
abstract: As a fence-mending trip to Japan by a senior Chinese official ended in acrimony on Monday, China made clear on Tuesday that the official had cut short her visit to protest possible new visits to a war shrine by Japan's prime minister.    A spokesman for China's foreign ministry said China was ''extremely dissatisfied'' that Japanese leaders had made new statements about possible coming visits to the Yasukuni war shrine during an official visit to Japan by Wu Yi, a vice premier.

headline: Schiavo autopsy shows 'irreversible' damage
World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KPN Buys a Rival
abstract: Royal KPN, the largest Dutch telephone company, agreed to buy Telfort, a closely held company, for as much as 1.12 billion euros ($1.36 billion) to eliminate a local competitor and add 14 percent more mobile phone clients. KPN, based in The Hague, also agreed to as much as 140 million euros in additional payments linked to unspecified targets for sales, profit and clients, the company said.

headline: Under pressure, Sharon puts Palestinian prisoner releases on hold
Deutsche Bank Denies Reports That Its Chief Will Quit if Faced With New Fraud Trial
abstract: The clouds just will not seem to lift from the man who is perhaps Germany's most powerful banker.    Deutsche Bank on Thursday denied rumors that Josef Ackermann, its Swiss-born chief executive, would resign if faced with a new trial on charges that he defrauded shareholders of the telecommunications giant Mannesmann in the wake of a takeover battle with Vodafone of Britain.

headline: Canon gets another lift from lasers
Chinese Oil Company Offers $18.5 Billion for Unocal
abstract: The bid by CNOOC may be a watershed in Chinese corporate behavior and demonstrates the increasing influence of Wall Street's bare-knuckled tactics in Asia.

headline: Pope Is Buried, Mourned by the Mighty and the Ordinary
abstract: Pope John Paul II is buried after funeral mass that attracts hundreds of thousands of admirers from around world; it is the biggest funeral for a pope in the nearly 2,000-year history of the office; heads of state from over 70 countries attend amid tight security and concern over a terror attack; Pres Bush becomes the first American president to attend a pope's funeral; Italian authorities all but shut down central Rome, making it difficult to get to St Peter's Square, and the air space is closed to private planes; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Tribunal Has More Srebrenica Films
abstract: Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor for the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, said in the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, that her office had more videotapes of the massacre of Bosnian Muslims from Srebrenica by Serbs in 1995 and would show them at the tribunal next week, when the trial of Slobodan Milosevic resumes. She spoke as she was winding down a tour of former Yugoslav states ahead of a report she is to give to the Security Council next week on the region's cooperation with the court.   Nicholas Wood (NYT)

headline: Despite Tension, Bush-Putin Meeting Is Called a Success
abstract: The leaders met in what was widely expected to be a tense encounter, but advisers to both men moved swiftly to pronounce the meeting a success.

headline: Nine killed in Uzbek unrest
Despite G.M.'s Talk of Bold Plans, Analysts Ask if More Needs to Be Done
abstract: On Tuesday, almost immediately after Rick Wagoner, the chairman and chief executive of General Motors, said he planned to cut 25,000 jobs at the company, analysts were saying it was not enough. But on Wednesday, investors pushed G.M.'s stock up. Were they both right?    The analysts remain cautious because G.M. has purged hundreds of thousands of American jobs over the last three decades but has not yet found the formula for lasting success in a world that includes Toyota and other foreign competitors. The analysts said they saw the job cuts, laid out at G.M.'s annual meeting in Delaware, as a first step. But they are still looking for a fuller strategy from Mr. Wagoner.

headline: Photo Prints? Everyone Wants Your Business
abstract: CHERYL CONTEE has owned a digital camera for five years, and until last month, she always printed photos the same way: at home, using her Hewlett-Packard printer.    But on Mother's Day, just as she was about to print snapshots from a trip to California to show her grandmother later that day, Ms. Contee, who lives in Washington, discovered she was out of photo paper and low on toner. She didn't have time to get both things and print the photos, so she went to a digital printing kiosk at a CVS pharmacy down the street.

headline: Blair picks May 5 to hold elections
Wild ginseng harvest dwindles
Executive admits aiding AIG distort its finances
Can a Shy Theologian Transform into a Pope for the People?
EU trims British budget payment
AMERICAN AIRLINES WILL CUT 600 JOBS IN KANSAS CITY
abstract: American Airlines will cut as many as 600 jobs at maintenance base in Kansas City, Mo, as its losses extend to fifth year; reduction of up to 43 percent of center's workers wil occur in June (S)

headline: AIDS Now Compels Africa to Challenge Widows' 'Cleansing'
abstract: African political and tribal leaders are starting to link AIDS spread to so-called sexual cleansing, tradition that requires new widow to have sex with one of husband's relatives after funeral to protect self and village by breaking bond with his spirit; are speaking out against practice, prodded by leaders of region's fledgling women's rights movement, who say lack of control over their sex lives is major reason 6 in 10 of 25 million sub-Saharan Africans infected with HIV are women; change is coming slowly in region where belief in witchcraft is widespread; map; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Training Pakistani Units Fighting Qaeda
abstract: Americans have been training Pakistanis in night flying and airborne assault tactics to combat foreign and local fighters in the tribal areas of Pakistan near the Afghan border, the United States commander here, Lt. Gen. David W. Barno, said Tuesday in an interview.    It is the first time the American military has acknowledged the training. The presence of American troops in Pakistan is regarded as extremely delicate.

headline: Currencies: U.S. GDP data send dollar to new highs
New clients, services fuel rise in TIM profit
When Stock Tips Go Bad, Is the Broker to Blame?
abstract: IF you've seen more than one suspense movie, you know that it's just when a character is standing on the deck of his new boat, calm and confident and looking out into the sunset, that everything generally goes wrong. So, maybe, in retrospect, that should have been the tip-off.    In August 2000, Gene Murdock was, in fact, standing on the deck of his new houseboat, docked on the shore of Clarks Hill Lake on the Georgia-South Carolina border. He was on the cellphone to his broker and friend, Joseph Harris of the Merrill Lynch office in Augusta, Ga., a few miles away.

headline: Whoops! We Seem to Have Misplaced Your Identity
abstract: THE diesel-powered utility van is the unappreciated speed demon of the digital age. Even lumbering along city streets in stop-and-go traffic, it can move a trillion bytes of corporate data across town far faster than if they were sent across the Internet.    The homely Ford Econoline 350 is the workhorse of Iron Mountain, the dominating presence in the off-site data protection business. Its customers include more than three-fourths of Fortune 500 companies, and it had revenue of $1.82 billion last year, earned largely out of public sight as its unmarked vans shuttled among the back-office operations of its clients.

headline: First, Know Where to Dig
abstract: I GREW up on Long Island. My father was a homicide cop who retired as a detective captain. I met a number of F.B.I. agents through his work, and for a while I was interested in becoming one. Back then you needed an accounting degree or a law degree. I was ready to get my career started, so I stuck with my business major.     My first job was in seventh grade as a clam digger on the Great South Bay. You could earn $25 for digging 500 littleneck clams, a bushel's worth, or $5 for the same amount of chowder clams, which could only be used in soup. It didn't take long to figure out I wanted to find the places in the bay that had the littlenecks. On my best day, I earned almost $200, which was more than my dad's daily pay.

headline: Print industry strikes back in ad campaign
Israeli Chief Rabbi's Son Is Held in Kidnapping of Teenager
abstract: The wife, son and daughter of Israel's Sephardic chief rabbi were arrested by the police on Thursday night in connection with the kidnapping and beating of a 17-year-old boy who was in a romantic relationship with the rabbi's 18-year-old daughter.    The rabbi's son, Meir Amar, 30 or 31, was ordered held on Friday by a Tel Aviv court, along with two Israeli Arabs, who are accused of being accomplices. The police said that Meir Amar had confessed to kidnapping his sister's boyfriend after arranging to meet him in the street, and then took him to Kalansawa, an Israeli Arab village northeast of Tel Aviv.

headline: Another Anxious Journey for Chalabi: Across the Iraq Insurgency's Heartland
abstract: Ahmed Chalabi has had a dizzying succession of roles amid the turmoil of Iraq: initially, as the Pentagon's favorite to succeed Saddam Hussein, and when that relationship soured, as a petitioner for favors among the ruling ayatollahs of Iran. Earlier this year, he surfaced as political partner of Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric who twice staged uprisings against American troops.    But on Sunday, Mr. Chalabi offered a new dimension to his reputation. A month into a new job as a deputy prime minister in the new Shiite-led government, he set off on a nearly 400-mile road trip across northern and central Iraq. His purpose was to stamp his authority on the country's troubled northern oilfields, in his capacity as the overseer of energy in the new government.

headline: CONFLICTING ROLES PROMPT RESIGNATION FROM G.M. BOARD
abstract: General Motors, following assessment required under antitrust law, says Alan Lafley, who is also director of General Electric and chief executive of Procter & Gamble, has resigned from GM board; Erskine Bowles is nominated to board (S)

headline: Fraud Complaint Expected Against General Re Executive
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly plans to file civil securities fraud charges against General Re Corp top executive Richard Napier, who worked closely with American International Group senior executive Christian M Milton on deal several years ago that artificially inflated AIG accounts; AIG has admitted deal was improper and dismissed Milton for not cooperating with probe; former AIG head Maurice R Greenberg allegedly personally lobbied former General Re chief executive Ronald E Ferguson to handle deal (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: G.E. Unit Orders Jets From Two Makers
abstract: GE Commercial Aviation Service, the aircraft leasing unit of General Electric, placed an order for 30 jets from Airbus of Europe and Embraer of Brazil to meet rising demand from airlines seeking to expand and renew their fleets. The order is for 10 planes from the Airbus A350 family, which can carry up to 300 passengers, and 20 regional jets from the new Embraer 190/195 aircraft family, which have 100 to 118 seats. GE Commercial has a fleet of more than 1,300 aircraft. At list price, the Airbus deal is valued at about $1.6 billion; the purchase from Embraer would be $650 million.   Todd Benson (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Drought Hurts G.D.P.
abstract: Thailand's economy shrank for the first time in four years in the first quarter as a drought parched crops and tourists stayed away after the Dec. 26 tsunami. Gross domestic product fell a seasonally adjusted 0.6 percent from the fourth quarter, when it expanded 1.5 percent, the National Economic and Social Development Board said. The drought hurt Thailand's farms and food processing plants, which provide a living for three-fourths of the country's 65 million people.

abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

Lack of information slows bird flu investigation in China
Spain says it has cut pipeline to Iraq rebels
Bank in Utah Says Its Data Was at Risk in Intrusion
abstract: Utah-based Merrick Bank is latest company to become entangled in controversy over security breach that has put personal data on 40 million cardholders at risk for fraud; Merrick Bank began using CardSystems Solutions when it bought portion of Provident Bank's merchant business in November 2004; Merrick acknowledges that CardSystems had not complied with Visa and MasterCard's security standards, National Australia Bank says it detected fraudulent activity by few hundred MasterCard and Visa accounts as early as November 2004; cardholders in Australia, Japan, China and elsewhere in Asia have been told that their accounts are now at risk (M)

headline: The Quarter When Nothing Worked
abstract: Article on poor performance of stock and bond funds in first quarter; one niche that gained was natural-resources stock funds, which surged more than 13 percent in quarter on strength of high oil prices; declnes in other sectors were setback for investors after dreamlike fourth quarter 2004, when stock funds surged more than 10 percent; drawing (M)

Stocks: Mixed U.S. signals depress Wall Street

abstract: General Electric forms joint venture with Shanghai Xin Hua Control Technologies Co to expand production of power plant control systems in China; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: The Farm-Subsidy Model of Financing Academia
abstract: THE University of Michigan received $4 million for curriculum development and training at its Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy. Marshall University in West Virginia received $11 million for a new heart institute. The University of Iowa is hoping to get $16.5 million from a pending highway bill to study taxation of drivers based on miles driven on certain types of highways.     These are just three of thousands of examples of recent ''academic earmarks,'' provisions inserted into federal spending bills to finance specific university projects, like research, or the construction of classrooms and laboratories.

headline: 536 killed in flooding in China
At a Paris Cafe, a Stranger's Inquiries Break the Silence
abstract: Like many frequent travelers, I often mix business with pleasure. A meeting in Salzburg, Austria, is an excuse to visit Mozart's boyhood home, for example. A conference in Spain is a chance to see Picasso's ''Guernica.''     But I'll never forget the trip to Paris with my mother one summer. I attended my meetings in the morning and during the afternoon we did all the tourist things. We sipped espresso in out-of-the-way cafes and visited all the attractions, including the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre and the flower market.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Children Now As Deprived As After War
abstract: Millions of Russian children are being neglected and their situation is on a par with the desperate post-World War II period, the interior minister, Rashid G. Nurgaliyev, told a meeting of ministry officials. About 700,000 children are orphans, he said, while two million adolescents are illiterate and four million use drugs. He called for more collaboration between law-enforcement agencies and human rights groups and other public organizations.   Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

headline: Germany, Russia sign major business deals
Programs That Start When XP Does
abstract: Programs That Start When XP Does    Q. My Windows XP machine takes forever to start up. How can I tell what programs are loading during the start-up process?    A. One way to sneak a peek at what programs start up when you turn on your computer is to use the System Configuration Utility that comes with Windows XP. To get to it, go to the Start menu and select Run. In the Run box, type ''msconfig'' (without the quotation marks) to start the utility.    Click the Startup tab in the System Configuration box to see the list of programs that open when Windows starts up, along with check boxes to turn each program off or on during the next start-up.

headline: U.S. COURT BLOCKS SALE OF BRASIL TELECOM SHARES
abstract: Citigroup won a temporary restraining order blocking a deal that would allow Telecom Italia to gain greater control over Brasil Telecom Participações, a Brazilian telephone company in which the bank is a controlling shareholder. The ruling, by a federal court in New York, stops Citigroup's former investment manager in Brazil, Daniel Dantas, from selling his shares in Brasil Telecom to Telecom Italia. Last week, the Italian group agreed to pay 341 million euros ($439.8 million) to end all legal disputes with Mr. Dantas and buy his stake. Citigroup, which shares control of Brasil Telecom with Brazilian state-run pension funds, contended that the deal violated a court order.   Todd Benson (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: May Likely For South Asian Summit Meeting
abstract: The annual meeting of prime ministers from South Asian countries is most likely to be rescheduled for late May in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, the Press Trust of India reported. The previously scheduled meeting of the group, the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, was canceled in February when India refused to attend, citing insecurity in Bangladesh and King Gyanendra's seizure of power in Nepal.   Somini Sengupta (NYT)

headline: Oil Companies in Venezuela Face More Control by State
abstract: Venezuela's energy ministry, in new revenue-raising measure, says private oil companies operating in country will have to convert to joint ventures with governemnt within six months; Energy Min Rafael Ramirez says operating agreements will have to be swapped for ventures that are 51 percent state-owned and pay royalties of 30 percent; fields in question produce about 500,000 barrels of oil a day of Venezuela's total production of 2.6 million barrels a day; adds ministry, along with national oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, will begin process of discussion with 32 operating agreements so that they can reach objective of migration of contracts to existing law; says this will benefit Venezuelan government as well as companies that want to continue operating in country; BP Shell and ChevronTexaco, all of which have contracts that will be affected by new policy, cannot be reached for comment; photo (M)

abstract: Massive advertising agency chief executive Mitchell Davis hopes to make advertisements and product placements integral part of video games; Massive ads will appear for now only in games played on personal computers connected to Internet; Massive's technology will eventuallly work in games played on consoles that have Internet connection; Internet link lets Massive's software modify ads as players progress through game; Davis has signed deals with 10 major game publishers, which together will include Massive's software in 40 games by end of year, and with major advertisers; photos (M)

headline: View Points: Second thoughts from a onetime fan
Feeling Shortchanged, Genteelly
abstract: The 90-odd curators, security guards, horticulturists and other employees of the Hillwood Museum and Gardens have what might seem perfect jobs. They spend their workdays at the sumptuous Washington estate of the late cereal heiress and arts patron Marjorie Merriweather Post. They care for her treasures, said to include the largest collection of Russian imperial art outside Russia. Heads of state, ambassadors and first ladies grace the visitors' list.    But there is trouble in paradise. The museum failed to make all of its promised contributions to its employees' retirement plan in recent years, though it did deduct and forward the employees' own amounts. Nor did the museum explain its failure to the employees' satisfaction. In April, the missing money arrived in their accounts, but even then nothing was done to make up for the investment income the employees had lost. In the wave of anger and suspicion that now taints this genteel workplace lies a cautionary tale for America's coming ownership society.

headline: At least 73 dead, 440 hurt in Japan train derailment
Obituaries: Leslie Smith, toy car maker
Managing the Edge (and Bono)
abstract: I WAS a service brat. My father was in the British Air Force and my mother had been a schoolteacher in Ireland. I was born on a base in Germany. I lived in countries that included Malta and Yemen. When I was 10 my parents sent me to boarding school in Ireland. My childhood gave me an aptitude for travel and an ability to adapt to new circumstances.    I discovered quite early that I had no musical ability when I started numbering the piano keys before each lesson. But I liked listening to music, and during my teens I became aware of other jobs in the music industry. My heroes were the guys who managed Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones and the Beatles. I thought managing a big band would be enormous fun, but I didn't quite know how to get there.

World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Girl, 16, Held In 'Happy Slap' Attack
abstract: A 16-year-old girl was arrested and charged with being part of a group of youths that attacked another girl in Manchester while filming the incident on a mobile telephone. The victim, 16-year-old Becky Smith, was briefly knocked out and spent two days in the hospital with head injuries. The assault was the latest example of an apparent British craze known as ''happy slapping,'' in which youths randomly attack passers-by and then use their mobile phones to circulate pictures of the victims. Miss Smith's mother, Georgina, said that video phones should be banned from schools.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)

abstract: Analysts say integral part of Coca-Cola Co's growth over next decade will need to comef from other than traditional sodas; Coke investors are hoping company's new marketing chief Mary E Minnick will apply companywide product development lessons she learned in Japan, Coke's most profitable market; Minnick's new position merges two areas crucial to Coke's future: marketing and product development; she is also first woman to ascend to such central role at Coke; graph; photos (M)

headline: UBS Ordered to Pay $29 Million in Sex Bias Lawsuit
abstract: UBS is ordered by federal jury in New York to pay more than $29 million in damages to Laura Zubulake, former saleswoman who sued firm for sex discrimination; jury decides bank mistreated Zubulake because she is woman and then fired her after she complained to Equal Employment Opportunity Commission; UBS to appeal; photo (M)

Visa Job Is Said to Go To Shepardson Stern
abstract: Visa USA has awarded an assignment to create concepts for marketing campaigns aimed at younger consumers, ages 18 to 24, to Shepardson Stern & Kaminsky in New York, according to advertising executives who were told of the decision. The executives spoke on the condition of anonymity because a contract had not been signed.

headline: Indictments claim men plotted New York attacks
Appeals Court Rules Investors Can't Sue Seller of Tax Shelter
abstract: A federal appeals judge has ruled that wealthy investors cannot sue a big accounting firm over the sale of an illegal tax shelter, saying that they must seek arbitration instead.     Nine investors sued the accounting firm of BDO Seidman and Deutsche Bank in 2003 over the accounting firm's sale of a shelter known as Cobra, or currency options bring reward alternatives. The shelter generates artificial losses through offsetting trades of currencies that are channeled through partnerships. The Internal Revenue Service, which has never recognized the shelter, banned it in 2000 and has since assessed the nine investors for millions of dollars in unpaid taxes, plus penalties and interest.

headline: Bush Tells Putin Not to Interfere With Democracy in Former Soviet Republics
abstract: President Bush used the 60th anniversary of Nazi Germany's defeat to warn President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Saturday that ''no good purpose is served by stirring up fears and exploiting old rivalries'' in the former Soviet republics on his borders.    ''All the nations that border Russia will benefit from the spread of democratic values, and so will Russia itself,'' Mr. Bush said in a speech in Riga, Latvia, in the Small Guild House, a neo-gothic meeting hall in the capital's Old City. ''Stable, prosperous democracies are good neighbors, trading in freedom and posing no threat to anyone.''

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Bhutto Supporters Held Ahead Of Rally
abstract: Pakistani police arrest hundreds of opposition Pakistan People's Party members ahead of rally planned for arrival of Asif Ali Zardari, who is married to former Prime Min Benazir Bhutto, from Dubai (S)

headline: Sony Buys Warner Brothers' Matrix Game
abstract: Sony Online Entertainment will acquire Warner Brothers Entertainment's Matrix Online, studio's first internal foray into video games; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Carmaker's Profit Rises
abstract: The biggest carmaker in India, Maruti Udyog, said fourth-quarter profit surged 65 percent, beating expectations, setting off a 4 percent gain in its share price. Net income rose to 2.59 billion rupees ($60 million) from 1.57 billion rupees a year earlier, the company said.

headline: Wyeth Will Eliminate 750 Drug Sales Jobs
abstract: Wyeth will eliminate as many as 750 jobs, or 30 percent of its US sales force that calls on primary-care physicians; will switch some of its sales representatives to part time from full time (M)

abstract: Toyota Motor says it plans to build a hybrid version of its Camry sedan at its manufacturing complex in Georgetown, Ky (S)

abstract: Pres Emile Lahoud of Lebanon appoints Najib Mikati, pro-Syrian businessman and member of Parliament as prime minister-designate, breaking weeks of deadlock over formation of Lebanese government and paving way for parliamentary elections in late May or June; photo (M)
