World Briefing | United Nations: Security Council Orders New Lebanon Inquiry
abstract: United Nations Security Council orders investigation into assassination of former Lebanese Prime Min Rafik al-Hariri; asserts that earlier investigations, conducted by Lebanese law enforcement, were insufficient and that Syrian involvement in events prior to Hariri's death need to be assessed (S)

headline: Iran Reports Gain in Test of Missile Fuel
abstract: Iran says it has successfully tested solid-fuel motor for its medium-range ballistic missile known as Shahab 3, raising concerns that it could reach its enemies, including American forces in region and Israel, with more precision (S)

headline: Europeans' Anger May Step Up the Pace of Change
abstract: If voters are angry about economic legislation that rolls back the social welfare state, and they take out their anger on the governing party, does that make more such legislation inevitable?    As undemocratic as that might sound, investors in Germany seem to think so. As financial analysts said chances of new legislation had increased, the country's stock market rallied Monday after a stinging defeat in regional elections for the Social Democratic Party of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, which led him to call for national elections in the fall.

headline: Oil Companies Lose Effort to End Suits Over Contaminated Water
abstract: Federal Judge Shira A Scheindlin rules that major oil companies must defend dozens of lawsuits accusing them of fouling groundwater by using gasoline additive that has become political liability in proposed energy bill; ruling means that plaintiffs can proceed with some 80 lawsuits against oil companies asserting that additive, methyl tertiary-butyl ether, or MTBE, fouled groundwater; suits were brought by water providers, towns, counties and cities, including New York City and state of New Hampshire; members of Congress debate energy bill with legal protections for producers of additive that would nullify most of lawsuits; opposition to waiver in Senate bill was crucial reason energy bill failed in 2003; Scheindlin does not rule on merits of cases, but she outlines new theory of 'commingled product' liability that would place more legal burden on MTBE producers, which include Exxon Mobil and Lyondell Chemical (M)

headline: TRIAL BALLOON
abstract: Amid the growing rivalry between the Nasdaq market and the New York Stock Exchange, nothing is being overlooked, not even how to celebrate an I.P.O.    The Big Board has its opening-bell ceremony, while Nasdaq offered a photo op in front of its eight-story-tall animated sign in Times Square.

headline: Obituaries: Robert Creeley, leading poet in literary avant-garde, 78
World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Health Concern For Father Of Bomb
abstract: A.Q. Khan, the disgraced former head of Pakistan's nuclear arms program, suffered chest pain and was advised to undergo angiography, but Information Minister Sheik Rashid Ahmed denied reports Dr. Khan, 69, had suffered a heart attack. Acquaintances of Dr. Khan, however, insisted he had had a minor heart attack. He has been under house arrest since confessing last February to running the largest illegal nuclear proliferation network in history.   Salman Masood (NYT)

headline: Putin rejects criticism by his Israeli hosts
When It Comes to Cash, Sooner Looks a Lot Like Later
abstract: THE good news for people with a stash of ready cash is that short-term interest rates have climbed to almost four times their paltry year-ago levels of less than 1 percent.     The bad news is that this gain has not produced all of the usual long-term benefits for savers.

headline: 2 Citigroup Officers Settle S.E.C. Claims
abstract: Two executives of Citigroup agreed to settle regulators' claims that they failed to properly supervise the analyst Jack B. Grubman, who has been banned from the industry for publishing fraudulent research.    John B. Hoffmann and Kevin J. McCaffrey will pay $120,000 each and be barred from overseeing others in the securities industry for 15 months, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday. The executives, who supervised Mr. Grubman in 2000 and 2001, did not admit or deny wrongdoing.

headline: CBS Promotes Fall Lineup and Takes Shots at Rivals
abstract: CBS presents its fall program schedule at Carnegie Hall; Leslie Moonves, co-president of Viacom, which owns CBS, mercilessly baits Jeff Zucker, president of NBC Universal Television Group, and Moonves's archrival; photo of Jennifer Love Hewitt, who will be in Ghost Whisperer, new show this fall on CBS (M)

headline: Men's Fitness Magazine Takes a Little Dig at Hip-Hop Celebrity
abstract: Men's Fitness magazine puts rapper Ja Rule on its cover, ranking him No. 1 in its list of '25 Fittest Guys'; earlier cover with 50 Cent, with whom Ja Rule has feuded, sold more copies than any issue in five years; photos (S)

headline: 15 Recruits, Mostly Kurds, Are Killed by Car Bomb
abstract: Car bomb kills 15 and wounds 125 in Erbil, northern Kurdish town that had until recently been one of most peaceful towns in Iraq; mayor says strike is reminiscent of May 4 strike that killed 60 people; militant group Ansar al-Sunna claimed responsibility for that strike; June 20 bombing in Erbil is one of several leaving total of 30 people dead; two bombs go off near Kirkuk, also in north; in Baghdad, four car bombs explode, killing 10 members of Iraqi security forces; photo (M)

headline: Wider Net Cast in Saks Inquiry
abstract: SEC expands investigation of Saks Fifth Avenue to include so-called chargebacks, deductions merchants take on payments to apparel makers for supposedly defective or unwanted goods; vendors have complained that chargebacks are fanciful deductions from what stores rightly owe them; SEC is also examining some records from late 2004; Saks Inc's own internal investigation identified no improper collections in 2004 fiscal year, but Saks Fifth Avenue is reportedly returning some money collected during that period (M)

headline: A Broadband Beat-Down
abstract: IT looked for a while as if the United States was firmly entrenched as the world's leader in Internet innovation. President Bill Clinton and Al Gore, his vice president, did much to encourage development of the country's technology infrastructure, writes Thomas Bleha in an article accessible on the Foreign Affairs magazine Web site (www.foreignaffairs.org).    From the 1960's until the day President Bush took office, he writes, ''The United States led the world in Internet development.''

headline: Siemens to Shed Sagging Phone Unit
abstract: Siemens is a pillar of German industry and one of Europe's most-recognized brand names. BenQ is an ambitious, but little known, Taiwan maker of flat-panel screens and cellular phones that was spun off by the Acer Corporation just four years ago.    On Tuesday, the Asian upstart helped dig the European giant out of a hole, by agreeing to take over its money-losing cellular phone unit. To shed the business, Siemens will pay BenQ 250 million euros ($306 million), and buy 50 million euros ($61 million) worth of its shares.

headline: Morningstar shines in Nasdaq debut
What Difference Does Digital Make? Ask 5 Photographers
abstract: INSTANT -- I took this picture at the Landmark Tavern in Manhattan, intentionally creating a ghostlike effect to hark back to the tale of a Confederate soldier who was supposedly shot and killed at the very spot. Had I shot this with film, it would have been mostly guesswork.   LIBRADO ROMERO

headline: News Media's Careful Plans Still Left Room for Emotions
abstract: After a long, sorrowful vigil, the Vatican chose to inform the news media of Pope John Paul II's death in the most efficient, if prosaic, way possible: an e-mail message sent to all the major news organizations.     And after two days of somber vigil, the television coverage was just as no-nonsense. The broadcast networks interrupted regular programming with the long-expected announcement and briskly delivered assessments of the John Paul's legacy and the search for a new pope.

headline: Europeans Schedule New Talks With Iran on Its Nuclear Plans
abstract: Leading foreign ministers of Europe set another round of talks with Iran for early next week, most likely in Paris, amid growing hopes that they can put off confrontation over Iran's suspected nuclear program until next month (M)

abstract: Serbian government says that Nebojsa Pavkovic, former Yugoslav army chief indicted by UN war crimes tribunal in 2003 for his role in 'widespread and systematic campaign of terror and violence' against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, has agreed to surrender; photo (S)

headline: Baghdad Violence Claims Life of Iraqi Official
abstract: A recent lull in terrorist activity in Baghdad ended today in an outburst of violence that included the killing of an Oil Ministry official and an American soldier.

headline: Vatican Says Mexican Priest Will Not Face Abuse Trial
abstract: The founder of an influential Roman Catholic order in Mexico will not face a church trial on longstanding allegations that he molested teenagers, a Vatican spokesman said on Saturday.     In December, the Vatican opened a full-scale investigation into the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado, the 85-year-old founder of the Legionaries of Christ and a prominent religious figure in Mexico. At least eight people came forward in the late 1990's to accuse him of abusing them between 1943 and the early 1960's.

headline: Canadian leader apologizes
Tokyo governor visits disputed islets
Dragnet Arrests in Zimbabwe Send Warning
abstract: With grocery stores bereft of basic goods and the currency once more in free fall, Zimbabwe's government said Monday that it had rounded up more than 9,600 residents of the capital, Harare, in a crackdown on black-market peddlers and ''general lawlessness.''    The official explanation for the dragnet, announced in state-run newspapers, was that the raids were aimed at black-market profiteers who were hoarding commodities like cooking oil and corn meal, creating artificial shortages.

headline: Victory Is Seen for Hard-Liner in Iranian Vote
abstract: The conservative mayor of Tehran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, a former hard-line militia member, appeared to be rolling to a landslide victory in the presidential runoff election as votes were being counted Saturday, after a campaign that exposed deep class divisions in Iran and a widespread desire to rid the country of corruption and cronyism.    In the first official preliminary results of Friday's voting, released by the Interior Ministry on state television at 9 a.m., Mr. Ahmadinejad was said to have won 14.4 million of 23.2 million votes counted.

headline: Blair and Archrival Are Now Seen Everywhere Together
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair and Chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown appear together publicly at several events and in brief movie causing speculation that show of unity between men is intended to shield Blair from protest voting in May elections because Brown is more popular with voters in some opinion polls; two men have had tense and competitive relationship over Brown's role as Blair's heir apparent; photo (M)

headline: Madison Avenue Replicates Old Game Shows for TV Advertising
abstract: MADISON Avenue's going for game shows, and quiz shows too, not to mention talent shows.    To attract attention amid the commercial clutter, a growing number of advertisements appearing on television are borrowing creative elements from famous TV shows of the past. There are spoofs of vintage game shows, salutes to successful quiz-show contestants, fast-talking announcers delivering prize pitches and characters who impersonate the judges on ''American Idol.''

headline: Paris Holds Street Party in Olympic Bid
abstract: Why does this page look this way?

headline: As Cellphones Bulk Up, How Much Is Too Much?
abstract: EVEN when it's turned off, the cool cellphone of the moment -- the slender, silver Moto Razr by Motorola -- makes a statement: it knows what it is. The Razr has a collection of nice features like a sizable screen, a decent camera, good battery life and Bluetooth for cordlessly communicating with a personal computer or a headset.    Yet the Razr is largely defined by what it is not. It stands apart from the industry drift toward making the cellphone into a digital Swiss Army knife, a supermarket of technology squeezed into a palm-size device that includes a typewriter's worth of keys, and enough storage and software to accommodate everything from family photo albums to corporate presentations.

headline: Dozens killed in Iraq as rebels strike back
Bush Says Iran's Elections Ignore 'Basic Requirements'
abstract: On the eve of the election in Iran, President Bush declared Thursday that the electoral process there had failed to meet ''the basic requirements of democracy'' and that the ''oppressive record'' of the country's rulers would undercut the legitimacy of the vote.    Mr. Bush's criticism of Iran was in sharp contrast to the praise that members of the administration had showered on Egypt and Saudi Arabia for their modest moves toward elections, and it appeared to amount to a pre-emptive American effort to challenge Friday's vote.

headline: Two veiled women shoot Cairo tour bus
When Bulls and Bears Dine, Lots of Grist to Chew Over
abstract: On a cold evening a few months back, 25 casually clad traders and portfolio managers gathered in a Bear, Stearns conference room over crab cakes and filet mignon to discuss stock ideas in the technology sector. Bear, Stearns technology and telecommunications analysts waxed poetic about their ideas and encouraged the usually cagey traders and managers to share theirs, without much success.    Few would acknowledge that they came away from the meeting with anything worthwhile. ''Information is key,'' one trader who has attended various idea dinners said. ''You don't want to give away what you've got.''

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: U.S. Must Wait For Qaeda Suspect
abstract: Abu Faraj al-Libbi, the Libyan described as the third-most-senior leader in Al Qaeda's network, is still in Pakistani custody and will not handed over to the United States quickly, Foreign Minister Khurshid Mehmood Kasuri, said. ''Until all the issues are cleared, there is no question of him being handed over to anyone else,'' he said. ''Anything relevant to American security is being shared.'' Pakistan announced the arrest last week. Mr. Libbi is suspected of orchestrating two assassination attempts on Pakistan's president and of heading a plot to kill its prime minister. A number of arrests followed the seizure of Mr. Libbi near Peshawar, and officials say the army has stepped up the hunt for Osama bin Laden. If he is alive, Mr. Kasuri speculated, he is probably continually moving between the tribal areas of Pakistan and Afghanistan, and not with a large group of people, ''otherwise he'd be detected.''   Salman Masood (NYT)

headline: With Its Home Page, Google Could Get a Bit Closer to Its Users
abstract: Google begins testing service that lets users build customized Google home page filled with news, stock quotes and other features found on Internet portals, adding another potential entry point in battle to deliver ads tailored to user's stated or implied tastes or product searches; some privacy advocates believe that as Google entices users to agree to surveillance of their online activities, it must do more to prove it deserves their trust; photo (M)

headline: Tech Brief: RIM hits impasse in patent feud
Internet Site Says Zarqawi Is Healthy and in Charge
abstract: A posting on Friday on the Internet site for Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the group led by the Islamic militant Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, reversed two days of dire warnings about his condition and stated that he was ''in good health and runs the jihad operation by himself,'' according to the SITE Institute, a group that tracks the postings.    It was one in a series of conflicting statements in recent days about Mr. Zarqawi's health. On Tuesday, his group said he had been seriously injured and urged Muslims to pray for his recovery. On Thursday, postings on two different Islamist sites said after suffering a bullet wound in his lung, he had appointed a deputy to stand in for him and left Iraq to seek medical care.

headline: Swiss voters likely to say 'yes' to closer EU ties
In Amsterdam, mayor is a job for a mediator
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Federal Forces Sent To Border City
abstract: President Vicente Fox deployed hundreds of federal forces to take control of the border city of Nuevo Laredo to contain increasing violence. On Saturday, the local police opened fire on a convoy of federal agents, seriously wounding one, and on Wednesday, gunmen killed the new police chief on his first day on the job. A turf war among rival drug gangs has unleashed a wave of violence in Nuevo Laredo, with more than 50 people killed so far this year. A spokesman for Mr. Fox, Rubén Aguilar, said the federal action was necessary ''because there are very clear indications of the relationship of elements of the police of Nuevo Laredo with the drug traffic.'' After the attack on the federal convoy, 41 local police officers were detained and taken to Mexico City for questioning.   Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

headline: Pakistan's High Court Reviewing Officially Ordered Gang Rape
abstract: Supreme Court of Pakistan begins hearing case of Mukhtaran Bibi, also referred to as Mukhtar Mai, whose gang rape on orders of village council inspired international outrage and made her symbol of mistreatment of women in Pakistan; she was gang-raped in 2002 as punishment after her 12-year-old brother was accused of having sex with woman from higher-caste tribe; investigators later said charge was cover-up after boy himself was victim of sex crime; case of Bibi's gang rape has undergone series of twists and turns; Pakistani government barred her from traveling to United States, then lifted restriction after American officials condemned it; now Supreme Court will decide whether to uphold death sentences imposed on those who raped her, or let accused go free; photo (M)

headline: Tech Brief: AOL plans unlimited mail space
Benedict XVI Promises Dialogue and Reconciliation
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI and cardinals who elected him seek to transform his image from authoritarian doctrinal watchdog to humble servant and pastor; he uses his first papal Mass to send message of openness and reconciliation to his Roman Catholic followers; says his 'primary commitment' would be to work toward 'full and visible unity of all Christ's followers'; this is striking shift in tone from two days ago, when then-Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger denounced what he called 'dictatorship of relativism' and 'new sects' that draw in believers through 'human trickery'; cardinals take unusual step of appearing at joint news conferences and agreeing to individual interviews, describing new pope as 'compassionate,' 'collegial' and 'shy'; Vatican has demonstrated sensitivity to public image and skillful use of television to promote John Paul's papacy; all seven American cardinals, appearing at news conference, acknowledge concern that some American Catholics might prejudge new pope by his reputation as cardinal; photos (L)

headline: Letter: Is 'see no evil' a stone in Beijing's global path?
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Boston Scientific, Natick, Mass., a maker of cardiac stents, said it had bought TriVascular, Santa Rosa, Calif., a manufacturer of devices that patch and bypass weak spots in blood vessels. Terms were not disclosed.    Honeywell International, Morristown, N.J., the technology and manufacturing company, agreed to buy Zellweger Analytics, a Swiss maker of systems to detect toxic and flammable gases, from Hesta, a Swiss real estate company. Terms were not disclosed.    Pitney Bowes, Stamford, Conn., the maker of office supplies and equipment, said it had acquired certain assets of Fala Sorting Services, Melville, N.Y., which provides domestic and international mailing services in the greater New York region. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Yuan exceeds trading range
Macao gets tough to clean up its image
Other Perils of Overweight
abstract: Article in series Obesity Inc focuses on weight-loss surgery known as bariatric surgery, which has eliminated debilitating diseases and improved quality of life for thousands of patients, but is now threatened by malpractice lawsuits against and growing reluctance of health plans to provide coverage; American Society of Bariatric Surgery says patients and insurers spent more than $3.5 billion in 2004 for 145,000 bariatric procedures at average of $25,000 each; add complications can raise patient's costs to $100,000; some other treatments for obesity that are under development discussed; chart; photos (M)

headline: 1 Afghan and 20 Insurgents Killed in Firefight Around Mountain Villages
After Cost-Cutting, MCI Posts a Small Loss
abstract: MCI Inc., the long-distance carrier that has agreed to be sold to Verizon Communications, posted a small loss in the first quarter as it made deep cost cuts to offset steep declines in revenue.    The company, based in Ashburn, Va., said yesterday that it lost $2 million, or 1 cent a share, in the first quarter after losing $388 million, or $1.19 a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 12 percent, to $4.8 billion.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Another Appeal For Taiwan Talks
abstract: China renewed its offer to open talks with Taiwan's governing party, its latest attempt to ease tensions with the island. Beijing generated widespread international criticism after it passed legislation last month authorizing war if Taiwan declares formal independence but has since been seeking to smooth relations. The offer came after a top official of Taiwan's opposition Nationalist Party ended a high-profile visit to the mainland. Beijing repeated its longstanding condition that Taiwan must accept that it is part of ''one China'' before formal talks could commence.   Joseph Kahn (NYT)

headline: DataBank; Falling Oil Prices Bolster the Stock Market
abstract: Stock market rose modestly during week; Dow Jones industrial average climbed 57.04 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,461.34; Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 8.28 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,181.20; Nasdaq composite index climbed 14.54 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,999.35; graphs (M)

headline: Oil Prices Are Up, Scandals Are Down and Trade Squabbles Erupt
abstract: Not so long ago, it looked as if the country was in the middle of a Decade of Corporate Scandal. Beginning with the bankruptcy of Enron in 2001, there has been a steady drumbeat of corporate blowups, including the WorldCom fraud, the Wall Street analysts' scandal, the mutual fund trading chicanery, HealthSouth's dodgy accounting and now the balance-sheet legerdemain of the American International Group and other big insurers.

headline: Currencies: Trade-deficit data push dollar higher
COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: A COMPANY THAT BUYS real estate only from financial institutions and then signs long-term leases with tenants is one of a growing number of real estate investment trusts tailored to individual industries. [C6.]    COMMUNITY COLLEGES, often working closely with public officials, are taking important roles in the renewal of downtown areas in parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. [C7.]

headline: India uses VAT in tax-evasion battle
Court Frees Dissident Who Said Iranians Wanted Better Ties With U.S.
abstract: A prominent Iranian dissident, jailed more than two years, was released after the Iranian Supreme Court turned down espionage charges against him, his lawyer said today.

headline: Barclays goes back to Africa
Martha Stewart to Get Sirius Radio Channel
NEWALLIANCE BANCSHARES TO BUY CORNERSTONE BANCORP
abstract: NewAlliance Bancshares agrees to buy Cornerstone Bancorp for $49 million in cash or stock to add branches in southwestern part of Connecticut (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NORTHROP GRUMMAN, Los Angeles, the military contractor, said that it had received a $3.2 billion, five-year contract from Boeing to continue production work on the Navy's F/A-18 Super Hornet aircraft.    DSM, a Dutch maker of drug ingredients, said that it would close a vitamin plant in Belvidere, N.J., by the end of the year, cutting 150 jobs, and move production to a plant in Scotland.    TIAA-CREF, New York, the retirement fund, named John Wilcox senior vice president in charge of corporate governance, one week after a report criticized the fund's oversight of its auditor.    MCDONALD BRADLEY, McLean, Va., which provides networking software to the United States government, said that it had agreed to acquire Infodata Systems, Herndon, Va., which creates software, for $7.56 million.

headline: Indians Investing, but Carefully, in Hollywood
abstract: Motion picture and television producers are asking Indian tribes to invest some money from gambling casinos in films and programs; tribes, long unimpressed with often non-Indian storylines or what they deemed cliched depictions of Indian culture, have begun backing few projects; securing commitment from tribe can take months and Indian nations rarely partner among selves to invest in projects; photos (M)

headline: China calls for 6-party Korea talks
Tax Protester Pleads Guilty to Filing False Claim
abstract: A California businessman who boasted that he paid no income taxes because no law required him to do so has pleaded guilty to filing a false refund claim, the latest blow to the tax protest movement.      George H. Jesson, 54, of the Orange County town of Fountain Valley, admitted in Federal District Court in Los Angeles on Monday that he committed a felony in obtaining a $215,000 tax refund from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: U.S. Attorney Subpoenas Chubb Over Its Use of Reinsurance
abstract: Chubb Corp receives subpoena from federal prosecutors investigating its use of nontraditional insurance that can artificially enhance financial results; such policies are central to multiple investigations into insurance industry in general and into American International Group in particular; specific type of insurance of interest to prosecutors is known as finite or financial reinsurance (M)

headline: Nice Fit: Old Lens on a New Digital S.L.R.
abstract: New Pentax digital single-lens reflex camera accepts every lens Pentax has made for its 35-millimeter cameras, although adapters are required in some cases; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israeli And Palestinian Mayors Pledge Peace
abstract: More than dozen Israeli and Palestinians mayors meet in Jericho and pledge unified effort against continuing violence in Israel (S)

headline: Violence erupts in north Kosovo town
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Alltel, Little Rock, Ark., the mobile telephone company, said it had sold its stake in Fidelity National Financial, Jacksonville, Fla., a title-insurance company, to Goldman Sachs Group, New York, the investment bank, for about $350 million.    Honeywell International, Morris Township, N.J., the technology and manufacturing company, said it had sold its industrial wax units in Belgium and China to Paramelt, a Dutch producer of specialty wax. Terms were not disclosed.    United Defense Industries, Arlington, Va., which makes weapons for the United States military, said it would provide more Bradley Combat Systems vehicles to the Army under a contract valued at as much as $143 million.    Restoration Hardware, Madera, Calif., the home furnishings retailer, said its chief executive, Gary Friedman, would also serve as chairman.

headline: In Gaza, the Scene Is Bloody but Settlers Vow to Stay
abstract: GANEI TAL, Gaza Strip, June 7 - In the early afternoon, Amnon Ditur said goodbye to his Palestinian and Chinese workers and went home for lunch, leaving them seated at a metal table in his greenhouse on this Gaza Strip settlement, where they were sorting fresh chives into fist-sized bundles bound with rubber bands.

headline: Test of Wills: the Burmese Captive Who Will Not Budge
abstract: Seventeen years ago, as the people of Myanmar filled the streets in mass protests against their military dictatorship, a striking, self-possessed woman rose to address a rally at the great golden Shwedagon Pagoda. At the time, nobody realized the price she would pay for her outspokenness.    The woman, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was visiting from her home in England to tend to her sick mother when pro-democracy protests swelled throughout the country in August 1988 despite a brutal response by the military that took thousands of lives.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group, London and The Hague, consolidated its worldwide media account, with spending estimated at $240 million, at two media agencies owned by the WPP Group, which competed in a review as Team Media for Shell. The agencies, MediaCom, New York, and Maxus, London, already handle various media assignments for the company and will be assuming duties that had been handled by agencies including Carat USA, New York, part of the Carat division of the Aegis Group; Initiative, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies; and the Starcom MediaVest Group, Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe. Team Media for Shell competed against Initiative in the review.    American Century Investments, Kansas City, Mo., the investment management company, named TBWA/Chiat/Day, New York, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled by RPA, Santa Monica, Calif. American Century also named Tequila, New York, part of TBWA, to handle interactive duties and OMD, New York, part of Omnicom, to handle media duties. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

headline: Tragicomedy of Life in Baghdad Is Brought Home in a TV Series
abstract: One morning last month, Qasim al-Malakh, one of Iraq's best-known actors, stood near a dusty vacant lot in a dangerous part of southern Baghdad. He was dressed immaculately in a dark suit and tie, and his co-star, Nagham al-Sultani, stood next to him in a white bridal gown.    They were there to film the last episode of ''Love and War,'' Iraq's most popular television drama. Their characters, Fawzi and Fatin, had just married after a long and troubled romance.

headline: Demand for Oil Helped Push U.S. Trade Deficit to $61 Billion in February
abstract: The United States trade deficit expanded in February for the third month in a row, reaching a record $61 billion, as the rising cost of oil and America's unrestrained appetite for foreign goods propelled imports to unprecedented heights.    The Commerce Department reported yesterday that imports ballooned to $161.5 billion, $2.6 billion more than in January. Meanwhile, exports remained virtually flat at $100.5 billion. Over all, the nation recorded a $64.7 billion deficit in the trade of goods, slightly tempered by a $3.7 billion surplus in services.

headline: Time change joins list of 'holidays' used to market products
10-Month Trial of Oil Tycoon in Moscow Draws to Close
abstract: Former oil tycoon Mikhail B Khodorkovsky makes final plea of innocence, ending most prominent criminal trial in post-Soviet Russia; chief judge says she will hand down vedict on Apr 27; Khodorkovsky calls criminal charges against him and partner Platon Levedev a farce, to allow plunder of Yukos, oil company he once headed that now lies in tatters after government auctioned off core asset to state oil company; says judges will decide his fate based on instructions from Kremlin; even some political analysts with ties to Pres Vladimir V Putin's administration agree with that (M)

headline: Digeo Chooses Samsung to Make Set-Top Boxes
abstract: Digeo, company that designs software for set-top boxes used with cable television systems, to name Samsung to make its next generation of boxes; deal is bid by two companies to break into market tightly controlled by Scientific Atlanta and Motorola, which both make boxes and other equipment used in cable systems (S)

headline: U.S. economy grows at slowest in 2 years
Japan Reiterates Apology to China for World War II
France wins contest for new fusion reactor
Israelis' Departure Imperils Booming Gaza Industry Zone
abstract: Gaza's economic future may be imperiled by Israelis' departure; industrial park on northern edge of Gaza Strip may be permanently crippled; it has been rare example of win-win arrangement, with Israelis and Palestinians owning factories in park in roughly equal numbers, employing 5,000 workers from Gaza; map (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Fuso chooses new chief in bid for trust
MOODY'S MAY CUT RATING ON LIBERTY MEDIA
abstract: The Liberty Media Corporation's debt was placed under review for a possible downgrading by Moody's Investors Service yesterday after the company said it might seek acquisitions or return equity to shareholders. Liberty, controlled by the cable television entrepreneur John C. Malone, has about $10 billion in long-term unsecured debt that is rated Baa3, the lowest investment-grade level. Liberty's plan to raise up to $2 billion of bank debt at its QVC television shopping business ''contributes to the credit pressure,'' Moody's said. The review will focus on the company's long-term strategy and its ability to meet financial obligations, Moody's said. Stock in Liberty, which is based in Englewood, Colo., fell 8 cents, to $10.40 a share.

headline: Trade data bode well for the U.S.
Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates To Double Dividend
abstract: Computer Associates International, the world's fifth-largest software maker, said yesterday that it would double its dividend and buy back as much as $400 million of its shares in fiscal 2006. The annual cash dividend will be increased to 16 cents a share, the company said. The dividend increase comes after similar moves by other software, semiconductor and computer companies to reward shareholders as their stocks have languished. Computer Associates' shares have fallen 11 percent this year, in contrast to a 2 percent loss in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The company had $3.33 billion in cash and short-term investments as of Dec. 31. Shares of Computer Associates, based in Islandia, N.Y., rose 42 cents, to $27.65.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Turkish Phone Sale Disputed
abstract: TeliaSonera plans to sue the owner of a stake in Turkcell Iletisim Hizmetleri, Turkey's biggest mobile phone company, for backing out of a $3.1 billion sale of its holding. The owner, Cukurova Group of Turkey, cited public pressure for the operator to remain in Turkish control. TeliaSonera, the Nordic region's largest phone company, already owns 37 percent of Turkcell. Cukurova signed a preliminary agreement in March to sell 27 percent of Turkcell to TeliaSonera. ''We still want to go through with this deal,'' TeliaSonera's chief executive, Anders Igel, above, said in a phone interview from Istanbul.

headline: Duke to buy Cinergy for $9 billion
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: US Airways and America West to Merge In $1.5 Billion Deal Creating the No. 5 Airline  US Airways and America West plan to merge in a $1.5 billion deal that would create the nation's fifth-largest airline. The deal, the first significant merger in the airline industry in four years, might be the start of a long-expected wave of industry consolidation. [C1.]    European Economies Diverge, Challenging Policy Makers  Some European countries are flourishing while others linger on the brink of recession, challenging the continent's economic policy makers [C1.]    Google to Let Users Customize Its Search Page  Google introduces new features that will allow users to personalize its homepage with features they use frequently. [C1.]    Wal-Mart is retreating from an ambitious online venture, a DVD rental service meant to compete in the market pioneered by NetFlix. [C3.]    G.M. Revising Its Development and Sales Strategy  General Motors outlined a new product development and sales strategy, saying that Chevrolet and Cadillac would be the company's only brands to offer a full lineup of vehicles. [C1.]    Ford suffered another hit to its bruised credit rating as Fitch downgraded its debt but left it at investment grade. [C6.]    Fannie Mae Says It Meets Regulator's Standards  Fannie Mae said yesterday that it was able to satisfy its regulator's most recent standards for capital, even as Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan separately prodded the mortgage giant to shrink its portfolio to raise its reserves. [C3.]    Scrushy Jury Rehears Secretly Taped Conversation  A secretly made recording of a conversation between Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, and his chief financial officer is replayed for the jury at Mr. Scrushy's fraud trial. [C2.]    Leading Indicators and Jobless Claims Both Fall  The economy offered conflicting signs yesterday as a gauge of future business activity fell for the fourth consecutive month while people signing up for unemployment insurance dropped sharply. [C3.]    Stocks rose for a fourth day, extending their biggest rally in six months, as oil prices dropped below $47 a barrel and technology shares advanced. [C10.]    Restrictions on Morgan StanleyBonuses  Morgan Stanley said two senior executives who resigned last month would have to forgo bonus payments of $6.4 million each if they join dissident executives opposed to Philip J. Purcell this year. [C3.]    Gateway Founder Resigning as Chairman  Ted Waitt said he was resigning as chairman of Gateway, the personal computer maker he started 20 years ago. [C8.]    Investor Group to Buy Maytag for $1.13 billion  Maytag, the appliance maker, agrees to be acquired by a private investment group for $1.13 billion, buying time to reorganize. [C2.]    Fauchon, a Paragon of French Food, Retrenches in Paris  Fauchon, a luxury food emporium, is selling its satellite shops to a rival gourmet food chain and retrenching to its flagship store on Place de la Madeleine in Paris. The move ends an aggressive expansion campaign for the company, which was founded by a pushcart grocer in 1886. [C4.]    Hollinger's Black Sells his London Townhouse  Conrad M. Black, the deposed head of the publisher Hollinger International, recently sold his townhouse in the upscale London neighborhood of Kensington for £13.5 million ($25 million), executives who had been briefed on the transaction said. [C2.]    Fox and UPN Introduce Their Fall Lineups  Fox and UPN introduce their new lineups to advertisers, with Fox retaining most of the shows that made it the leading network this year. [C7.]    Internet Phone Companies Told to Provide 911 Service  Companies that deliver telephone service over the Internet must provide 911 emergency service, the Federal Communications Commission said. [C8.]    Two Who Escaped the Fallout of the Sunbeam Collapse  Two financiers who were among the most respected and feared in America sat down to make a deal that turned out to be disastrous for almost everyone involved -- except for themselves. Floyd Norris. [C1.]    A Fuel Efficient Wardrobe in Japan Shuns Neckties  Japan is encouraging executives to dress casually -- that is, without a necktie -- this summer to reduce energy use. [A1.]    Technology Erodes Big Board Family Traditions  Fathers and sons and siblings have been the lifeblood of the New York Stock Exchange for generations, but the need for speed and capital is eroding that tradition and a merger with Archipelago could hasten its demise. [C9.]    The new face of Wall Street might be compliance lawyers. They are frequently the only people standing between their investment firms and a lethal blow from the government, and their status is assured and growing. [A1.]

headline: Bulgaria pulling troops out of Iraq
Turkish Leader Spells Out More Vigorous Role in Iraq
abstract: Turkey's prime minister, Recip Tayyip Erdogan, said yesterday that while Iraq had become a ''training ground for terrorists'' since the start of the war, which Turkey opposed, he had confidence in Ibrahim al-Jaafari, the Iraqi leader, and was helping him to make Iraq a democracy.    ''My impression with meeting Mr. Jaafari is that he is very keen on achieving democracy in Iraq, he really believes in democracy, and he asked for our support, and we said we are ready to help in any way with all our institutions,'' Mr. Erdogan said.

headline: Currencies: Dollars advances to 7-month high
Greenspan Says Low Rates Tempt Investors to Risk More
abstract: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned Monday night that the baffling persistence of low long-term interest rates was driving investors to hunt for higher returns by plowing money into hedge funds that will not be able to deliver on their promises.    Speaking to a conference of central bankers in Beijing, Mr. Greenspan reiterated that he is perplexed that long-term Treasury bond rates are lower today than they were a year ago, when the Federal Reserve began systematically raising short-term rates.

headline: Janus Funds: Everybody Loves a Loser
abstract: YOU keep hearing that this is a rough year for hedge funds, and from the perspective of a hedge fund manager, I suppose that's true. General Motors bonds are downgraded to junk status -- and the rumors begin flying that hedge funds holding the bonds are in trouble. Hedge fund losses are said to be ''piling up, sparking concerns about a shakeout in the business.'' Or at least that's how our friends at The Wall Street Journal put it last week.    But do you know how much hedge funds have lost, collectively, in this supposedly dismal year? Almost nothing -- around 1 percent, according to the CSFB Tremont Hedge Fund Index. (To be fair, that was before the events of May.) And yet the doomsayers are at least partly right: because most managers have as their stated goal to generate positive returns in up markets and down ones, there are undoubtedly some funds facing problems right now because they are underwater.

headline: For the U.S. trade envoy,Congress is old and new
Summit Fight Shakes Europe
abstract: Something shattered in Europe on Friday night.     The leaders of the 25 European Union nations went home after a failed two-day summit meeting in anger and in shame, as domestic politics and national interests defeated lofty notions of sacrifice and solidarity for the benefit of all.

headline: Wen ends his visit with giants vowing to be cooperative
Emirates holds off on orders for Airbus A350
Icahn in Rite Aid, Siebel and Hewlett
abstract: WASHINGTON, May 13 (Dow Jones/AP) - The financier Carl C. Icahn, who has been actively making investments this year, disclosed on Friday that he holds stakes in Rite Aid, Siebel Systems and Hewlett-Packard.

headline: Poker firm details listing
Uzbeks Say Troops Shot Recklessly at Civilians
abstract: Government of Uzbekistan maintains that it acted cautiously and minimized use of force in putting down prison break and demonstration, but survivors with gunshot wounds dispute this; they say security forces fired indiscriminately at unarmed civilians, striking women and children in public square in Andijon with little warning; say many civilians had gathered in square in hope of seeing Pres Islam A Karimov, to complain about joblessness and poverty; say they were met by troops instead; Karimov blames unrest on Islamic extremist groups; photo (M) with

headline: Briefly: Mitsubishi wins Dubai rail deal
Palestinian Leader Expected to Defer Election
abstract: The Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, is expected to announce Saturday that he has decided to postpone parliamentary elections that had been scheduled to take place on July 17, according to an unidentified official cited by the Reuters news agency.    The delay in the elections had been expected, with the Palestinian election commission saying last week that the move might be necessary because of a dispute over reforms to a new election law focusing largely on how legislative seats are filled.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Catholic Priests Arrested
abstract: Seven priests in China's underground Catholic Church were arrested after attending a religious retreat, according to a United States-based group that monitors persecution of Catholics in China. The group, the Cardinal Kung Foundation, reported that security officers in Hebei raided a religious gathering organized by Jia Zhiguo, a bishop recently released from house arrest. China has an estimated 12 million Catholics who are divided between those who attend churches sanctioned by the government and those who attend illegal underground churches that retain allegiance to Rome.   Jim Yardley (NYT)

headline: Equity Firm Is Set to Buy DoubleClick
abstract: Hellman & Friedman reportedly will buy Internet marketer DoubleClick in cash deal worth $1.1 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Bombing Before Maronite's Return
abstract: A bomb ripped through a shopping district in the predominantly Christian port of Juniye, killing at least one person and wounding four. The blast, the fifth in two months against Christian areas around Beirut, was centered near a Christian religious radio station and came on the eve of the return to Beirut of Michel Aoun, the Maronite Christian leader and former army chief, after 15 years of exile in France.   Hassan M. Fattah (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Threat To 'Out' Party Members
abstract: A gay leader in the conservative Popular Party threatened to reveal the names of other homosexual members if they did not drop their opposition to same-sex marriage. The leader, Carlos Biendicho, president of a group within the party called the Gay Popular Platform, told the news agency EFE that some of his colleagues were being hypocrites in opposing a measure to legalize gay marriage, which was passed by the lower house of Parliament in April but has yet to become law. Conservative and Roman Catholic groups have scheduled a rally in Madrid on Saturday to demonstrate against the bill. Mr. Biendicho called on his party to boycott the event.   Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline: Taiwan President's Ally to Carry Message to China
abstract: President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan said Sunday morning that he had called another prominent Taiwanese politician, James Soong, on Saturday night and asked him to carry a message to China's leaders during Mr. Soong's visit to China beginning later this week.    The president's decision to open any kind of dialogue with mainland China, even by sending messages through an informal intermediary, is another hint of possibly warming relations across the Taiwan Strait.

headline: Corrections
abstract: The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about Craigslist, the online bulletin board, misstated the name of a consulting firm that found in a survey last fall that many newspaper industry executives were unaware of the site's arrival in their cities. The firm is Classified Intelligence, not Creative Intelligence.

headline: Télécom raises stake in Romania
4th Patient on M.S. Drug May Have Brain Infection
abstract: Shares of Biogen Idec and Elan fell yesterday on news that a fourth patient may have developed the life-threatening brain infection that prompted the companies to halt sales of their multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri earlier this year.     If the fourth case of the normally extremely rare infection is confirmed, it would make it more difficult for the drug to return to the market, doctors and analysts said. The new case might indicate the drug is more dangerous than previously thought because it appears the fourth patient might have taken the drug for a substantially shorter time than the other three.

headline: A Modern French Revolution Strikes Havas
abstract: The investor Vincent Bolloré won a showdown with the management of Havas, the French advertising company, as shareholders defied managers Thursday during a raucous annual meeting infused with the spirit of revolt that is running through French society.    Mr. Bolloré, who owns 20.7 percent of Havas, was elected to the board, along with three other executives representing his investment firm. The 18-member Havas board, led by the chief executive, Alain de Pouzilhac, had urged shareholders to reject Mr. Bolloré's bid for the board, saying he had consistently failed to express his intentions since he began accumulating shares about a year ago.

headline: Uzbekistan Increases Death Toll of Crackdown
abstract: The number Â 169 dead, including 32 soldiers Â was well below the unverified estimates of survivors and witnesses, say the toll was in the hundreds.

headline: Seal Officer's Trial Gives Glimpse of C.I.A.'s Role in Abuse
abstract: The court martial of a member of the Navy Seals accused of abusing an Iraqi detainee who later died in Central Intelligence Agency custody is providing revealing glimpses of the agency's involvement in the prisoner abuse scandal.    The role of the agency is not directly at issue in the trial of the Seal officer, Lt. Andrew K. Ledford, and only a few references to the agency have been made in public testimony since the trial started Monday.

headline: In Praise of Good Coaching
abstract: I LEARNED a lot in terms of the person I am from my parents. My dad worked for Alcoa Aluminum for 27 years in Edgewater, N.J., and my mom worked for Bendix building airplanes during World War II.    We didn't have a lot of money. When it came to something my older sister or I needed, my parents would put off purchases for themselves. They even sent us on vacation by ourselves because they couldn't leave their jobs. My grandfather used to have a bungalow in Seaside Heights, N.J., and we'd spend summers with him.

headline: Diller to Sell Stake in Vivendi for $3.4 Billion
abstract: Barry Diller, the former Hollywood executive turned Internet media mogul, has agreed to sell his 5.4 percent stake in Vivendi Universal Entertainment to NBC Universal for $3.4 billion.

headline: China assails U.S. textile quotas
Floyd Norris: Who cares about the EU charter?
Sharp drop in growth of economy in France
Time Warner Says Data on Employees Is Lost
abstract: Time Warner reports loss of computer backup tapes containing sensitive data, including names and Social Security numbers of about 600,000 people; include current and former employees, some of their dependents and beneficiaries, and even individuals who have provided services for company; Time Warner says data, on 40 tapes, disappeared more than month ago while being shipped to offsite storage center; Secret Service is continuing to investigate missing tapes (M)

headline: Nintendo lifts profit forecast and dividend
Hybrid-Car Tinkerers Scoff at No-Plug-In Rule
abstract: Idea of making hybrid cars that have option of being plugged in is supported by diverse group of interests, from neoconservatives who support greater fuel efficiency to utilities salivating at change to supplant oil with electricity; conventional hybrid electric cars will slow growth rate of oil imports only marginally, at best, with amount depending on how many hybrids are sold; to actually stop growth of oil imports and potentially even reduce consumption, automakers have focused on developing cars powered by hydrogen fuel cells; fuel cells would require complete reinvention of automobile and nation's gas stations, and technology to put them on road is still long way from fruition; photos (M)

headline: Are Business Schools Failing the World?
abstract: JEFFREY E. GARTEN, 58, who is stepping down after 10 years as dean of the Yale School of Management, says he does not think American business schools are doing a good enough job. Here are excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Garten, who became the dean after a career on Wall Street specializing in debt restructuring abroad and a stint as under secretary of commerce for international trade.    Q. Do you feel that in your 10 years, you were able to improve the way business students are educated?    A. Ten years ago, the role of business in society was on an upward trajectory. There was a sense that business leaders would be the champions of globalization and would in fact fill in where governments had left a huge vacuum in terms of the rules of the world economy.

headline: AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO BUY FIRST ASSET OF CANADA
abstract: Affiliated Managers Group, American company that owns stakes in money managers, agrees to buy First Asset Management of Canada for about $250 million, its first move into Canadian market (S)

headline: Japan Still Bans U.S. Beef, Chafing American Officials
abstract: Japan's $1.2 billion-a-year beef market remains closed six months after American negotiators thought they had deal to resume beef exports to Japan, as result of single case of mad cow disease detected in Washington State in 2003; Japan's barriers to American beef are drawing heavy fire in Congress, conjuring up 1980's-style battle over American export access to Japan; delegation of American specialists is to arrive in Japan next week from Washington to testify about measures taken in last 15 months to prevent new cases of mad cow disease; but late summer looks like earliest that Japan's food safety bureaucracy might reopen doors to American beef; polls in Japan show that majority are in no rush to open to American imports; photo (M)

headline: Currencies: Euro remains weak despite U.S. data
China warns new pontiff on Taiwan
The Feng Shui Kingdom
abstract: Walt Disney Co has taken many steps at new Hong Kong Disneyland to reflect local culture, including heeding advice of feng shui consultant; park is venture with Hong Kong government and first of parks Disney wants to build in China; Disney invested $316 million for 43 percent equity stake; Hong Kong contributed $419 million; map; photos (M)

headline: Bush to steeraid to Abbas,officials say
Canada Moves to Limit Online Bulk Sales of Drugs
abstract: The government is drafting legislation to limit bulk exports of Canadian drugs in an effort to assure that online pharmacy sales to the U.S. do not cause domestic shortages.

headline: Tech Brief: Philips to book gain from sale
A grueling workout with the right MP3
Europe and Microsoft in Accord on Competition Rules
abstract: The competition commissioner of Europe, Neelie Kroes, has agreed to exclude open-source developers, who distribute their software free, from the benefits of the antitrust ruling last year against Microsoft -- but only for the time being.    After more than a year of wrangling, the European Commission and Microsoft appeared on Monday to have reached agreement on how to meet Europe's competition standards. In March 2004, Microsoft was fined 497 million euros (about $613 million at the time) for monopolistic practices, and ordered to share details of its Windows operating system with rival software makers, including developers of open-source software. Sharing those details would allow Microsoft's competitors to build programs that could work with Windows.

headline: All-Embracing Man of Action for a New Era of Papacy
Tiscali sells French unit to Italia
Huge but quiet Airbus makes first test flight
Marine is nominated to lead Joint Chiefs
MBAs seektheir fortunesat thefrontier
Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about investing in technology stocks misstated the name of a T. Rowe Price mutual fund managed by Larry J. Puglia. It is the Blue Chip Growth fund, not Global Technology.

headline: Three attacks on Iraqi security forces kill 20
Art lover drops plans for museum near Paris
Rome's immigrants embraced pope
Chinese envoy skips talks with Koizumi
Consumers Are Wary, but Housing Remains Hot
abstract: Conference Board reports its index of consumer confidence dropped to 97.7 in April, from 103 in March; National Association of Realtors says sales of new homes rose sharply by 12.2 percent in March and hit record annual pace of 1.43 million; unexpected surge came despite slightly higher mortgage rates last month; sales of existing homes climbed 1 percent in March and have climbed 4.9 percent over last year; graphs; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Tells U.N. That It Continues to Oppose Torture in Any Situation
abstract: The United States told the United Nations on Friday that despite the abuse of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison, it continued to oppose torture.    ''The United States is unequivocally opposed to the use and practice of torture,'' the Bush administration declared in a report to the United Nations Committee Against Torture, adding that ''no circumstance whatsoever, including war, the threat of war, internal political stability'' or any other dire situation can justify torture, the report said.

headline: Yes, They Can Say No to a Merger
abstract: IN the six months since the Symantec Corporation, a leading provider of Internet security software, announced its plan to acquire Veritas Software, a maker of storage products, investors have done nothing but boo and hiss the buyout. Reaction to the deal has been so virulent that investors have dumped Symantec shares, taking the value of the all-stock deal down to about $9 billion from about $14 billion at the time it was announced.    While Mr. Market has already made his views clear, shareholders of both companies will vote yea or nay on the combination this Friday. Only then will we see whether investors still holding Symantec shares have the stomach to vote against management, or whether they will support it as institutional holders almost always do.

headline: While Shares Fell, Viacom Paid Three $160 Million
abstract: Viacom's chief executive Sumner M Redstone and co-presidents Tom Freston and Leslie Moonves received total compensation in 2004 valued at about $52 million to $56 million each insalary, bonus and stock options, for total of about $160 million; compensation specialist Brian Foley says compensation is beyond breathtaking, and it dwarfs what their competitors are earning; Viacom spokesman Carl Folta says overall compensation was based on operating performance of company, and that was excellent in 2004; adds compensation was not based on stock price, which declined 18 percent in 2004; chart (M)

headline: Airbus A380 delays to hit additional carriers
Navy of Tomorrow, Mired in Yesterday's Politics
abstract: Article in series Arsenal of the Future explores soaring price of new warships; says soaring shipbuilding costs, driven by old-school politics and rusty machinery of American shipbuilding, may scuttle Pentagon's plans for 21st-century armada of high-technology aircraft carriers, destroyers and submarines; Navy wants more fast boats and aircraft to fight offshore and upriver, and says it can make do with fewer big ships patrolling oceans; Congress, seeking to sustain America's shipyards, wants as many big ships as possible; political hagging may also add to price; Navy wants winner-take-all competition to build destroyers; Congress wants contracts given to both Northrop Grumman and General Dynamics, only military shipbuilders that can produce ships Navy needs; officials say two companies do not really compete in traditional sense; shipbuilding system's critics say system is 'prehistoric' and that military shipbuilding is 'unbelievably regulated socialist industry'; photo; chart (L)

headline: Pop Lodi unveils bid to thwart Dutch bank
Ex-Director Sentenced in Insurer's Collapse
abstract: Rodney Adler, former director of HIH Insurance, becomes first person imprisoned over insurer's collapse; pleads guilty to four charges, including two of making false statements intended to induce others to buy shares in HIH; must serve at least two and half years in jail before being eligible for parole (S)

headline: Civilian Dogfight at the Air Show
abstract: Boeing Co, which seemed in danger of being flattened by Airbus juggernaut, has stormed back into contention as two aircraft manufacturers display their most recent models at Paris Air Show; Boeing's new midsize plane, 787, is selling briskly, while Airbus has been dogged by production problems with A380 and questions about how it will finance its next new planes, particularly A350, which is intended to go head-to-head with 787; reversal of fortune comes just as European Union is fighting mammoth trade suit brought by US on aircraft subsidies; graph; photo (M)

headline: A new'China syndrome'
World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Consultant's Profit Misses Forecasts
abstract: India's Tata Consultancy Services says fourth-quarter profit rose 30 percent, to 4.71 billion rupees ($107 million), but falls short of market expectations; sales rose 27 percent, to 26.03 billion rupees ($595 million) (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
Egyptian Judges Are Entering Growing Reform Movement
abstract: When thousands of Egyptian judges gathered in Cairo last week to demand greater independence from the government, they highlighted the entry of a powerful new force in the country's growing reform movement: official institutions.     Long taken for granted as appendages of the government, some institutions are less willing to tolerate business as usual this election year. The judges' extraordinarily public step is perhaps the most obvious display of resistance, and builds on a similar call by judges in Alexandria weeks earlier.

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Poland ties treaty vote to EU summit actions
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economists Concerned About Effect Of Rise in Adjustable Mortgage Rates  With adjustable-rate mortgages, American homeowners have made a trillion-dollar bet that mortgage rates will remain near record lows for at least a few more years. But with some rates already rising, economists worry that the bet could turn bad. [Page C1.]    Union Leader Says He Opposes G.M. Plan on Cuts  Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Auto Workers, said he would not agree to reopen negotiations on General Motors' labor contract before it expires in 2007 or to roll back health benefits for G.M.'s hourly workers to match the lesser benefits of the company's salaried workers. [C1.]    The likelihood of a schism in organized labor increased when five major unions formed a growth-oriented coalition and the presidents of four of the unions hinted strongly that they might quit the A.F.L.-C.I.O. [A23.]    Report Shows Consumer Prices Declined in May  Consumer prices edged down in May for the first time in nearly a year, pushed by lower energy prices. [C1.]    Former Bristol-Myers Executives Are Indicted  Two former executives of Bristol-Myers Squibb were indicted on conspiracy and securities fraud charges related to a wholesale inventory manipulation that artificially inflated company revenues. [C1.]    Officials Overrode Objections on Tobacco Penalties  Justice Department officials overrode the objections of lawyers running the government's tobacco racketeering trial and ordered them to reduce the penalties by $120 million, despite concerns that the move would be seen as politically motivated, internal documents and interviews show. [A1.]    OPEC Raises Its Quotas on Oil Production  OPEC said that it had agreed to lift its oil production quotas by 500,000 barrels a day, a sign of its unease with soaring worldwide energy demand. The decision, which was largely expected, failed to prevent another increase in oil prices. Crude oil futures for July delivery rose 57 cents yesterday, to $55.57 a barrel, in New York. The price reached a record last April, exceeding $58. [C3.]    Senate Democrats agreed with Republicans on the need to reduce the nation's dependence on imported oil. But they differed on how to do it. [A24.]    Payments by Public Broadcasting Are Examined  Investigators at the Corporation for Public Broadcasting are examining $15,000 in payments to two Republican lobbyists last year that were not disclosed to the corporation's board, people involved in the inquiry said. [A1.]    S.E.C. Recommends Accounting Changes  In an effort to make it easier to determine the accurate state of companies' balance sheets, the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended steps to change accounting for leases, pensions and derivatives. [C4.]    The Securities and Exchange Commission is assembling an advisory committee for small public committees with the aim of lightening their regulatory load because of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. Small Business. [C6.]    Senate Panel Approves Crawford for F.D.A.  A Senate panel cleared Dr. Lester Crawford to head the Food and Drug Administration, but his nomination still faces uncertainty. [A20.]    Chiron to Offer Fewer Doses of Flu Vaccine  The Chiron Corporation said it would provide fewer doses of its flu vaccine this year than it had anticipated, tightening the supply somewhat. [A22.]    Stock Indicators Post Modest Gains  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.80 points, to 10,566.37. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 2.67 points, to 1,206.58. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 5.88 points, to 2,074.92. [C7.]    Boeing and a Rival Vie for Air Force Tanker Contract  As the Air Force studies how to replace its aging fleet of 540 fleet aerial tankers, Boeing has been proclaiming the wonders of its new tanker plane. EADS North America, the American military subsidiary of the parent company to Airbus, meanwhile, has been conducting a highly publicized campaign to line up American political support for its offering. [C3.]    France and Japan are hoping to develop a commercial jet that could cut the flight time between Tokyo and New York by more than half. [C4.]    Group Plans Internet Service for Villages in India  An international consortium is planning to establish thousands of rural Internet centers in India to bring services to isolated villages. [C17.]    Absolut Unveils Ad Campaign for Flavored Vodka  Absolut vodka is starting a campaign to promote its flavored varieties, separate from the ads for its unflavored version. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

headline: Gas Prices and Poor Sales Push Down Ford's Profit
abstract: Ford Motor Co, citing rising gasoline prices and falling sales, says first-quarter profit fell 38 percent, to $1.2 billion; says it will break even at best in second quarter, and cut production of cars and trucks by 5 percent in Europe and North America; executives say they are considering selling its Hertz rental car division, or other alternatives related to business, to shore up cash reserves; company reports net income of $1.2 billion compared with $1.95 billion year earlier; revenue rose to $45.1 billion, from $44.7 billion year ago; chairman-chief executive William Clay Ford Jr seeks to explain diminished outlook; photo (M)

headline: WPP Group Keeps Agencies Separate
abstract: WPP Group decides against combining its GCI Group, where Robert Feldman is leaving as president and chief executive, with its Cohn & Wolfe public relations agency; Donna Imperato, who would have run combined agency, will remain as Cohn & Wolfe chief executive and have management oversight of GCI, whose chief executive will be Jeff Hunt (S)

headline: 500 bodies laid out in Uzbek town
The Fall of Berlin: Red Army tanks rolled in, and Germans kept firing
Briefly: Agricole to buy Italy fund firm
World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Crackdown On Islamists
abstract: The government arrested four senior members of the Muslim Brotherhood organization, including its spokesman, Essam el-Erian. The crackdown against the banned but tolerated group, Egypt's most effective political opposition, came after it organized a series of unprecedented nationwide protests by thousands demanding greater political freedoms. Brotherhood officials put the numbers detained since Wednesday in the hundreds.   Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

headline: Warnings Galore That Madison Avenue Needs to Be Nimble About Changing
abstract: MADISON AVENUE was warned yesterday that it risked being marginalized by profound changes in technology and demographics that are fundamentally changing the ways products are sold to consumers.    The warning came from speakers at the opening session here of the 2005 management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

headline: Nokia phones sport advanced features
Chirac Goes on TV to Promote Europe's Constitution
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac appears on French television to urge voters to approve draft constitution for European Union; photo; struggles to explain why document of more than 850 pages would be relevant to daily lives in France, amid mounting evidence that it may not pass referendum; many in France fear more powerful union will threaten French social benefits and cause even higher unemployment; others are wary of expanding union that may include Muslim Turkey (M)

headline: Nike Decides Not to Do Business With Sears
abstract: NIKE'S decision to stop selling its sneakers and clothes at Sears is shining a spotlight on the impact retail environments have on marketers' brands.    Though the companies themselves have said little about the move, retail analysts quickly pronounced it a result of the Kmart Holding Corporation's $12 billion acquisition of Sears, Roebuck & Company in March.

headline: Crude oil rises to new high of US$60.47
People
abstract: Linda Wolf will retire at the end of the week as the global chairwoman and chief executive at Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, and Tom Bernardin, the global president and United States chief executive, will succeed her. The changes had been expected since Mr. Bernardin joined Burnett last year. Ms. Wolf, 57, has spent 27 years at Burnett and has served as the chief executive since 2001.    Jamie King was named senior vice president and director for brand integration, a new post, at Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of the Publicis Groupe. He had been executive vice president and group account director at Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, also part of Publicis.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Plan for Big Wind Farm
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, E.ON and other partners applied for permission to build the world's largest wind farm, a £1.5 billion ($2.5 billion) project with a 1,000-megawatt capacity, in the North Sea near the River Thames. The energy companies and CORE, a partnership of wind farm manufacturers and operators, plan to put 270 turbines 12 miles off England's shores, equidistant from Essex and Kent. If national and local governments grant consent for the project, it could be completed by 2010, organizers said.   Heather Timmons (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fewer Cars, but More Profits
abstract: Canadian auto production will probably stagnate this year, the Conference Board of Canada predicted. Weak demand in the United States, which is the main market for Canadian-made automobiles and auto parts, and a relatively high Canadian dollar will lead to three consecutive quarters of declining production, the report said. The study predicted that by the end of the year the auto sector would increase production by only 0.1 percent. The report was not all bad news, however. The Conference Board, which is based in Ottawa, expects that auto industry profits in Canada would rise sharply because of declining costs for labor and materials. The Conference Board forecast profits of 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($2.9 billion) in 2005 compared with 1.4 billion last year.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: Congress takes up Social Security plan
Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: A Green Light for 'Mission: Impossible III'
abstract: After a week of negotiations over the budget, Paramount Pictures has decided to push ahead with plans to shoot ''Mission: Impossible III'' starring Tom Cruise. The chairman, Brad Grey, said in a statement on Tuesday night that the studio would go ahead with the movie.    Paramount was considering whether to move forward with the latest installment of the lucrative franchise because the budget had soared well above $150 million, and because Mr. Cruise was owed such a high percentage of the revenue.

headline: Stocks:As oil prices rise, stocks move ahead
Iraqi Sunni clerics stage an about-face
Earnings Beat Expectations at Bear Stearns
abstract: Bear Stearns said yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter rose 5 percent, more than expected, buoyed by equity trading and investment gains.    Net income climbed to $365 million, or $2.56 a share, in the three months ended May 31, from $348 million, or $2.49 a share, a year earlier. Bear Stearns had been expected to earn $2.37 a share, according to the average estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

headline: European banks keep borrowers home
Political reform ignored as Assad lays out goals
Uzbek Government Restores Authority in Area of Revolt
abstract: Government of Uzbekistan restores authority to small swath of eastern territory, ending shortlived and bloodily suppressed revolt against authoritarian government; with authorities gone, local residents on Uzbek side of Karasu, border town, quickly restore metal footbridge to Kyrgyz side, opening border for free passage between nations; photo (M)

headline: Explaining a defeat
Wealth Management: An investment with a sporting chance of profit
Free Flow: Truck tolls hit the road in Germany
Arms Fiascoes Lead to Alarm Inside Pentagon
abstract: Article in series Arsenal of the Future explains how years of fiascoes in new weapons planning and huge cost overruns have left top Pentagon officials, led by Sec Donald Rumsfeld, alarmed that machinery for building weapons is breaking down under own weight; example is Navy's nine-year effort to build new guided missile, for which bill is almost $400 million with little to show; Pentagon has more than 80 major new arms systems under development at combined cost of $1.47 trillion and climbing; new planes and ships cost many times those being replaced, reverse of next-generation technology in civilian world; David M Walker of GAO observes that, as private company, Defense Department would be out of business; experts say military conjures up dream weapons and sets immensely expensive technological requirements while handful of major military contractors cross their fingers as they promise to fulfill visions; almost no one flatly rejects wish lists, projected costs are routinely understated, testing is unrealistic and oversight has dwindled with staffing cuts; costs of new weapons, $148 billion a year, are hidden, with one in five dollars in classified budget; members of Congress raise alarms about Army's Future Combat System, Navy's crushingly expensive DD(S) destroyers and Air Force plan for three different new jet fighters; photo (L)

headline: South African Guilty of Bribing Deputy President Over Arms Sales
abstract: A Durban businessman with close ties to the governing African National Congress was found guilty on Thursday of paying $186,000 in bribes to the deputy president, Jacob Zuma, South Africa's second in command and heir apparent, in some eyes, to President Thabo Mbeki.    The verdict brought demands from the A.N.C.'s critics for Mr. Zuma to resign or to abandon any quest for the presidency when Mr. Mbeki leaves office in 2007. But it remained unclear whether government prosecutors even intended to press charges against Mr. Zuma for what the trial judge called ''overwhelming'' evidence of corruption.

headline: Berlusconi faces crisis as allies pull out
Vatican ousts U.S. editor
Expansion overseas hits profit at Nomura
Politicus: Howard's star falling as Blair's again climbs
Hindu Leader in India Quits Over Remarks in Pakistan
abstract: A chief architect of the political ascendancy of Hindu nationalism in India in the 1990's resigned Tuesday as head of his party.

headline: 'Minnesota Nice' at the Top
abstract: MY father had taken over his father's business: a bowling alley, restaurant and bar in North St. Paul, Minn. He suffered a lot of frustration to make a go of it. I cleaned up the place weekends as a kid. My life was somewhere between Lake Wobegon and a G-rated ''Fargo.'' In fourth grade it was like I woke up and became an independent thinker. I decided that I would find a way to trade that kind of frustration for success and a happy life.    My father worked hard, and that's where I got my work ethic. Now I have a problem: I'm guilty when I'm not working, like I'm never putting in quite enough time. It's that old Studs Turkel stuff that there is fundamental value in the goodness of work. That also comes from growing up in a Midwestern blue-collar neighborhood.

headline: CSI: Wendy's Restaurants
abstract: Wendy's International executives are trying to track down origin of part of human finger that Anna Ayala found in her cup of chili at one of Wendy's outlets in Santa Clara County, Calif, on March 22; DNA samplings, including check of FBI's databases, has turned up nothing; questions have been raised about Ayala; Associated Press has reported that Ayala has had litigious history that includes settlement for medical expenses for her daughter, who claimed she became sick at El Pollo Loco restaurant in Las Vegas; Wendy's has offered $100,000 reward and has team of private investigators running tip line 10 hours a day; Wendy's restaurants in Northern California have lost 20 percent to 50 percent of their business; photo (M)

headline: Israel to release Jordanian prisoners
Psst! Want Internet Phone Service?
abstract: Selling of Internet-based phone service is expected to attract hundreds of mom-and-pop operations because seller only needs few hundred dollars, Web site and some marketing moxie; Woodrow Cundiff spent $500 in March to become 'reseller' of service that aims to replace expensive landline phones with software that runs on high-speed data lines to provide voice connections; Cundiff has signed up 200 customers from his home in Port Charlotte, Fla, and claims to hacve made his money back, nearly 10 times over; photo (M)

headline: For Charles, Camilla and Britain, the Wait Is Over
abstract: Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles, who have been lovers, on and off, for past 30 years, plan to follow their wedding ceremony with religious blessing, centerpiece of which will be stern prayer of penitence from 1662 Book of Common Prayer; photos (M)

headline: Burger King Ads Make the Best of an Unappetizing Situation
abstract: Burger King Restaurants of Canada promotes special '100 percent Canadian beef' version of its Whopper hamburger in ad featuring US boarder guard going after Americans trying to import Whoppers from Canada in violation of ban put in place after discovery of mad cow disease in an Alberta cow two years ago; spokesman says beef consumption has actually risen in much of Canada since discovery; photo (M)

headline: Security tight as Thailand nears riot date
Abduction, Often Violent, a Kyrgyz Wedding Rite
abstract: When Ainur Tairova realized she was on her way to her wedding, she started choking the driver.    Her marriage was intended to be to a man she had met only the day before, and briefly at that. Several of his friends had duped her into getting into a car; they picked up the would-be groom and then headed for his home.
