Newspapers' Circulation Still Going Down
abstract: Newspaper circulation continues to tumble; Audit Bureau of Circulations says daily circulation dropped 1.9 percent and 2.5 percent decline on Sundays over last six months, compared with period year ago; weak numbers represent largest circulation losses for industry in more than decade, and indicate acceleration of decline; among newspapers that show biggest declines are large regional dailies owned by Tribune Co, which has been shaken by circulation scandal at Newsday; Los Angeles Times, owned by Tribune, reports daily circulation fell 6.5 percent,to 907,997, and Sunday circulation dropped 7.9 percent; Chicago Tribune says its average weekday circulation fell 6.9 percent, to 573,743, and Sunday fell 4.7 percent, to 953,815; Wall Street Journal says weekday circulation declined 0.8 percent, to about 2.07 million after aggressive price increases; USA Today held steady with average circulation of about 2.8 million; New York Times posts 0.2 percent gains; daily circulation rose 1.14 million and Sunday circulation reached about 1.68 million; chart (M)

Name Goods in China but Brand X Elsewhere
abstract: Never heard of brand names like Great Wall, Hisense, Konka, Amoi and Panda? Outside China, few have. That may change someday, but in the meantime, some Chinese companies are taking a shortcut and adopting widely known names to make their presence felt abroad.     China's leaders have been quietly encouraging Chinese companies for years to set up overseas operations, acquire foreign assets and transform themselves into multinational corporations -- in other words, to make themselves more competitive in a world increasingly dominated by Wal-Mart, Microsoft and Coca-Cola.

abstract: International opinion poll conducted by Pew Center finds anti-Americanism that surged through much of world over war in Iraq shows modest signs of abating, although distinctly negative views persist in Muslim world; poll surveyed 17,000 people in US and 15 other countries; results detailed (M)

Pilgrims Pay Last Respects Before Papal Funeral
abstract: Final visitors pay their last respects to Pope John Paul II in St Peter's Basilica, before his body is to be transferred to simple cypress coffin; outside, authorities begin to clean and seal off St Peter's Square, where funeral will be held; dignitaries and ordinary worshipers continue to pour into Rome for funeral; Vatican officials expect million pilgrims to attend outdoor funeral in square, most of them spilling out into surrounding streets; 27 mega-screens are being set up around city for hundreds of thousands more who will not fit into limited space near St Peter's; photos and diagrams (L)

headline: Briefly: Norwegian man dies in Eiffel Tower jump
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Growth in Medical Copters Makes for Crowded Skies  Competing helicopter services are locked in air wars across the country as medical airlifting grows more profitable and common.     As with other health care services that have become routine, the public price tag is soaring and helicopters are being used when ambulances might do. An estimated 700 medical helicopters operate nationally, about twice the number flying a decade ago. [Page A1.]    No 2nd Payday for Neiman Holders  Neiman Marcus shareholders expressed their disappointment that the private equity firms buying the company for $5 billion were also buying its credit card business. They had hoped for a separate sale. [C2.]    $1.6 Billion Deal for Fitness Chain  Forstmann Little agreed to buy 24 Hour Fitness, a private company that operates 345 fitness clubs, for $1.6 billion. [C2.]    Ground Zero Project Chief Resigns  Kevin M. Rampe, left, the man overseeing the multibillion-dollar rebuilding effort at the World Trade Center site, is leaving to become global ethics and compliance officer for Ace Ltd., a Bermuda-based property and casualty insurer. His departure comes at a sensitive moment for a rebuilding effort that has been plagued by bad news and delays. For example, the construction of the Freedom Tower is months behind schedule. [A1.]    Group Sues Over Meat Alternative  A consumer activist group says Quorn products, which are marketed as healthful alternatives to meat, are anything but healthy for some people. The group is suing Quorn's manufacturer and its largest United States retailer, Whole Foods Market. [C2.]    Time Warner Employee Data Is Lost  Time Warner reported the loss of computer backup tapes containing sensitive data including the names and Social Security numbers of about 600,000 people. [C4.]    Power Rangers Meet Pac-Man  Bandai, the Japanese maker of the Power Ranger action figures, will buy Namco, Pac-Man's creator, in a $1.7 billion deal. [C8.]    Nortel Profit Drops 75% in Quarter  Profits at Nortel Networks, the telecommunications equipment maker, fell 75 percent in the fourth quarter as sales declined. The company is still dealing with financial restatements as well as criminal and securities investigations. Nortel's net income declined to $133 million, from $528 million in the same quarter a year earlier. [C16.]    Circulation Falls at Many Papers  The newspaper industry reported its most serious declines in circulation in more than a decade. Only 3 of 10 newspapers gained in daily circulation. [C4.]    On Sony Device, Commercials to Go  Heavy.com, a Web host of short films and animation, has started making advertiser-supported clips available as free content for the PlayStation Portable. Advertising. [C5.]    Small Gains for Stock Market  Stocks closed higher despite a sharp rise in oil prices. The Dow rose 59.19 points, to 10,251.70. The S.&P. was up 5.31 points, at 1,162.16, and the Nasdaq gained 7 points, to 1,928.65. [C10.]    When Babies Go on Business Trips  More women are taking young children along when they travel for work. [C7.]    Take the Gun, Leave the Nail File  Airport security checkpoints inspire laughter and tears. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C7.]

abstract: Massively multiplayer online video games provide rich, virtual envrionments that combine tangled plotlines with social experience similar to that of chat room; are considered mainstream entertainment in Taiwan and South Korea, but still represent small fraction of United States video game business; Warner Brothers Interactive Entertainment hopes its Matrix Online game, which it publishes with Sega Corp, will expand market; games involve both purchase price and monthly subscription fee; photos (M)

World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Production Falls
abstract: Industrial production in Japan unexpectedly fell in March for second consecutive month, suggesting economy remains sluggish even after emerging from mild recession in 2004; production dropped seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent in March from February; retail sales increased 0.6 percent in March from year ago (S)
